column2: BRAMWELL--Elizabeth. The Women's National Republican Club mourns the sudden passing of their Treasurer, Elizabeth Bramwell. She was a dedicated and devoted member of the Club. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband William and her family. May she Rest in Peace. 1/3

TOFEL--Robert L.,died on March 12, 2015 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Susan and earlier of Carol. Adored father, father-in-law and stepfather of Dick, Larry, Janice, Cathy, Ken, Bob, Sally, Wendy, Andrew, Barbara, Peter, Peter and Camilla. Proud and much loved grandfather of Rachel, Colin, Carly, Alex, Jeremy, Ben, Leah, Sara, Henry, Ethan, Nathaniel, Timothy, Nicholas, Jack, Megan, Whitten and Wheeler. He practiced law with joy and verve for half a century, but found his greatest pleasure in family and friends. Services Sunday at noon, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. Receiving at Cathy's 4-8pm Friday and Saturday. In lieu of flowers contributions to a charity of your choice. 1/3
SCHOFF--Peter. In memory of my beloved husband who died March 13, 2013. Your loving and devoted wife Sam Schoff, England.

FLANZER--Gloria. The Division of Cardiology at Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourn the passing of our great friend and benefactor, Gloria Flanzer. The extraordinary generosity of Mrs. Flanzer and her family have truly transformed our work, and her gentle manner, profound curiosity and abiding compassion will be long remembered and much missed by those of us who were fortunate to know her. We offer our condolences to the Flanzer and Milstein families. Allan Schwartz, MD Chief, Division of Cardiology Columbia University Medical Center 1/3
MEHRAN--Farrokh . Born: 29-Jun-1936, Tehran, Iran. Died: 13-Mar-1995, New York, NY, USA
SCHOFF--Peter. In memory of my beloved husband who died March 13, 2013. Your loving and devoted wife Sam Schoff, England.

SLUTSKY--Adele. The board and staff of The New York Community Trust mourn the loss of our president's beloved mother, Adele, whose generous smile and radiant warmth were cherished by all who knew her. Valerie S. Peltier, Chair 1/3
HIRSCH--Dr. Harvey. Two years. Too long. Miss you everyday. Love, Ellen 1/3

OZIMEK--Phyllis Blake. 80, formerly of Rye, NY and Ponte Vedra Beach, FL died peacefully in her home in Warren, NJ on March 7, 2015 from complications as the result of Alzheimer's disease. She was born in Philadelphia, PA on October 11, 1934 to the late Alfred Greene Blake, former CEO of Engelhard Co., and Mildred Inez Cordeaux. She graduated from Smith College in 1956 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Sociology with peers who led the woman's liberation movement. She then completed a one year business program at Harvard-Radcliff in 1960 and ultimately earned her MBA at Pace University in 1985. Phyllis had a successful career as a computer programmer and systems analyst and during her final years working, she was a Vice President in charge of financial systems at New York Life Insurance Company. Phyllis was predeceased by her husband of 51 years, Richard Ozimek who passed away in the fall of 2014. She is survived by her brother Johnson C. (Jack) Blake of Kiawah Island, SC and her two daughters, Kimberley Vessa and husband Paul of Bernardsville, NJ and Elizabeth Crowley and husband Charlie of Ridgewood, NJ. Phyllis is also survived by her seven grandchildren Blake, Taylor, Michael, Claire, Colin, Edie, and Ian, who will all miss her dearly. Phyllis loved to spend time with her family and enjoyed shopping and keeping a beautiful home. She possessed a bright, curious mind and loved to laugh. There will be a memorial celebration for Phyllis and Richard in Rye, NY in the spring. All services are private under the direction of Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home. For further information, please contact Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home at 908-766-0250, or to light an online condolence candle please visit our website at www.gcfuneralhome.com. 1/3

APPELBAUM--Ann, MD. The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine mourn the loss of our distinguished colleague. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Funeral services private; memorial to be announced. Eric R. Marcus, M.D. Director, CU Psychoanalytic Center Marvin D. Wasserman, M.D., President, APM

FLANZER--Gloria. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Gloria Flanzer, a beloved friend and benefactor to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University Medical Center. With her husband Louis, Ms. Flanzer supported numerous patient care programs and helped establish the Milstein Hospital, the Flanzer Eye Center, and the Gloria and Louis Flanzer Cardiac Center, touching thousands of lives. Her philanthropy extended beyond our walls to many worthy causes both in New York City and around the country. We offer our deepest condolences to her family and loved ones. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO Herbert Pardes, MD, Executive Vice Chair NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Lee C. Bollinger, President Lee Goldman, MD, Executive Vice President and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Columbia University P. Roy Vagelos, MD, Chair, Board of Advisors Columbia University Medical Center 1/3

SWERSEY--Burt L.,of Stephentown, N.Y., age 78, died unexpectedly on March 9. An inventor, entrepreneur, farmer, teacher and dreamer, he believed in the power of engineering to improve the world. He attended Bronx Science and Cornell and founded four medical technology companies and a plant nursery. He taught for 23 years at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute where his Inventors Studio course fostered creativity and innovation and spawned numerous successful companies. In 2009 it was named one of the best entrepreneurship courses in America. His latest course How to Save the World emphasized creative solutions to important problems. In addition to his wife Alice and brother Arthur, he is survived by a son, William, daughters Sarah and Rachel, and six grandchildren, to whom he was utterly devoted. 1/3

KAPLOVE--James Evan, 60 years old, of New York City. Beloved father of Jacqueline and Bryan Remmen, Jessica Kaplove and Jillian Kaplove. Loving son of Lila and the late Jay Kaplove. Dear brother of Kenneth and Jules Kaplove. James earned a BBA and MBA from The George Washington University. His business career spanned more than 35 years, serving as a Senior Financial Executive. His love of life included music, sports and travel. James never missed an Allman Brothers concert at the Beacon Theater and reveled in his hole-in-one on the fifth hole at Alpine Country Club. James was a devout New York Giants fan. Above all, James adored and was extremely proud of his three daughters. Donations may be directed to the American Heart Association. 1/3
KADUSON--Elaine (Rodman), Remembered with love on your 97th Birthday by Your Turquoise Jelly Bean

FARBSTEIN--Avraham. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of Avraham Farbstein, beloved father and grandfather. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his daughter Lihi, son Itay and grandson Lior, his brother David, his sister Dr. Miriam Adelson and brother-in-law Sheldon Adelson (distinguished Benefactors of Yad Vashem) and the extended family. May his memory be for a blessing and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman Ron Meier, Executive Director 1/3
COOK--Michael F. Remembered with treasured memories and everlasting love. Your adoring wife Michele and daughter, Alessia.

BIRDOFF--Harvey. Born on March 30, 1928. Died on March 11, 2015. Survived by: his wife of 65 years, Joyce; Three children, Gwen, Robin and Rick; Daughter-in-law, Vicki, and son-in-law, Peter; Eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren; his sister Sandy and brother-in-law Bernie; Funeral Services will be held on Sunday March 15, 2015 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York. 1/3

WILLIG--Gloria (nee Chirico), on March 12, 2015 Beloved wife of the late USN Captain Frederick J. Loving mother of Jean (Jack), Tim (Bridget), Stephen (Immaculate) and the late Barbara (Joe). Cherished grandmother of Jennifer (Anthony) , Melissa, Christina, Vincent, Stephen Jr., Amanda, Joseph, Brian, Kimberly, Alexa and Grace. Great Grandmother of Cameron. FRAWLEY--David John Devoted husband and father, "Dave" Frawley passed peacefully from this life on March 7th in Kingwood Texas with his son Timothy by his side. He was 91. His three children, Christopher, Timothy, and Margaret Anne and their families including eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren survive him. Dave was born on May 14th, 1923 in Whitestone, New York to John Joseph Frawley and Anna (Lynch) Frawley. He grew up in Harlem, graduating from St. Cecilia's Elementary School, Patrick Henry Junior High School, and the New York School of Printing. Dave served in the Army Air Corps in World War II as a bomber tail gunner, flying missions into Europe from Africa and Italy. After the war, he started his long career with Eastern Air Lines. Dave was the manager of Eastern's New York City Ticket Offices and ran the company's operation at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. During that time he married Margaret "Peggy" Raake of Audubon, New Jersey in 1953. They expanded their family to include three children and settled in Kendall Park, New Jersey. Dave commuted to Manhattan and Peggy worked for Princeton University. He retired from Eastern in 1985 and they both relocated to Clearwater Florida. His beloved Peggy died in 1994. In addition to his family, Dave's great loves were horseracing, cigars, and jazz. He helped found the non-profit Suncoast Dixieland Jazz Society to provide scholarships for young musicians. Dave's mental faculties began to slowly fade and in 2008, he relocated to Kingwood Texas to live near his son, Tim and daughter-in-law Barbara. All that were privileged to know him will miss his warm heart, bright smile, charm, and sense of humor. A funeral service will be held Saturday March 14th at 10:00AM at St. Denis Catholic Church in Havertown, PA. Donations can be made in Dave's name to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

FRANKS--Cyril Maurice, 91, of Bloomington, died Monday, February 23 in Bloomington Hospital. Dr. Franks was born in Neath, Wales, United Kingdom. He was the son of the late Harry and Celia Franks, Swansea, Wales. Prior to his arrival in Bloomington, Dr. Franks lived for 52 years in Princeton, New Jersey. In addition to being distinguished faculty member of Graduate School of Applied and Professional Psychology, Rutgers, until 1991, he spent his professional career promoting Behavior Therapy. He was a founding member and first president of the American Association of Behavioral Therapy and founding editor of the journal Behavior Therapy, as well as editor of Child and Family Behavior Therapy until 2013. He has served many professional associations including the New Jersey Psychological Association and the British Psychological Association. Dr. Franks was a licensed practicing psychologist in New Jersey and consulted with patients at Carrier Clinic. In addition to his wife of 63 years, Violet, a distinguished psychologist in her own right, he is survived by one son, Steven Franks, his wife Karen and their children, Julia, Elisabeth, and David Franks as well as one daughter, Sharrin Vernall and her two children, Brendon and Emily Sage Vernall of Auckland, New Zealand. A memorial service will be held at the Princeton Jewish Center, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ on Sunday, March 15 at 1pm. Donations may be made in his memory to American Psychological Foundation, 750 First Street NE, Washington, D.C. 20002 or online www:apa.org/ APF Violet and Cyril Franks research fund for stigma in mental illness. On-line condolences may be made The Funeral Chapel http://pdcfuneralchapel.com/ 1/3

McCARTNEY--Daniel F. Daniel F. McCartney, age 64, died Wednesday after a courageous battle with Myelofibrosis. He is remembered as a devoted husband, father, brother, uncle, and friend. A proud native of Queens, NY, Dan was a teacher and coach at The Buckley School, where he worked from 1974 until his death. He is survived by his wife of 36 years, Dodie McCartney, his son Ryan, and five siblings, Peg Leder, Noreen Haffner, George McCartney, Kathleen Ryan, and Kevin McCartney. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to the Myeloproliferative Disease Program and The Buckley School's McCartney Scholarship Program. The family will receive friends on Sunday, March 15, from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm at Beecher Flooks Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY. The funeral mass will be on Monday, March 16, at 10am at St. John and St. Mary Church, in Chappaqua, NY. 1/3

BIRDOFF--Harvey. You were the best father, father-in-law and grandfather that anyone could ever ask for. Always with a smile and wanting to help. We will miss you tremendously. Love you with all our hearts. Rick, Vicki, Alix, Kayle and Reid 1/3

FLANZER--Gloria. The Ophthalmology faculty and staff at Columbia University mourn the loss of our dear friend and benefactor Gloria Flanzer. She and her late husband, Louis, were both members of our Board of Advisors and were deeply committed to bringing outstanding eye care to all New Yorkers. Their vision, advocacy, and generosity helped make transformative changes to the Department. The Flanzer Eye Center, the Gloria and Louis Flanzer Vision Care Center, and the Gloria and Louis Flanzer Amphitheatre are the most visible examples of how the Flanzers led the effort to provide the absolute best care possible to all affected by eye disease. We will miss her concern for all patients, her wise counsel, and warm friendship. We extend our deepest condolences to the Flanzer and Milstein families. G. A. Cioffi, M.D., Chairman Stanley Chang, M.D., Chairman Emeritus Sir Howard Stringer, Chairman, Board of Advisors Department of Ophthalmology, Columbia University 1/3

GRAVES--Michael. The Board of Trustees and staff of the American Academy in Rome mourn the passing of Michael Graves. Michael's relationship with the Academy began in 1960 when he won the Rome Prize; he was a Resident in 1979. He became a Trustee in 1981 and was a frequent juror for the Rome Prize. Michael was named the Academy's first Life Trustee in 2009 and remained deeply engaged in Academy life. 1/3

GRAVES--Michael. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, whose energy, talent, and passion for the art of architecture and its teaching brought joy beyond the boundaries of space and time. 1/3

HERTZBERG--Milton H. Age 98, died peacefully at home March 12, with his beloved wife Rhoda of 65 years by his side. He is also survived by his devoted children Brian, Barbara, and his son-in-law George L. Jurow. He was cherished by his grandson John Ross Jurow. Milton graduated from St. John's University, followed by military service during WWII. After the war, he worked for the IRS. He then owned a chain of retail stores in New York, Florida, and Maine. He was well loved by his family and many friends for his warmth and sense of humor. He will be deeply missed by those who had the fortune of knowing him.

TABACHNIK--Irene S.,88, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away on March 12th. She was born on April 24th, 1926. She met her future husband, William, in junior high school, and they were married on February 20th, 1945. Together with over 50 of their family and friends, they recently celebrated their 70th wedding anniversary. Irene was a quiet intellect with a great sense of humor. She is survived by her beloved husband, William, her children, Joel, Neil (Laura), Douglas (Juliet) and Barbara (Mace), her grandchildren, Cori Neuhaus (Michael), David, Bryan, Michael, Melanie, Tara, Kendall and Justin, and great-grandchild Parker. She leaves us all with the fondest of memories, and a deep hole in our hearts, but with the joy that we had her in our lives for as long as we did.

BLOOM--Gary Martin, of New York and Remsenberg died peacefully on Monday, March 9, 2015 after an extended illness. He was predeceased by his mother and father, Sara Lieberman Bloom and Jacob Bloom, and by his long-time companion and best friend, William Wolfston, who he spent many years with traveling and at home in their lovely house in Remsenberg, Long Island. He is survived by many cousins and loving friends who all enjoyed his larger than life personality and remember him as a sparkling, intelligent, bon vivant friend who loved people, parties, art, clubs, being well dressed and great conversations. He was Director of Development for the Urban League and then was a well-respected executive (Vice President) with the American Red Cross. He was an active member of the Lotos Club, Doubles, the Dutch Treat Club, the Westhampton Mallet Club, Quantuck Beach Club and American Friends of Blerancourt. Cremation is private. Gifts appreciated to East End Hospice Inc., Westhampton Beach, NY. 1/3

GLADSTONE--M.J. (Mike), publisher, editor, designer, and historic preservationist, died on February 13. Mr. Gladstone was born in New York City in 1923, attended public schools there and received an MA in Fine Arts from Harvard in 1946. He did superb work in publishing and the arts throughout his professional life. He apprenticed at the Elm Tree Press in Woodstock, VT, worked as art and illustrations editor for Merriam-Webster, as advertising manager for Yale University Press, and participated in the early days of mail order publishing at George Braziller, Columbia Records, and McGraw Hill. He headed publications for the Museum of Modern Art and for Arno Press. Mr. Gladstone was a publications consultant to the New York State Council on the Arts, the National Endowment for the Arts, the Ford Foundation, the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, the Twentieth Century Fund, Commentary magazine, and the Preservation League of New York State. He served briefly as Director of the Museum of American Folk Art and was the author of a book on roadside American folk art, A Carrot for a Nose, published by Scribner. In 1973 he founded the Publishing Center for Cultural Resources, to help nonprofit institutions become effective publishers. In the late 80's, Mike moved from Manhattan to Columbia County where he lived with the art historian Mary Black in the historic Rockefeller Tavern, which together they restored. In his later years, he worked as senior consultant to Furthermore (a program of the J.M. Kaplan Fund) on their grants in publishing. He was an active volunteer, board member, and leading force of local non-profits including Historic Hudson, Hudson River Heritage, Hudson Opera House, the Columbia County Historical Society and the Hudson Valley Chamber Music Circle. Mr. Gladstone was married twice; to Doria Higgins, and to Diane Brooks, with whom he had two children. He is survived by his daughter Abby Yozell, her husband John, and their daughter, Esme; and by his son Charles, his wife Elaine Souza, and their daughter, Lucy Gladstone. A memorial occasion will be held this month at the Hudson Opera House. Contributions in Mike's memory may be made to Historic Hudson, Hudson River Heritage, Hudson Opera House, or the Border Terrier Club of America. 1/3

GRAVES--Michael. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, whose energy, talent, and passion for the art of architecture and its teaching brought joy beyond the boundaries of space and time. 1/3

MELEDANDRI--Risha. Risha Meledandri, left us in the wee hours of March 9, 2015. She was a spirited, intelligent and beautiful woman known for her sense of style, her strong opinions and a forthright honesty. She was a lover of nature, birds, the woods, the beach, dogs, beauty, art, music, film, books and public radio. She was an activist, a poet and a perpetual student of life who possessed an uncanny prescience and a discerning eye. Born Risha Honey Levine in New York City to parents Rhea and Harry Levine, she attended George Washington High School and New York City Community College. She lived in Providence, RI for four years during her marriage to Monroe Davidson with whom she shared a love of sports cars and road rallies. On returning to New York she married men's clothing designer Roland Meledandri with whom she had two children; Nina and Christopher. She was both an inspiration and a partner in building his distinctive and highly successful business. During the early '70's Risha enrolled in Queens College to complete her undergraduate degree as a creative writing major. During this time she volunteered at WBAI public radio station where she became Assistant to the Program Director eventually conducting interviews of her own on-air. A committed activist, she participated in the anti-war movement and helped spearhead the fight to save Central Park from over development. At 55, fueled by her deep knowledge and connection to the music, ritual, art and religion of African based cultures she opened Espiritu; a folk art gallery focused on objects from all cultures that address a universal common spirit. In 1993 Risha left the city for Austerlitz, NY to live surrounded by nature. She continued her involvement in community affairs by volunteering for Meals on Wheels, the Austerlitz Historical Society and WAMC in Albany. She relocated to Rhinebeck, NY continuing her work at WAMC and her quest for knowledge at the Lifetime Learning Institute at Bard College before spending her final year in Park Slope, Brooklyn after being diagnosed with stage IV ovarian cancer. In Brooklyn she was charmed by the endless parade of dogs and children in Grand Army Plaza and she enjoyed weekly trips to the Brooklyn Public Library. Risha is survived by her two children: artist Nina Meledandri of Brooklyn, NY and producer Christopher Meledandri of Los Angeles, CA and two grandchildren: Nicholas Meledandri and James Meledandri. Donations in her memory can be made to public radio station WAMC (by mail: WAMC NE Public Radio/318 Central Ave./Albany, NY 12206 or as a memorial gift online at wamc.org/support-wamc by choosing "pledge now"). A memorial service is planned for the spring. 1/3

David Silvers, mother of Teri Silvers and mother-in-law of Steve Betensky, cherished grandmother of Daniel and Sarah, born December 3, 1934, attended Smith and graduated Barnard College and Simmons School of Social Work. She will be deeply missed. 1/3
SCHOENFELD--Mel. 5/27/30 -3/14/13 The sun has come up and set 24 times without you. How could that be! In my heart everyday. Love, your Aud. 1/3

FLANZER--Gloria. The Ophthalmology faculty and staff at Columbia University mourn the loss of our dear friend and benefactor Gloria Flanzer. She and her late husband, Louis, were both members of our Board of Advisors and were deeply committed to bringing outstanding eye care to all New Yorkers. Their vision, advocacy, and generosity helped make transformative changes to the Department. The Flanzer Eye Center, the Gloria and Louis Flanzer Vision Care Center, and the Gloria and Louis Flanzer Amphitheatre are the most visible examples of how the Flanzers led the effort to provide the absolute best care possible to all affected by eye disease. We will miss her concern for all patients, her wise counsel, and warm friendship. We extend our deepest condolences to the Flanzer and Milstein families. G. A. Cioffi, M.D., Chairman Stanley Chang, M.D., Chairman Emeritus Sir Howard Stringer, Chairman, Board of Advisors Department of Ophthalmology, Columbia University 1/3

MORRIS--Sue. Sue Nell Frymire Morris of Williamsburg, VA, and formerly of Manhasset and Water Mill, NY, passed away peacefully on March 7, 2015 at the age of 90. She was predeceased by her husband Walter Adams Morris Jr. Sue was born May 25, 1924 to Richard and Jesse Frymire in Irvington, Ky. Sue leaves behind her brother Maj. Gen. Richard L. Frymire (Phyllis) of Madisonville, KY; children: Susan of Alexandria, VA; Joan of Warrenton, VA; Walter Adams III (Penni) of Pompano Beach, FL; Jonathan (Margaret) of Essex, CT and NY, NY; Nancy Ford Miller (Kevin) of Manhasset and Water Mill, NY; and Ann Barrett (Jonathan) of Hyattsville, MD; five grandchildren: Kevin and Gordon Miller, Catherine Morris, Nancy and Betsy Barrett. Her sister Virginia Wavell-Smith predeceased her. Sue attended Western Kentucky University, where she was a cheerleader, and Judson College in Alabama. A woman of beauty and style, Sue moved to NYC to become one of American Airlines first stewardesses. There she met a dashing law student and the love of her life, Walter Adams Morris, Jr. They were an elegant couple that shared a loving life together for 64 years. A day did not go by when Walter asked Sue, "Have I told you how much I love you?" A woman deeply devoted to her family and home, she added beauty to the world in everything she did. She will be greatly missed by her adoring children. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and North Shore Southern Society. Burial will be at Southampton Cemetery, NY. 1/3
NASSER--Moise, passed away peacefully on March 11th, 2015 in Sao Paulo, Brazil. He is survived by his beloved wife Daisy, and his children Marina, Karina, Harry and their children.

BIRNBAUM--Gerald "Jerry", who lived a full and joyous life, passed away on March 12, 2015. He was born on April 14, 1923 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of the late Hilda (Jacobson) and Louis Birnbaum. He is survived by his beloved wife, Florence; three sons, Howard (Helayne), Lloyd (Julia), and Jeffrey (Ariel); and 11 grandchildren. His only sibling, Murray, preceded him in death. He graduated from City College of New York with a degree in Business. During WW II, he served in US Army Corps Intelligence and marched triumphantly down the Champs Elysee on V-E Day. Designated as a "Liberator," Jerry witnessed the atrocities at Buchenwald and was present at its liberation. His happiest moments were spent with his family. He was a devoted son, brother, husband, father, uncle and grandfather. He will be missed. 1/3

McCARTNEY--Daniel Francis. With great sadness, The Buckley School of New York City announces the death of beloved faculty member Dan McCartney. STACEY--Bob (Robert), aka Stacey Arceneaux, passed away on March 4, 2015 in Florida after a long illness. "Stacey," as he was universally known, was a New York City high school basketball legend and a member of the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame who played for the St. Louis Hawks of the NBA. He has been a long time teammate at Salenger, Sack, Kimmel and Bavaro, as its chief negotiator for personal injury cases. Our sincere condolences to his wife Roberta and her extended family. Salenger, Sack, Kimmel & Bavaro 1/3
BRAMWELL--Elizabeth. In memory of Elizabeth Bramwell: Your leadership and competitive spirit will be greatly missed. The Badminton Club of the City of New York 1/3

DUTTA--Manoranjan "Jan," one of the first economists of Indian-American heritage, died on February 22, 2015, from complications after a stroke. He was 90. A professor emeritus at Rutgers University, he pioneered American engagement with AsianPacific economies. The author of many books like "The Asian Economy and Asian Money" and "The United States of Europe: The European Union and the Euro Revolution," he specialized in the economics of globalization. A Fulbright Senior Specialist, he was a frequent guest lecturer in the United States and internationally. He chaired the National Advisory Council for South Asian Affairs, served as President of the Board of Trustees of the American Committee on Asian Economic Studies and founded the "Journal of Asian Economics." Born in India on October 1, 1925, he received his B.A. from Presidency College and his M.A. from the University of Calcutta. In 1958, he arrived as a Fulbright Fellow at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School where he became the first student to earn a Ph.D. under Nobel Laureate Lawrence Klein. A student leader in India's fight for independence, in the U.S. he battled for the rights of Indian-Americans, uniting the community as a social, cultural and political force in America. In 1967, he founded the Association of Indians in America (AIA), the oldest organization of Asian Indian immigrants in the United States with chapters nationwide. He is survived by his wife Kanak, his daughter Kavery, and his grandchildren Usha and Ashok. His life had a fullness that leaves ours less filled. 1/3

HAYS--William Henry III, Of Nantucket, died Wednesday, February 25, 2015. He was 84. Mr. Hays was born in New York City March 24, 1930 to William Henry Hays Jr. and Elizabeth Whiting Hays. He was a graduate of St. Paul's School (1947), Yale University (1951) and Harvard Law School (1957). He served as an active-duty deck officer in the United States Navy from 1951 to 1954. In 1957 he married Katharine Heard, who died in 1970, and in 1971 he married Lucile Thornton Walker. They moved from New York City to Nantucket in 1974. He was a partner of Holmes and Hays Law Offices for 25 years. Julie Fitzgerald joined the firm in 1981 as an associate and later became a partner. He was a member of the board of governors and past secretary of the Nantucket Yacht Club, as well as a member of the board of trustees of the Sankaty Head Golf Club, where he also served as secretary and legal counsel for many years. He joined the board of trustees of Nantucket Cottage Hospital in the late 1970s, and was secretary of the board for many years, and also chairman of its nominating committee. He retired as a trustee in 1997, but remained on as a corporator until 2009. He was a founding member of both its original advisory council, and the patient family advisory council, from 2009 to 2012. He remained supportive of efforts to engage community support for a new hospital by serving as a neighborhood captain of its community outreach program until his death. He is survived by his wife, Lucile Walker Hays; two daughters, Katharine Hays McBride and Elizabeth Hays Carroll; and four grandchildren, Elizabeth McBride Ford, Samantha Hays McBride, William Walker Carroll and Emily Hays Carroll. There will be a service at 11am, Saturday, June 27 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Fair Street in Nantucket. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to Nantucket Cottage Hospital. 1/3

COHAN--Felice S. Born in New York City, NY August 7, 1931 and passed away in Redding, CT on February 5, 2015 after a long illness. A long-time resident of Westport, Connecticut and Manhattan, New York, Felice was predeceased by her husband of 49 years, Richard L. Cohan, in 2000. She is survived by her daughters and their husbands, Cathy Cohan and Jeff Barat of Stamford, CT and Betsy Cohan and Ira Novsam of Weston, CT; her granddaughters Sydney and Jane Zorowitz; her sister and brother-in-law, Jennifer and Alden Englander of Greenwich, CT and Palm Beach Gardens FL; her brother and sister-in-law, Leonard and Joanne Schramm of Scottsdale, AZ and her nephews: Jason Englander of Purchase NY, Ron Schramm of Houston TX, Neal Schramm of Randolph, NJ and Michael Schramm of Morristown, NJ. Known for her keen intellect, Felice was also admired for her commitment to excellence in everything she did. She lived and loved courageously and encouraged those around her to do their very best in all endeavors. Now, when we walk Compo Beach; ski the most challenging runs; take off to discover new places; or simply gaze at the magnificence of the sky, we will remember this woman who was an ardent lover of life and we will miss her. 1/3

FARBSTEIN--Avraham. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of Avraham Farbstein, beloved father and grandfather. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his daughter Lihi, son Itay and grandson Lior, his brother David, his sister Dr. Miriam Adelson and brother-in-law Sheldon Adelson (distinguished Benefactors of Yad Vashem) and the extended family. NICHOLS--Thomas (Timothy) Steele, Jr. on February 25th at home in Jamaica, Vermont. He resided in Annapolis, Maryland. Burial at Forest Home Cemetery in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Born May 11, 1942 in New York City, Tim attended the Buckley School, Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University and Fordham. He served honorably in the U.S. Air Force Reserve and was a lifelong teacher of many disciplines, both in the classroom and on the athletic field. Tim was devoted to The Allen-Stevenson School. He was a highly skilled photographer, flew his own helicopter, loved skiing, accurate weapons, fast cars, was a brilliant linguist who dreamed in Italian and was a world traveler with an insatiable curiosity about life and a matching capacity to absorb knowledge and impart it to those wise enough to listen. Tim will be sorely missed by his many friends and family, who loved him dearly. 1/3

ZAGOR--Howard S. Beloved husband of the late Beverly Zagor, father of Stephen and Patricia Moger, grandfather of Max, passed peacefully on March 11, 2015. Born on October 21, 1919 he was a former resident of Norwich, VT and New York City, a graduate of Columbia Grammar and Dartmouth College, a recipient of the Bronze Star for his service in World War II, a past officer and current member of The Harmonie Club and president of Marcel Rochas US and later of Stricker and Zagor, Inc. Private services will be held for the family. 1/3

MacEACHRON-Allison Frances Bailey. 61, beloved wife of Frederick Grant MacEachron, died on March 8 at home in New York City, from breast cancer. She was born on January 5, 1954 to Avis Gilbert and Francis Wheeler Bailey in Bridgeport, CT. She attended Wheaton College, graduating in 1976 with Honors in Government. Allison grew up in Fairfield, CT, but her roots were in Maine where she spent summers on Echo Lake in Fayette. She loved her Maine heritage; her parents and several generations of grandparents were from Maine. Her great-greatgreat-great grandfather, Chase Elkins, was among the first settlers in Fayette following the American Revolution. Allison dreamed of being a New Yorker from the time she saw "Breakfast at Tiffany's" in her teens. She moved to Manhattan in 1979 where she worked in advertising for twenty-six years, the last seventeen of which were with Grey Group where she was Senior Vice President. In 2009, Allison transitioned to the non-profit sector where she was Director of the Business Council of the United Nations, a unit of the United Nations Foundation. Allison was a member of the Society of Mayflower descendants in the State of New York, having traced her roots back to four of the Pilgrims: William Brewster and Stephen Hopkins on her father's side and John Alden and William Mullins on her mother's side. She was a former treasurer of the New England Society in the City of New York, and she was a Director of the Off-the-Record (OTR) organization. She served on the board of her co-op apartment building for several years. Allison was an active Elder at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, where she and her husband were married in 1993. She served on several committees there, including the Global Ministries Fellows Committee, and on two occasions, she traveled to Africa with her church. Allison traveled all over the world; she loved skiing in the Alps and the Rockies with her husband, Fred, and she enjoyed European trips with her sisters. She especially loved this country's National Parks. Allison was an avid runner, and she was an accomplished pianist. In addition to her beloved husband, Allison is survived by her father; two sisters, Christy Bailey and her partner, Herb Shumway, Anne B. Hoover and her husband, Hap Hoover; a brother, Cory Bailey and his wife, Nancy Lok Bailey; two sisters-in-law, Jane M. McCandless and her husband James, Patricia M. Cox and her husband, Daniel; several nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews and several dear and life-long friends. A Celebration of Allison's life will be held on March 28, 2015 at 2pm at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Outreach Programs at the church. 1/3

ROSENBERG--Ilse, age 89, passed away peacefully in her sleep with her family by her side on the night of Tuesday, March 10th at the family home in Wrightsville Beach, North Carolina. She is survived by her husband of 51 years, Alan S. Rosenberg, Esq., her children Gary, Robert and Charlotte and her grandchildren Chelsea and Adam, all of whom adored her and she loved very much. Ilse was an aestheticist having been an accomplished fashion designer and fine artist. She danced to her own drummer, adored fine food, opera, especially being serenaded by her husband, classical music and the ballet. A holocaust survivor, she never took life for granted, practiced Pilates, ran, biked and swam. STARK--Dr. David Callum, passed away on March 11, 2015, aged 87, in Naples, FL. He had been a resident of the Naples area for over 20 years. Dr. Stark was born in Stirling, Scotland in 1927, a son of David Carmichael Stark and Elizabeth Helen Mary Cowan. He attended the High School of Stirling and the University of St. Andrews in Scotland. He qualified at the Royal College of Surgeons of England in 1956. He served in the Royal Army of Medical Corps and rose to the rank of Major. In 1954, he married Jean Mary Jenkins of Griffithstown, Wales. Dr. Stark was a Consultant Anesthetist at Newcastle General Hospital in 1965 when he and his family decided to emigrate to the United States. In the United States, Dr. Stark was on the Attending Staff and was Anesthesiologist-in -Chief and Chairman at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, as well as a Professor of Anesthesiology. In 1983, he joined the Attending Staff at Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse, NY. He was the Chief of Anesthesiology and Professor of Clinical Anesthesiology. He retired in 1991. He was also a member of numerous professional societies and presented many papers internationally over the span of his career. Dr. Stark was the author of "Practical Points in Anesthesiology," published in 1974, as well as numerous chapters in other publications. Dr. Stark is survived by his wife, Jean Mary Jenkins Stark of Naples, FL. In addition, he is survived by three sons and a daughter, and six grandchildren. They are J. Cowan Stark and his fiancee Beth Emmett of Durham, NH, Donald M. Stark and his fiancee Stacy Waters of Chicago, IL, Peter Stark and his wife Deborah of Lewisburg, PA, and Fiona H. M. Manseau of The Villages, Florida. His grandchildren are: John C. Stark of Towson, MD, Christina E. Stark and her husband Robert West of New Haven, CT, Elizabeth A. Stark and her fiance John F. Davis of Wichita, KS, Andrew C. Stark of Danvers, MA, Katlyn Manseau and her fiance Richard Lowe of Tampa, FL, and Michael Manseau of Boca Raton, FL. In addition to his parents, Dr. Stark was predeceased by a brother, Robert Donald Cowan Stark of Scotland in 1940, and a daughter-in-law, Jane Hyland Stark, in 2009. Dr. Stark was an avid golfer throughout his lifetime, and most recently was a member of Spanish Wells Country Club in Bonita Springs. He was an Elder at the First Presbyterian Church of Bonita Springs, a member at Saint Andrews Society of Southwest Florida, and the English-Speaking Union of the United States, Naples Branch, where he was a past president. Services will be on Monday, March 16 at 10am at First Presbyterian Church of Bonita Springs, FL. A reception will follow the service at the church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Dr. Stark's memory to The First Presbyterian Church of Bonita Springs or to the charity of your choice. Online condolences may be made at shikanyfuneralhome.com 1/3

PELLICANE--Rose Codell, 106, died peacefully in her sleep at the Manhattan home of her daughter Mary Susnjara. She is survived by her three children: Dr. Charles Pellicane, Mary Susnjara and Roseanne Washington. Mrs. Pellicane had five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She will be remembered for her warmth, generosity and the unconditional love she showed toward her family and friends. The wake will be held on Sunday, from 3pm-5pm, and 7pm-9pm at McLaughlin Kramer Funeral Home, 220 Glen St, Glen Cove. The funeral will take place on Monday, March 16, 10am at St. Gertude's Church in Bayville, Long Island. 1/3

FRAWLEY--David John Devoted husband and father, "Dave" Frawley passed peacefully from this life on March 7th in Kingwood Texas with his son Timothy by his side. He was 91. His three children, Christopher, Timothy, and Margaret Anne and their families including eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren survive him. Dave was born on May 14th, 1923 in Whitestone, New York to John Joseph Frawley and Anna (Lynch) Frawley. He grew up in Harlem, graduating from St. Cecilia's Elementary School, Patrick Henry Junior High School, and the New York School of Printing. Dave served in the Army Air Corps in World War II as a bomber tail gunner, flying missions into Europe from Africa and Italy. After the war, he started his long career with Eastern Air Lines. Dave was the manager of Eastern's New York City Ticket Offices and ran the company's operation at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. During that time he married Margaret "Peggy" Raake of Audubon, New Jersey in 1953. They expanded their family to include three children and settled in Kendall Park, New Jersey. Dave commuted to Manhattan and Peggy worked for Princeton University. He retired from Eastern in 1985 and they both relocated to Clearwater Florida. His beloved Peggy died in 1994. In addition to his family, Dave's great loves were horseracing, cigars, and jazz. He helped found the non-profit Suncoast Dixieland Jazz Society to provide scholarships for young musicians. Dave's mental faculties began to slowly fade and in 2008, he relocated to Kingwood Texas to live near his son, Tim and daughter-in-law Barbara. All that were privileged to know him will miss his warm heart, bright smile, charm, and sense of humor. A funeral service will be held Saturday March 14th at 10:00AM at St. Denis Catholic Church in Havertown, PA. Donations can be made in Dave's name to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

GILLESPIE--Paula W. It is with a profound sense of loss that we share the passing of Paula W. Gillespie. Born to Charlie W. Gillespie and Marilyn Slater in New Haven CT, she was the eldest of five sisters. She is survived by her three children and a current total of three grand-children who affectionately refer to her as "Nana." A gifted, unrelenting student and lover of the arts, she returned to school earning her Master's Degree from Columbia and recently resettled in the Philadelphia area. She brought life, love and laughter to all she met. Flowers can be sent to the Weber Funeral Home, Riverton, NJ for services on Tuesday, March 17 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent for an endowment created in her honor to support the Philadelphia Arts. 1/3

NIVES--Fred. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Fred Nives, who along with his wife, Donna, was greatly committed to wildlife conservation and animal well-being. The generosity toward animals by Mr. and Mrs. Nives will be memorialized at the WCS Bronx Zoo's Fred and Donna Nives African Wild Dog Pavilion. WCS was inspired by Mr. Nives's great love for horses, dogs, cats and all animals. The founding of the animal rescue group, Adopt-A-Dog, located in Greenwich, CT, and Armonk, NY, is a tremendous legacy to the couple's kindness and dedication to companion animals. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Donna Nives, Julie Nives Schwartzman, Dan and Zoe Schwartzman, Miriam and Marissa Nives, Vivian and Richard Van Buren, Annie, Jimmy, James and Nicholas Angellino. 1/3

STEINBREDER--Cynthia Means, passed away peacefully March 4th at her home in Sonoma, CA. She was 84 years old. Born in El Paso, TX on December 15, 1930, she was raised on a cattle ranch in the Davis Mountains just outside the town of Valentine. Cynthia graduated from the Radford School for Girls in El Paso and studied at Texas Western University and the University of Texas, earning a B.A. in Drama. Soon after, she married the love of her life, a St. Louis native named Sandy Steinbreder, who she had met when he was stationed as a United States Army First Lieutenant at Fort Bliss in El Paso. While Sandy took a sales job at Time Incorporated and moved to Fairfield, CT, Cynthia cheerfully took on the role as homemaker, corporate wife and, in time, mother. Survivors include her children, John Steinbreder of Redding, CT; Sissy Luciani of Dunwoody, GA; Gillett Brescia of Sonoma, CA; and Sarah Steinbreder of San Francisco. Also mourning her loss are her daughter-in-law Cynthia Crolius, her sons-in-law Michael Luciani and Bruce Brescia and her grandchildren Exa Steinbreder, Tyler and Drew Luciani and Lydia Cross. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Southport, CT on April 25 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Bloys Camp Meeting Association (c/o Maxie Watts, 125 Bluebriar Lane, Buchanan, Dam, TX, 78699) and the Alzheimer's Fund (800-272-3900; or visit her tribute page at alz.org). 1/3

Birdoff--Harvey. The best way to describe the man we will all miss, is with four simple words. "A very nice man". We can think of no better way to be remembered. The Murrays Bruce, Hilary, Jack, Max and Lucas

GOTTFRIED--Alex. Alex Gottfried, professor of political science and progressive political activist, died March 18, 2014. He was 94 and lived in Seattle. Dr. Gottfried's central passion was civil liberties. On the Board of the ACLU's Washington affiliate from 1961 to 1988, he was a gadfly who pushed the organization to broaden its definition of civil liberties. Born October 23, 1919, in Hungary, he grew up in Chicago. He joined the U.S. Army Air Corps in 1942, where he headed a de-Nazification unit of the U.S. military government in occupied Germany. He married the former Betty Sue Davidson in 1943. After the war he earned a PhD from the University of Chicago. He joined the political science faculty of the University of Washington, Seattle, in 1950 and taught there until he retired in 1982. He wrote "Boss Cermak of Chicago: A Study of Political Leadership", a primary text on American"machine politics." Dr. Gottfried is survived by his wife of 70 years, Sue Davidson Gottfried; daughter, Erika Gottfried, granddaughter, Sophia Fischler-Gottfried, and son-in-law, Steven Fischler. 1/3
GRAVES--Michael. Manitoga/The Russel Wright Design Center remembers its first Russel Wright Awardee, Michael Graves, for inspiring daily living for all through architecture and design. 1/3
LAZAR--Helene. Cherished friend, forever in our hearts. Barbara, Carol, Jeanne, Margie, Rae, Rita, Rona and Rose 1/3

PINCUS--Dr. Jonathan Henry, a neurologist academician, died on February 23, 2015 in Washington, DC. at the age of 79. At the time of his death he was serving as Chief of the Neurology Service at the DC VA Medical Center, as Professor of Neurology at Georgetown University and as Clinical Professor of Neurology at George Washington University School of Medicine. His areas of specialty were metabolic neurological disorders such as Leigh's Disease, mechanism of action of anti-seizure drugs such as Phenobarbital and Dilantin, and Parkinson's Disease and other movement disorders. Born in Brooklyn, NY, to Hannah and Dr. Joseph B. Pincus, a prominent pediatrician, he attended Amherst College and obtained his MD degree from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. He spent 25 years at Yale University rising from a Resident to a full Professor of Neurology. In 1986 he was appointed Chair of Neurology at Georgetown University becoming Chairman Emeritus in 2000. Dr. Pincus was a Fellow of the American Academy of Neurology and served for two years as a vice-president and was a member of the American Neurological Association where he served as a counselor for two years. In addition to the more than 150 articles published in peer reviewed journals and as chapters and editorials, he co-authored a well-known textbook, "Behavioral Neurology," with Gary Tucker, four editions, used extensively in residency training programs in Neurology and Psychiatry; and published a popular book, based on extensive research on the neurological basis for violent crime, entitled, "Base Instincts -What Makes Killers Kill." A loving husband to wife Joan (Maslansky) and father to Daniel, Jeremy (Sherry) and Adam (Ayelet) and brother to Dr. Matthew (Naomi) Pincus, to step-daughters Alyson (Daniel) and Debra, and to 20 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. 1/3

BIRDOFF--Harvey. You were the best father, father-in-law and grandfather that anyone could ever ask for. Always with a smile and wanting to help. We will miss you tremendously. Love you with all our hearts. Rick, Vicki, Alix, Kayle and Reid 1/3

BRAMWELL--Elizabeth R. Elizabeth R. Bramwell, 74, Wall Street pioneer, devoted wife and mother, fierce competitor to the end. A native New Yorker and daughter of a church organist, she was graduated from Bryn Mawr in 1962, where she was captain of the field hockey team, and Columbia Business School in 1967. She thereafter embarked on a celebrated career as a Wall Street equity analyst. Her 1974 William D. Witter report on Walt Disney predicted earnings per share down to the cent. In 1987, she started the Gabelli Growth Fund, one of the top-performing mutual funds of its era, and, in 1994, founded Bramwell Capital Management. She was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, The Economic Club of New York, the Cosmopolitan Club, the Women's National Republican Club, Colonial Dames of America, The National Society of Colonial Dames, The Hillsboro Club, The Quogue Field Club, and The Badminton Club of the City of New York. She is survived by her husband, William M. Bramwell, Jr., her two children, Austin W. Bramwell and Hilary F. Bramwell, her grandchildren, William P. Bramwell and Eva v. A. Bramwell, her brother, Robert C. Reed, three half sisters, Analise Reed, Kari Reed, and Kirstin Reed, and her step-mother, Joanne Reed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Elizabeth R. Bramwell scholarship fund at Columbia Business School. A memorial service will be held at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on May 7 at 2 pm. 1/3

BERKOWITZ--Esther, of Riverdale, NY passed away on March 14, 2015. She was 99. Born in Wielun, Poland to Daniel and Brahna Berkowics. Beloved wife of the late David Berkowitz, loving mother of Daniel Berkowitz M.D. (wife Judy) and Aida Gurwicz (husband Alan Siegel), cherished grandmother of Joel, Adam, Dana, and David Berkowitz and David Gurwicz, and great-grandmother of Ari, Raisa, Amalia, Reuben, Nathan and Zella. A Funeral service will be held at Westchester Jewish Center, 175 Rockland Ave. Mamaroneck, NY 10543 on Monday, March 16, 2015 at 11am. Interment will follow at Riversville Cemetery in Glenville, CT. For more information: www.zionchapel.com. 1/3
BLOCK--Burton "Bud". Farewell dear friend, we shall miss you. Helen, Alan, James and Michael Greene 1/3

HERTZBERG--Milton H. Age 98, died peacefully at home March 12, with his beloved wife Rhoda of 65 years by his side. He is also survived by his devoted children Brian, Barbara, and his son-in-law George L. Jurow. He was cherished by his grandson John Ross Jurow. Milton graduated from St. John's University, followed by military service during WWII. After the war, he worked for the IRS. He then owned a chain of retail stores in New York, Florida, and Maine. He was well loved by his family and many friends for his warmth and sense of humor. He will be deeply missed by those who had the fortune of knowing him.

KATZ--Donald B.,85, passed away at home on March 15, 2015. Beloved husband to Gertrude and loving father to Phyllis Katz, Susan Leavitt (Alan), Hank Katz (Jayne), and Jane Levy (Alan). Adoring grandfather (Poppy) to nine grandchildren. Also survived by a sister, Arlene. A graduate of NYU School of Commerce, Don began his accounting practice on a card table in his mother-in-law's store, The Fil-Net Shoppe, in Sag Harbor. He, later, established The Donald B. Katz accounting firm in his own building on Main Street. His avid love for tennis motivated him to be a founding partner of The Bridgehampton Tennis and Surf Club. For twenty five years, he was President of Temple Adas Israel. He relished his role of the shofar blower on the high holidays. Don, truly, loved his family and his life in Sag Harbor. We will miss him every day. Services will be held on Tuesday, March 17th at 11am at Temple Adas Israel, 30 Atlantic Avenue, Sag Harbor. Donations in memory of Donald B. Katz may be made to East End Hospice, Sag Harbor Food Pantry or Temple Adas Israel. 1/3

GILLESPIE--Paula W. It is with a profound sense of loss that we share the passing of Paula W. Gillespie. Born to Charlie W. Gillespie and Marilyn Slater in New Haven CT, she was the eldest of five sisters. She is survived by her three children and a current total of three grand-children who affectionately refer to her as "Nana." A gifted, unrelenting student and lover of the arts, she returned to school earning her Master's Degree from Columbia and recently resettled in the Philadelphia area. She brought life, love and laughter to all she met. Flowers can be sent to the Weber Funeral Home, Riverton, NJ for services on Tuesday, March 17 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent for an endowment created in her honor to support the Philadelphia Arts. 1/3

DARCY--Richard M.,of Rockaway Park, NY on March 14, 2015. Beloved brother Francis E. Darcy and Kathleen Mooney. Loving uncle to six nieces and nephews and great-uncle of thirteen. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Ave, Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 12pm at St Martha's RC Church, Uniondale, NY. www.mackenmortuary.com 1/3

NEWMAN--Eileen D.,an exceptionally kind and caring woman, died peacefully in New York City on March 14, 2015 from complications related to lung disease. She was 71. Eileen was a loyal and lifelong friend to many. She enjoyed competitive bridge, reading on the beach, playing with her grandchildren, and traveling the world. Eileen was an extraordinarily devoted wife and mother, and a doting grandmother. She was happily married for 45 years to her warm and gregarious late husband Arthur and is survived by her children, Sondra, Allison, and David; her son-in-law, Cengiz; her daughter-in-law, Stephanie; and her eight grandchildren: Leah, Alex, Sarah, Oliver, Zeki, Ella, Alara, and Adelia. Eileen balanced raising children with a career as a teacher and reading specialist. Her generosity of spirit and desire to help people in need extended and evolved throughout her life. She served for 14 years on the board of the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction (myFace), the last seven of which as president. In honor of her late husband, she established the Arthur B. Newman Honors College Scholars Endowment at Rutgers-Newark. Eileen recently joined the board of trustees of NYU Langone Medical Center. Eileen D. Newman was born in Newark, New Jersey on September 3, 1943. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to myFace at 333 E. 30th St., New York, NY, 10016. Funeral Service, Wednesday 11:00am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St. 1/3

ZAGOR--Howard S. The Harmonie Club notes with sorrow the passing of our honored member Mr. Howard S. Zagor. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Philip R. Cowen, President, The Harmonie Club 1/3
HASEN--Irwin, survived by Dondi, Wildcat, Green Lantern, The Goldbergs, and countless fans. We'll miss him. Beth, Fred, and the gang. Cheers. 1/3

GANFER--Susan, on March 15, 2015. Beloved wife of Steven. Devoted mother of Heather and Jason (Natali). Loving daughter of Edythe Schweitzer. Dear sister of Arthur Schweitzer and Alice Glick. Cherished grandmother of Aaron and Benjamin. An extraordinary mother who devoted herself to her family. Services Tuesday, 10am at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, NYC. 1/3

PELLICANE--Rose Codell, 106, died peacefully in her sleep at the Manhattan home of her daughter Mary Susnjara. She is survived by her three children: Dr. Charles Pellicane, Mary Susnjara and Roseanne Washington. Mrs. Pellicane had five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She will be remembered for her warmth, generosity and the unconditional love she showed toward her family and friends. The wake will be held on Sunday, from 3pm-5pm, and 7pm-9pm at McLaughlin Kramer Funeral Home, 220 Glen St, Glen Cove. The funeral will take place on Monday, March 16, 10am at St. Gertude's Church in Bayville, Long Island. 1/3

RUBENSTEIN--Charles, 1931-2015, died peacefully at his home in New York City on March 13th. His beloved partner, Marion, was at his side. A truly nice and gentle man. Charles was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, class of 1955. He was an avid gin player and golfer. He loved the camaraderie of being around his friends. He will be remembered and missed by many. He is survived by his partner, Marion Benedek, his sons, Jon and Robert Rubenstein, his brother Stuart, and sister-in-law Lois, daughters-in-law, Jamie and Katia Rubenstein, Elizabeth and Alan Kaye and Karen and Michael Benedek. He loved his 11 grandchildren very much; Blake, Samantha R, Alex, Brian, Ethan, Natalie, Jack, Samantha K, Drew, Oscar and Violet. 1/3

COHEN--Philip Allen, friend to all, passed away Thursday, March 12, 2015 at the age of 72. Former Senior Managing Director at Bear Stearns, Phil was famous for his larger than life personality, contagious smile, devotion to New York sports teams, playing tennis, love for Coca Cola, and always picking up the check. Phil is survived by his loving wife, Geri Moser-Cohen, his daughters Stacy Liu and husband Tom Liu, Sara Carlesimo and husband Paul Carlesimo, Jenna Moser-Cohen, and grandson Jaden Liu. 1/3

LIBMAN--Spencer Yale, husband, father, grandpa, financial consultant and friend of many, passed away on September 16, 2014. The cause of death was a fall precipitated by Parkinson's disease. He is deeply missed by his wife Lynn (of Naples, FL and Teaneck, NJ), loving children Allison, David and Michael, grandchildren Ashlee, Lindsay, Nicholas, Amelia, Neysa and Elijah, brother Lee (and wife Marsha) and their children, the children and grandchildren of his late brother Steve(and wife Joan), his cousin Arthur (and wife Marilyn), and his brothers-in-law Alfred Padula and Warren Padula (and wife Elaine). A private gathering was held at the time of his death. If anyone wishes to make a donation in his honor, the Parkinson's Association of Southwest Florida (www.PASFI.org) was very helpful to us.

COHEN--Arthur C.,"Art", died in the early morning of Sunday, March 15th with his wife Eve Imberman Cohen by his side. He was 75. A dedicated father, grandfather, brother, uncle, and cousin, Art was an iconoclast and extrovert, a raconteur and occasional provocateur who delighted in spirited evenings and debates. An avid train buff and lifelong student of military history, he possessed an encyclopedic knowledge of long-forgotten railways and the battlefields of WWII - his great passion. A graduate in history from the University of Wisconsin, he later earned an MBA from Columbia, and spent most of his career as a business and real property appraiser. He was a Member of the Appraisal Institute for 38 years, mentored dozen of appraisers, and taught financial aspects of real estate at Baruch College. A lifelong sports fan, he thrilled in watching the Yankees and Jets, treasuring Super Bowl III most of all. Art suffered through a host of illnesses and maladies in his lifetime, and remained steadfast and resolute in the face of challenges. He was a courageous, kind, warm, funny, highly intelligent, and sensitive man whose spirit and good humor touched hundreds of people in his lifetime. We will always remember the great "ACC." He is survived by his wife of 49 years, his sons Dan and Alex Cohen, his daughters-in-law Emily Thall and Lauren Shapiro Cohen, his three grandchildren Sydney, Raphael, and Milena, and dozens of family members and close friends. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, March 17th at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research at North Shore-LIJ, 350 Community Dr., Manhasset, NY 11030 or the University of Wisconsin. 1/3
