LOWENSTEIN DICINTIO--Dorothy. Born September 7, 1931, Died March 15, 2015. Survived by husband Domenick, children Terri, Bruce, Brian, and Debra

MacEACHRON--Allison. The Board of Governors of the Off-the-Record Lecture Series mourns the untimely passing of our friend and colleague, Allison MacEachron, a member of our board since 2010. We will miss her wise counsel and invaluable contributions. 1/3

MANDELKER--Sam, on March 16 at age 90. From the Lower East Side to Boca Raton; from New Guinea to his coffee shop to Kimco Realty, Sam saw and did it all with honor and class. He leaves behind a legacy of good deeds and love of family and friends. He is predeceased by his wives Sally Mandelker and Anita Kramer. He was a devoted father to Howard, Donna (Bruce) Abend and Robin (Robert) Spielman, and an extraordinary Poppi to Matthew (Sara) Abend, Max (Julianne) Abend, Ben (Jamie) Spielman, Michele (Ross) Gabel, Stacey Spielman and Allison Spielman, and five great- grandchildren. He was a devoted son and brother, deeply caring for those less fortunate, and a man of high moral standards. He was truly a benevolent and charitable soul. The family requests that donations be made to the Sam Mandelker College Connection at B'nai Torah Congregation, 6261 SE 18th St, Boca Raton, FL 33433. 1/3

NEWMAN--Eileen. On behalf of the trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center, we extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Eileen Newman. Eileen was a longtime friend and generous benefactor of NYU Langone, and served as a member of the Board of Trustees. We are most thankful for her commitment to our Department of Plastic Surgery, which she supported through myFace (formerly the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction) where she served as president for seven years. Through her personal foundation, Eileen also generously supported our work within the KiDS of NYU Langone Foundation and FACES (Finding a Cure for Epilepsy and Seizures). We offer our deepest sympathies to her children Sondra K. Neuschotz, Allison Beth Newman, and David E. Newman, and her six grandchildren. Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees, Robert I. Grossman, MD, Dean and CEO 1/3

HERTZBERG--Milton H. Age 98, died peacefully at home March 12, with his beloved wife Rhoda of 65 years by his side. He is also survived by his devoted children Brian, Barbara, and his son-in-law George L. Jurow. He was cherished by his grandson John Ross Jurow. Milton graduated from St. John's University, followed by military service during WWII. After the war, he worked for the IRS. He then owned a chain of retail stores in New York, Florida, and Maine. He was well loved by his family and many friends for his warmth and sense of humor. He will be deeply missed by those who had the fortune of knowing him.

FRIEDMAN--Kathe. Kathe A. Friedman. Suddenly on March 15, 2015 beloved wife of Cory E., Devoted mother of Weston H. and Cameron S., Dear sister of Barbara Rothnberg. Services Thursday, March 19, 2015 at 12:00pm at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. 1/3

NEWMAN--Eileen D.,an exceptionally kind and caring woman, died peacefully in New York City on March 14, 2015 from complications related to lung disease. She was 71. Eileen was a loyal and lifelong friend to many. She enjoyed competitive bridge, reading on the beach, playing with her grandchildren, and traveling the world. Eileen was an extraordinarily devoted wife and mother, and a doting grandmother. She was happily married for 45 years to her warm and gregarious late husband Arthur and is survived by her children, Sondra, Allison, and David; her son-in-law, Cengiz; her daughter-in-law, Stephanie; and her eight grandchildren: Leah, Alex, Sarah, Oliver, Zeki, Ella, Alara, and Adelia. Eileen balanced raising children with a career as a teacher and reading specialist. Her generosity of spirit and desire to help people in need extended and evolved throughout her life. She served for 14 years on the board of the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction (myFace), the last seven of which as president. In honor of her late husband, she established the Arthur B. Newman Honors College Scholars Endowment at Rutgers-Newark. Eileen recently joined the board of trustees of NYU Langone Medical Center. Eileen D. Newman was born in Newark, New Jersey on September 3, 1943. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to myFace at 333 E. 30th St., New York, NY, 10016. Funeral Service, Wednesday 11:00am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St. 1/3
SUTTER--EM, 10/1/22-3/17/13. Friend and raconteuse, not forgettable or forgotten. As promised. -- Anne 1/3

HOCKERT--Lorance, 76, died on March 11, 2015. A native New Yorker, graduate of NYU Law School, he used his training to serve his clients, and the community. He received numerous awards for public service: New York State Bar Association - Pro Bono Award for service to the mentally ill, New York City Parks Council - Leadership for Parks, and the Riverdale Mental Health Association Dodge Award among others. He held leadership roles in Community Board 8 in the Bronx and Manhattan and was founder of the Chinese American Culture and Art Association among other affiliations. Lorance is survived by his wife Ruth, sons Geoffrey and Kenneth, and sister Joan Donnelly. 1/3

GOODGOLD--Murray, Dearest Dad, 19 heartbroken years. Every year just gets harder, more painful and lonlier. The dreadful void never goes away. Life isn't the same without you and never will be. No amount of time will lessen my grief for you. Death leaves a heartache no one can heal. My love for you is eternal, you are with me everyday in my heart. I adored you, you were a gift from above. Love, Iris 1/3

AFFLECK--James Gelston III 92, passed away Sunday March 8, 2015 at his home in Shaftsbury, VT. Jim was born in Yonkers, NY on February 6, 1923, the son of James Gelston Affleck, Jr. and Francelia Johnson Affleck. Educated at Deerfield Academy, he received undergraduate and graduate degrees from Princeton University. During World War II, he served in the United States Navy and participated in the Normandy Invasion at Utah Beach, as well as in the Pacific theater. Jim worked for American Cyanamid his entire career, starting as a research chemist and rising to CEO and Chairman of the Board. A great believer in scientific research, he developed the pharmaceutical research program at Lederle Labs. He loved golf and was a member of Augusta National Golf Club, where he once scored a hole-in-one. He enjoyed fishing, sailing, and boating on the St. Lawrence River and was an avid football fan (Giants, Patriots) and baseball fan (Brooklyn Dodgers, Red Sox). Jim also enjoyed listening to big band and classical music. He is survived by his children, Nancy Affleck McKenzie and her husband Bruce of Danbury, CT, James G. Affleck, IV and his wife Diane of Andover, MA, and Margaret Affleck of Shaftsbury, VT; and by his sister May F. Affleck of Shelburne, VT, grandchildren Elizabeth, Catherine, and Caroline McKenzie, Meredith and Kellen Affleck, and great- granddaughter Emily Bryant. At the request of the family, funeral services will be private. There are no visiting hours. Gifts in Jim's memory may be made to the Long Trail School, 1045 Kirby Hollow Rd, Dorset, VT 05251 and designated as donations to the "Affleck Scholarship Fund." Or Clayton Volunteer Fire Dept., c/o Fire Chief, 855 Graves Street, Clayton, NY 13624. To send the family personal email condolences please visit: www. sheafuneralhomes.com. The family has entrusted services to the care of Brewster & Shea Funeral Service, 34 Park Place, Manchester Center, VT. 1/3

MANN--Harriet, nee Brechner, of New York City, passed away on March 13, 2015 with George, her beloved husband of 65 years by her side. Harriet was a force of nature, living a full and powerfully vibrant and exceptional life. Loving mother to Andy (Kathy), Richard (Lisa), Steven (Stephanie) and Thomas (Melissa). Proud grandmother to Ethan, Grace, Max and Aiden. Harriet had a special place in her heart for her dear Stefania, Max and Olivia Girombelli. Born in Brooklyn, NY to Rhea and Dan Brechner on May 12, 1928, Harriet found joy in her husband, sons, daughters-in-law, grandchildren, and dear friends. Harriet lived her life on the move. Walking (really fast!) everywhere, exercising, laughing and traveling. Harriet loved good food, wine, theater, music and anything beautiful. A special celebration of Harriet's life will be announced in the near future. 1/3

DALTON--Christopher Scott, age 59, died peacefully, after a long illness, on January 5, 2015 at his home in Prides Crossing, MA with his wife of 22 years, Susan Power Dalton, by his side and his son Jason E. Power of New York City. Christopher grew up in Garden City, NY on Long Island, the youngest of three sons. He was devoted to his parents, George and Dell Dalton. His father, George E. Dalton, for decades personified the five Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Homes on Long Island where he was a comforting and familiar face throughout the community prior to his death in 2002. Christopher lived by his father's example placing faith, family and community at the center of his life. When he was young and throughout his life, Christopher increasingly sought relaxation and refuge at the home he and his family owned on Shelter Island, NY until 2010. After graduation from Garden City High School (1973) Christopher followed his big brother Matthew to Colorado College, in Boulder where he graduated in 1977. He attended Boston University's School of Law where he was Editor of the Law Review, graduating Magna Cum Laude at the top of his class in 1982. That summer he accepted the position as Law Clerk to Justice Paul J. Liacos, Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Upon completing his clerkship he began his practice at Goodwin, Procter and Hoar of Boston, MA where he is still remembered as a valued friend and mentor. During his years at Goodwin, Procter Christopher achieved special recognition for his work on the Harbor Point Development in Charlestown, MA, ensuring affordable housing and in 1990 from Friends of the Shattuck Shelter for his "enthusiasm and expertise" on behalf of the Charles Francis Spillane Lodging House providing shelter for the homeless. In 1992, after his marriage to Susan Power, Christopher began work with the law firm of Craig and Macauley, P.C. of Boston, MA where he was a Partner upon his retirement in 2004 at the age of 49 after a diagnosis of Early Onset Alzheimer's Disease. Christopher's dedication to community service at home included the Vestry of St. John's Episcopal Church, Beverly Farms, as a Board Member and Treasurer for Glen Urquhart School, Beverly Farms, and through contributions supporting his wife's work with victims of abuse during her tenure as President of the Board of Directors for HAWC (Help for Abused Women and their Children) a non-profit in Salem, MA. He loved nature and enjoyed any outdoor activities, cross-country and downhill skiing, winter mountain hiking and snowshoeing, and achieved recognition for climbing all the "4000 footers" in New Hampshire (and a few in Maine). He, with a flock of like-minded friends, bicycled year round, including weekend "centuries", 100 mile rides up the coastline, drives to North Conway, NH to bicycle the Kangamangus Pass, and organized events like the Mt. Washington Climb and Pan Mass Challenge to benefit the Jimmy Fund. Throughout the ten years after his diagnosis in 2004 Christopher was cared for in his home by his wife, Susan, where he retained the cheerful, good natured disposition he is remembered for. When he could no longer speak he still laughed and smiled, enjoyed music of all kinds, cheered for the home teams and was delighted by visits from friends and son, Jason, a consistent and comforting presence. Christopher was blessed to have his childhood friend, Vincent Shanley of Darien, CT, Godfather to son Jason, ever present to the end, a true friend for life. Beloved husband, he is survived by his wife Susan Power Dalton. Devoted father to Jason E. Power of New York City and Emily A. Dalton l/k/a Brighton, MA (2008). Survived by his mother, Dell Dalton, his eldest brother and mentor of his youth, Matthew Dalton of Ferndale, WA as well as brother, Tim and sister, Martha. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale Street, Beverly Farms, MA on Saturday, April 25th at 3:00pm, reception to follow. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 480 Pleasant St., Watertown, MA 02472 or at www.alz.org where Christopher S. Dalton is listed so that names (but not the amounts) of those who contribute in his memory can be passed on to the family. All contributions are tax deductible and any amount is appreciated. Services by the Campbell Funeral Home, 525 Cabot Street, Beverly, Massachusetts. Information, directions, condolences a www.campbellfuneral.com. 1/3

GANFER--Susan. The partners and staff of Ganfer & Shore, LLP mourn the passing of Susie Ganfer, loving wife of our senior partner Steven, beloved mother of our colleague Jason (and wife Natali) and sister Heather, cherished grandmother of Aaron and Benjamin and devoted daughter of Edythe Schweitzer. Our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Susie will be remembered always. 1/3
SCHWARTZ--Martin S.,December 25, 1914 - March 17, 2014. You were the best father. We miss you and love you every day. Barbara and Peter 1/3

KYRIAKOU--Konstantinos, known as Dinos, died in Florida on March 11 at age 79. A long-time Manhattan resident, he divided his retirement time between Long Island and Florida. Dinos was born on the Greek island of Kalymnos and left in 1960 to build his life in the US. He arrived in New York with no money, no family, and no friends to begin the remarkable journey that brought him professional success, a loving family, and a host of friends. His career centered on Wall Street, where he was both a stock and futures broker. In the 1980s he served as New York manager of Clayton Brokerage. Dinos married Linda La Gamma in 1967, and together they welcomed their daughter, Christina, in 1978. Family was paramount to Dinos. He embraced his personal family and regarded his friends and associates as an extension of family. In addition to his wife and daughter, he is survived by his son-in-law, David Kahn; his sister-in-law, Madeleine Blanc; his nieces, Jennifer Blanc-Tal, Victoria Blanc, and Kalliope Kakanakis; his nephews, Jason Tal, and Dino and George Kakanakis; grandnephews, William Tal and Nicholas Stephanopoulis, and grand nieces, Josette Tal and Zoe Kakanakis. Celebrations of his life will be held in Florida and New York. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering. 1/3

SCHWARZ--Julia Bach. In memory of our dear aunt, Julia Bach Schwarz. Devoted mother of John Squire and Jill Keech, beloved sister of Margery Bach Brodsky and Emily Bach Bishop, and fast friend to all of our families' offspring. Her son and daughter reciprocated their mother's love with deep devotion. With selfless grace, Julia built community wherever she lived; in New York City where she was born on March 28, 1913, in Tucson, Arizona where she lived for many years, and in Gaithersburg, Maryland where she died on March 11, 2015. When she could no longer travel the world, it was her love of reading that sustained her. All who knew her sent her books. The last of her generation, she was our sustaining matriarch. Alice Brodsky Forcier and Joan Brodsky Schur 1/3
BRECKIR--Albert Yale. Happy Birthday it's been 28 long years. We think of you. Your Family 1/3

GANFER--Susan, on March 15, 2015. Beloved wife of Steven. Devoted mother of Heather and Jason (Natali). Loving daughter of Edythe Schweitzer. Dear sister of Arthur Schweitzer and Alice Glick. Cherished grandmother of Aaron and Benjamin. An extraordinary mother who devoted herself to her family. Services Tuesday, 10am at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, NYC. 1/3

VAN LEER--Lia. You were so special and you touched so many lives. You changed the world to be a better place not only in Cinema but with your kindness and love. You made us feel like family. We love you and miss you very much. Leon, Michaela, Joanna & Philippe 1/3

PITLER--Robert M. The Brooklyn Law School community deeply mourns the loss of Professor Robert Pitler, Class of 1966, a cherished teacher, scholar, colleague, and friend. Bob joined the Law School faculty in 1988 after 13 years at the Manhattan District Attorney's Office, where he served as Chief of its Appeals Bureau, Chief of the Investigation Division, and Counsel to the District Attorney. He taught Criminal Law, Criminal Procedure, Evidence, and a seminar in Law and Film. He had a profound impact on the lives and careers of generations of students who treasured his strong intellect, his passion for teaching and, above all, his genuine warmth and care. For the last 12 years, he was the faculty advisor to the Moot Court Honor Society, a program that stands out as a law school highlight for many Brooklyn Law School Students. For more than 20 years he directed the prestigious Dean Jerome Prince Memorial Evidence Competition, for which he received a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2013. In January 2015, he was named a Distinguished Alumnus of the Year for his many achievements and for his remarkable devotion to teaching. His dedication to students extended beyond their time at the Law School. Nearly two decades ago, he created the Criminal Justice Post-Graduate Fellowship, which provides loan forgiveness to alumni practicing criminal law in the public sector. He will be greatly missed by all, especially by his students and colleagues at the Law School. We extend our deepest sympathy to his daughter, Rebecca Pitler, his brother, Sandy Pitler, his extended family, and his large circle of close friends. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Nicholas W. Allard, President and Dean 1/3

BUTLER--Claire Garvey, 84, died peacefully on March 14, 2015. Born June 16, 1930, in New York City, she attended the Convent School of the Sacred Heart and received degrees from the College of New Rochelle and Teachers College at Columbia University. Married to Dr. John K. Butler (now deceased) in 1957, she raised her eight children in Orange, New Jersey. She was a former president of the Garden Club of the Oranges. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10am on Wednesday, March 18, at Saint James the Apostle Church, Springfield, NJ. Visiting hours will be from 4pm to 8pm on Tuesday, March 17, at Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, Westfield, NJ. 1/3

DEMING--Vida Ginsberg, died at home March 11, 2015 surrounded by family. She was born in New York City on August 17, 1920 and attended the Lincoln School and Bennington College where, working in summer stock, she met Quentin Deming with whom she spent the next 75 years of her life. She had a long, inspired and inspiring career as a teacher and dramatist throughout which she was a mentor to three generations of artists, family and friends whom she nurtured with her unfailing energy, intelligence and great imagination. She is survived by her husband of 65 years, Dr. Quentin B. Deming; her daughters, Lilith Deming and Maeve Guesdon, her loving grandchildren, Julie and Jeremy Guidoni and Jules Guesdon, her son-in-law Jean-Francois Guesdon, her brother, Robert Ginsberg and her extended adoring family and friends. To view an online memorial and or send a message of condolence to the family, please visit www.rand-wilson.com. Services are under the direction of the Rand-Wilson Funeral Home of Hanover, NH. 1/3

RUBIN--Edwin "Ed," 86 of New York City, on March 16, 2015. Survived by his wife Jacqueline, son and daughter-in-law Joshua and Gina, and first cousin Roberta Silberberg. Born and raised in Massachusetts, Ed graduated from Boston University with a degree in TV and Radio Production. He proudly served our country as a Sergeant in the United States Army during the Korean War in the 1950s as an Information Specialist. Post-Army years found Ed working his way up the ladder in the entertainment business. As President of Magna Artists Corporation, one of the top independent music agencies of the 1970s. Later in his career, he worked for the Nederlander Organization, booking and managing theaters throughout the country. Graveside service: Tuesday at 1pm in Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn. Donations to Calvary Hospital. For condolences, directions, or information: edenmemorial.com or call (201)947-EDEN. 1/3
WILSON--Lela J. September 19, 1919 - March 17, 2014

LIEBOWITZ--Solomon, M.D. July 24, 1931 to March 14, 2015. "Life is a Journey," and for Sol it began in the Bronx on July 24th, 1931 born to Lilly (died 1983) and Nathan Liebowitz (died 1959), immigrants from Gravna and Lithuania. After Bronx Science High School, NYU Heights and NYU Medical School, all on scholarship, Sol became a Captain and Medic in the United States Air Force stationed in London during the Berlin "no fly channel." His residency at The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary, where he was so dedicated to patients, staff, alumni and colleagues, began his career as an extraordinary, well-respected, loved and leading ophthalmologist in his field. Sol's Journey as a loving and caring son, brother to George (died 1983), father to Nancy Rabinowitz (Jason) and Samantha Kaufman (Neal), and grandpa to Madeline, Alex and Reese, brother-in-law to Betty Leibowitz (died 2005) and Barbara and Edward M. Selsky. Most of all he is survived by Susan, his best friend, soulmate, partner and beloved wife. And so his Journey with us is complete. He will be forever and ever in our hearts. For funeral info., please call Plaza Funeral Home at 212-769-4400 or go to www.plazajewish.org 1/3

NEWMAN--Eileen. The Trustees of MyFace, formerly the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, and the faculty and staff of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at the NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Eileen Newman on Saturday, March 14. Eileen served as President of myFace for the past seven years. Along with her late husband, Arthur, she had been a generous supporter for many years. Through her boundless generosity, energy, and dedication to MyFace and the Institute, Eileen enriched the lives of the patients and families of the Institute. She was ever a loyal and steadfast friend to all who knew her. Eileen will be sorely missed, but her legacy will live on through the work of the Newman Family Support Center and the Newman Adult Patient Care Fund. Eileen is survived by her children, Sondra, Allison, and David; her son-in-law, Cengiz; her daughter-in-law, Stephanie; and her eight grandchildren: Leah, Alex, Sarah, Oliver, Zeki, Ella, Alara, and Adelia, to whom she was so loving and devoted and to whom we express our deepest sympathy. John R. Gordon Chair, MyFace Eduardo D. Rodriguez, MD, DDS Chair, Department of Plastic Surgery Director, Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at the NYU Langone Medical Center 1/3

FLOWERS--Richard Clark, 66, died March 14, 2015 in Manhattan after a long illness and hospitalization. He is survived by his daughter, Jennifer Flowers-Maldonado; his long-time companion, Wendy Milone; and his siblings, William, Kenneth and Donald Flowers and Carolyn Wilson. He was predeceased by his former wife, Roberta Dulong Flowers. Born August 17, 1948, he grew up in Larchmont, NY as the fourth child of Roy and Esther Flowers. He graduated from Ithaca College and the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College. He joined Arthur Andersen LLP in New York City in 1972 after business school, and continued there as a partner and certified public accountant until 2002, and then moved to the New York City office of Grant Thornton LLP as a partner and later as a consultant. His specialty was accounting issues for Wall Street securities firms. A memorial service will be held on April 2, 2015 at 11:00am at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the American Diabetes Association or the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation. 1/3

KATZ--Edward C. Beloved husband of Candace Leeds, died on March 12, after a prolonged battle with Parkinson's disease. Ed had a distinguished career in the financial industry, designing and managing investment strategies for private and institutional investors. Before retiring to pursue a wide range of personal interests, he was a partner at Sanford C. Bernstein (now AllianceBernstein). Prior to that he rose to President of J & H Equity Corporation, the investment advisory unit of Johnson & Higgins, which was one of the largest insurance companies in the world before it was sold to Marsh & Mclennan. Ed served on the adjunct faculty of NYU, and the editorial board of the Journal of Compensation and Benefits. He received his AB degree, magna cum laude, from Rutgers University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Ed was revered by his colleagues and clients throughout his career. After retiring, he continued to provide voluntary financial counseling to non-profit organizations such as Citymeals-on- Wheels. He was devoted to his wife of 18 years, Candace; and his family, particularly his late brother Marty, his sister and brother-in-law, Meri and Tom Pollak and the entire Pollak and Friedman families. Also, he will be missed by his friends who loved him and will miss his wit, his warmth and caring, and his always sage advice. Donations in his name can be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, NYC, NY 10018 (www. Pdf.org) A memorial celebration of his life will be held in late April. 1/3

MANDELKER--Sam. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Sam Mandelker, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our deepest condolences to Sam's children Robin (Bob Spielman), Howard Mandelker, and Donna (Bruce Abend); his grandchildren; his great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3
PITLER--Robert M. 1941-2015. He will never be forgotten. Rest in peace dear friend. Charlie "George" Solomon 1/3

COATES--Nancy. Nancy Sloane Coates, of Haverford, PA. died on Thursday March 12th, at home. She was the wife of the late Benjamin Coates and mother of Theodate Coates and Benjamin Coates Jr., grandmother of Dionicia O'Sullivan and Anatole Xavier Hernandez, great grandmother of Sebastian, Oona and Lucian. Nancy Sloane Coates was born in New York City, October 16, 1920. Her family founded "W and J Sloane" whose flagship department store was located at 19th Street and Broadway in the "Ladies Mile." W and J Sloane's decorators were responsible for the decor of the White House and the Breakers in the late 1800's. As a young woman, Nancy was inspired by Florence Nightingale. She entered the Columbia School of Nursing and graduated in 1944 earning a degree as an R.N. She also married Benjamin Coates in 1944 who was in the Navy at the time and later earned a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. Throughout her life, she was concerned with charities for veterans and the mentally ill. In 1956 she expanded the work of Mrs. Lytle Hull, who founded the Musicians Emergency Fund in New York City to provide professional concerts and musical therapy for wounded American veterans, to Philadelphia. Her organization raised funds by holding parties and an annual designer clothing sale. When the U.S. government took over funding for musical therapy for the veterans, the women of the Pennsylvania branch of the organization decided to continue their clothing sale with a new focus on local charities. In 1977 they reorganized as Community Clothes Charity. In the years since, the sale has grown from a one-day event in a private house to a three-day public sale. The Community Clothes Charity is continuing and every year a different charity receives the proceeds of the sale. Nancy's favorite charity recipient was "Puppies behind Bars." She also served on the women's committee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art for 58 years. She is much loved and remembered by her family, friends and the members of the Community Clothes Charity. 1/3

KATZ--Donald B.,85, passed away at home on March 15, 2015. Beloved husband to Gertrude and loving father to Phyllis Katz, Susan Leavitt (Alan), Hank Katz (Jayne), and Jane Levy (Alan). Adoring grandfather (Poppy) to nine grandchildren. Also survived by a sister, Arlene. A graduate of NYU School of Commerce, Don began his accounting practice on a card table in his mother-in-law's store, The Fil-Net Shoppe, in Sag Harbor. He, later, established The Donald B. Katz accounting firm in his own building on Main Street. His avid love for tennis motivated him to be a founding partner of The Bridgehampton Tennis and Surf Club. For twenty five years, he was President of Temple Adas Israel. He relished his role of the shofar blower on the high holidays. Don, truly, loved his family and his life in Sag Harbor. We will miss him every day. Services will be held on Tuesday, March 17th at 11am at Temple Adas Israel, 30 Atlantic Avenue, Sag Harbor. Donations in memory of Donald B. Katz may be made to East End Hospice, Sag Harbor Food Pantry or Temple Adas Israel. 1/3

NEWMAN--Eileen. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the loss of our dear friend Eileen Newman, whose grace and empathy will continue to inspire our mission. Eileen, along with her late husband and former Hospital trustee Arthur, embodied the ethos of patient- centered, compassionate care. Together, their generosity has touched and comforted the lives of many in need, as evidenced by the Infusion Center named in their honor. We offer our deepest condolences to their son David and all of her family at this time. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chair, Board of Trustees Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO Herbert Pardes, MD, Executive Vice Chair, Board of Trustees NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital 1/3

CARROLL--Rev. Patrick J.,born in New York City on April 19, 1928, died at home on March 13, 2015. He is remembered for his patience, kindness, courage, intellect and wit which contributed to his special presence in the lives of his friends, fellow priests and family. He will be greatly missed by his sister Mary C. McCarthy and her husband Thomas, his brother John F. Carroll, Ann M. Ahern, 10 nieces and nephews, 15 grand nieces and nephews and countless cousins. He is predeceased by his brother Aeneas Carroll and his Irish born parents, John and Anastasia Carroll. He graduated from St Joseph's Seminary and was ordained a priest at St Patrick's Cathedral in 1953. He served in parishes across the Archdiocese of New York including Church of the Sacred Heart, Highbridge, Bronx, Our Lady of Loreto, Bowery, Manhattan, and on the staff of Family Consultation Service of the Archdiocese with residence at Holy Name Center. He earned his Ph.D in psychology from St. John's University and was a gifted pastoral and family counselor. Throughout his life people turned to him for guidance and counseling: he was a trusted and beloved confidant to all. He had an enduring love of Ireland and shared fond memories of his childhood in Abbeyfeale, Co. Limerick. The family is grateful for the compassionate care provided by Verney George, Carleen Cochrane, and Juliano Innocenti, under the guidance of his loving nephew Thomas P. McCarthy. Receiving hours will be on March 18 from 2pm to 9pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, New York, NY 10021. A funeral Mass will be held on March 19 at 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral followed by burial at St. Raymond's Cemetery. All are welcome. 1/3
KATZ--Donald B. Farewell to our guiding light. We will miss you. Our sincere condolences to the Katz family. The Board and members of Temple Adas Israel, Sag Harbor, NY 1/3

FARBER--Roberta. She is survived by two sons, Peter and Steven, and sister Grace. She will be missed. 1/3

LIEBOWITZ--Solomon, M.D. July 24, 1931 to March 14, 2015. "Life is a Journey," and for Sol it began in the Bronx on July 24th, 1931 born to Lilly (died 1983) and Nathan Liebowitz (died 1959), immigrants from Gravna and Lithuania. After Bronx Science High School, NYU Heights and NYU Medical School, all on scholarship, Sol became a Captain and Medic in the United States Air Force stationed in London during the Berlin "no fly channel." His residency at The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary, where he was so dedicated to patients, staff, alumni and colleagues, began his career as an extraordinary, well-respected, loved and leading ophthalmologist in his field. Sol's Journey as a loving and caring son, brother to George (died 1983), father to Nancy Rabinowitz (Jason) and Samantha Kaufman (Neal), and grandpa to Madeline, Alex and Reese, brother-in-law to Betty Leibowitz (died 2005) and Barbara and Edward M. Selsky. Most of all he is survived by Susan, his best friend, soulmate, partner and beloved wife. And so his Journey with us is complete. He will be forever and ever in our hearts. For funeral info., please call Plaza Funeral Home at 212-769-4400 or go to www.plazajewish.org 1/3

O'ROURKE--Robert B.,of Massapequa Park, formerly of Brooklyn and Rosedale Queens, on March 14, 2015 in his 83rd Year. Member of The New York Times pressman union for 46 years. Proud Army Veteran. Beloved husband of the late Kathleen O'Rourke and the late Frances O'Rourke. Dear son of the late Helen and Joseph. Predeceased by his siblings Joseph, Donald, Maureen and Linda. Loving father of Barbara (James), Robert (Jodi), John (Peggy) and the late Mary. Dear Stepfather of Brendan, Kathleen and Maureen. Adored grandfather of 16. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10:45am at Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Massapequa Park. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale. 1/3

RUBENSTEIN--Charles. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of our esteemed member, Charles Rubenstein. Mr. Rubenstein was a member of Fresh Meadow Country Club for 52 years and he was 83 years of age. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Michael Lamoretti, President Harvey Kadden, Secretary 1/3

FLOWERS--Richard Clark, 66, died March 14, 2015 in Manhattan after a long illness and hospitalization. He is survived by his daughter, Jennifer Flowers-Maldonado; his long-time companion, Wendy Milone; and his siblings, William, Kenneth and Donald Flowers and Carolyn Wilson. He was predeceased by his former wife, Roberta Dulong Flowers. Born August 17, 1948, he grew up in Larchmont, NY as the fourth child of Roy and Esther Flowers. He graduated from Ithaca College and the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College. He joined Arthur Andersen LLP in New York City in 1972 after business school, and continued there as a partner and certified public accountant until 2002, and then moved to the New York City office of Grant Thornton LLP as a partner and later as a consultant. His specialty was accounting issues for Wall Street securities firms. A memorial service will be held on April 2, 2015 at 11:00am at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the American Diabetes Association or the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation. 1/3

MANN--Harriet. To the most elegant lady, the vision of you in your Pucci dresses will remain in our hearts forever. With love, Maxine & Skip Pines Roberta & Les Sufrin Annelies & Harris Freedman Marianne & Harvey Bernstein Judy & Mike Wahl 1/3

COATES--Nancy. Nancy Sloane Coates, of Haverford, PA. died on Thursday March 12th, at home. She was the wife of the late Benjamin Coates and mother of Theodate Coates and Benjamin Coates Jr., grandmother of Dionicia O'Sullivan and Anatole Xavier Hernandez, great grandmother of Sebastian, Oona and Lucian. Nancy Sloane Coates was born in New York City, October 16, 1920. Her family founded "W and J Sloane" whose flagship department store was located at 19th Street and Broadway in the "Ladies Mile." W and J Sloane's decorators were responsible for the decor of the White House and the Breakers in the late 1800's. As a young woman, Nancy was inspired by Florence Nightingale. She entered the Columbia School of Nursing and graduated in 1944 earning a degree as an R.N. She also married Benjamin Coates in 1944 who was in the Navy at the time and later earned a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. Throughout her life, she was concerned with charities for veterans and the mentally ill. In 1956 she expanded the work of Mrs. Lytle Hull, who founded the Musicians Emergency Fund in New York City to provide professional concerts and musical therapy for wounded American veterans, to Philadelphia. Her organization raised funds by holding parties and an annual designer clothing sale. When the U.S. government took over funding for musical therapy for the veterans, the women of the Pennsylvania branch of the organization decided to continue their clothing sale with a new focus on local charities. In 1977 they reorganized as Community Clothes Charity. In the years since, the sale has grown from a one-day event in a private house to a three-day public sale. The Community Clothes Charity is continuing and every year a different charity receives the proceeds of the sale. Nancy's favorite charity recipient was "Puppies behind Bars." She also served on the women's committee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art for 58 years. She is much loved and remembered by her family, friends and the members of the Community Clothes Charity. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Kathe. Kathe A. Friedman. Suddenly on March 15, 2015 beloved wife of Cory E., Devoted mother of Weston H. and Cameron S., Dear sister of Barbara Rothnberg. Services Thursday, March 19, 2015 at 12:00pm at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. 1/3

CARROLL--Rev. Patrick J.,born in New York City on April 19, 1928, died at home on March 13, 2015. He is remembered for his patience, kindness, courage, intellect and wit which contributed to his special presence in the lives of his friends, fellow priests and family. He will be greatly missed by his sister Mary C. McCarthy and her husband Thomas, his brother John F. Carroll, Ann M. Ahern, 10 nieces and nephews, 15 grand nieces and nephews and countless cousins. He is predeceased by his brother Aeneas Carroll and his Irish born parents, John and Anastasia Carroll. He graduated from St Joseph's Seminary and was ordained a priest at St Patrick's Cathedral in 1953. He served in parishes across the Archdiocese of New York including Church of the Sacred Heart, Highbridge, Bronx, Our Lady of Loreto, Bowery, Manhattan, and on the staff of Family Consultation Service of the Archdiocese with residence at Holy Name Center. He earned his Ph.D in psychology from St. John's University and was a gifted pastoral and family counselor. Throughout his life people turned to him for guidance and counseling: he was a trusted and beloved confidant to all. He had an enduring love of Ireland and shared fond memories of his childhood in Abbeyfeale, Co. Limerick. The family is grateful for the compassionate care provided by Verney George, Carleen Cochrane, and Juliano Innocenti, under the guidance of his loving nephew Thomas P. McCarthy. Receiving hours will be on March 18 from 2pm to 9pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, New York, NY 10021. A funeral Mass will be held on March 19 at 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral followed by burial at St. Raymond's Cemetery. All are welcome. 1/3
HOCKERT--Lorance. Riverdale Mental Health Association's Board of Directors expresses condolences to the family of Lorance Hockert. Long-time Board Member and Counsel, his support was unwavering. 1/3
SELIG--Marion. A cherished and wonderful friend who will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt sympathy and much love go to her beautiful children, Marea and David. Diana and Richard Feldman 1/3

VAN LEER--Lia. You were so special and you touched so many lives. You changed the world to be a better place not only in Cinema but with your kindness and love. You made us feel like family. We love you and miss you very much. Leon, Michaela, Joanna & Philippe 1/3

SELIG--Marion M.,born March 20, 1940 in Vancouver, British Columbia, only daughter of Mary Toine Torvinen of Finland and Francis Renault Joubin of France. She is survived by her children Marea M. Selig and David Selig, Jose Ignacio "Mono" Casas and Cecilia Dean. She died peacefully at home in New York, March 16, 2015. A celebration of Marion's life will be announced in the near future. 1/3

FARRELL--Thomas J.,former Marine aviator and retired AT&T executive died January 3, 2015. Born November 9, 1943, he was the beloved husband of Patricia, loving father of Thomas and Kathryn, devoted grandfather to Thomas and Riley and loving uncle to Mary and Jacqueline. A graduate of Fordham and NYU, Tom served in Vietnam with the 1st Marine Airwing before beginning his career in telecommunications. In our hearts we will always carry his wisdom, his courageous nature, his genuine goodness and his constant smile. 1/3

JOELSON--Walter, age 92 of Stamford, CT, passed away peacefully on Monday, March 16, 2015 at the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT. Mr. Joelson was born in Berlin, Germany a son of Fritz and Antoinette Joelsohn, who perished in the Holocaust. Walter fled to Switzerland, where he earned his Ph.D. in Economics before coming to the United States. He is survived by his beloved wife, Karen, by his devoted children Deborah and her husband David Neal, David and his wife Sharon, Ronald and his wife Renee, and by his cherished grandchildren, Michael and his wife Christina, Andrew, Benjamin and his wife Ashley, Michelle and her husband Shane, Jonathan, Madeline, Peter, Richard, Patrick, and Katherine. Mr. Joelson was predeceased by his adored sister, Ursula, who also perished in the Holocaust. 1/3

Liebowitz--Solomon. The congregation of Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deepest sorrow the death of our longtime, cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Susan and their family. May God comfort his loved ones and may his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch Michael Starr, President 1/3

NEWMAN--Eileen. The Trustees of MyFace, formerly the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, and the faculty and staff of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at the NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Eileen Newman on Saturday, March 14. Eileen served as President of myFace for the past seven years. Along with her late husband, Arthur, she had been a generous supporter for many years. Through her boundless generosity, energy, and dedication to MyFace and the Institute, Eileen enriched the lives of the patients and families of the Institute. She was ever a loyal and steadfast friend to all who knew her. Eileen will be sorely missed, but her legacy will live on through the work of the Newman Family Support Center and the Newman Adult Patient Care Fund. Eileen is survived by her children, Sondra, Allison, and David; her son-in-law, Cengiz; her daughter-in-law, Stephanie; and her eight grandchildren: Leah, Alex, Sarah, Oliver, Zeki, Ella, Alara, and Adelia, to whom she was so loving and devoted and to whom we express our deepest sympathy. John R. Gordon Chair, MyFace Eduardo D. Rodriguez, MD, DDS Chair, Department of Plastic Surgery Director, Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at the NYU Langone Medical Center 1/3

RIGG--Jean, died peacefully at her home in Cedar Key, Florida, on March 11, 2015, after an energetic and exceptionally varied life. Diagnosed with lung cancer, she had the help in her last months of her sister and friends, both local and from further away, who were with her at the end. Jean was born in Chicago, on November 17, 1938, the only child of Emily De Beukelaer and Jack Wallen. Her parents divorced, and Jean's mother married Col. Robert Rigg, who adopted Jean. His military assignments at the close of World War II took the family abroad, and Jean spent part of her early childhood in China. She grew up in the Virginia suburbs of Washington, D.C, then attended Rollins College in Winter Park, Florida. After graduation, she moved to New York City, where she taught school on Staten Island. In the 1960s, she joined the orbit of the Cunningham Dance Company, eventually becoming its administrator, a role that called upon her delight in responding to new challenges and unanticipated problems. Jean made many long-lasting friendships in the company and with the large circle of artists, musicians, and others who collaborated on Cunningham's projects. She left her position with Cunningham to attend Cardozo Law School, graduating in 1979. As she looked for the legal job she wanted, for a time she drove a taxicab in New York City. Jean went on to work in the television industry, but continued to be involved with the Cunningham circle. Jean's lifelong interest in artistic experimentation also drew her into the work of the Judson Memorial Church. She was a founder of the annual marathon readings of Gertrude Stein's The Making of Americans. After Cunningham's death in 2009, she helped see to completion a multivolume CD collection of music composed to accompany many of his dances. In 2000 she bought her house in Cedar Key, and threw herself into activities there. Joined in her later years by her beloved partner, Amber Harris, Jean never ceased seeking out unusual opportunities. All who knew her will remember her infectious laugh and her eager interest in others, old and young. Jean did not want a funeral or a memorial service; she preferred a celebration. She is survived by her brother, Bill Rigg, of Melbourne, Florida, her sisters, Ginny McLaren, of Columbia, SC, and Jackie Wallen of Takoma Park, Maryland, and by numerous cousins. 1/3

HARWOOD--Lowell. 85, of Short Hills passed away on March 18, 2015. Born in Newark and raised in Jersey City, Harwood returned to Hudson County after graduating from Kent State University and serving in the United States Army during the Korean War to work in the family parking business that began in 1920. Harwood built and grew the business, breaking into the competitive New York market with a shrewd business model of choosing the right locations and charging reasonable prices. The company went public in 1969, with Harwood becoming chair of Square Industries, Inc., headquartered at 921 Bergen Avenue in Jersey City where Harwood was raised. By the time the company was sold in 1997, the family operation had grown to a $100 million business with 135 locations across the United States. During Harwood's leadership of Square Industries, the company managed parking at the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, NY, one of Harwood's proudest achievements. After selling the company, Harwood continued running Harwood Properties LLC, a private parking and property management company that continues to be managed by the Harwood family in Jersey City. Harwood was a pillar of the Jersey City business community, serving on the board of the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce, and served as the Chamber's president in 1958. In 1997, the Harwood Family purchased the site of the former State Theater and created the first, new residential development in Journal Square in more than 50 years, helping to transform the area into the pride of Jersey City. Harwood was also involved in numerous parking business associations, serving on the Board of Directors for the National Parking Association, the Metropolitan Parking Association and the New York Parking Association. A philanthropist in Jersey City and throughout his home state, Harwood was a dedicated supporter of Christ Hospital serving on the Board of Trustees, the Executive Board and the Christ Hospital Foundation Board for 40 years. While serving on the Foundation Board, Harwood donated funds to establish the Harwood Heart Center, a state-of-the-art coronary-care unit, which continues to bear Lowell's name. Harwood's philanthropy included more than 10 years of service as a Kean University Trustee and Trustee Emeritus. As Trustee, Harwood implemented numerous campus improvement projects and donated a beautiful stained-glass window that remains the centerpiece of the Kean Hall Conference Center. Harwood also founded the Kean University Gala Event in 1997, which raised more than $1.4 million over seven years for the school's scholarship fund, a cause for which Lowell was very passionate. In recognition of his dedicated service to Kean, he was named the University's "Man of the Year" at the University's sixth annual gala in 2003. The Harwood Arena at Kean University is named after Harwood in honor of his leadership and generosity for the University. The Harwoods were members of Temple Beth El in Jersey City for more than 50 years, and Lowell Harwood was a member of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC). Lowell Harwood is survived by his loving wife, Toby; his brother, Sanford; his children, Leslie and Craig; his grandchildren, Jonathan, David and Laura Ehrlich; and his nephews Brett and Scott Harwood. The funeral service will be held on Friday, March 20, 2015 at 10am at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel (973-422-0600) at 68 Old Short Hills Road in Livingston. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Kean University or the charity of your choice. 1/3

McGOVERN--Michael Harry. Renaissance man, world traveler, graduate of SUNY Albany, University Massachusetts Amherst and Princeton. Lover of French mystery novels, Star Trek, physics and Indian food. MEADE--Thomas Francis, age 80, passed peacefully on March 14 surrounded by his loving family. Tom was born on September 17, 1934 and raised in Bellerose, NY. He was the youngest of six children born to Kathryn and James Meade. Tom was a long time resident of Brookville, NY, having served as President of the Brookville Taxpayers Association, as a volunteer firefighter in the Jericho Fire Department and as a lector for 40 years at St. Paul the Apostle Church - a parish he loved and helped to build. Tom attended Manhattan College, graduating in 1956 with a B.S. He began his career at Bankers Trust Company while earning an MBA from New York University. After working on the Municipal Bond desk at Smith Barney, Tom joined Bear Stearns as a talented and spirited fixed income salesman. He loved the bond business and was a passionate mentor to many young professionals heading to Wall Street. Ultimately retiring from Bear Stearns as a Senior Managing Director, Tom earned the respect and, most importantly, the friendship of customers, colleagues and competitors. Tom loved, and was beloved by, his family and his friends. He would often regale them with stories of his shenanigans in school and stickball in the street. All who knew him were touched by his kindness, his generous spirit and his enormous heart. Tom was always an optimist and quick with an encouraging word whenever one was needed. Tom shared his time, talent and treasure with many charitable organizations. Over the years, he served as a Trustee of St. Francis College in Brooklyn, NY, and was a fundraiser for The Ronald McDonald House, The Boy Scouts of America, The Archbishop's Council for the Laity and many others. He sold thousands of boxes of Girl Scout Cookies and was the long-time "official Santa" at Bear Stearns. Tom's true love was his family. He was an amazing husband, father and grandfather. He and his loving wife Joan were married for 58 years. His three children, Paul (Bernadette), Charlie (Julie) and Regina (Anthony) and the loves of his life, his eight grandchildren, Lauren, Gregory, Courtney, Marielle, Perry, Gracie, Tommy and Xavier were adored by him. An avid reader of United States history, Tom enjoyed being surrounded by books and maps. He enjoyed classic WWII movies with his favorite treat, Junior Mints. He loved golf, always commiserating about his game with his buddies. When not on the golf course, he was often spotted with his leaf-blower, making sure the driveway was pristine. A summer barbecue, a dip in the pool, a Macanudo cigar in his hand while pushing a grandchild on a swing made a perfect day for Tom and that is how his family will always remember him. Tom was surrounded with love and laughter throughout his life and in his final days. His brilliant light will live on in our hearts forever. Please keep him in your prayers. Donations may be made in his honor to: St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, Memphis or to the charity of your choice. A Mass of Resurrection will be held at 12:30pm, Saturday, March 21 at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church, Brookville, NY. He will be interred at the Locust Valley Cemetery in Locust Valley, NY. 1/3

MINTZ--Anita Franz, On March 16, 2015. Beloved wife of Morton Mintz, beloved mother of Margaret (John Birdsall), Roberta (Harry Levine) and Daniel (Meredith Berkman), and much loved grandmother to Jules, Sophia, Emilia, Peter, Jesse, Isaac, Noa, Caleb, Avital and Yael. Born in Springfield, Ill., February 28, 1925 to the late Herman R. and Anna Levinson Franz. She attended Grinnell College and graduated from the University of Michigan. She was a writer for the Michigan Daily where she met Morton the day he returned from his WW II naval service. They married three months later, and remained happily married for 69 years. Never unkind, never prejudiced, she defined sweetness. Always thoughtful, she was an avid book reader. She will remain forever in our hearts. After a private burial service on March 18, the family is sitting Shiva in Washington D.C. and Manhattan. Contributions in Anita's memory may be made to American Jewish World Service at http://ajws.org/get--involved/ donate, or to the Anita Mintz Memorial Fund of the International Rescue Committee, Attn: Donor Services, 11th Floor, 122 East 42nd St., New York, NY 10168, https:// engage.rescue.org/donate 1/3

BARON--Leonard, loving father, grandfather, father-in-law, friend passed away peacefully on March 16 at his home in Palm Beach, FL. He was born April 23, 1919 in NYC, graduated from Columbia Grammar, UNC Chapel Hill and Harvard Business School. He served in the US Navy during WWII and was one of the first to land on Normandy Beach. He spent his career leading Royal Paper Corp of New York/New Jersey, a family owned business. He is survived by his two daughters Marcia Hershey and Lisa Schenker, her husband Gregg, four grandchildren; William, Emma, Nicholas and Olivia. Joan his beloved wife of 54 years predeceased him. He lived longer than he ever dreamed, but much shorter than his family hoped. A family service will be held graveside. 1/3

GARLAND--Dr. Paul Griffith. Griff Garland, as he was known, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his family, on March 16, 2015. He was born in Moscow, Idaho to JV and Rachel Garland on April 30, 1930. He was married to Joan Marie Bruder on August 28, 1954. He earned his B.A. from Yale University in 1952 and his law degree from Harvard in 1955. He earned his Brazilian law credentials in Sao Paulo and practiced international corporate law for 35 years, also writing three books including Doing Business in and with Brazil. During the last 20 years of his life, he worked extensively on family genealogy, and traveled the world with his wife Joan. He is survived by his wife Joan, his sons Patrick and John, his daughter and son-in-law, Cathy Garland and Michael O'Hanlon, and his grandchildren Grace and Lily. He was predeceased by his daughter Bonnie and his brother John. The family invites visitors at Edwin Bennett Funeral Home in Scarsdale, NY from 1-3 and 5-7 on Saturday, March 21. 1/3

FRESCHMAN--David Jay. Age 52, of Hockessin, DE, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, March 17, 2015, surrounded by his loved ones after losing his battle with pancreatic cancer. Born in Wilmington, DE to Rachael and Morris Freschman, he received a BS in Accounting from the University of Delaware and a MBA from Loyola University. David was a Certified Public Accountant (CPA), a Charted Global Management Accountant (CGMA) and an astonishing venture capitalist. With a mix of entrepreneurship, creativity and immense passion for the world of business, David became a veteran in the Venture Capital Industry. Some positions from his astounding resume include the founder of Delaware Innovation Fund, Early Stage East, ARC Angel Fund, Innovation Capital Advisors and FashInvest. David was a consultant for the hit television show, Shark Tank on ABC. He was also a professor and board member at LIM College where he enjoyed spreading knowledge and educating future entrepreneurs. David is survived by his wife, Robin; two children, Samara and Jared; parents, Morris and Rachael; brother, Neil; sister, Iris Harris (Ken); many nieces and nephews; and many great friends. Funeral services will be 1:00pm, Thursday, March 19, 2015 at Congregation Beth Emeth, 300 W. Lea Boulevard, Wilmington, DE 19802. Shiva will be observed 7:00pm, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings at the late residence. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in David's memory to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (www.pancan.org), Congregation Beth Emeth or a charity of your choice.

HOLMAN--Thomas Seth (born April 21, 1953 died March 16, 2015) died in Manhattan of respiratory failure. He was born in Manhattan the second son of Adele and the late Merton Holman of Teaneck, NJ. Tom as he was known had a lifelong career as an art historian, author and private art advisor. Tom earned his bachelor's degree at Macalester College '76 and his master's degree from the University of Chicago '78 as well as studying at Oxford University and University of Vienna. During the past 40 years he served as Chief Curator at the Norton Museum of Art, Curator of Collections at the Minnesota Museum of American Art, Associate Director at Forum Gallery, and Executive Director at the Hudson River Museum, Albany Museum of Art, and Marietta/Cobb Museum of Art. He assembled an extensive 42-year collection of Grand Tour souvenirs that were recently auctioned at the Skinners Gallery in Boston. Tom is survived by his mother Adele Holman of Teaneck, NJ, brother Bert Holman and sister-in-law Randy Sue Foster of Waban, MA and nieces Mollie Jo of New York City and Ella of Washington, DC. Graveside service will be private on Friday. The family will be receiving family and friends on Sunday from 1 to 4pm, at 580 Rutland Avenue Teaneck, NJ 1/3

PITLER--Robert M. It is with profound sadness that we announce the passing of Robert M. Pitler, adored husband, father, brother, uncle, friend and mentor. Born in the Bronx in 1941, Bob stayed true to his roots (a Yankee fan) through a lifetime of accomplishments. He was a distinguished Professor of Law at Brooklyn Law School, his alma mata, for more than 25 years, where he taught with a passion for his profession and a desire to infuse his love of the law to his many students. He was a man of extraordinary integrity. Prior to teaching at Brooklyn Law School, he served the public with distinction for thirteen years as an Assistant District Attorney in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, heading the Appeals Bureau and the Investigations Division. Bob previously taught law at Syracuse University Law School, and the University of Colorado Law School. He served as Senior Law Clerk to Chief Judge Charles Brietel of the New York State Court of Appeals, and was also the Chairman of the New York State Law Revision Commission. Bob will be sorely missed by his family, his many friends, and by the students he inspired over the years. There will be a memorial tribute to Bob at Brooklyn Law School open to all on April 27th, in the late afternoon. 1/3

NEWMARK--Gladys, born August 26, 1935, passed away on Thursday, March 19, 2015. Survived by son Marc and Andree Frost, and their children Lauren and Michael. Son, Glenn Newmark and family. Stepdaughter Deborah Newmark and Leonid Turchinsky and their daughter Alex. Sister Alice and Paul Stahl. Services at "The Riverside" at 180 West 76th Street NYC on Sunday March 22nd at 11:30am. 1/3

EDDY--Jane Lee J. The Taconic Foundation Trustees who served for several decades with the Foundation's devoted and wonderful Executive Director, Jane Lee Eddy, mourn her recent passing and extend deep condolences to her three children. 1/3
GANS--Larry: My mentor, my partner, my uncle, my best friend. I lost all four with your passing. Miss you already. Say hi to Dad. Love, Andy 1/3

SLATER--Bruce, of Chilmark, MA died in Cambridge on January 27th, a few weeks short of his 82nd birthday. His loving wife Marcy predeceased him in 2008 much to his surprise and deep sorrow. He is survived by two children and a granddaughter. A graduate of the Wharton School he earned an MBA at NYU. After serving in the US army in Japan he founded a development business building homes, apartment houses and shopping centers. He became committed to Martha's Vineyard enjoying sailing and involvement in local community organizations for over 30 years. He has been interred there next to his beloved Marcy. Donations in his memory can be made to Felix Neck Wildlife Sanctuary, P.O. Box 494, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568 or Sail Martha's Vineyard, PO Box 1998, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568. Mike, Bob and Howard 1/3

CYPRUS--Eleanor Caviris. Eleanor Caviris Cyprus dies at age 84. Born in Manhattan, NY. Resident of Manhasset, NY; Palm Beach, Florida and Vouliagmeni, Greece Eleanor Cyprus, beloved wife of Evans Cyprus, passed away on Wednesday, March 18th, 2015. She is survived by her three children and their spouses - Nicholas and Oriana Cyprus, Irene and Dimitri Dellis, Marguerite and Michael Loucas. She was the beloved grandmother to Sophia, Margot, Elena, Evans, Gregory, Jack, Isabella, Ava and Theodore. She is also survived by her sister, Effie Hoimes, and sister-in-laws Florence Johnnidis, Parie Talas and Evangelia Cyprus. She was an aunt to many nieces and nephews and family whom she adored, and a good friend to many. She would wish to be remembered as a person who loved her family and friends more than anything; a woman with a great sense of humor and a positive attitude; a philanthropist, and someone who loved to throw a great party and to explore the world. Funeral Arrangements: Wake, Sunday, March 22, 2015, 3-8pm, The Archangel Michael Church, 100 Fairway Drive, Port Washington, NY 11050. Funeral Monday, March 23, 2015, 11:00am, The Archangel Michael Church. Interment: Flushing Cemetery. In Lieu of Flowers donations in her memory to: Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation LIAF, 5 Channel Drive, Port Washington, NY 11050. 1/3

GANS--Laurence. The officers, directors and employees of New York Design Center, Inc. deeply mourn the passing of our friend and fellow director, Larry Gans. We will miss his counsel, wit and overall knowledge of the furniture Industry. He will be fondly remembered. James P. Druckman, President; Daniel M. Farr, Managing Director; Harold L. Gordon, Vice-President/Treasurer 1/3
MENKES--Barbara (31/14) This was not the plan/m, honeybunny. And you were right... the same values. I miss you more than I ever thought pos- sible. Love Always, Cyn 1/3

JAWOROWSKA--Wladzia (nee Bazanowska) died peacefully on March 15, 2015. Beloved wife of Henry Jaworowski (deceased). She was the loving sister to Zygmunt (deceased) and Alfreda (Chomowicz) Bazanowski, devoted aunt to Anne Bazanowski and Robert and Christine (Bazanowski) Scaffidi, and adoring great-aunt to Larissa and Sarina Scaffidi. Born in 1929 in Brooklyn, NY, to Kazimierz and Bronislawa (Gruszecka), Wladzia was a graduate of Hunter College. Although she worked in an office setting for most of her career, her true passion was in teaching, sharing and promoting traditional Polish dance and culture. "Miss Wanda" taught many generations of Polish dancers at schools which included: St. John Kanty Polish School, East New York, Educational Council, Polish Schools, New York City, Maria Konopnicka Polish School, "Krakowianki" - Our Lady of Consolation School, Williamsburg (NY), "Krakowianki" - St. Stanislaus School, New Haven (CT), Henryk Sienkiewicz Polish School, South Brooklyn (NY), Matusz Polish Dance Circle, "Krakowianki i Gorale" - St. Stanislaus Kostka Parish, "Krakowianki" - SS. CyriI and Methodius School, Brooklyn (NY). Together with her beloved husband Henry, Wladzia taught and preserved authentic Polish dance with the reknowned Matusz Polish Dance Circle. The Matusz dancers appeared on nationwide television, performed at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, both World Fairs, and numerous international folk festivals and Kosciuszko Foundation Balls. Wladzia was also a dedicated member of the Marie Sklodowska Curie Professional Women's Association and the Pro Arte League of the Kosciuszko Foundation, having served as its President. Wladzia was an amazing person who shaped and gave direction to all the dancers she met. She held strong in her beliefs and was a longtime volunteer for both Mayors Rudolph Giuliani and Michael Bloomberg. Her passion for life and her positive outlook, as further evidenced by her dedication to personal fitness and worldwide cruising, are her legacy. She will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday March 21st at 10:00 a.m. at St. Stanislaus Kostka Church, Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Contributions may be made in her memory to Calvary Hospital (www.calvaryhospital.org) or The Kosciuszko Foundation Scholarship Fund (www.thekf.org). 1

SHEA--Joan M.,in New York City on March 17, 2015. Born Jerome, AZ in 1917. Arrived in NYC in 1940 as a professional actress in radio, TV and theatre. Dedicated volunteer as pianist-singer-entertainer at Nursing Homes. Survived by much loved nieces and nephews. Visiting hours at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Sunday March 22 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:30am at the Holy Family Chapel at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to "City Meals-on-Wheels" 355 Lex Ave., NYC. 1/3

WEINER--Gina Ingoglia. The Board and staff of Theatre Development Fund extend their heartfelt sympathy to our chairman, Earl D. Weiner and his family on the loss of their beloved Gina. Her support and encouragement of TDF was reflective of the support and encouragement she provided so many New York City institutions. Victoria Bailey, Executive Director 1/3

GOLDMAN--Jerome, passed peacefully at home on March 19th, 2015. Jerry was a lifelong, proud New Yorker. Born, raised and educated in Brooklyn, he eventually settled in Manhattan. A talented designer and writer, he worked at various jobs from advertising to comedy writing, before starting a business with his brother, Marvin. Penn-Plax became one of the most respected family-run pet product manufacturers in the country. Aside from his achievements, he was unfailingly kind, intelligent, warm, interested in life and art in equal measure. A wonderful father to his daughter Dina and loving grandfather to Rafael, he was also an inspiringly optimistic man, even when faced with illness. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Service Sunday, March 22, 2015, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam. 1/3

HARWOOD--Lowell. A dear friend and business associate. A giant in the parking industry, well known for his foresight. Noted for his warmth and good humor. Our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Toby, their children, Leslie and Craig, and their grandchildren. Margy and Elliot Brownstein 1/3

MOULTON--Paul Richard, born November 7, 1971, died March 19, 2015 from pneumonia. Beloved son of Harriet Hayflick Moulton and the late A. Conant Moulton. Brother of Merion Estes, Roger Conant Moulton, Pamela Moulton, John Moulton, and Emily Elizabeth Moulton. Paul afflicted at birth with hydrocephalus, was nurtured at home for 43 years by his loyal mother who never gave up. RIP Paul. Memorial service on Sunday, March 22, 2015, at 1:30pm will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. 81st and Madison. 1/3
KETIVE--Samuel. We can't believe it's been 1 year without you. There is still a hole in our hearts. We will miss and love you forever. Your Girls 1/3

DUBOWY--Michele. The Children's Aid Society mourns the passing of Michele Dubowy, a fierce advocate for the children of New York City and a highly respected social worker within the child welfare community. She retired in 2014 after nearly three decades at Children's Aid, most recently as the Deputy Director of the Child Welfare and Family Services Division, supporting thousands of children and improving countless lives. Our hearts go out to her family, which asks that donations be made to the American Cancer Society. Phoebe C. Boyer, President and CEO. 1/3

GANS--Larry: Died March 20th after a long illness. Survived by his two daughters Lynne and Julie, stepdaughter Leslie and stepson Michael, four grandchildren. Funeral Sunday at Gutterman Warheit, Boca Raton at 10:45am. Burial Tuesday at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY at 11am. Contributions can be made to American Cancer Society. 1/3

KARP--Jerome (Jerry), beloved husband, father and grandfather passed away at the age of 87 on March 20 peacefully at his home.
