EHRLICH--Edna E. (nee Gottesman), economist, age 96, died March 11, 2015, at a hospital near her Manhattan home. Edna started her 43 - year career with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1944 and became the second woman ever to serve as Research Officer, Senior Economist and International Advisor. Upon her retirement in 1987, she became an international consultant on Asian banking and financial systems and founded a nonprofit to support performances of contemporary Asian classical music. She published many articles in professional journals and traveled extensively, particularly in Asia, where she spoke at numerous conferences. Edna received a BA cum laude from Brooklyn College in 1943, a MA in economics from Columbia University in 1945 and a PhD in economics from the New School for Social Research in 1960. She is survived by her sister, Shirley Geller of Margate, Florida, seven nieces and nephews, and their children. Her husband, economist Otto H. Ehrlich, died in 1979. There will be a memorial service on April 18th from 4-7pm at her home. For information contact Phyllis Gottesman (email: prg1900@gmail.com). 1/3

GILL--Corita Ann, was passionate about volunteering and always had an ear for a friend, died on March 1, 2015 in Manhattan. She was 86. Corita was a true New Yorker, and lived on the Upper East Side her entire life. She attended the Convent of the Sacred Heart and Manhattanville College. Corita had a 30 year career at IBM; volunteered as a docent at The Met, and at Mary Manning Walsh. Her good humor and loving nature will be greatly missed by her family, extended family, and her friends. Corita was the epitome of grace, strength and elegance; to know her was a blessing. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Joseph's Church on E 87 Street in Yorkville on Saturday, March 28 at 9:30am. 1/3

ISKO--Irving D. Passed away peacefully at his home on March 20, 2015 at the age of 87. He was the loving father of Laura, Steven and Susan and devoted grandfather of Julia and Alison. Irving was born November 26, 1927 in NYC. He graduated from Townsend Harris, Cornell University and Harvard Law School. After starting his career at the Berliner Law Firm, he worked at Philipp Brothers, then Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals and finished his career as President and Chief Executive Officer of Engelhard Corporation. Services will be held at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ ON Sunday, March 22, 2015 at 11:30 AM. For information contact Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, (973) 422-0600. 1/3

MACK--Stephen M. of Houston, TX, and New York, on March 19, 2015, after a long but valiant struggle. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Kate Mack Kozak and her husband Kevin, of Austin, TX, and "number one son", Christopher. Cherished son of Ethel and the late Ivan A. Dear brother of Kevin, Brian, Eileen Parascandola and the late Kathleen Borzello, and Leslie Marie Mack. Family will receive friends Thursday, March 26 from 3PM, with prayer service beginning at 7PM at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st Street, with Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 11 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola, R.C. Church, Park Ave. at 84th St. A giant of American Funeral Service, an extraordinary mentor and leader, Steve will be remembered for inspiring others with his commitment to integrity and excellence. As Steve recently wrote, "Let's agree to keep moving forward. Always be moving forward." 1/3

HELLERMAN--Marvin L. Passed away on March 17, 2015 at the age of 87. He was the beloved husband of Claire, loving father of Jeffrey and Lee. Devoted grandfather of Cameron, Michael and Matthew. He had a successful career in the toy industry including Ideal Toy. Founder of Tara Toy and founder of MarvLee Toy. He also served on the board at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck and coordinated the annual toy industry dinner on behalf of Brandeis University. Services will be held at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck on Friday March 20, 2015 at 11:30am, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. For information contact Riverside Nassau North Chapels, (516) 487-9600.

INGOGLIA WEINER--GINA The Acting Company mourns the loss of our dear friend. As our Education Chair, Gina exhibited her deep concern for students who, without our programs, would have no access to theater arts. Her generosity ensured we reached as many as possible. We send our heartfelt sympathy to Earl, Melissa and Barr. Margot Harley, Producer Edgar Lansbury, Chairman Emeritus

GAINOR--Victor T.,Jr. of Forest Hills - March 19, 2015. He was 79. Born and raised in NYC, he graduated from Sacred Heart HS and attended Iona College before becoming a United States Marine. A successful career in financial services allowed time for other meaningful pursuits. A strong supporter of the armed services, he was past president of the NY Council of the Navy League, a National Director of the Navy League of the United States, and past Commander of American Legion Post 754 in NYC. A recipient of civilian honors and service awards from the US Marine Corps and the US Coast Guard, for many years he was delighted to host events for service members visiting NYC during Fleet Week. For nearly 40 years he was a member of the New York Athletic Club, where he served on the Board of Governors and as Treasurer. He also served on the Board of the Xavier Society for the Blind. He is survived by his wife of 55 years Pat, his children Vic, Debby, Sue and Tim, his daughter-in-law Toni and son-in-law Scott, his grandchildren, Catie, Victor, Sean, Gabriella and Connor, and his sister Florence. A gregarious sort, he will be remembered for his warm smile and quick wit, his loyalty to family and friends and his kindness to many. He will be greatly missed. Semper Fi! 1/3

HERZBERG--Melvin, died on March 15, aged 95, of natural causes, at the home in Brooklyn he shared with his beloved companion of 16 years, Sally Brody, An inveterate New Yorker, he is survived by Sally; his three sons, Peter, Andrew and Kenneth; and their families, which include four granddaughters and one great-granddaughter. His wife, Joan, with whom he had a long and happy marriage, pre-deceased him in 1990. Mel was an avid lover of music, especially opera and, earlier in his life, tennis. He was an unrepentant liberal who loved discussing and reading about politics. In later life, with Sally's encouragement, he became a "country boy" as well, helping to grow a flourishing garden at their lovely country home in the Hudson Valley. Mel was a graduate of NYU and, during the Second World War, served in the Air Force. From the late 1950s until 1980, Mel was the founder and CEO of Boulevard Keystone Business Machines, in Queens, New York, an import-export and servicing company for office machines. Thereafter, he undertook several real estate and securities ventures. His compassion, his intellect, interest in world affairs, humor and optimistic, gentle spirit will be remembered and celebrated by the many friends and family who knew and loved him. Plans are being finalized for a memorial services which will be held in Brooklyn. 1/3

MILROD--David. Beloved husband of Frances, father of Barbara, grandfather of James, father-in-law of John, brother of Sam (and Joyce). Born October 2, 1924 in Toronto, Canada, died peacefully Saturday, March 21, 2015 in New York City from cancer. Sweet, scholarly, courteous, thoughtful, he survived childhood empyema to become a doctor, a leading psychoanalytic scholar, and proponent of neuropsychoanalysis at The New York Psychoanalytic Institute. During internship in St. Louis, he met Frances, love of his life; they were married more than 66 years. Service at The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam March 24 at 12:45 pm. Family will receive visitors March 25 7-9:30 pm at 151 West 86th Street, Apt. 2C. 1/3

BOHEN--Frederick M. After a distinguished career in university administration and public service, Frederick Martin Bohen died peacefully at home in Manhattan on March 15, succumbing to progressive lung failure at age 77. In both his personal and professional life, he was admired for his dedication, leadership, kindness and gentlemanly qualities. Before retiring in 2005, Bohen served as Executive VP and COO at Rockefeller University in New York City. His career in academic administration began at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School in 1964. Public service took him to Washington, where he was on the White House domestic policy staff in the Johnson administration, and in the Carter administration at HEW and HHS. In the 1970s he twice ran as a Democratic candidate for Congress in New Jersey. Bohen resumed academic administration in the early 1980s, first at the University of Minnesota, then at Brown University, and finally at Rockefeller in 1990. Between stints in government and academia, he worked in public television and philanthropy at WNET and the Ford Foundation. He served on various corporate and charitable boards, including: Apache Oil Company; Sallie Mae; the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center; the American Council of Learned Societies; the Polish American Freedom Foundation; and the TEAK Fellowship. Bohen grew up in Ridgewood, NJ, son of Arthur and Lillian Bohen, and brother of Helen B. O'Bannon. He attended Harvard College on an NROTC scholarship, graduating in 1959. After his naval service, he received his Master's in Public Affairs from the Woodrow Wilson School in 1966. He is survived by his three daughters, Shawn Jacqueline Bohen, Kim Penelope Bohen and Courtney Lisa Bohen, and eight grandchildren. He was formerly married to Halcyone Harger Bohen of Washington, D.C. Gifts may be made in his memory to the TEAK Fellowship, which helps talented New York City students from low-income families gain admission to top high schools and colleges. He was a long-time Trustee at TEAK. teakfellowship.org. 1/3

GANS--Larry: Died March 20th after a long illness. Survived by his two daughters Lynne and Julie, stepdaughter Leslie and stepson Michael, four grandchildren. Funeral Sunday at Gutterman Warheit, Boca Raton at 10:45am. Burial Tuesday at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY at 11am. Contributions can be made to American Cancer Society. 1/3
GANS--Larry: It's been a long journey. May you rest in peace. Mona and Felix 1/3

HARWOOD--Lowell. A dear friend and business associate. A giant in the parking industry, well known for his foresight. Noted for his warmth and good humor. Our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Toby, their children, Leslie and Craig, and their grandchildren. Margy and Elliot Brownstein 1/3

HOCKERT--Lorance. The Riverdale Nature Preservancy Board of Directors mourns the passing of long time Board member Lorance Hockert. His service to the community was extraordinary. Our thoughts go out to his family. 1/3

MANDELKER--Sam, on March 16 at age 90. From the Lower East Side to Boca Raton; from New Guinea to his coffee shop to Kimco Realty, Sam saw and did it all with honor and class. He leaves behind a legacy of good deeds and love of family and friends. He is predeceased by his wives Sally Mandelker and Anita Kramer. He was a devoted father to Howard, Donna (Bruce) Abend and Robin (Robert) Spielman, and an extraordinary Poppi to Matthew (Sara) Abend, Max (Julianne) Abend, Ben (Jamie) Spielman, Michele (Ross) Gabel, Stacey Spielman and Allison Spielman, and five great- grandchildren. He was a devoted son and brother, deeply caring for those less fortunate, and a man of high moral standards. He was truly a benevolent and charitable soul. The family requests that donations be made to the Sam Mandelker College Connection at B'nai Torah Congregation, 6261 SE 18th St, Boca Raton, FL 33433. 1/3

McCORMACK--Joy Karn. A pioneer in the early childhood all day school industry and founder of The Children's All Day School and Joy McCormack's All Day Nursery in New York City, died peacefully at home on March 6, 2015. Long time resident of New York City and Vero Beach, FL. She leaves behind her beloved daughters Lisa Crawford (Philip) and Julia McCormack and grandchildren John and Kingsley Crawford. Service to be held at a future date. Services are by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book is available at www. strunkfuneralhome.com. 1/3

SELIG--Marion, passed away peacefully in the evening of March 16, 2015 at home surrounded by her two children and the dedicated people who have affectionately assisted her during the last weeks of her life. My whole family is shattered by her departure since my friendship was a sisterhood going back over 50 years to the time in Paris as students and fun loving admirers of French culture and continued through 30 years of life in the US. I always admired her unconditional loyalty to her friends, her appreciation of art and her love to her two children in their extended worlds. My daughters' families including my three grandchildren will always remember her numerous gestures of kindness, her thoughtful gifts and heart warming presence throughout the years. I will miss her terribly because she guided me through difficult days of illness and emotional suffering with balance and optimism. May God give her peace after a full life of kindness and gentility of spirit. Anna Bulgari and Family 1/3
PILMAR--Howard. 19 years have gone by since your brutal murder. We pray for justice. Dad and Carol 1/3

PFEIFER--Timothy Scott. LARAGH, John H. MD--Died on March 20, 2015. Born in Yonkers, NY; he graduated from Cornell University Medical College and then trained in medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons where he became a world renowned clinician-scientist. By observing his patients, indentifying key medical questions, and applying scientific rigor, he showed that renin, a kidney hormone, can cause human hypertension, and that blocking it can control high blood pressure. This led to the development of two new hypertensive drug classes, angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers. These drugs revolutionized the treatment of hypertension, diabetes, kidney disease and cardiovascular disease. His discoveries led to a cover story in Time magazine in 1975. John was founding President of the American Society of Hypertension. He crossed the traditional boundaries of medicine as Chief of Nephrology at Columbia P&S, then Chief of Cardiology at Weill Cornell Medical College. He was a generous mentor - warm hearted with boyish charm who liked to sing and whistle around these prestigious institutions. He inspired generations of clinician-scientists to become leaders world wide. His patients became his friends, and they supported his research and encouraged his passion for golf. This visionary, yet humble man brought the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular disease into the 21st century, thereby improving innumerable lives. Dr. Laragh was 90 years old. He was predeceased by his mother Grace Coyne and father Henry Laragh. He is survived by his wife and collaborator Dr. Jean Sealey, his sons John and Robert, daughter-in-law Marci and granddaughter Eliana. Contributions in his name can be made to Doctors Without Borders and The Salvation Army. 1/3

She loved reading and was faithful to the local libraries and NY Times until her death. She worked in Human Resources in the Garment district for many years and at Temple Beth-El in North Bergen, NJ. Natalie valued friends and family. She and her two sisters were nearly inseparable throughout their lives. She treasured"simchas" and sharing meals. She never missed sending a personal, handwritten card (with generous gifts enclosed) for every occasion. She cherished her independence, which she maintained until after her 90th Birthday. She is survived by her two children, Iris Berke and Ira Polk, and their families including grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The family extends thanks to her many friends who helped her maintain her independence and the Harborage Nursing Home for her wonderful care. In memory of Natalie, read a book, and make a contribution to your local library. 1/3

BOHEN--Frederick M. The Rockefeller University community is tremendously saddened by the loss of our beloved friend Fred Bohen, a seasoned leader in academia and government who served the University as executive vice president for 13 years, beginning in 1990. Fred made immeasurable contributions to the University during a remarkable period now recognized as a scientific renaissance at Rockefeller. A key steward of the University, he was widely respected for his exceptional financial acumen and the managerial brilliance with which he oversaw Rockefeller's operations. Fred was instrumental in creating an environment in which gifted scientists--and great science --can truly flourish. His leadership enabled Rockefeller to achieve financial stability, develop innovative research programs, modernize its infrastructure, and build for the future. The many achievements realized under Fred's watch include the completion of the Rockefeller Research Building and the recruitment or promotion of 50 heads of laboratory--a large portion of our faculty today. In 2006, Fred received the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service--the University's highest non-scientific honor. Fred was a man of great warmth and compassion, with an extraordinary gift for friendship. We feel enormously grateful that he remained a part of our extended campus family until his death, and we will miss him very much. We send our heartfelt sympathy to Fred's three daughters, Shawn, Kim, and Courtney, and to his entire family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Paul Nurse and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti Thomas Sakmar, Professor 1/3

An accomplished teacher and lecturer, community activist and scholar of great integrity, Sandy was born on October 22, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY. PITLER--Robert M. It is with profound sadness that we announce the passing of Robert M. Pitler, adored husband, father, brother, uncle, friend and mentor. Born in the Bronx in 1941, Bob stayed true to his roots (a Yankee fan) through a lifetime of accomplishments. He was a distinguished Professor of Law at Brooklyn Law School, his alma mata, for more than 25 years, where he taught with a passion for his profession and a desire to infuse his love of the law to his many students. He was a man of extraordinary integrity. Prior to teaching at Brooklyn Law School, he served the public with distinction for thirteen years as an Assistant District Attorney in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, heading the Appeals Bureau and the Investigations Division. Bob previously taught law at Syracuse University Law School, and the University of Colorado Law School. He served as Senior Law Clerk to Chief Judge Charles Brietel of the New York State Court of Appeals, and was also the Chairman of the New York State Law Revision Commission. Bob will be sorely missed by his family, his many friends, and by the students he inspired over the years. There will be a memorial tribute to Bob at Brooklyn Law School open to all on April 27th, in the late afternoon. 1/3

AVERY--John Edwin, Jr. Of Palm Beach, FL, died Sunday March 15, 2015, in West Palm Beach. He was 86. Born and raised in Connecticut, he was son of John E. Avery Sr. and Vera Gallagher Avery. After serving in the Army, he earned his Bachelor's degree at Yale University in 1952. He married Antonia Ariani and they raised four children during 32 years of marriage. In 1984 he married Caron Girard Cox, who predeceased him in 2012. Mr. Avery spent his career in international business. In Sao Paolo, Brazil, he was employed with J.T. Baker Chemical Company. He joined Johnson & Johnson in 1962 as CEO of the J&J subsidiary in Manila, Philippines. While there he expanded the company's global footprint by opening new Southeast Asian markets. As a senior executive with J&J, he rose to Company Group Chairman of all operations in Latin America and the Caribbean. He also acted as a special international Advisor to the Chairman. Upon retiring from J&J, Mr. Avery served as Chairman of the Americas Society/Council of the Americas in New York City from 1993-1996. Both organizations were instrumental in promoting the North American Free Trade Agreement during his leadership. He was Chairman of AusAm Biotechnologies, Inc., and at various times served as a Director of R.P. Scherer Corp., Catalent Pharma Solutions, Inc., AAIPharma Inc., and the Argentine- American Chamber of Commerce. He continued as an Honorary Director of the Americas Society/Council of the Americas, and he was a member of the Dean's Council of the Yale University School of Medicine. Mr. Avery was a member of The Society of The Cincinnati, the Everglades Club of Palm Beach, the Union Club of New York City, and the Madison Beach Club in Madison, Connecticut. Mr. Avery will be remembered by his family and many friends for his love of life, integrity, and unfailing generosity. He is survived by his four children, John E. Avery III, Alicia M. Avery, Paul B. Avery, and Andrea Avery Renault, as well as his step-daughter Jenner Girard Beck; he had four grandchildren; he is also survived by his brother George A. Avery and sister Patricia A. Avery. His Funeral Mass was celebrated at St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach. Memorial contributions may be made to Doctors Without Borders or American Kidney Fund. Funeral services are entrusted to Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL. www.QuattlebaumFH.com. 1/3

BOGDONOFF--Morton. Morton David Bogdonoff, a professor of medicine at Weill Cornell Medical School for forty years, died on Sunday, March 1st in Calvary Hospice, his family at his side. He had been a patient at New York Hospital for the previous month. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Mary, and her sons Robert Welt of China, and Frederick Welt of Utah. His children by his previous marriage, Reid, Ladd, Jesse, and a daughter Drue, all reside in California. Born in Brooklyn on December 8, 1925, the son of Myron and Minna Bogdonoff, he was a graduate of Erasmus Hall, and a student at Cornell University in Ithaca. He graduated from Cornell University Medical School in the accelerated medical school program in 1948. He was a resident at Cornell Medical School until 1950 when he went to Baltimore as a senior resident at the National Heart Institute. He spent his remaining residency years at Duke University Medical School where he was Chief Resident in 1954-55, and professor of medicine in the Division of Endocrinology and Director of the Division of Behavioral Medicine until 1970 when he became Chairman of the Department of Medicine at Abraham Lincoln School of Medicine of the Illinois School of Medicine in Chicago. In 1975 he returned to his alma mater, Cornell Medical School. From 1977-78 he was a fellow at the Center for the Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford in Palo Alto. He was editor of the journal Archives of Internal Medicine from 1967-1976. During his years at Cornell he was the director of the Living at Home Program with the Commonwealth Fund and the Pew Memorial Trust Consortium as well as co chief of the Geriatric Division. For many years he was tutor to the third year students at Cornell and attending physician at New York Hospital. There will be a memorial service in the near future. 1/3

KATZ--Edward C. Beloved husband of Candace Leeds, died on March 12, after a prolonged battle with Parkinson's disease. Ed had a distinguished career in the financial industry, designing and managing investment strategies for private and institutional investors. Before retiring to pursue a wide range of personal interests, he was a partner at Sanford C. Bernstein (now AllianceBernstein). Prior to that he rose to President of J & H Equity Corporation, the investment advisory unit of Johnson & Higgins, which was one of the largest insurance companies in the world before it was sold to Marsh & Mclennan. Ed served on the adjunct faculty of NYU, and the editorial board of the Journal of Compensation and Benefits. He received his AB degree, magna cum laude, from Rutgers University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Ed was revered by his colleagues and clients throughout his career. After retiring, he continued to provide voluntary financial counseling to non-profit organizations such as Citymeals-on- Wheels. He was devoted to his wife of 18 years, Candace; and his family, particularly his late brother Marty, his sister and brother-in-law, Meri and Tom Pollak and the entire Pollak and Friedman families. Also, he will be missed by his friends who loved him and will miss his wit, his warmth and caring, and his always sage advice. Donations in his name can be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, NYC, NY 10018 (www. Pdf.org) A memorial celebration of his life will be held in late April. 1/3

CLARK--Jim. Legendary Builder of Modern Washington. Alfred James "Jim" Clark, legendary builder of modern Washington, DC, and Chairman of the Board of Clark Enterprises, Inc., died March 20, 2015. Clark Construction Group, the company he led for decades, is one of the largest privately-held construction firms in the United States. Clark Construction transformed the character and vistas of the Washington area. The company's achievements include: 28 Metro stations, the World Bank headquarters, Verizon Center, the National Museum of the American Indian, FedExField, the United States Institute of Peace, Nationals Park, Sidney Harman Hall, Arena Stage, CityCenterDC, the United States Coast Guard Headquarters, the American Red Cross Headquarters building, and Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. Clark Construction opened its first regional office in Atlanta in 1970, followed by seven more offices over the next four decades, including locations in Chicago, Costa Mesa, Houston, San Antonio, San Francisco, San Diego, Seattle, and Tampa. Clark buildings include the Central Terminal at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, the Ronald Reagan State Office Building in L.A., and PETCO Park in San Diego. The company also developed convention centers in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, and Nashville. Its projects outside the Washington area include highways and bridges, libraries, performing arts centers, healthcare facilities, and the tallest building on the West Coast. Jim Clark's personal values of honesty, integrity, and a dedication to quality helped grow Clark Construction into a national company with $4.5 billion in annual revenue. His legacy includes a reputation for fair dealing, beginning multi-million dollar projects without a written contract and leading the industry in efforts to recruit and train minorities and women for jobs in the growing construction sector. His commitment to employee safety was uncompromising. While the construction company undertakes the most challenging projects, it remains an industry leader in job site safety. Jim Clark had a passion for education. He was among the largest donors to his alma mater, the University of Maryland, where the engineering school bears his name. He endowed the deanship at Johns Hopkins University's engineering school in the name of his mentor, Benjamin Rome and made a multi-year commitment to George Washington University to create the A. James Clark Engineering Scholars program, to recruit and train engineering leaders. His generosity extended beyond education into areas of homelessness, addiction, and to a variety of organizations servicing those in need. Jim Clark and his companies have consistently been recognized as some of the Washington region's most philanthropic. His passionate commitment to service in his community is embedded in the culture of his company. Jim Clark was often sought out for his wisdom and advice. He served on the Board of Directors of Lockheed Martin, Pepco, Carr America and GEICO. And, when relaxing, he turned to the outdoors to pursue his love of fishing, hunting and golf with family and friends. Born in Richmond, VA in 1927, Jim Clark moved to the Washington, DC area with his family when he was six years old. He attended Bethesda-Chevy Chase High School and graduated from Devitt Preparatory School in Washington, D.C. He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in engineering from the University of Maryland. Jim Clark's career began in 1950 when he was hired by The George Hyman Construction Company. He became the company's general manager in the early 1960s. Under his leadership, George Hyman Construction gained renown as an innovator called on to execute cutting-edge projects. It was among the first companies to use the now iconic tower crane. Clark was named President and Chief Executive Officer of Hyman in 1969. He formed a second construction firm, Omni Construction, in 1977. In 1996, the George Hyman Company and Omni Construction merged to become Clark Construction. These investments and others are managed by Clark Enterprises, a holding company founded in 1972. The love and support of his life was his wife of 64 years, Alice Bratton Clark. The couple met in high school and married in 1950 at the Bethesda Presbyterian Church. Their lifetime of devotion to each other was evident to all who knew them and an inspiration to their children and grandchildren. Jim Clark is predeceased by his parents, Woodruff and Salley Wray Clark, and sister, Jeanne Curren, and is survived by his wife, Alice Bratton Clark; two sons, Paul Clark and wife Carol Parrish, of Mill River, Massachusetts and A. James Clark, Jr. (Brad) of Bethesda, Maryland; a daughter, Courtney Clark Pastrick and her husband R. Scott Pastrick, also of Bethesda, Maryland; and ten grandchildren. Known as "Grandaddy" or"Grand", his happiest times were when all ten were visiting. A memorial service is planned for the Washington National Cathedral on Wednesday, April 8, 2015 at 10:00 a.m. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in Jim Clark's honor to A. James Clark Scholarship at the University of Maryland, 3207 Kim Engineering Building, College Park, MD 20742. 1/3

CONESE--Eugene P. Sr.,It is with profound grief that we write about the passing of Mr. Eugene P. Conese, Sr., loving husband, adoring father, devoted son, brother a warm and giving friend that was willing to share his insights, advice and wisdom. Gene's life was one of dedication and love, and he positively impacted the lives of countless people during his life. There are no words to describe the enormous void he will leave behind in his family, his community, and his extensive circle of friends and associates. Gene began his new journey on Thursday, March 19th, 2015, peacefully in his sleep. He will be remembered for his great life stories which he wrote in his memoir, Making Memories - The Story of my Life. His dedication to his family ensured a strong bond between all generations. His legacy is his defining characteristics of integrity, loyalty and generosity. He leaves behind his wife of 60 years, Anna May, and his two daughters and two sons and their spouses, Deborah and Jim Eagan, Susan and Peter Metzger, Eugene and Marianne Conese, Jr., Mark and Cynthia Conese; his ten grandchildren and their spouses, Amanda (Metzger) and Matt DeSocio, Melissa (Metzger) and Steve Finkelstein, Jeffrey Metzger, Kendall Eagan, Meredith Eagan, Conor Eagan, Caroline Conese, Jaqueline (Conese) and Matt Johnson, Christine Conese, Katherine Conese; and two great grandchildren, Ella and Jordan DeSocio. He is also survived by his sister Mary Bertoncini, brother-in-law, Renny Bertoncini, his sister Anita Healy, his sister-in-law, Nancy Hermann, seven nieces and nephews and nine great nieces and nephews. His steadfast commitment to his family and those he loved made him a role model to everyone. Gene was born in Eastchester, NY on August 1st, 1929 the son of Frances and Frank Conese. He graduated from Iona College in 1951 with a Bachelor of Business Administration degree. In 1954, after serving in the Korean War, he earned his MBA from NYU. In 1976 he received an honorary Beta Gamma Sigma Award from St. John's University. In 1977, a speech Mr. Conese gave as a panelist with investment bankers to New York business leaders was published in Vital Speeches of the Day. In 1992, in recognition of Mr. Coneses Outstanding Achievement as an Entrepreneur, he was awarded the Iona College Alumni Association's Brother Arthur A. Loftus Award. He has served with distinction and commitment as a member of the board of trustees and contributing generously to both the Vision into Reality and Visions of Excellence capital campaigns. In 2001, Iona conferred on Mr. Conese the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. In recognition of Mr. Conese's service and contributions to Iona College over the years, in 2008 its principal student dormitory was named after him and is now and forever known as Conese Hall. Eugene P. Conese, Sr. was the founder, Chairman of the Board of Directors and Chief Executive Officer of Greenwich Air Services, Inc. until its sale to General Electric in 1997. Under Gene's leadership it became the world's largest independent jet engine overhaul and rebuilding service company as well as one of the world's largest business and regional aircraft ground maintenance, parts and engine repair companies. It had offices in North America, Europe, Asia and the Middle East, with plants throughout the U.S. and Europe and employed over 10,000 people at the time of the sale to General Electric. Mr. Conese was the winner of the prestigious Wright Brothers Memorial Award (1996) from the Greater Miami Aviation Association. In 1997, Greenwich Air Services, under Mr. Conese's leadership, was awarded the Emerging Company Award by the South Florida Chapter of the Association for Corporate Growth in Miami (prior recipients include Office Depot, Blockbuster Entertainment and Sunglass Hut). Mr. Conese had also served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Jackson Memorial Foundation which leads fundraising activities and resources on behalf of Miami-Dade County's Public Health Trust, which operates Jackson Memorial Hospital of Miami, Florida. In March of 2004, Mr. Conese's name was permanently inscribed on the Smithsonian's National Aviation and Space Exploration Wall of Honor as a leader in aviation and space exploration. In November of 2009, Mr. Conese received the 2010 Ellis Island Congressional Medal of Honor in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the community. He had a larger than life persona, was an inspiring leader who will be missed by all that ever had the opportunity to meet him, a loving husband, wonderful father and a true friend. There will be a Wake Service on Monday, March 23, 2015 from 6-9pm at Van Orsdel Funeral Chapel at 4600 SW 8th Street, Coral Gables, FL 33134 and there will be a Funeral Mass on Tuesday, March 24,, 2015 at 11:30am at St. Hugh Catholic Church, 3460 Royal Road, Coconut Grove, Florida 33133. 1/3

KOSTICK--Samuel Robert, lifelong businessman, student, mentor and friend, died at his home in Seattle on March 5, 2015, age 97. Born in Boston on February 16, 1918, Sam was a child actor on local radio. He earned a BA from Tufts and an MBA from Harvard. He met his future wife, Marilyn Glassman, during WW II while in the U.S. Army Air Corps in Denver. He lived in New York and was Executive Vice President of Loft Candy Corporation for 24 years, then headed the marketing firm KGA in the 1960s. In Boston from the 1970s, he co-owned (with Marilyn) Dorison House Publishers, and worked in real estate and in M&A. Moving to Seattle in 2006, Sam studied bio-anthropology at the University of Washington and founded the 826 Seattle Pen Pal Club. He was preceded in death by Marilyn, his wife of 61 years, and by his brother, Edward. Sam is survived by his daughters, Susan Kostick of Edmonds, WA and Anne Kostick of Brooklyn, NY; three granddaughters, two great granddaughters, two sons-in-law, and many nieces, nephews, and friends. A memorial gathering will be held in Boston in May. Contributions may be made to the Greater Seattle Bureau of Fearless Ideas or The University of Washington Burke Museum Biocultural Anthropology Fund.

SLATER--Bruce, of Chilmark, MA died in Cambridge on January 27th, a few weeks short of his 82nd birthday. His loving wife Marcy predeceased him in 2008 much to his surprise and deep sorrow. He is survived by two children and a granddaughter. A graduate of the Wharton School he earned an MBA at NYU. After serving in the US army in Japan he founded a development business building homes, apartment houses and shopping centers. He became committed to Martha's Vineyard enjoying sailing and involvement in local community organizations for over 30 years. He has been interred there next to his beloved Marcy. Donations in his memory can be made to Felix Neck Wildlife Sanctuary, P.O. Box 494, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568 or Sail Martha's Vineyard, PO Box 1998, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568. Mike, Bob and Howard 1/3
FUDIM--Murray. 3/19/07. Remembered with love, today and always. Marilyn 1/3

READ--Bertram 85, died March 16, Exeter, NH. Leaves children, William, John, and Wendy; brother Thomas; sisters Nancy, Joanne, and Helen, and four grandchildren. Graduate of Harvard and avid sportsman; dedicated to conservation, he served as a past president of the Squam Lakes Conservation Society. He held leadership positions at JW Clement, Regensteiner Press, and the Williams Press, and became president and owner of Shiver Mt. Press in CT in 1990. A devoted husband to Clare, generous father, and brother, also a hail-fellow-well-met by all those who knew him, confirmed by his many friends and admirers. Donations may be made to Squam Lakes Conservation Society. Memorial service at the chapel, Wonalancet, NH, June 6 at 1:30pm.
BROWN--Michael. Beloved husband of Yvonne. Adored son of Betty Socolof Lookofsky. Brother of Joseph. Devoted father of Adrian and Skylar. Cherished grandson of Elsie and Alexander Socolof. 1/3

ANCONA--Ruth, on February 28, peacefully, at home, in her 95th year. Daughter of Arthur Levy and the former Dorothy Bronner. Widow of Victor Ancona (1912-1998); mother of Barry Ancona and Ronnie Ancona; mother-in-law of Shannon Carr and Steven Cole; grandmother of Polly Ancona Carr, Cally Ancona Carr and David Ancona-Cole. Native New Yorker, world traveler, opera lover. Graduate of the Wadleigh High School Annex and Packard Business College, market researcher at Fairchild Publications, U.S. Labor Department analyst during WWII, student at Columbia SGS, The New School and Baruch College CUNY (until age 90). Education volunteer, including 20 years as director of the NYC School Volunteer Program (now Learning Leaders) reading program at P.S. 2 in Greater Chinatown. No services, at her request. 1/3
GANS--Laurence. Handsome, funny cousin we love you and will miss you. Phyllis and Laurette 1/3

GOLDMAN--Jerome, passed peacefully at home on March 19th, 2015. Jerry was a lifelong, proud New Yorker. Born, raised and educated in Brooklyn, he eventually settled in Manhattan. A talented designer and writer, he worked at various jobs from advertising to comedy writing, before starting a business with his brother, Marvin. Penn-Plax became one of the most respected family-run pet product manufacturers in the country. Aside from his achievements, he was unfailingly kind, intelligent, warm, interested in life and art in equal measure. A wonderful father to his daughter Dina and loving grandfather to Rafael, he was also an inspiringly optimistic man, even when faced with illness. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Service Sunday, March 22, 2015, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam. 1/3

KARP--Jerome (Jerry), beloved husband, father and grandfather passed away at the age of 87 on March 20 peacefully at his home. He leaves behind his wife Myrna, children Franklin (Caryl), Lori (Seward) and Ellen (Marc). Loving grandfather of Jason (Janet), Zachary, Amanda and Max. A gentle, loving man who will be greatly missed. Services Sunday, March 22 at 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

MANN--Harriet, nee Brechner, of New York City, passed away on March 13, 2015 with George, her beloved husband of 65 years by her side. Harriet was a force of nature, living a full and powerfully vibrant and exceptional life. Loving mother to Andy (Kathy), Richard (Lisa), Steven (Stephanie) and Thomas (Melissa). Proud grandmother to Ethan, Grace, Max and Aiden. Harriet had a special place in her heart for her dear Stefania, Max and Olivia Girombelli. Born in Brooklyn, NY to Rhea and Dan Brechner on May 12, 1928, Harriet found joy in her husband, sons, daughters-in-law, grandchildren, and dear friends. Harriet lived her life on the move. Walking (really fast!) everywhere, exercising, laughing and traveling. Harriet loved good food, wine, theater, music and anything beautiful. A special celebration of Harriet's life will be announced in the near future. 1/3

NEWKIRK--Ruth Harriet Wilson, 98, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on March 10, 2015. She was the beloved wife of the late Rudolph Newkirk, mother of Thomas, James and Joyce Newkirk, mother-in-law of Nancy Newkirk, and the late Barbara Newkirk. She was the devoted grandmother of Jennifer, Christopher, Brian and Katherine Newkirk, Laura Johnson Sera and Jonathan Ayres as well as a doting great-grandmother of seven. She attended Westfield State University. Before her marriage, she worked in the fashion industry designing and selling women's hats. She was a member of the Altar Guild at the Church of the Heavenly Rest and the Regency Whist Club. She was active in many charities. Her creative talents were recognized in The Family Creative Workshop (Time-Life 1976), which featured her stamp decoupage and were displayed at Adventures in Crafts in New York. For many years, she created and sold charming original stuffed animals based on children's stories. Services private. 1/3

WEINER--Gina Ingoglia, of Brooklyn Heights, a writer, artist, landscape designer, and tireless volunteer for NYC causes, died at home on March 17, 2015, of cancer. She was 76. Under her professional name Gina Ingoglia, she wrote more than 80 books for children, including the awardwinning The Tree Book for Kids and Their Grown-ups, which features her lucid descriptions and luminous paintings of North American trees. Among the institutions for which she volunteered are Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where she cofounded the Florilegium Society of botanic artists; Brooklyn Historical Society (a Vice Chair); Prospect Park Alliance (Trustee, Program Chair); The Acting Company (Education Chair); New York League of Conservation Voters Education Fund (Trustee, Secretary); Historic House Trust of NYC (Directors' Council member); and Mount Vernon Hotel Museum (garden advisor). The daughter of artist Frank Ingoglia and writer and artist Danis Gerdes Ingoglia, Gina grew up in Forest Hills Gardens. She received her BA (and an honorary PhD) from Dickinson College in PA, where she met her beloved husband of 53 years, Earl D. Weiner. Gina held a BS in landscape architecture from Rutgers, and designed graceful spaces in New York and New England. As devoted as she was to her many pursuits, she somehow found bottomless time for family. From her hand-drawn valentines to her hilarious emails to her unrivaled turkey soup, she was a master of daily gestures that never let loved ones forget what lay at the heart of her generous life. She is survived by Earl; her daughter, Melissa Balmain Weiner; her son, John Barlow Weiner; her son-in-law, William J. FitzPatrick; her daughter-in-law, Caroline P. Schaefer; and her grandchildren, David and Lily FitzPatrick. In lieu of sending flowers, the family suggests donating to one of Gina's favorite organizations. A celebration of her life will be held this spring at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. 1/3

ISRAELOFF--Phyllis (Snyder) Died peacefully on March 19th. Born October 30, 1924 in Philadelphia. Raised five daughters with husband, Al. Memorial service on Sunday, March 29th, 11am at Ballard/Durand Funeral Home, White Plains. Donations to Life Choice Hospice (lifechoicehospice.com)

CHAMINE--Robert James, 76 of New York City and Verbank, NY died unexpectedly on Wednesday, March 11, 2015. Son of the late Robert B. Chamine and Margaret Whelan Chamine, he graduated from Fordham University in 1960 and attended New York University Graduate School of Business. He did his military service in the United States Marine Corps Reserve from 1958 to 1963. In 1964 he married Claire A, Masterson of Irvington-on-Hudson, NY. For more than 30 years they lived in Rumson, NJ and in 1998 they returned to New York City and their farm in Dutchess County. His 40 year career on Wall Street began after college at Kidder Peabody where his father was a partner. Subsequently he joined Morgan Stanley as a vice president in charge of Equity Trading and in 1977 Wertheim and Company as a partner. He remained there for 23 years while they merged with Schroders, a British merchant bank, and finally Citibank in early 2000. During this time he was a member of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors, a member of the Risk Committee, as well as the Capital Commitment Committee. He also served on a Special Advisory Committee to the Chairman of the New York Stock Exchange for Institutional Trading. At the time of his death he was a General Partner of LR Global where he had been since 2002. He was an avid sportsman who enjoyed fishing and shooting around the world, as well as on weekends at the Mashomack Preserve Club where he contributed to its continuance. He was a voracious reader, lover of blues and jazz and could animatedly converse on any topic. His great sense of humor, loyalty and immense love of his family were recognized by all. He will be greatly missed by his wife of 51 years, Claire; his daughters Courtney Moss (George F.) of New York City; Suzanne Wood (Michael H.) of Cross River, NY; and grandsons George B. and Oliver F. Moss. A Memorial Mass will be held on May 6th at 3:30pm at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Ave., New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made to the Rogosin Institute, Development Dept., 504 East 74 Street, suite 1W New York, NY 10021 or Saint David's School, 12 East 89 Street, NYC, NY 10128. 1/3

COLE--Katharine Hamilton. Died March 4, at 93. Child of Katharine B (Esselstyn) and Richard E. Coon of Poughkeepsie. Graduated from Wellesley; MS in Social Work from Simmons, and worked as a psychiatric social worker. Widow of Ben R., survived by Jon, Betsy, Constance, four grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. 1/3
GANS--Larry: My mentor, my partner, my uncle, my best friend. I lost all four with your passing. Miss you already. Say hi to Dad. Love, Andy 1/3
SERBAN--Marin. 1919-2015. Announcing with profound regret the passing of our beloved grandfather, father and father-in-law on March 19th. Your legacy will always live in our hearts, TATA! 1/3

BOGART--Vincent L.,died March 26, 2012. Born on a farm in Kirwin, KS on June 8, 1922. Your death leaves a heartache no one can heal, but our love leaves a memory no one can steal. To this extraordinary lawyer, father and cherished husband of 61 years, I remember with gratitude and admiration. Your Kansas Sunflower, Judy 1/3
KETIVE--Samuel. We can't believe it's been 1 year without you. There is still a hole in our hearts. We will miss and love you forever. Your Girls 1/3

DOYLE--M. Brenda (nee Mary-ellen Doyle) died March 14, 2015, at St. Joseph's Hospital, Yonkers, after a short illness. Born in Boston, MA, on August 20, 1926, Ms. Doyle was graduated from The Convent of the Sacred Heart, NY (1944), Manhattanville College School of Nursing (1948), and the Frontier School of Midwifery, Kentucky (1955), where she visited expectant mothers on horseback and children were told the new baby had arrived in the nurse's saddlebag. She received an MA from Teachers College, Columbia University (1959.) A licensed RN and certified nurse-midwife, Ms. Doyle worked several years overseas and eventually retired from Lincoln Hospital, the Bronx, in 1980. In 1973, she was profiled in Women's Day Magazine, advocating for natural childbirth practices. She resided over 50 years in Spuyten Duyvil, the Bronx; from June, 2012 at Schervier Nursing Care Center and is survived by 30 nieces, nephews and their families. Memorials may be made to Scholarship Fund, Frontier Nursing University, 132 FNS Dr., Wendover, KY 41775 or www.frontier.edu.

FAY--Conner Martindale, 85, passed away Wednesday March 11, 2015 in Asheville, NC. He was a graduate of Yale University and Harvard Business School, later serving in the Navy on the Carrier Midway, and in the Antarctic. Following military service, he was employed by Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati and Rome, and Bristol-Myers in New York City. In college, Conner sang with the Whiffenpoofs, and the Yale Glee Club. He served as Chairman of the Yale Alumni Fund, numerous Reunion Gift Programs, and helped establish the Yale Alumni Chorus Foundation. In the year 2000, he was honored to receive the Yale Medal. Conner was an active member of many boards including St. Stephen's School in Rome, Italy, The Katonah Museum of Art, Hunter College School of Social Work, and the Asheville Symphony Orchestra. He was Senior Warden of St. Paul's Church in Rome Italy as well as St. Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua, NY. For many years he led the Board of Foreign Parishes of the Episcopal Church, receiving the Bishops Award for distinguished service. He is survived by his wife Evelyn Buford Fay and their three children; Leslie Fay of Asheville, Buford Fay of Charlotte and David Fay of Santa Cruz, Ca., as well as four grandchildren; Campbell, Camilla, Corinne, and Aiden. His greatest passions and deepest satisfactions have always been family, music, church and education. A memorial service will be held in Asheville NC at the Trinity Episcopal Church at 2 pm on Saturday March 28th. Memorial donations may be made to the Hall Fletcher School Park Project for which he was a champion: To: Hall Fletcher PTO Attn: Donations to HFE Outdoor Learning Center, 60 Ridgelawn Rd, Asheville, NC 28806. 1/3

NEWMAN--Jeffrey. On March 17, 2015 in New York, NY. Devoted father of David and Deborah, treasured brother of Charles, adored grandfather of Lucy, Maeve and Eva, and loving partner of Nancy. A litigator by trade and a big-hearted and gentle soul by nature. Your memory lives in all who love you.

DUBOWY--Michele. The Children's Aid Society mourns the passing of Michele Dubowy, a fierce advocate for the children of New York City and a highly respected social worker within the child welfare community. She retired in 2014 after nearly three decades at Children's Aid, most recently as the Deputy Director of the Child Welfare and Family Services Division, supporting thousands of children and improving countless lives. Our hearts go out to her family, which asks that donations be made to the American Cancer Society. Phoebe C. Boyer, President and CEO. 1/3

HAMMERMAN--Benjamin The Yeshiva University family grieves the passing of Benjamin Hammerman, of blessed memory, an admired member of the Jewish community and the jewelry industry, and conveys heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Lorelei; his children, Deborah (and Dr. Richard Born, a member of the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers), Judith (and Dr. Lawrence Weiss) and Dr. Hillel (and Caren) Hammerman; his brother David; his grandchildren, great-grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1

JAWOROWSKA--Wladzia (nee Bazanowska) died peacefully on March 15, 2015. Beloved wife of Henry Jaworowski (deceased). She was the loving sister to Zygmunt (deceased) and Alfreda (Chomowicz) Bazanowski, devoted aunt to Anne Bazanowski and Robert and Christine (Bazanowski) Scaffidi, and adoring great-aunt to Larissa and Sarina Scaffidi. Born in 1929 in Brooklyn, NY, to Kazimierz and Bronislawa (Gruszecka), Wladzia was a graduate of Hunter College. Although she worked in an office setting for most of her career, her true passion was in teaching, sharing and promoting traditional Polish dance and culture. "Miss Wanda" taught many generations of Polish dancers at schools which included: St. John Kanty Polish School, East New York, Educational Council, Polish Schools, New York City, Maria Konopnicka Polish School, "Krakowianki" - Our Lady of Consolation School, Williamsburg (NY), "Krakowianki" - St. Stanislaus School, New Haven (CT), Henryk Sienkiewicz Polish School, South Brooklyn (NY), Matusz Polish Dance Circle, "Krakowianki i Gorale" - St. Stanislaus Kostka Parish, "Krakowianki" - SS. CyriI and Methodius School, Brooklyn (NY). Together with her beloved husband Henry, Wladzia taught and preserved authentic Polish dance with the reknowned Matusz Polish Dance Circle. The Matusz dancers appeared on nationwide television, performed at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, both World Fairs, and numerous international folk festivals and Kosciuszko Foundation Balls. Wladzia was also a dedicated member of the Marie Sklodowska Curie Professional Women's Association and the Pro Arte League of the Kosciuszko Foundation, having served as its President. Wladzia was an amazing person who shaped and gave direction to all the dancers she met. She held strong in her beliefs and was a longtime volunteer for both Mayors Rudolph Giuliani and Michael Bloomberg. Her passion for life and her positive outlook, as further evidenced by her dedication to personal fitness and worldwide cruising, are her legacy. She will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday March 21st at 10:00 a.m. at St. Stanislaus Kostka Church, Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Contributions may be made in her memory to Calvary Hospital (www.calvaryhospital.org) or The Kosciuszko Foundation Scholarship Fund (www.thekf.org). 1

MINTZ--Anita Franz, On March 16, 2015. Beloved wife of Morton Mintz, beloved mother of Margaret (John Birdsall), Roberta (Harry Levine) and Daniel (Meredith Berkman), and much loved grandmother to Jules, Sophia, Emilia, Peter, Jesse, Isaac, Noa, Caleb, Avital and Yael. Born in Springfield, Ill., February 28, 1925 to the late Herman R. and Anna Levinson Franz. She attended Grinnell College and graduated from the University of Michigan. She was a writer for the Michigan Daily where she met Morton the day he returned from his WW II naval service. They married three months later, and remained happily married for 69 years. Never unkind, never prejudiced, she defined sweetness. Always thoughtful, she was an avid book reader. She will remain forever in our hearts. After a private burial service on March 18, the family is sitting Shiva in Washington D.C. and Manhattan. Contributions in Anita's memory may be made to American Jewish World Service at http://ajws.org/get--involved/ donate, or to the Anita Mintz Memorial Fund of the International Rescue Committee, Attn: Donor Services, 11th Floor, 122 East 42nd St., New York, NY 10168, https:// engage.rescue.org/donate 1/3

WEINER--Gina Ingoglia. The Board and staff of Theatre Development Fund extend their heartfelt sympathy to our chairman, Earl D. Weiner and his family on the loss of their beloved Gina. Her support and encouragement of TDF was reflective of the support and encouragement she provided so many New York City institutions. Victoria Bailey, Executive Director 1/3

WINKLER--Rhoda Mann, chief puppeteer and exclusive operator of Howdy Doody, died of cancer at 87 on March 18, 2015 in Dobbs Ferry, New York. She performed for five and a half years with the Howdy Doody Show beginning with its premier on December 27, 1947. Rhoda also animated the puppet Princess Summerfall Winterspring. Rhoda later recorded more than 80 radio and TV commercials and performed character voices for children's animated TV. One of these, "The Year Without a Santa Claus," is still running. Rhoda was a passionate semi-professional dancer, loved tap dancing and won a silver medal for dance roller skating. Her husband of 62 years Robert Winkler of Dobbs Ferry, NY and their son Dean and his wife Shellie of New York City survive Rhoda. Contributions in her honor may be made to World Parrot Mission, 99150 Overseas Highway, Key Largo, FL 33037. 1/3

LARAGH--John H. MD. The Hypertension Center at New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center mourns the loss of our founder and mentor John H. Laragh, MD. Dr. Laragh started the Hypertension Center in the 1970's. He was a true pioneer in the field; his passion for exploring and understanding the mechanisms of hypertension resulted in brilliant clinical investigations and development of a paradigm for treatment that remains relevant, useful and innovative even today. He loved medicine and his patients and they admired and loved him in return. His original discovery of the role of aldosterone in malignant hypertension led to an understanding of the important role of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system in hypertension, and ultimately, to the discovery of drugs that block the system and are used widely today to treat not only hypertension but also heart disease and kidney disease. His curiosity, command of the literature, and his innovative thinking of hypertension as a heterogeneous condition that requires individualized treatment presaged the advent of precision medicine by decades. We are grateful to have had the opportunity to work with him and we miss his brilliance, humor and creativity. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Dr. Jean Sealey, his sons John and Robert, his daughter-in- law Marci, and granddaughter Eliana. The Hypertension Center Division of Nephrology and Hypertension New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center Phyllis August, MD, MPH Frances Gillen Rochelle G. Katz Marie Ange Losco Samuel J. Mann, MD Rosemerie Marion, ANP Franco B. Mueller, MD Mark Pecker, MD 1/3

BRYAN--John Frederick, loving husband of Jane Rogers Bryan, passed away on March 20, 2015 at the age of 84 after a short struggle with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis. John was the brother of Richard, Gray, and Marsh Bryan and was the son of Gretchen Schoen Bryan and Gray MacWhorter Bryan. John graduated from Princeton University in 1952 and had been a Captain in the USMC. John was an avid golfer, an enthusiast of classical music, a volunteer with the Central Park Conservancy, and an accomplished bridge player. John is survived by his loving wife of 42 years, Jane Rogers Bryan; seven children; 17 grandchildren; and his brother Marsh. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021 on Tuesday, April 14, 2015 at 2:00pm EDT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in John's memory to the Central Park Conservancy or the New York Philharmonic. 1/3

SCHECHTER--Danny, died on March 19, in New York City. Danny Schechter, aka "The News Dissector" aka "troublemaker," grew up in the Bronx, in the progressive, union-sponsored Amalgamated Houses. His immigrant grandparents were garment workers who brought their socialist ideals with them from the Old Country. His mother Ruth Lisa Schechter was a secretary who became a poet. His father, Jerry Schechter was a pattern-maker who became a sculptor. Danny attended DeWitt Clinton High School, where he served as the editor-in-chief of the legendary Clinton News. From there it was on to Cornell, Syracuse, the London School of Economics, and Harvard as a Neiman Fellow. But this is only a small part of his life's journey. He joined the Northern Student Movement in high school and became actively involved in the Civil Rights Movement, going down to Mississippi in 1964. He became a leader in the movement to end the Vietnam War, was a member of SDS and began a lifelong commitment to South Africa in 1967 as an original member of the "London Recruits." He fought tirelessly against Apartheid from then on. Danny never hesitated to put his convictions on the line. In the 1970s, he turned back to his first love - journalism - and became the "news dissector" at radio station WBCN in Boston. He wove news and music together in collages that not only reported the day's events but also helped explain how the world worked. He was a huge influence on those who valued his independent perspective - and trusted him. He went on to become a prolific, Emmy award-winning TV producer and filmmaker, who made "South Africa Now," six films about Mandela, and spent decades criticizing and cajoling the media to do a better job covering the news. He interviewed Bob Dylan. He walked with Jesse Jackson. He embraced the Dali Lama. Malcolm X nicknamed him "Danny X." He was invited by Nelson Mandela to his inauguration. He was determined to "let justice roll down like waters" and to see all people free. His commitment and integrity were never for sale. Friend to thousands. Great and loving dad to Sarah, brother to Bill and Denzil, and uncle to Ethan and Jamie. He was so much fun. So much energy. A solar flare. A meteor across our sky. If there is an afterlife, you should soon be receiving a blog post from our beloved Danny Schechter, "the news dissector." In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Danny's name to Cornell University, Cornell University Office of Alumni Affairs, 130 E. Seneca Street, Ithaca, NY 14850. Please specify that the donation is for the "Civil Rights History & Memorial Project," which will honor Cornell students like Danny who went down south during the 1960's. We do not want this history to be lost, but to live on and inspire students today. A celebration of Danny's life will be held in New York City in the spring, at a date and place to be announced. 1/3

FINK--Paul, age 84, of Brooklyn, NY and Hemlock Farms, PA, died on March 21st at home surrounded by family after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Professor Nancy H. Fink, his daughter Rachael, and her husband Jeff Schweon, their daughter Abigail Rose, and his son Eric of Phoenix, AZ. He is also survived by a brother Martin Harper of Roslyn Heights, LI, his companion Terri Maisano, as well as his sister Sylvia Chase of Queens, NY, and by numerous nieces and nephews. Paul and his wife were both graduates of City College and Brooklyn Law School. Paul practiced law in Brooklyn for more than 50 years. He was a tenacious defender of the rights of ordinary citizens in both civil and criminal matters. Paul and his wife were active members of the Kane Street Synagogue in Brooklyn for many where numerous life-long friendships were formed. They were also members of the Lords Valley Country Club in Hemlock, PA for more than 40 years where they spent summers and found many more wonderful friends. Paul was athletic, enjoying soft-ball, basketball and paddle-ball in his youth, then tennis, swimming, hiking, running and skiing. He was a loving husband and brother, a devoted father and a passionate advocate for his clients. Funeral services will be held at noon on Monday, March 23rd at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st Street), New York. Shiva will be observed at home. Contributions in Paul's memory may be made to Kane Street Synagogue. 1/3

He was the beloved husband for 65 years of Marianne, father of Leslie (Joel Copperman) and David (Suzie) and grandfather of Hannah, Daniel, Jacob, Ethan, Judah, and Isaiah. BIENSTOCK--Miriam, record business pioneer and theatrical producer, died on Saturday March 21 at the age of 92. Mrs. Bienstock, together with Ahmet Ertegun and her then-husband Herb Abramson, was a founder of Atlantic Records in 1947. During her tenure at Atlantic it became the premier Rhythm and Blues and Jazz label in the United States with a roster that included such giants as Ray Charles, John Coltrane and Bobby Darin. She married the late music publisher Freddy Bienstock in 1957 and left Atlantic in 1962. She later became a theatrical producer, investing in such shows as "Strider" and the current hit musical "Beautiful: The Carol King Musical." She is survived by her two children, Robert and Caroline Bienstock and eight grandchildren. Services 11:15am Tuesday at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

GAINOR--Victor T.,Jr. of Forest Hills - March 19, 2015. He was 79. Born and raised in NYC, he graduated from Sacred Heart HS and attended Iona College before becoming a United States Marine. A successful career in financial services allowed time for other meaningful pursuits. A strong supporter of the armed services, he was past president of the NY Council of the Navy League, a National Director of the Navy League of the United States, and past Commander of American Legion Post 754 in NYC. A recipient of civilian honors and service awards from the US Marine Corps and the US Coast Guard, for many years he was delighted to host events for service members visiting NYC during Fleet Week. For nearly 40 years he was a member of the New York Athletic Club, where he served on the Board of Governors and as Treasurer. He also served on the Board of the Xavier Society for the Blind. He is survived by his wife of 55 years Pat, his children Vic, Debby, Sue and Tim, his daughter-in-law Toni and son-in-law Scott, his grandchildren, Catie, Victor, Sean, Gabriella and Connor, and his sister Florence. A gregarious sort, he will be remembered for his warm smile and quick wit, his loyalty to family and friends and his kindness to many. He will be greatly missed. Semper Fi! 1/3

MILROD--David. Beloved husband of Frances, father of Barbara, grandfather of James, father-in-law of John, brother of Sam (and Joyce). Born October 2, 1924 in Toronto, Canada, died peacefully Saturday, March 21, 2015 in New York City from cancer. Sweet, scholarly, courteous, thoughtful, he survived childhood empyema to become a doctor, a leading psychoanalytic scholar, and proponent of neuropsychoanalysis at The New York Psychoanalytic Institute. During internship in St. Louis, he met Frances, love of his life; they were married more than 66 years. Service at The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam March 24 at 12:45 pm. Family will receive visitors March 25 7-9:30 pm at 151 West 86th Street, Apt. 2C. 1/3

HALLADAY-WYCKOFF-- Jenny, beloved wife of Aaron Halladay, daughter of the late E. Lisk Wyckoff, Jr. and Claire Wyckoff, and stepdaughter of Dannell Maguire. Of cancer in New York City on March 19, 2015. 1/3

BEINBRINK--Shirley, of Hilton Head Island and formerly Manhasset, NY, passed away on Friday, March 13, 2015, at age 92, surrounded by her loving family. Shirley, was the daughter of Adelaide and Lawrence Wiegert of Woodhaven, NY. Shirley's last days and hours were the perfect reflection of her life: value family above all. She attended the Katharine Gibbs School and was a member of the Order of the Eastern Star. During that period she sang with the Les Brown Band. She married her high school sweetheart Robert Beinbrink in 1943. They settled in Roslyn Heights, NY then to Manhasset, NY where their three children were raised. During those years she worked in administration at the Jackson Avenue School in Mineola, NY. She was one of the early members of the Congregational Church of Manhasset, and later the First Presbyterian Church of Hilton Head. She is preceded in death by her husband Robert, son Jeffrey R. Beinbrink, Capt. USN, and sister Adelaide Wiegert. She is survived by son and daughter-in-law Glenn and Julie Beinbrink of Charleston, SC, daughter and son-in-law Nancy and Charles Gilman of Manhasset, NY, and daughter-in-law Barbara Beinbrink of San Diego, California. She leaves seven grandchildren Andrew and William Beinbrink of San Diego, Peter, Douglas and Kate Gilman of Manhasset, NY, and Wade and Garrett Beinbrink of Charleston, SC. A memorial service will be held to celebrate her life on Sunday, March 29th at 11:30 at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, 1845 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, the Congregational Church of Manhasset or Planned Parenthood. 1/3

BIENSTOCK--Miriam, record business pioneer and theatrical producer, died on Saturday March 21 at the age of 92. Mrs. Bienstock, together with Ahmet Ertegun and her then-husband Herb Abramson, was a founder of Atlantic Records in 1947. During her tenure at Atlantic it became the premier Rhythm and Blues and Jazz label in the United States with a roster that included such giants as Ray Charles, John Coltrane and Bobby Darin. She married the late music publisher Freddy Bienstock in 1957 and left Atlantic in 1962. She later became a theatrical producer, investing in such shows as "Strider" and the current hit musical "Beautiful: The Carol King Musical." She is survived by her two children, Robert and Caroline Bienstock and eight grandchildren. Services 11:15am Tuesday at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

SCHOENFARBER--David. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst mourns the sudden and untimely passing of David Schoenfarber. David was a second generation member of Beth El, a longtime officer of the synagogue and a beloved friend to all. He had a heart of gold and an eternal smile. Our condolences to his wife Barbara, his sons Jeffrey, Steven, Harris and Adam and their respective and extended families. May his memory be for a blessing. Matthew Futterman, Rabbi Sholom Stern, Rabbi Emeritus Richard Holland, President Edward Edelstein, Executive Director
KELLER--Jerry, New York. Survived by Edith and Edward. Memorial at St. Andrews, Boca Raton, FL. March 27, 2pm. 561-487-5500.

KITSELMAN--Jane. Died in her Manhattan home on March 18, 2015 at the age of 87, after a long, adventurous, and cultured life. Daughter of Walter and Catherine White, she was born and raised in Muncie, IN. She was a graduate of Indiana University in music and art history, and while still a student, set off alone to post-war Europe to study cello in Salzburg and Vienna. Following her interests and friendships with musicians, including members of the Budapest String Quartet, she participated in the early days of the Prades Festival for chamber music, later to become the Casals Festival. Throughout her life, Jane retained friendships with a wide circle of notable artists, classical musicians, writers, and poets. A serious and gifted musician and sculptor, she pursued her music as a young woman, playing in amateur string quartets and studying cello with Klaus Adam, and later focused on her sculpture, while residing in France, New Brunswick, Canada, and New York City. Jane was also a quiet, and generous patron of the arts, offering crucial support to help establish the young, conductorless Orpheus Chamber Orchestra on its way to world fame, the contemporary music group Speculum Musicae, and The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. These were among many cultural institutions she supported, often opening her home to private concerts and sometimes accompanying musicians on tour, wining and dining them along the way. She was a fierce defender of environmental causes, and with her companion Anne Dunn, fought many battles throughout the years against the increasing degradation of the forests of New Brunswick due to massive clear-cutting so destructive to the birds and wildlife of the province that she loved. In spite of her inherent shyness, Jane Kitselman, having grown up with three brothers, possessed the best taxi-summoning whistle in the City of New York, had a pointed sense of humor, and was known quietly to break into song at the slightest provocation flawlessly remembering lyrics going back decades. She was married to Richard Kitselman, widowed in her early thirties, and was also pre-deceased by her adoptive daughter Alice. She is survived by her companion Anne Dunn Moynihan, their close and extended family, and a circle of friends who will cherish the memory of this very original individual. 1/3

LARAGH--John. Weill Cornell Medical College and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. John H. Laragh, a physician-scientist and pioneer in the field of hypertension. Dr. Laragh was devoted to understanding the mechanisms behind the disease, and established the existing paradigm for clinical care that underscores the importance of precision medicine in treating hypertension in individual patients. An alumnus of the Medical College, he championed this work and founded the Hypertension Center at Weill Cornell and NewYork-Presbyterian. We will miss his scientific ingenuity, leadership and humor. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Steven J. Corwin, CEO, NewYork- Presbyterian Hospital 1/3

BOHEN--Frederick M. The members of the Board of Directors of The Polish-American Freedom Foundation note with deep sadness the passing of Fred Bohen. Mr. Bohen served on the Board with distinction from 2003 to 2013, when he became Director Emeritus. During that time, he served as Chairman of the Investment Committee, providing financial guidance and contributing his deep knowledge of nonprofit governance to support the Foundation. The Foundation's mission is to bolster civil society, democracy and a market economy in Poland, while equalizing opportunities for personal and social development and sharing the Polish experiences in transformation with other countries in Central and Eastern Europe. A true humanist and gentleman in the best sense of that term, he will be greatly missed. We extend to his entire family our deepest condolences. Andrew Nagorski, Chairman John P. Birkelund, Chairman Emeritus Jerzy Kozminski, Chief Executive Officer Carla H. Skodinski, Chair, Investment Committee The Polish-American Freedom Foundation 1/3

BURNS--Perry Lorimer, 79, resident of Greenwich CT, died February 28, 2015 due to Lewy Body Disease. He was a board member of the Literacy Volunteers of America, Stamford/Greenwich and the Greenwich Council, Boys Scouts of America. Beloved husband of Joan Blissert and loving father to Lorimer (David Benson), Perry, Jr. (Jolie Parcher), Samantha (Kip Robbins) and Robert. A memorial service will on May 15, 2015 at 11:00am at the Stanwich Church, 202 Taconic Rd, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Greenwich Council, Boys Scouts of America. 1/3

MACK--Stephen M. Stephen M. Mack, of Houston, TX, and New York, on March 19, 2015, after a long but valiant struggle. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Kate Mack Kozak and her husband Kevin, of Austin, TX, and "number one son", Christopher. Cherished son of Ethel and the late Ivan A. Dear brother of Kevin, Brian, Eileen Parascandola and the late Kathleen Borzello, and Leslie Marie Mack. Family will receive friends Thursday, March 26 from 3pm, with prayer service beginning at 7pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st Street, with Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 11am at St. Ignatius Loyola, R.C. NEPOMNYASHCHY-- Catharine. With heartfelt sadness and a deep sense of loss, the Trustees, Administration, and Faculty of Barnard College mourn the passing of Catharine Nepomnyashchy, professor of Slavic studies and beloved member of our community for 28 years. Over the course of her distinguished career, Professor Nepomnyashchy was a mentor to countless Barnard students and an ongoing source of inspiration. She will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched. Barnard honors the memory of this extraordinary woman and extends its deepest sympathies to her family. A memorial service is being planned at Barnard for a future date. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald, Chair of the Board, Debora L. Spar, President 1/3

BLANK--Cynthia Fisher, 89, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan, on March 4, 2015 following a stroke. She was the widow of Dr. Sanford Blank, a thoracic surgeon to whom she was happily married for 62 years. Born on March 5, 1925, the daughter of Rose and Irwin Fisher of New York City, Mrs. Blank attended Friends Seminary graduating in the Class of 1940. She received a B.A. degree from Western Reserve University in 1944, and attended Salmon P. Chase College of Law in Cincinnati, Ohio graduating first in her class in 1956 with a J.D. degree. Later she earned an LL.M. degree from New York University School of Law, Class of 1973. Mrs. Blank became the first woman partner in the law firm of Taft, Stettinius & Hollister LLP in Cincinnati, specializing in Estate Planning and Taxation. She worked there for 20 years prior to her retirement in 1988. Before working at the Taft firm, she served as Director of the Domestic Relations Court of Hamilton County. After her retirement, Mrs. Blank and her husband moved to Fishers Island, New York where they enjoyed many wonderful years. She is survived by her brother, Wendell Fisher, two daughters, Claudia Marks and Leslie Tombari, son-in-law, Paul Tombari, and three grandchildren, Robert Marks, Daniel Marks, and Meris Enright. There will be a private burial on Fishers Island. Donations in her memory may be made to Opengate, Inc., 357 Main Street, Armonk, New York 10504, Attn: Pat Gundersen. 1/3
