Her keen interest in her family and its history were matched by her love. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 26, 2015, at 11:00 o'clock at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue, New York, New York. 1/3
CREAGHAN--Ellen Mary Manning. Honoring your 101st Birthday from your ever faithful, devoted and loving children. Patricia, Dennis, Georgina 1/3

CHANOS--Steven J. died peacefully 18th March, 2015 in Sarasota, FL. Beloved husband of Nancy Wussow Stover Chanos, and the late Mary Catherine Sullivan. Dear father of James, Thomas (Cheryl), and Steven (Gina) Chanos, and step-father to Gordon and Grant Stover. Grandfather of Nicholas, Lisa, Eric, Michael, Carissa, Melanie, Andrew, Alexa, and Cali Chanos. Uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. Fraternal brother of Arthur (deceased) and George Chanos. Beloved son of James and Jenny Chanos (both deceased). Steve was the son of immigrant parents, and was a 1942 graduate of Lincoln HS in Milwaukee, WI, where he was a star athlete and captain of the cross-country team. He served in the US Army Air Corps, 1942-45, where he saw action in the Pacific Theater. After attending the University of Wisconsin, Steve joined the family business, and in 1972 became a corporate executive of the BASF Corp. He retired at an early age to Longboat Key, FL, where he enjoyed golf and World travel. Visitation at Krause Funeral Home, 9000 West Capitol Drive, Milwaukee, WI 53222 on Wednesday, March 25th, 4pm-7pm. Trisagion at 6pm. Additional visitation at Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church, 9400 W. Congress, Milwaukee, WI 53225 on Thursday, March 26th, at 10-1030am. Funeral Service at 1030am. Interment to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park. "Dad, we will miss your gentle spirit, kindness of heart, bedrock integrity, and fierce loyalty to your family and friends. You always saw the best in people, were a self-made success, and became friends with everyone you met. We all aspire to those qualities. Yet your inimitable sense of style, love of history and your Greek heritage, and curiosity to see the world were traits that made you unique. We will mourn your passing, but celebrate your life!" With All Our Love, The Chanos Family 1/3

McKELVEY--Gerald J.C.,died at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Manhattan on March 16, 2015. He was 71 years old. He was born on June 27, 1943 in Waynesboro, PA, and was the son of Mary Louise and Gerald Campbell McKelvey, Sr. He was a graduate of Waynesboro High School, class of 1961, and Washington College, class of 1965. After college, he worked as a newspaper reporter and editor, including 10 years at each of The Philadelphia Inquirer and New York Newsday. He was Press Secretary to the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, for nine years. He retired in 2013 as an Executive Vice President at Rubenstein Associates, where he worked for 17 years as a crisis management and public relations specialist. From 1984 until his death, he was active with the Inner Circle, which is composed of reporters who cover city politics for New York newspapers, and with its annual dinner and show poking fun at politicians. He was also a member of the New York chapter of Sons of the American Revolution. He served as Acting President and Vice-President of the Board of Trustees at his church, St. Mary the Virgin, located in Manhattan. Gerald is survived by his wife of 14 years, Maria-Liisa Lydon McKelvey, his three children from prior marriages, Patrick, Nora, and Jennifer McKelvey, and his sister, the Reverend Diana Rogers. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, March 26th, 2015 at 10am at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin located at 145 West 46th Street, New York, NY. Donations in his name may be made to the Police Athletic League or the Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

SCHOENFARBER--David J.,69, longtime resident of New York/Massachusetts died March 21st. Loving husband of Barbara, father of Jeff, Steven, Harris and Adam, brother of Harriett and grandfather. Funeral will be Tuesday, March 24th at 12pm at Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home in Great Barrington, MA. Donations may be made to Team Tangerine or UJA through the funeral home, 426 Main St., Great Barrington, MA 01230. To view full obituary go to www.finnerty andstevens.com 1/3

NOVICK--Sylvia Greenwald, passed March 22, 2015 at 97. Best friend, lover, wife of the late Irv. Mom to Leslie (Bill), Wayne, Jan (Donna) and Kim (Susannah). Grandma to Jad, Mia, Eliza, Cray, Great-Gran too! A devoted, kind friend; a choco-holic, foodie, serial volunteer whose unselfish efforts benefited many. Donations can be made to GHC, The Kiddish Fund, 515 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY, 10522. 1/3

SCHWEITZER--Richard. The members, students and staff of the New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute mourn the loss of Mr. Richard Schweitzer. A longtime and devoted employee, he served as NYPSI's bookstore manager since its founding. We will always remember him for his love of music and the arts, his kind heart, and his wit. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Ian D. Buckingham, MD, President 1/3
BIENSTOCK--Miriam. Lauren and Louis DePalo mourn the passing of Miriam Bienstock; Mother, Oma, Friend. In the words of Frank Sinatra, she "lived 'till she died." 1/3

FOGEL--Dr. Sander H.,renowned psychiatrist, died at age 87 of complications from pneumonia on March 19, 2015 at his home in Ossining, NY. Sandy Fogel was a warm, gentle, loving man with a ready smile and a playful sense of humor, and an avid reader with a passion for history, politics, music, art, theater and film. For over 60 years, Dr. Fogel specialized in child and family therapy, developing new therapeutic approaches and presenting these innovative techniques at numerous international symposia. An accomplished teacher and lecturer, community activist and scholar of great integrity, Sandy was born on October 22, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife Ruth Sherman, his former wife Natalee Saxon Fogel, his children Jan, Alice, and Brian Fogel, adopted Chinese son Joe Lam, step-sons Steve and Peter Sherman, 10 grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. 1/3

COWIT--Selma, died at home March 22, 2015. Wife of Seymour Cowit (deceased) Beloved mother of Rosalyn and Ike (Harris) and Mark and Michelle Cowit. Grandmother of Tracy, Steven, Abigail and Scott. Mom, we love you and miss you. Donations can be made to Hollis Hills Jewish Center. Roz Harris Mark Cowit

MILROD--David. The members of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the loss of our longtime member Dr. David Milrod. ROONEY--Francis C. Francis C. Rooney, Jr.,the Chairman of H.H. Brown Shoe Company and the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Melville Corporation, died on March 24, 2015 at Greenwich Hospital. He was 93 years old. Rooney was married for 65 years to the love of his life, the former Frances Heffernan of Worcester, Massachusetts. One of the leading retail executives of his generation, Rooney transformed Melville Corporation from a shoe company with $180 million in revenue at the time he became chief executive officer at age 42 into a specialty retail business with over $7 billion of revenue at the time of his retirement in 1987. In 1987, Melville's businesses included Marshall's, Linens & Things, K.B. Toys and CVS Drug Stores. Today the company's name has changed from Melville Corp to CVS Health Corporation. In 1990, after three years of retirement, Rooney agreed to become CEO of H.H. Brown Shoe Co., Inc., which was owned by his late father-in -law. In 1991, the company was sold to Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and at Warren Buffett?s request he became Chairman. In a press interview, Mr. Buffett concluded, Frank "is a sensational human being and a great manager." Throughout his adult life Rooney maintained a commitment to numerous civic, charitable and education causes. He was one of the founding trustees of the Inner City Scholarship Fund, which today provides over 30,000 inner city children with scholarships to attend Catholic schools in New York City. He also served as a trustee of United Cerebral Palsy; Greenwich Hospital; March of Dimes; Smithsonian Institute; Boys & Girls Club of America; St. Ignatius School in the Bronx; The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania; Pace University; and Fordham University. In 1987, Rooney received an honorary degree from Boston College. In addition, Rooney served on the Board of Directors of Bankers Trust Company; Collins & Aikman Textile Company; ADT; AMF Corporation; Black & Decker; Dunkin Donuts; and Neiman Markus. Frank Rooney was born at home in North Brookfield, Massachusetts on Thanksgiving Day, November 24, 1921. He graduated in 1939 from North Brookfield High School where he was captain of the basketball team, and he received his bachelor degree from the University of Pennsylvania (Wharton School) in 1943. He graduated as an Ensign in the U.S. Naval Reserve and was assigned that year to the battleship USS North Carolina in the Pacific. He was aboard as a gunnery officer in 10 major engagements between 1943 and 1945. He began his business career in 1946 as a sales trainee with the John Foote Shoe Company in Brockton, Massachusetts. Two years later, he went to work for the Florsheim Shoe Company in Chicago, and in 1953 he joined the Thom McAn Shoe Company, a subsidiary of Melville Shoe Corporation, as a buyer/ stylist. He rose to President of Thom McAn in 1961 and in 1964 he was elected Chairman, President and CEO of Melville Shoe Corporation. Mr. Rooney is survived by his beloved wife Frances Heffernan and eight children: Peter M. Rooney (Kathy) of Basking Ridge, NJ; Michael F. Rooney (Joann) of New Rochelle, NY; Stephen G. Rooney (Susan) of Pelham Manor, NY; Jean R. Weil (Jerry) of Greenwich, CT; William A. Rooney (Amy) of Charlotte, NC; Carol R. Flanagan (James) of Greenwich, CT; Frances R. Cifrino (Michael) of Hingham, MA and Clare R. Butler (David) of Harrison, NY, as well as 27 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Mr. Rooney was an avid golfer and a long time member of Blind Brook Golf Club, Winged Foot Golf Club, Ekwanok Golf Club, Sankaty Head Golf Club, Seminole Golf Club, Lyford Cay Club and Lost Tree Club. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Friday from 2 to 4 PM and 7 to 9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection on Saturday at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Inner City Scholarship Fund. For information go to innercityscholarshipfund.org. 1/3

LARAGH--John, MD. The Rogosin Institute mourns the passing and celebrates the life of John H. Laragh, MD. A graduate of Cornell University Medical College (now Weill Cornell), he trained at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and became a world-renowned clinician- scientist. His discovery of the link between renin, a mostly forgotten kidney hormone, and the mechanisms that govern normal blood pressure regulation and the pathogenesis of hypertension provided the foundation for the modern treatment of high blood pressure and its heart and kidney complications. His tenacious pursuit, limitless imagination, and perspicacity led to the development of angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers, which revolutionized the treatment of hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and cardiovascular disease. The broad scope of his work is evident from his academic titles, which extended beyond traditional boundaries: at Columbia he was Chief of Nephrology, and then at Cornell he was Director of Cardiology and the Cardiovascular Center, and member of the Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery. The impact of his collaboration with Dr. Albert Rubin, the late Director of The Rogosin Institute, still resonates today. He has trained generations of leaders worldwide in hypertension research. In addition to these accomplishments, Dr. Laragh was the founder and inaugural President of the American Society of Hypertension and the first Editor-in-Chief of the American Journal of Hypertension. He was first and foremost a master clinician whose guiding principle was to improve the lives of all patients. He loved his family, friends, colleagues, and all that life had to offer. All of us at The Rogosin Institute salute Dr. Laragh's remarkable life and offer our condolences to his wife and co-investigator Dr. Jean Sealey, his sons John and Robert, daughter-in-law Marci, and granddaughter Eliana. Barry H. Smith, M.D., Ph.D. President & CEO The Rogosin Institute 1/3

RUBIN--Martin, died peacefully on March 24 at 92. He is survived by the love of his life Natalie to whom he was married for 68 years. He was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. He was a classic member of the Greatest Generation who landed in France and fought in the Battle of the Bulge and marched into Germany as part of Patton's Third Army. While he was in the US waiting to ship off to Japan the war ended and he met Natalie and his life's course was set. He lived the motto that it is not having what you want but wanting what you have that makes a man happy. And in his beloved Natalie and his children and grandchildren and greatgrandchildren of whom he was so proud he had what he wanted and he lived a rich and happy life. Funeral at Plaza Memorial on Thursday at 12:30. 1/3

JENSEN--Jytte. The trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art are deeply saddened by the death of our admired and beloved colleague Jytte Jensen, who was a Curator in the Department of Film. Jytte joined MoMA in 1982 as a Research Assistant in the Circulating Film Library, was officially hired in 1984 as a Curatorial Assistant, and rose to become Curator in the Department of Film and Media (now the Department of Film) in 2003. Throughout her career at MoMA, her pioneering exhibitions and publications ranged from Cinema Novo in Brazil to the experimental cinema of the Arab world. She organized numerous surveys of international film, retrospectives of individual artists, and programs of experimental and independent American cinema, with highlights including annual programs such as Premiere Brazil! (2003-12) and Global Lens (2003-13); Prix Jean Vigo (2006), a yearlong celebration of French film; Big as Life: An American History of 8mm Films (1998-99), the three-part Mapping Subjectivity series (2010?12), which explored Arab cinema since the late 1960s;Discovering Georgian Cinema (2014); and monographic retrospectives on Bernardo Bertolucci (2010), B?la Tarr (2001), Abbas Kiarostami (2007), and Pier Paolo Pasolini (2013), among others. She was a member of the selection committee for New Directors/New Films, the annual collaboration between The Film Society of Lincoln Center and The Museum of Modern Art. A native of Denmark, Jytte earned an MA in Cinema Studies from New York University. Her publications include Benjamin Christensen: An International Dane (1999), "Four Decades of Brazilian Cinema" in Cinema Novo and Beyond (1998), and monographs on Carl Th. Dreyer (1994) and Bela Tarr (2001), as well as interviews and articles for newspapers in the U.S. and abroad. In addition, Jytte participated on several international festival juries, including those of the Oberhausen, Rio de Janeiro, Mexico City, and Sundance festivals. She will be deeply missed by all of her colleagues at MoMA, and by countless artists, filmmakers, and friends around the globe. The Staff and Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art 1/3

MAGNOZZI--Mara Mahon, was granted her angel wings on March 24th, 2015. Her final days were spend surrounded by family. Mara was born June 21st, 1927, in Livorno, Italy. She was the daughter of Dina and Mario (a soccer Olympian) and the sister of the late Mario (Mimma). In 1947 she married Michael Mahon and soon thereafter emigrated to the United States. One of her fondest memories was the sight of the Statue of Liberty from a transatlantic troopship deck. As a war bride she encountered many challenges, but soon adapted to the many cultural changes. She was a student at Columbia Medical School until her family obligations took precedence. She was a very proud and caring mother. She took her responsibilities as a single parent quite seriously and ensured a smooth transition to adulthood for her children. Mara was proudly ahead of her time in breaking the glass ceiling. Her professional career began as a comparison shopper with Abraham & Straus, moved on to the fashion industry at Korvettes and culminated as the founder and head of the very successful International Division of May Department stores. She gained worldwide recognition for her knowledge and skills in the areas of textiles and fashion, as well as her exuberant and inimitable spirit and personality. Her experience in the upper echelons of international commerce was constantly sought out by specialists in her field from North America, Europe and Asia. She was a life and career mentor to many. Her professional and personal travels took her to many countries around the world where she expressed her special appreciation for cultures and their nuances. Her time was not solely devoted to her work, as she was a great lover of the arts and music. Her greatest love was for her family. She devoted her time and love to them across the generations. She was the beloved mother of Christine (late John), Dean (Hilda), Lisa (Dennis) and Kerry. She was also the proud grandmother of seven girls and great grandmother of two children. Visitation will be held on Friday, March 27th 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Hunt-Stellato Funeral Home, 1601 Palisade Avenue, Fort Lee, NJ. Funeral services will be held Saturday, March 28th at 10am at Epiphany R.C. Church, Cliffside Park. Entombment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx. The family request that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in her name to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis TN 38105. Send condolences to stellatofuneralhomes.com. A memorial celebration of her life will be held at a later date. 1/3

SCHWEBEL, M. Mac. The Schechter Westchester community mourns the death of its beloved Lifetime Chairman of the Board of Trustees. Mac's generosity and leadership sustained our school during its first 50 years. He provided funding for the purchase of our Lower School campus and the lead gift to build our Upper School. His optimism and good cheer gave hope to a fledgling community, his mature determination gave stability, his generosity gave inspiration, his modesty gave comfort at times of challenge, his leadership set the standard for future generations. He provided the strength to grow and expand. We send our condolences to John and Zelda, Laura and Les, Anne and David. May Mac's memory continue to be a blessing to all who knew him and who continue to benefit from his kindness and foresight. Michael J. Leffell, President, Board of Trustees Michael A. Kay, PhD, Head of School Dr. Elliot D. Spiegel, Headmaster Emeritus

SCHWEBEL--M. Mac. In loving memory of Morris "Mac" Schwebel who passed away on March 24th. A family man, successful corporate lawyer and philanthropist, Mac, as he was known by all, left his mark in New York where he resided for the first half of his life and then in Palm Beach, Florida where he spent his retirement. He was married to the love of his life, Irene Michaels Schwebel until her death in 1985. He was devoted to his three children, seven grandchildren and five great grandchildren. His passion was educating Jewish children. One of his greatest accomplishments was founding the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester, where he was Chairman of the Board and of which the upper campus is named in his honor. He served for many years on the Board of Overseers for the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York. One of his proudest moments was receiving an Honorary Doctorate from JTS with former Vice President Al Gore. Deeply committed to Conservative Jewish life, he also supported the Masorti Movement in Israel. Born in Brooklyn in 1909, the youngest of six brothers, he graduated with honors from St. John's Law School. As a Wall Street corporate attorney for over thirty years, he was a lawyer for Warner Bros-Seven Arts, served on the Board of Directors of Warner Bros. and was instrumental in facilitating a merger that created Warner Communications, Inc., the precursor of Time Warner Inc. After retiring from the law, his love of golf led he and two partners to build Sherbrooke Golf and Country Club in Lantana, Florida. He spent many happy days on the golf course, playing like a person half his age! His other passion was the opera. His children fondly remember him singing opera throughout their home in White Plains, NY. During his life, he and his wife, regularly attended performances of the opera in New York and Palm Beach. For many years he served as President of the Board of the Palm Beach Opera. He is survived by his children John Schwebel (Zelda Schwebel), Laura Landau (Les Landau) and Anne Diamond (David) and his grandchildren, Andrew Schwebel and James Schwebel (Lisa Schwebel), Leigh Landau (Jimmy Stewart), Michael Landau (Paige Landau), Lee Diamond (Michelle Diamond), Emily and Evan Diamond and great grandchildren, Jessica, Alexis, Jacob Schwebel, Natalie Stewart and Jonah Diamond. He had a generous spirit and a love of life and was as principled as he was prosperous. He became known as "Mac the nice" and when asked throughout his life how he was, he would always reply, "never better." Perhaps it was his positive outlook that helped to create such a wonderful and enriched long life. He will be dearly missed, by everyone who knew him. Services 11 am Thursday at Temple Beth El. 2815 N. Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Fl. In lieu of flowers, the family respectfully requests that donations may be made to the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester or the Temple Beth El of West Palm Beach. Arrangements Entrusted to Riverside-Stanetsky Memorial Chapels, Delray Beach, Fl. 561-496-7550. 1

WEINER--Gina Ingoglia. The Trustees, staff, and volunteers of Brooklyn Botanic Garden are greatly saddened by the passing of Gina Ingoglia Weiner. In 2000, Gina cofounded the Brooklyn Botanic Garden Florilegium, a guild of more than 50 botanical artists who contribute to the illustration of BBG's treasured living collections. A celebrated children's book author, Gina wrote the awardwinning Tree Book for Kids and Their Grown-ups, which was published by BBG in 2008; it became an instant classic and is now in its third printing. Gina also wrote a children's gardening page for BBG's newsletter for more than 13 years. We extend our deepest sympathy to Gina's husband, BBG Trustee and past Board Chair Earl Weiner, and their entire family. Frederick Bland, Board Chair Scot Medbury, President Frances Mendlow, Auxiliary President 1/3

ASHDOWN--Cecil Spanton has died at 92, familiarly known as "Span," died Monday morning (March 23) at NYU Langone Medical Center in Manhattan after treatment for longstanding heart disease. Trained as an engineer, he had served as a naval officer and became a recognized authority on steamship histories. A native New Yorker he was born at Flower Hospital on May 14, 1923, and brought up in Bermuda with a residence in New York. After prep school at Ridley College in St. Catharine's, Ontario, he earned his BSE (Bachelor of Science and Engineering) degree at Princeton in 1944, then proceeded immediately to the U.S. Naval Academy, emerging as an Ensign. There ensued several years of active service, during which he served as Chief Engineering Officer aboard the U.S.S Wrangell in World War II. He remained in the U.S. Navy Reserve and eventually retired as a Lieutenant Commander. After his wartime service he entered Harvard Business School (MBA, 1948) and began a business career of more than three decades with the Alcoa Steamship Company, where he became Purchasing Manager, served until 1980, and remained a consultant for life. He also became secretary of the board of directors of the Pan-Ore Steamship Company. Mr. Ashdown was a member of the World Ship Society, the Naval Reserve Association, the Navy League, and the Naval Order of the United States. His abiding nautical interests led to board service for the Bermuda Maritime Museum, the Steamship Historical Society of America (1950-76), and the Maritime Industry Museum at Fort Schuyler. Other interests led to board memberships for the Grenfell Association of America, of which his father, Cecil Spanton Ashdown, Sr., was the founding financial director for Sir Wilfred Grenfell, and the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which his wife, Marie M. Ashdown, has served as executive director since 1985. Love for music also led to his membership in the Metropolitan Opera Club in 1966 and board service for that organization. In addition to his wife, Mr. Ashdown's survivors include their sons Cecil S. Ashdown III and Charles Coster Ashdown; stepchildren Mrs. Vivian Gartman Silliman, Rev. John Stephen Gartman; and grandchildren Marygrace and Helen Ashdown. No plans for visitation or a memorial service have been announced. 1/3

JENSEN--Jytte. The MacDowell Colony is deeply saddened by the death of friend and board member, Jytte Jensen. Over the last 15 years Jytte helped build a vibrant fellowship program for independent and international filmmakers. She loved to be surprised by a new filmmaker and helped so many with her encouragement. Jytte will be remembered with enormous gratitude and affection. 1/3

LEWIS--Arthur, on March 24, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Roberta. Loving father of Alison Sisun and the late John. Cherished grandfather of Dean. 1/3

RUBIN--Jerome, died on March 15 at his home in Marlborough, MA after retiring from practice at Held & Rubin Architects in East Meadow, NY for many years. He is mourned by a loving family and many dear friends. 1/3

DuBOIS--Peter C.,died peacefully on March 24 at 80. He was a journalist and editor at Barron's Weekly for over 30 years. He became Foreign Editor and began a weekly column called the International Trader in 1980 until his retirement in 2000. His passion for art lead to an eclectic collection which included ancient Chinese jades, Southeast Asian sculpture, Outsider Art and other contemporary works. He particularly enjoyed supporting emerging artists. Peter is survived by Helen, his wife of 56 years, daughter, Laura, son, Christopher, grandchildren, Simone and Desmond, and his half-sister Anne Dowling. A memorial service is will be held on Saturday, April 11 at 11am at Grace Church, 802 Broadway at 10th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Doctors without Borders. 1/3

ROCHFORD--Paul Edward, Esq.,93, of Glastonbury CT, passed away March 25, 2015. Born the third child of Thomas Rochford and Julia (Coss) Rochford on May 25, 1921. Paul received a Bachelor of Science in Chemistry at Queens College, and LL.B. at New York University Law School in 1950 and was admitted to the New York Bar Association in 1954. After gaining his degree at Queens College, Paul served as a chemist for the Manhattan Project at Columbia University, and then continued that work and extended as a patent agent at the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission at Brookhaven Labs, Long Island, NY in 1948. After admission to the Bar in New York, Paul had a 67 year career as patent counsel for Olin Matheson in New Haven, CT and General Electric in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Schenectady, NY. Paul married Angela Leary, also a graduate of Queens College, on February 3, 1951. They enjoyed a loving marriage of 59 years and raised a family of six children. Paul was strong supporter of the arts and was appointed to various roles promoting culture in the town of Stratford, CT during the 1960's including helping to found the Childrens' Theater, serving as Chairman of the Sterling Summer Art Show, and cofounding and serving as President of the Stratford Cultural Commission. Paul was a devoted husband who was fully committed through thick and thin, a resilient and determined father who gave love unconditionally, and a good neighbor. Paul possessed an inventive mind and generous spirit. He was a lover of music, an accomplished painter and skilled golfer early in his life. He was continuously inquisitive, had a quick wit, enjoyed a bit of mischief and was generally fun to be around. Paul is predeceased by his wife Angela, and his eldest daughter Ellen. Paul is survived by five of his six children, Celia Rochford Toraya of Johns Island, SC; Timothy Rochford and wife, Ann, of East Greenwich, RI; Jane Rochford of Middletown, CT; Susan Rochford and husband, Andrew Spatz, of Wakefield, RI; and Paul Rochford Jr. of Providence, RI. Sharing in their deep loss are five grandchildren, Erin Toraya, Jules Toraya, Grace Rochford, Conor Rochford and Devin Rochford. Funeral Service will be Saturday, March 28, 2015, 4pm, at the Mulryan Funeral Home, 725 Hebron Ave., Glastonbury. Family and friends may call at the funeral home on Saturday, March 28, 2015, from 1-4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Paul's memory may be made to the Prostate Cancer Foundation, Prostate Cancer Foundation, 1250 Fourth Street, Santa Monica, CA 90401. For online condolences, please visit www.mulryanfh.com. 1/3

MANLEY--Walter M.,Jr., died on March 11, 2015, at home among friends, after a valiant struggle with cancer. He was born July 21, 1951, in Bethesda, Maryland, the eldest of the three sons of Walter M. Manley, Sr. and Josephine Henderson Manley. He attended public schools in the District of Columbia, was the first Faculty Scholar at the Georgetown University School of Languages and Linguistics, and studied also at the Sorbonne; the University of Valencia, Spain; and the University of Dakar, Senegal. He was a well-known and sought-after motivational speaker and diversity specialist. From his early days in Africa with the United States Information Agency and the Peace Corps to creating social literacy programs for African-American and Latino youths in New York City, teaching at Medgar Evers College of the City of New York, and most recently originating and participating in a wide variety of training and development programs in this country and others, he always approached exploring differences and similarities with humor, verve, and belief in the best in each individual. At the time of his death, he was serving his beloved church, Broadway United Church of Christ, as President of the Board of Stewards. He is survived by his father, Walter M. Manley, Sr., of Highland, Indiana; two brothers, Andre and Keith, of Washington, DC; four aunts, Bessie, Yvonne and Vanessa Manley, all of Hammond, Indiana, and Mary Henderson of Richmond, Virginia; two uncles, Paul Manley (Wardine) of East Chicago, Illinois, and Sherman L. Manley, Sr. (Stephanie) of Dale City, Virginia; a number of nieces, nephews, and cousins, several godchildren and a host of devoted friends and colleagues. Memorial services will be held on Saturday, March 28, 2015, at 2:00pm at the Broadway United Church of Christ, 2504 Broadway at 93rd Street, New York, New York 10025. 1/3

SCHWEBEL--Morris Mack "Mac". The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Morris Mack "Mac" Schwebel, a beloved and longtime friend of JTS. An outgoing philanthropist and passionate supporter of education, Mac was the proud recipient of the Chancellor's Medal and an honorary doctorate from JTS. He was devoted to his late wife, Irene, children (John, Annie, and Laura), seven grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair 1/3
PERRY--Alan S. 3/27/23 - 9/23/95. Missed everyday. Love, Christine 1/3

BRYAN--John Frederick, loving husband of Jane Rogers Bryan, passed away on March 20, 2015 at the age of 84 after a short struggle with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis. John was the brother of Richard, Gray, and Marsh Bryan and was the son of Gretchen Schoen Bryan and Gray MacWhorter Bryan. John graduated from Princeton University in 1952 and had been a Captain in the USMC. John was an avid golfer, an enthusiast of classical music, a volunteer with the Central Park Conservancy, and an accomplished bridge player. John is survived by his loving wife of 42 years, Jane Rogers Bryan; seven children; 17 grandchildren; and his brother Marsh. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021 on Tuesday, April 14, 2015 at 2:00pm EDT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in John's memory to the Central Park Conservancy or the New York Philharmonic. 1/3
BAUM--Phil. Gone for one year today. Living in my heart forever. Thankful for our seventy-one years together. You are never to be forgotten. Always to be missed. Bette. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Dr. Melvin, PHD, ME, Psychologist with more degrees than a thermometer. A life long scholar died 3/27/14 whose kindness, good humor and generosity will be long remembered by all who knew him. I will always love and miss him. Lizzy 1/3

HARRISON--Joyce, 84, of Metuchen, passed away in Ramsey on March 26, 2015. She was born in Brooklyn on September 25, 1930. She was a diamond saleswoman at Tiffany & Co. in New York City. Joyce was predeceased by her husband, Herbert Harrison and brother, Howard Gross. She is survived by her children, Patti (Steve) Bieth of Ramsey; Gary (Diane) Harrison of Harrington Park; grandchildren, Harrison and Lindsey; sister, Corinne Engel of Hackensack. Services will be Friday, 11am at Temple Neve Shalom, Metuchen. Interment to follow in Beth Mordecai Cemetery. Services hanndled by the Flynn and Son/Koyen Funeral Home, 319 Amboy Ave., Metuchen, NJ 08840. 1/3

BOWMAN--Judith Lofton, a resident of Bedford Village since 1966, passed away on Monday March 23rd, at home surrounded by her family. Judith was an entrepreneur, sportswoman, mother, and wife. She was the proprietor of Judith Bowman Books, an antiquarian dealer of fishing and hunting books, known among her customers and friends as "The Uncaged Woman." She and her husband, Jim, were avid fly fishermen and traveled extensively in pursuit of trout, salmon and some salt water species. Their special love was their cabin in northern Michigan and the trout of Slagle Creek. In 1980, she founded her book business, publishing biannual catalogs of rare and collectible offerings of books on fishing, hunting, and related natural history. She eventually rose to become one of the preeminent dealers in the world known for her expertise in her specialty. She retired in 2010, but continued advising collectors and other dealers. Judith was born in Lake Bluff, Illinois and grew up in Dayton, Ohio. In college, she was an art major and attended Rollins College and Denison University. She and Jim Bowman were married in 1957, and would have celebrated their 58th wedding anniversary on March 29th. Judith was multi-talented and versatile, having mastered a variety of arts and crafts. She was a gardener and woodworker, dress-maker and decoupage artist and established several successful businesses. She also was a consummate collector, frequenting estate and tag sales throughout Westchester. Her children could always anticipate a gift of a unique garage sale "find", one that always surprised and delighted them. Judith is survived by her husband Jim, and their three children, Reed Bowman of Sebring, Florida, and his wife Charlotte and children Seth and Mei; Stacy Gates of Manchester Center, Vermont, and her husband David and children Kinsey and Jamie; and Todd Bowman, of North Kingstown, Rhode Island, and his wife Keegan and son, Rhys. She is also survived by her brother Todd Lofton of McLean, Virginia. Services will be private. Donations may be made to the Bedford Free Library or the Bedford Village Fire Department, both of Bedford, NY, 10506. 1/3

SMITH--Dr. Robert H.,of Bayside Gables, New York, on March 26th, 2015, at age 91, after a long illness. Cornell Medical School, M.D., 1948. Beloved father, grandfather, brother, and uncle, he leaves behind his three sons and their spouses, Richard (Joel), Douglas (Marjorie), John (Jane), and his two grandchildren, Julian and Jordan. Born in New Paris, Ohio, Robert came to New York City after enlisting in the army to study medicine during WWII. He met his wife, Jean, at a USO dance; they were married 62 years. He practiced family medicine as an internist in Astoria and Floral Park, Queens, from the 1950s until 1992. He traveled widely across the US and Europe. He received loving care from Fatema Elnasharty and her family. Wake service will be held Sunday, March 29th, 2015 from 5-9pm, at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home LLC, 36-46 Bell Blvd., Bayside. Funeral Mass at Sacred Heart RC Church, 215-35 38th Ave., Bayside, Monday, March 30th, 11:00am. 1/3

SANDERS--Florence Hanellin (Age 99). On March 27, 2015, Florence Sanders, beloved wife for 59 years of the late Renard "Boom-Boom" Sanders; devoted mother of Toni (David) Bickart and Scott (Bridget Collins) Sanders; proud grandmother of Rabbi Noah (Nadia Kahn) and Sarah Bickart and Zachary and Jacob Sanders; loving great-grandmother of Meir and Rina Bickart; sister of Lenore Good, passed away. A longtime resident of Brooklyn, NY, she was the daughter of Dr. Nathan and Ethel Hanellin. She moved to DC in 1995 and was an intrepid traveler for many years. The funeral will take place on Sunday, March 29 at 1pm at the Adas Israel Congregation, 2850 Quebec Street, NW Washington, DC 20008. Parking at the synagogue is limited, closest Metro is Cleveland Park. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY on Monday, March 30 at 1:00 p.m. Shiva will be observed at the Bickart residence on Tuesday and Wednesday, March 31 and April 1 at 7:30pm. The family will be receiving visitors on Tuesday and Wednesday from 12 noon to 3pm. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Adas Israel Congregation. 1/3

ROONEY--Francis C. Jr. His Eminence, Timothy Michael Cardinal Dolan and the Board of Trustees of Inner-City Scholarship Fund mourn the loss of our long time trustee and friend, Francis C. Rooney Jr. Mr. Rooney was part of the first generation of business leaders led by His Eminence, Terrence Cardinal Cooke to help preserve Catholic schools in New York's inner-city neighborhoods. For more than three decades, his generosity and leadership helped thousands of low income children receive a Catholic education. Mr. Rooney has been a treasured member of the Inner-City Scholarship Fund family since its inception and will be immensely missed. With heavy hearts we will continue to build upon the great legacy he leaves behind. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his beloved wife Fran and the entire Rooney family. 1/3

ROSENBLUTH--Audrey, (nee Backer), beloved wife of the late Joseph, passed away peacefully on March 27, 2015 in New York at the age of 96. Audrey devoted her life to children as a businesswoman-New York City school teacher and owner/director of Camp Swatonah, summer camp for girls. She served on the executive committees of the Association of Independent Camps and the New York Camp Directors Association for which she received numerous awards and honors. She is survived by her children, Nancy Kleiner and Bert Rosenbluth, daughter-in-law Miriam, grandchildren Carolyn, Jamie, Eric, Jodi and Joshua, and great-grandchildren Jack, Dylan, Eli and Tate. Service Sunday, March 29, 2015, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 7th Ave., Suite 900, NY, NY 10001 or www.surpriselake.org/ donate (click on "make a donation at bottom of page and scroll down to "one time tribute".) 1/3

ROCHFORD--Paul Edward, Esq.,93, of Glastonbury CT, passed away March 25, 2015. Born the third child of Thomas Rochford and Julia (Coss) Rochford on May 25, 1921. Paul received a Bachelor of Science in Chemistry at Queens College, and LL.B. at New York University Law School in 1950 and was admitted to the New York Bar Association in 1954. After gaining his degree at Queens College, Paul served as a chemist for the Manhattan Project at Columbia University, and then continued that work and extended as a patent agent at the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission at Brookhaven Labs, Long Island, NY in 1948. After admission to the Bar in New York, Paul had a 67 year career as patent counsel for Olin Matheson in New Haven, CT and General Electric in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Schenectady, NY. Paul married Angela Leary, also a graduate of Queens College, on February 3, 1951. They enjoyed a loving marriage of 59 years and raised a family of six children. Paul was strong supporter of the arts and was appointed to various roles promoting culture in the town of Stratford, CT during the 1960's including helping to found the Childrens' Theater, serving as Chairman of the Sterling Summer Art Show, and cofounding and serving as President of the Stratford Cultural Commission. Paul was a devoted husband who was fully committed through thick and thin, a resilient and determined father who gave love unconditionally, and a good neighbor. Paul possessed an inventive mind and generous spirit. He was a lover of music, an accomplished painter and skilled golfer early in his life. He was continuously inquisitive, had a quick wit, enjoyed a bit of mischief and was generally fun to be around. Paul is predeceased by his wife Angela, and his eldest daughter Ellen. Paul is survived by five of his six children, Celia Rochford Toraya of Johns Island, SC; Timothy Rochford and wife, Ann, of East Greenwich, RI; Jane Rochford of Middletown, CT; Susan Rochford and husband, Andrew Spatz, of Wakefield, RI; and Paul Rochford Jr. of Providence, RI. Sharing in their deep loss are five grandchildren, Erin Toraya, Jules Toraya, Grace Rochford, Conor Rochford and Devin Rochford. Funeral Service will be Saturday, March 28, 2015, 4pm, at the Mulryan Funeral Home, 725 Hebron Ave., Glastonbury. Family and friends may call at the funeral home on Saturday, March 28, 2015, from 1-4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Paul's memory may be made to the Prostate Cancer Foundation, Prostate Cancer Foundation, 1250 Fourth Street, Santa Monica, CA 90401. For online condolences, please visit www.mulryanfh.com. 1/3

READ--Bertram 85, died March 16, Exeter, NH. Leaves children, William, John, and Wendy; brother Thomas; sisters Nancy, Joanne, and Helen, and four grandchildren. SPITZ--George. 1922-2015. New York Road Runners mourns the death of George Spitz, a life-long New Yorker, father of the five-borough New York City Marathon, and indefatigable supporter of running, who died March 27, 2015. He spoke his mind and fought for what he believed in. In 1976, he played a key role in transforming the New York City Marathon by devising the idea of a five-borough course and getting City officials and sponsors on board. The five-borough TCS New York City Marathon has grown into the largest in the world, with 50,530 finishers from 130 countries in 2014. 1/3

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made, in his memory, to his alma mater, Jamaica College in Kingston. They may be sent to: Jamaica College Old Boys Association of Florida, P.O. Box 824643, Pembroke Pines, Florida 33082. 1/3

LABINER--Eileen Gallagher Our adored Eileen passed away suddenly on March 16, 2015. BRINN--Murray L. of Monroe Township, NJ died Saturday morning in his home at the age of 91. He was the devoted husband of Claire for 67 years, father of Robin and Shari Brinn, and grandfather of Jonathan and Laura Prigoff. He worked as an executive at Arlen Realty and Integrated Resources. Murray was a brilliant, hard working, self-made man who was robbed of his extraordinary mind by Alzheimer's disease. Donations may be sent in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

JOHNSON--Janice. Janice Johnson (nee Platt) (Clarke), died in New York City on November 30, 2014 at age 96 of complications of COPD. A native of Bronx, NY, she also lived in Miami, St. Petersburg, FL, and Decatur, GA. Jan was born March 9, 1918 in New York City to Simon Platt and Alma Louise Broaker. As a lifelong learner, she received a certificate in art from Pratt Institute in 1938, a BA from Eckerd College in 1971, and Master of Fine Arts from New York University in 1988. Her children and friends remember her as kind, intelligent, and generous, sharing her love of art with all she met. As an advertising artist, Jan entered the advertising world on Madison Avenue. After having spent a few years in the Bay area, California during the war, she moved to Miami Beach in the 1940s, became art director of the local newspaper. She married G. Winston Clarke in 1952. In the 1950s and 1960s, she ran Jan Platt Advertising, drawing pen and ink advertising for clients and designing 98 gas stations for Esso. Having married E. Ashby Johnson, professor at Eckerd College, in Gibraltar in 1964, she moved to St. Petersburg, Florida, and became a fine artist in the impressionist style and art instructor, with numerous solo and joint exhibitions. At Suntan Art Center and the St. Petersburg Art Club, she conducted demonstrations of oil painting of still life and was past President at Suntan Art Center. Having lived two years in Taiwan in the 1980s, she became accomplished in traditional Chinese watercolor and had a solo exhibit there and three in the U.S. For her MFA at New York University, Jan had another one-woman show in Manhattan. She learned a computer brailling program in the 1990s and brailled books for the Library of Congress, including the third Harry Potter book. Jan was a world traveler and lived in London, Bangladesh, and Puerto Rico, as well as Taiwan. Jan is predeceased by her husband of 31 years E. Ashby Johnson, her sister Marjorie Dycke Ferrigno of Flushing, NY, her brothers Samuel (Bud) Platt and Bill Platt, both of the Bronx and Miami Beach. She leaves a daughter Marjorie (Maggie) Clarke of New York, NY. and stepsons Paul (Mary) Johnson of Vienna, VA and David Johnson. Condolences can be sent to Maggie Clarke at marjorieclarke@yahoo.com 1/3

OPPENHEIMER--Harry. 93, of Lauderdale by the Sea, Florida, passed away on March 9, 2015. Born in 1921 to parents Paul and Hedwig in Alzey, Germany. As a young man, he moved his family and fled the holocaust, immigrating to the United States in 1939. This act saved the lives of his brother and parents. Mr. Oppenheimer was drafted and served in WWII behind the Battle of the Bulge. He was deployed to the Philippines for the staging of the invasion of Japan. The work of J Robert Oppenheimer and the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki ironically suspended this. In addition, due to his contempt for the Nazis and fluency in German, he also was trained as an OSS agent. After the War, Harry met his wife, Ellen, also a German emigrant, in New York City. For over 50 years, they built one of the most successful retail meat businesses in the history of New York City. His clients included the likes of Barbara Streisand, Joseph Papp, Hal Holbrook, Clarence Williams III, Sir James Galway and others. The meat for the 1976 Democratic Convention held in New York City, nominating former President Jimmy Carter, was supplied by his world famous, H. Oppenheimer Company in Manhattan. Mr. Oppenheimer was an avid swimmer and scuba diver. He visited many of the seven underwater wonders of the world with his son. In the summer of 1984, he was invited to accompany the New York Zoological Society on a live aboard vessel in the Red Sea and helped them identify and document the Photoblepheron or "flashlight fish", which was indigenous to that region. Mr. Oppenheimer enjoyed the ocean and lifted weights regularly until his 85th birthday. He enjoyed travelling between his New Jersey and Florida homes. Originally a practicing reformed Jew; Harry had declared himself atheist after the tragic loss of his son, Robert, granddaughter, Elyse and many deaths of relatives in the concentration camps. His is survived by his loving wife of 62 years, Ellen; son Jeffrey, a Neurosurgeon, brother Rudolph, daughter-in-law, Missy and grandchildren, Brianna, Jenna, Paul and Benjamin. In lieu of flowers and gifts, make contributions in his name to your favorite charity. A private ceremony will be held in the future when his ashes are interred in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of South Florida as part of the Neptune Memorial Reef. 1/3

ROSENFELD--Leonor. Leonor Rosenfeld, was born in Argentina. She came to New York to raise a family with her devoted husband, Henry. Her great joys came from unconditionally loving her family and playing golf. She was the Scarsdale Golf Club Champion in 1992! Her life came to a peaceful end surrounded by her family. She will be deeply missed by her husband, her children Jessica, Diego, and Julia, her daughter-in-law Heidi, her grandchildren, and by all those she touched with her generous spirit and bright smile. 1/3

AVNER--Yehuda. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale family mourns the loss of Yehuda Avner. Yehuda was a passionate voice for Israel and the Jewish people, admired and respected by all. A gifted storyteller, Yehuda witnessed Israeli history, and he helped shape it. We extend our deepest condolences to the Avner and Sable families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Daniel Reingold President and CEO David V. Pomeranz Chief Operating Officer Hebrew Home at Riverdale by RiverSpring Health 1/3

COLICE--Matilda Finkel, passed away March 19, 2015 in the early morning surrounded by family and friends. She was the devoted wife to the late Joseph Vincent Colice and loving mother to daughter Michele (John Hiram Cadwell) Colice-Cadwell and son Dr. Gene (Elisabeth O'Hare) Leslie Colice. She was the beloved grandmother to Emily, Brooke and Laura Cadwell and Max, Ben and Anne Colice. She was also a greatgrandmother of four. She was an avid world traveler and adventurous soul. A passionate lover of life full of imagination and wonder. She was adored by all who knew her and will be dearly missed and fondly remembered every day. Interment will be in Long Island. 1/3

EPSTEIN MYLES--Jeanne A. M.D.,died on March 26, 2015 at age 92. She was born in Jersey City, NJ, the daughter of Samuel and Ray Epstein. She received her B.S. from Douglass College and her M.D. from the Medical College of Pennsylvania. An endocrinologist, she was in practice with her husband, Martin B. Myles, M.D., and was a member of the clinical faculty of the NYU School of Medicine. She was also a staff physician at the Margaret Sanger Research Bureau. Later in her career she served as Medical Director of the Middletown Community Health Center in Middletown, NY. Survived by her beloved husband Martin and daughter Anne G. Myles and many loving nieces, nephews, and cousins, Jeanne was known by all as a highly intelligent, witty, and strong-minded woman. She was devoted to her family and friends and loved reading, nature, travel, fishing, and The New York Times crossword puzzle. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. 1/3

CLEMENT--Roland C.,102, died in his Hamden, CT home on March 21, 2015. Loving husband of his late wife Muriel; beloved father. Defender of nature. As National Audubon Society Vice President, Roland championed endangered bird breeding and banning of DDT. Catalyst to numerous initiatives including Environmental Defense Fund, Norwalk's Planning and Zoning Commission, the Army Corps of Engineers environmental advisory committee, Connecticut and Rhode Island Audubon. Celebration of life was held March 24th. 1/3

DUCHAK--Douglas A. The Englewood Hospital and Medical Center community mourns the passing of Doug Duchak, our former President and CEO. Doug was a valued leader, colleague, and friend who served our hospital and community with distinction for more than 20 years. We remember him fondly and extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Merri, children, grandchild, and his entire family. Thomas C. Senter, Chairman, Board of Trustees Jay C. Nadel, Chairman, Foundation Warren Geller, President and CEO 1/3

MAGNOZZI--Mara Mahon. Was granted her angel wings on March 24th, 2015. Her final days were spent surrounded by family. Mara was born June 21st, 1927, in Livorno, Italy. She was the daughter of Dina and Mario (a soccer Olympian) and the sister of the late Mario (Mimma). In 1947 she married Michael Mahon and soon thereafter emigrated to the United States. One of her fondest memories was the sight of the Statue of Liberty from the deck of a Liberty Ship. As a war bride she encountered many challenges, but soon adapted to the many cultural changes. She was a student at Columbia Medical School until her family obligations took precedence. She was a very proud and caring mother. She took her responsibilities as a single parent quite seriously and ensured a smooth transition to adulthood for her children. Mara was proudly ahead of her time in breaking the glass ceiling. Her professional career began as a comparison shopper at Abraham & Straus, then on to the fashion director at Korvettes; culminating as the Senior Vice President of the International Division of May Department stores. She gained worldwide recognition for her knowledge and skills in the areas of textiles and fashion, as well as her exuberant and inimitable spirit and personality. Her experience in international commerce was sought out by specialists in her field from North America, Europe and Asia. She was a life and career mentor to many. Her professional and personal travels took her to many countries around the world where she expressed her special appreciation for cultures and their nuances. Her time was not solely devoted to her work, as she was a great lover of the arts and music. Her greatest love was for her family. She devoted her time and love to them across the generations. She was the beloved mother of Christine (late John), Dean (Hilda), Lisa (Dennis) and Kerry. She was also the proud grandmother of seven girls and great-grandmother of two children. The family request that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in her name to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105. Send condolences to stellatofuneralhomes.com. A memorial celebration of her life will be held at a later date. 1/3

ROSENBLUTH--Audrey, (nee Backer), beloved wife of the late Joseph, passed away peacefully on March 27, 2015 in New York at the age of 96. Audrey devoted her life to children as a businesswoman-New York City school teacher and owner/director of Camp Swatonah, summer camp for girls. She served on the executive committees of the Association of Independent Camps and the New York Camp Directors Association for which she received numerous awards and honors. She is survived by her children, Nancy Kleiner and Bert Rosenbluth, daughter-in-law Miriam, grandchildren Carolyn, Jamie, Eric, Jodi and Joshua, and great-grandchildren Jack, Dylan, Eli and Tate. Service Sunday, March 29, 2015, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 7th Ave., Suite 900, NY, NY 10001 or www.surpriselake.org/ donate (click on "make a donation at bottom of page and scroll down to "one time tribute".) 1/3

GLASS--Gilbert W.,died after a brief illness in Roosevelt Hospital on February 21, 2015. He was 98 years old. He is survived by remaining members of the Glaschman family, Barbara Hellman and Robert Schey, and by his nephews Edmund and Jay Glass, and other members of the Glass Family. A longtime resident of Manhattan, he was born and grew up in Newark, NJ, the son of the late Sarah and Samuel Glass. He and his two brothers attended public schools there, and graduated from Weequahic High School. He then set out to explore the United States, traveling extensively to many parts of the country. Inspired by the professional and financial achievements of an uncle in Chicago, he returned to Newark and enrolled in the Newark College of Engineering (now New Jersey Institute of Technology), earning a BS degree in mechanical engineering in 1941. During World War II he was employed by the United States Navy, and at the end of the war decided to start a business. He remained in Newark, becoming a sales representative nationally in 1946 for major manufacturers of engineering equipment. He became successful quickly and as the business expanded he began to hire a sales force, many of whom remained with him until his retirement in 1975. During his years in business Gil developed friendships that flourished with people in his organization as well as with business contacts, most notably John Morris of Louisville, KY. His warm, extroverted personality, huge smile and bow ties, as well as his keen intelligence left lasting impressions on almost everyone he encountered. During the early 1950's Gil moved to Manhattan, where he lived for the rest of his life. He settled in Greenwich Village, where his free spirit and artistic interests thrived, and in the early 1960's, he moved to the Upper West Side, where he lived for the rest of his life. Gill Glass loved New York....he walked everywhere until his mid-90s....connecting with people, taking the children of friends on jaunts they still, now in their middle age years, remember vividly. He was every kid's "Uncle Gil." He enjoyed all the musical opportunities of Harlem with his friend "Schey," the Big Band and Jazz eras, the Metropolitan Opera and all that Lincoln Center offered, the museums, and his "front yard" across the street from his residence, Central Park, which he simply loved. Strangers befriended him, drawn to his warm smile and genuine interest in them and everything around him. His extraordinarily curious intellect led him to travel extensively, becoming fluent in Spanish during his many visits to Mexico, where he continued to expand his business. Gil Glass was an "original." He loved people and they loved him. His personal warmth and genuine interest, as well as an extraordinary sensitivity to the needs of others, led to his involvement with an extensive number of organizations. In retirement, he devoted himself to managing his finances, philanthropy and "living." He traveled extensively throughout the world but retained a particular love for Mexico and Central America. In Guatemala he was instrumental through his financial support in helping to establish educational opportunities for indigenous children and impoverished women, providing support financially to women in the region who struggled to support their families. These loans had to be repaid, teaching business responsibility as well as basic business skills to the recipients. Today, Pevi Fundap is a successful educational operation in Guatemala. Throughout his long and productive life he had a major interest in philanthropy. The spectrum of his interests was extensive. He ferreted out little-known charities that captured his interest, supporting them long before they were well-known. He also was a major supporter of established organizations and had on-going associations with them. He was a long -time supporter of his alma mater, the New Jersey Institute of Technology, where a library was named for him, recognizing his lifelong support. He was a very early supporter of YouthBuild USA, helping Dorothy Stoneman get support for the youth of the Bronx from union members of the Building Trades, teaching them skills that enabled them to rebuild abandoned buildings. Today YouthBuild USA is a national organization, receiving support from prominent donor organizations and the government, and is expanding its activities to other continents. He was also involved through the years with The Delta Society (now named Pet Partners), Doctors Without Borders, The United Jewish Appeal, The American Technion Society, The Smithsonian Institution, Nature Conservancy, Green Chimneys, The New York Public Library, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Planned Parenthood, The Central Park Conservancy, The American Museum of Natural History, WNYC, WQXR, the Institutions at Lincoln Center, The Doe Society, Earthwatch USA, The American Field Service, Accion International and others. He had a deeplyrooted concern for those he felt needed his help and whom he wanted to help, and for the organizations whose work he admired and wanted to support. He lived a simply wonderful life, on his terms. Our special thanks go to Dr. Lynn Ratner and Dr. Dialecti Voudouris and their entire warm and wonderful staff who cared for him during those last difficult months. We also thank the staff at 25 Central Park West, his longtime residence, who looked out for his well-being, and with whom he enjoyed mutual friendships during the years he lived there. And our profound thanks also to a friend for many years, Pat Duffy, who has always been there with his steadying support and friendship. Gil's mantra was "to love and be loved in return." He did, and he was. Funeral services were private. A celebration of his life is being planned for a future date. For additional information, call (212) 581-3640. Contributions honoring him can be made to: The Gilbert W. Glass Scholarship Fund, c/o The Albert Dorman Honors College, NJIT Foundation, The New Jersey Institute of Technology, 323 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd., Office of Advancement, Newark, NJ 07103 Attn: Joel P. Bloom, President, or to a charity of your choice. 1/3

SZE--Morgan Chuan-Yuan, 98, died at home in Portsmouth, NH on March 20, 2015 after a period of declining health. He was born on May 27,1916 (mistakenly listed as 1917 when he entered this country) in Tianjin, China, son of S.C. Thomas Sze, a 1905 Cornell educated engineer, and Elsie Sun Sze. He graduated from the Peking American School as valedictorian in 1935 and entered Tsinghua University in Beijing but was unable to complete his studies there because of political unrest. He transferred to M.I.T. in 1937, receiving his B.S. in 1939 and doctorate in 1941, both in chemical engineering. An internationally recognized engineer, he spent time at DuPont, Hydrocarbon Research, Lummus, where he rose to V.P. of Research and Development, and Wheelabrator-Frye. He was the author of numerous scientific papers and holder of some 80 U.S. patents. Honors included a 1969 award by the Chinese Institute of Engineers in recognition of outstanding contributions to chemical processes and Chemical Engineering magazine's Personal Achievement Award in 1976. That same year he was elected to the National Academy of Engineering, one of the highest professional honors accorded an engineer. He had an enduring belief in the role of science and technology for the betterment of individuals' lives and society as a whole. Morgan had a firm belief that a broad and deep education offered one the best opportunity for a successful life and that knowledge in one field could lead to insights or discoveries in another. He was deeply appreciative of the opportunity to start a new life in his adoptive country and greatly valued his American citizenship. He had a deep sense of responsibility and cared for many extended family members who came to this country as refugees. Morgan was a true gentleman and will be greatly missed by his longtime neighbors, his caregivers and his extended family. He was predeceased by his wife, Agnes, and his siblings, Gladys Sun, Dorothy Liu, Palmer and Y.Y. Sze. He is survived by sons, Karl and wife Kay of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, Arthur and wife Carol of Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Morgan C.W. and wife Bobbi of Hong Kong, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the M.I.T. Memorial Undergraduate Scholarship Fund in memory of Dr. Morgan C. Sze at: M.I.T. Director of Memorial Gifts, 600 Memorial Drive, W98-500, Cambridge, MA 02139. 1/3

Bass, Sr. He died March 5, 2015 at The Motion Picture Hospital, Woodland Hills, CA. Celebrated for his wit, talent and cherished friendships. Memorials may be made to The Actors' Fund. 1/3

BURNS--Perry Lorimer, 79, resident of Greenwich CT, died February 28, 2015 due to Lewy Body Disease. A graduate of St. Paul's School and Princeton, he served in the U.S. Navy and spent he entire career in institutional equity sales and fixed income research on Wall Street. He was a board member of the Literacy Volunteers of America, Stamford/Greenwich and the Greenwich Council, Boys Scouts of America. Beloved husband of Joan Blissert and loving father to Lorimer (David Benson), Perry, Jr. (Jolie Parcher), Samantha (Kip Robbins) and Robert. A memorial service will on May 15, 2015 at 11:00am at the Stanwich Church, 202 Taconic Rd, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Greenwich Council, Boys Scouts of America. 1/3

DuBOIS--Peter C.,died peacefully on March 24 at 80. He was a journalist and editor at Barron's Weekly for over 30 years. He became Foreign Editor and began a weekly column called the International Trader in 1980 until his retirement in 2000. His passion for art lead to an eclectic collection which included ancient Chinese jades, Southeast Asian sculpture, Outsider Art and other contemporary works. He particularly enjoyed supporting emerging artists. Peter is survived by Helen, his wife of 56 years, daughter, Laura, son, Christopher, grandchildren, Simone and Desmond, and his half-sister Anne Dowling. A memorial service is will be held on Saturday, April 11 at 11am at Grace Church, 802 Broadway at 10th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Doctors without Borders. 1/3

TERRY--William Holt "Will." Born July 25, 1932, died March 27, 2015. Beloved son of Davidson College, minister, dean, friend, and mentor. Service will be May 2, 2015 at 1pm, at Davidson College Presbyterian Church, Davidson, NC. Memorials may be sent to the William Holt Terry Scholarship at Davidson Col- lege. Friends of Will 1/3

BOGDONOFF--Morton. Morton David Bogdonoff, a professor of medicine at Weill Cornell Medical School for forty years, died on Sunday, March 1st in Calvary Hospice, his family at his side. He had been a patient at New York Hospital for the previous month. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Mary, and her sons Robert Welt of China, and Frederick Welt of Utah. His children by his previous marriage, Reid, Ladd, Jesse, and a daughter Drue, all reside in California. Born in Brooklyn on December 8, 1925, the son of Myron and Minna Bogdonoff, he was a graduate of Erasmus Hall, and a student at Cornell University in Ithaca. He graduated from Cornell University Medical School in the accelerated medical school program in 1948. He was a resident at Cornell Medical School until 1950 when he went to Baltimore as a senior resident at the National Heart Institute. He spent his remaining residency years at Duke University Medical School where he was Chief Resident in 1954-55, and professor of medicine in the Division of Endocrinology and Director of the Division of Behavioral Medicine until 1970 when he became Chairman of the Department of Medicine at Abraham Lincoln School of Medicine of the Illinois School of Medicine in Chicago. In 1975 he returned to his alma mater, Cornell Medical School. From 1977-78 he was a fellow at the Center for the Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford in Palo Alto. He was editor of the journal Archives of Internal Medicine from 1967-1976. During his years at Cornell he was the director of the Living at Home Program with the Commonwealth Fund and the Pew Memorial Trust Consortium as well as co chief of the Geriatric Division. For many years he was tutor to the third year students at Cornell and attending physician at New York Hospital. There will be a memorial service in the near future. 1/3

PERKINS--Donald S. Donald S. Perkins, of North Palm Beach, FL, retired CEO and a Chicago civic leader, died at his home in Northfield, IL, on March 25, 2015, at the age of 88. Mr. Perkins was named President of Jewel in 1965 at the age of 38 and then CEO and Chairman of the Board in 1970. His leadership at Jewel was marked by rapid expansion and exploration of multiple retail formats. He retired from Jewel in 1983 and devoted himself to championing strong corporate governance, serving on numerous for-profit and non-profit boards, including Time Warner, AT&T, Cummins Engine, the Ford Foundation and Northwestern University. Mr. Perkins was also instrumental in the founding of the Civic Committee of the Commercial Club of Chicago and served as its first chairman. Mr. Perkins was born in St. Louis, MO, and received his Bachelor's degree from Yale University and his Master's in Business Administration from Harvard Business School. He served in the Merchant Marine during World War II and in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War. His survivors include his wife of 30 years, Jane Phillips Perkins; his brother Bob Perkins and sister Joan Gerrard; his children Betsy Perkins Hill, Susan Perkins, Frank Phillips, and Elizabeth Phillips-Sorich, and daughter-in-law Pat Mayland Perkins; eight grandchildren; and a great granddaughter. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Phyllis Babb Perkins; his son, Jervis Perkins; and his grandson, Jeremy Hill. A celebration of his life will be held from 3 to 6pm on Saturday, May 16, at Shore Acres Club, Lake Bluff, IL. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Donald S. Perkins Scholarship Fund at Northwestern University, c/o Alumni Relations, 1201 Davis Street, Evanston, IL 60208. 1/3

PORTER--Morton B.,90, of Naples, FL passed away March 17, 2015. Donations in his memory may be made to Hillel at Ohio State University, where our parents met at the 1946 Seder. 1/3

RUBIN--Jerome, died on March 15 at his home in Marlborough, MA after retiring from practice at Held & Rubin Architects in East Meadow, NY for many years. He is mourned by a loving family and many dear friends. 1/3

SANDER--Fred. The members of the New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute mourn the loss of our valued member Dr. Fred Sander. He was a well respected author, an esteemed clinician, and a sought after instructor. He was a pioneer in applying psychoanalysis to the understanding of couples and families and conveyed his insights in his writings and in courses he taught in our Extension and Psychotherapy Programs. He also applied psychoanalytic understanding to theater, co-leading the popular Psychoanalysis and the Theater Series for many years. We extend our deepest condolences to his family Ian D. Buckingham, MD, President 1/3

HAYES--William (Bill) Abbot Jr.,former partner of Walter Frank & Company, specialist brokers, passed away peacefully March 18. A Brown University graduate, Bill received his MBA from Wharton School of Business and joined New York Life Insurance in 1960. His career included managing the ITT and Hughes Aircraft pension funds. He was a member of the Union League Club as well as the New York Society of Security Analysts, where he served as President from 1995-1997. He traveled extensively in retirement with his beloved companion, Shirley Zhu. He is survived by his brother, Charles Hayes of Annapolis, MD, 10 nieces and nephews and 22 great nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his parents, William and Hazel Hayes; sisters Margaret Hayes Waggoner and Jane Hayes Sullivan; and great niece, Emma Jane Taft-Lockard. Funeral services will be held April 11th at 11:00, Holy Name Parish in Springfield MA. Burial immediately following. A celebration of Bill's life will be held April 19th in Annapolis, MD. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to VNSNY Haven Hospice at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. The family wishes to thank VNSNY Haven Hospice for its exemplary care of Bill in his final days. 1/3
KATZ--Joan. Next door neighbor and fellow Smithie, longtime dear friend: some relationships are irreplaceable. Heartfelt condolences to all family from our family. Judy Chasanoff 1/3

LIU--Micky, loving and devoted son of Henry and Louise Liu, brother of Michael and May Liu has passed away on March 17, 2015 in NYC. Micky a gifted graduate of Bronx High School of Science, with a BS degree from Columbia University, was an IT professional with over 25 year career in financial and media industry. He's deeply loved and missed. 1/3

RUBIN--Martin, died peacefully on March 24 at 92. He is survived by the love of his life Natalie to whom he was married for 68 years. He was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. He was a classic member of the Greatest Generation who landed in France and fought in the Battle of the Bulge and marched into Germany as part of Patton's Third Army. While he was in the US waiting to ship off to Japan the war ended and he met Natalie and his life's course was set. He lived the motto that it is not having what you want but wanting what you have that makes a man happy. And in his beloved Natalie and his children and grandchildren and greatgrandchildren of whom he was so proud he had what he wanted and he lived a rich and happy life. 1/3

SOLOMON--Blanche, on March 26, 2015. Beloved wife of Dr. Howard Solomon. Devoted mother of Jordan and Evan. Dear sister of Rosalie Rosen and sister-in-law of Lon Rosen. Adored aunt of Jared, Joshua and Jillian. Services Sunday 11am at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation. 1/3

GOLDENBERG--C. Martin. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted and longtime member, C. Martin Goldenberg, beloved husband of Flower, father of Aaron, Daniel (Sara), and Rebecca. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

YIM--Kwan Ha, of Valley Cottage, NY passed away on March 28, 2015 after an illness. He was 85 years old. Born in North Korea in 1929, he was forced to flee to South Korea. He fought for the South Korean Army in the Korean War and was awarded a U.S. Bronze Star for Valor. He came to the U.S. in 1954 and attended Dartmouth College graduating Phi Beta Kappa in 1957. He then attended Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy receiving his PhD in 1963. For 50 years, Kwan Ha was a Professor at Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY. He was devoted to the peace and human rights movement in Korea. An avid writer, he wrote books on Asian politics and contributed articles to the letter to the editor page in The New York Times over 25 years on Korean Politics. He acted as special assistant to former South Korean opposition leader Kim Young-Sam who later became President of Korea. A grateful husband and proud father and grandfather, Kwan Ha is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years, Elizabeth, his four sons, Anthony, Peter, Richard and Andrew, daughters-in-law, Carolina and Lina, and grandsons, Brian, Eric, Martin and James. A wake service is Monday, March 30, 2-4pm and 6-8pm, at Hannemann Funeral Home, 88 South Broadway in Nyack, NY. Funeral Mass is on Tuesday, March 31, 10am at St. Anns Church, 16 Jefferson St. in Nyack.

GOLDENBERG--C. Martin, on March 27, 2015. Beloved and precious husband of Flower Goldenberg. MARTINEZ--Lionel R. Beloved husband of Barbara Fultz for 46 years, died on Friday, March 27. Filmmaker, photographer, author, and very proud New Yorker, he will be lovingly remembered by Ginger, Peppy, Tom, Michael, Ann, Ted, John, Stephen, Kate, and their families and friends. He will be missed for his personal warmth, fun sense of humor, and his never-ending fascination with the way the world works. There will be a private service. In lieu of flowers, donations in Lionel's memory may be made to the Boys & Girls Club of America, 1275 Peachtree Street NW, Atlanta GA 30309 or American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK 73123-1718. 1/3

WOOD--James, of New York, NY, passed away on Thursday, March 26, 2015, after a long illness. He was 85. Wood was born in 1930 in Newcastle Upon Tyne, United Kingdom, and there began a storied career in food retailing. From 1965 to 1980, he was a senior executive at Cavenham Foods and the Chief Executive Officer of Cavenham's international retail operations. In 1973, Cavenham acquired Grand Union and Wood was tapped by Cavenham's Chairman, Sir James Goldsmith, to lead the U.S. supermarket chain. In 1980, Wood became the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, where he led an historic turnaround of the troubled retailer. That turnaround was lauded by analysts as "an outstanding success" and in 1989 Wood was named the outstanding CEO of the decade in food retailing by Financial World magazine. Wood was a director of Schering-Plough Corporation, Asarco, Inc. and Datawatch Corporation. He also served as a Director of the USO and UNICEF and was Chairman of UNICEF's North American Corporate Alliance of CEOs. Wood was a passionate and energetic leader and a loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather. He led a rich and full life. His family and friends mourn his loss and will forever cherish his memory. Wood is survived by his wife of 61 years, Colleen Wood, two daughters, Julie Howard and Sarah Cox, and four grandchildren, Elizabeth Howard, James Howard, Maxwell Cox and Victoria Cox. 1/3

SMITH--Joseph Robert, pianist, vocal coach, music teacher, and lecturer, died on March 23rd, 2015. His death came as a sudden interruption of vigorous life. He is survived by his colleagues and students who loved him for himself and for his musical insights, and by his loving brother Daniel. He was born on July 4th, 1948, the son of Robert Paul Smith and Elinor Goulding Smith. He reveled in finding piano works of real musical value that had fallen unjustly into obscurity. He had professional interests in Field, Weber, Griffes, and Grieg, and a special devotion to the music of Percy Grainger and Robert Schumann. By his wishes there will be no traditional funeral. Colleagues expect to host a memorial event at Montclair State College in New Jersey. josephsmithpianist.com will remain online. Information on memorial events will be posted there when available. For videos of Joseph, search YouTube for "joseph smith steinway1901."

ANDERSEN--Marianne. Retired psychologist, passed away peacefully on March 21, 2015.
