ENDERS--Dr. March died peacefully in her home in Georgetown the morning of March 26, 2015. She was born in Hartford, CT on March 29, 1929 and spent her childhood years in Avon, CT. She studied Intellectual History at Oberlin College. Her career in medicine started with Yale University School of Medicine and she eventually became an associate professor in the Department of Medicine, Section of Rehabilitation Medicine at George Washington University. She was board certified in rehabilitation medicine (a physiatrist). She gave birth to her only son at the age of 47 and devoted herself to his development. She was extraordinarily loving and giving with her time and energy to those she was close to. In recent years, she took a particular joy in interacting with her grandchildren. While traveling through Europe on a summer break from college, she visited Switzerland and discovered the joys of hiking and alpine life. She continued to visit the same valleys in the Swiss Alps nearly every year since for more than sixty years. She shared her love of hiking in the mountains with her husband and son. Together they explored the mountains and loved finding and photographing rare alpine plants The family took their passion for flowers back home, where traveled throughout West Virginia searching for rare orchids and plants. She had a deep passion for dogs and horses. There were a series of energetic Springer Spaniels in her Georgetown home. She also had a strong bond with her horse, Wiecor, and nurtured his development into a top level dressage horse. She rode dressage and later enthusiastically encouraged and sponsored young riders. When she could no longer ride, she delighted in carefully choosing the music and designing the choreography for her riders' dressage shows. She was planning for the next decade in her recent purchase of a second dressage horse, named Louboutin. March possessed a powerful intellect and nurtured a lifelong interest in intellectual and European history, and archaeology. She loved watercolor painting, mostly of landscapes. She created hundreds of paintings and showed her work several times. March Enders was the daughter of Alice Talcott Enders and Ostrom Enders, president of Hartford National Bank and Trust Co., great-granddaughter of Thomas O. Enders, a founder and president of Aetna Life Insurance Co., a niece of John F. Enders, a nobel-prize-winning virologist, a direct descendent of Rev. Thomas Hooker, founder of Hartford, and of John Talcott, a member of the first group of settlers in Connecticut. March will be greatly missed by her husband, Wallace R. Kornack, her son, Dr. Thomas Whitmore Kornack, her daughter-in-law Dr. Elizabeth Foley, grandchildren Wallace Snow and Elias Enders, her brother Anthony Enders of Manhattan, and her many beloved nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her brother, Thomas O. Enders. A memorial service will be held at a later date in Waterford, Connecticut, where she spent many happy summers with her extended family on the shores of Long Island Sound. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Nature Conservancy in West Virginia.

UTEVSKY--Ruth, 94, of Lawrence, NY, died peacefully at her home on March 31, 2015. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Julian, son Daniel and grandson Stefan. She is survived by her loving son Michael Dov Utevsky and his wife Alexandra Leighton, daughter Naomi Lima and her husband Tom Lima, grandchildren Anna, Alex and Amanda Utevsky, step-grandchildren Lorraine and Tom Lima, and great-granddaughter Millie Ann Lima. She graduated from Hunter College and Smith College School for Social Work (MSW), and worked most of her life as a social worker and therapist. She believed fiercely in social justice for all. She was a confidante, advisor and inspiration to countless friends of all generations. She will be missed by so many. At her wish, no funeral will be held. A memorial service will be held at her home on May 30. 1/3

WALDEN-- Dr. William D. Passed away on April 3rd sleeping peacefully at the age of 85 in New York City. At the age of 6, he met Elinor Klotz, who later became his beloved wife of 62 years. Bill graduated from NYU Medical School. As a board certified OB/GYN at NY Presbyterian Hospital. Bill was one of the last solo practitioners who always sat through labor with his patients. His work was his passion. His patients adored him. During his career, he delivered over 5000 babies and, as he liked to say, "I never dropped one". Bill is survived by his wife Ellie, two children: Jonathan Walden (Sonya) and Elizabeth Corwin (Scott) and five grandchildren: Harrison, Zachary, Ryan, Amelia, and Sarah. Burial will be private. Please consider a donation in Bill's name directed to the Dawn Greene Hospice at Mary Manning Walsh Home 1/3

ROMANOFF-- Gerald "Jerry" We have just lost our most precious husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. Jerry would have been 79 on April 30. His body succumbed to complications due to cancer on April 4, 2015. Jerry loved life, and he loved all of us, his family and his friends. He had an adventurous spirit, and was always up for everything. He loved working, hunting, opera, poker, exotic travel, Broadway musicals and working around the house. Most of all he loved being with us, just hanging out. He devoted himself in a leadership capacity to the betterment of every community and business organization with which he came in contact. He did everything in life that he had wanted to do. Jerry truly leaves his mark on the world. The heartbroken family he leaves behind are Sheryl, Valerie, Richard and Debra, Robert, Zak and Mila, Joy, Danny, Doug and Tal, Natasha, Sabrina, Nicholas, Alexander, and Zoe. The funeral will be at Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, on Monday, April 6, 2015 at 1PM. 1

SPARER-- Tanya It is with profound sadness that we announce the death of Tanya Sparer, on April 2, 2015, at the age of 83. Born in New York City, Tanya attended Taft High School, City College and the Hunter School of Social Work. She married Edward Sparer, and until his death in 1983, they worked together in ways both big and small to make the world a better place. Tanya was a psychiatric social worker, thoroughly devoted to her patients' well being, and an endless seeker of intellectual, spiritual, and religious enrichment. She is survived by her three children, Ellen, Michael and Carol and their spouses, Harald, Jo, and David; her seven grandchildren, Esther, Emily, Madeline, Arik, Hannah, Abigail and Samuel; her aunt Hilda, with whom she shared so much of her life; and her many close friends and relatives. None of us can imagine a world without Tanya. We will miss forever her warmth, generosity and love. A memorial service will be held on April 6, 2015, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, on Amsterdam and 76th Street. Burial to follow at the Montrepose Cemetery in Kingston, New York. 1

LEIGHTON--Jerry. Passed away on March 21,2015 in Sea Cliff, NY at 76. Beloved husband of Polly and father of Greg (Rhonda), David (Lauren) and Josh. Grandfather of Zach, Mitchell, Jen, Ally. Brother of Phyllis (Dennis) Josephy. Loyal family man and friend. His 50 year toy industry career was legendary as a successful entrepreneur with GLJ, ARCO and as an executive and mentor at Mattel. Jerry will be remembered for his generosity, fun-loving personality and humor. He loved the simple pleasures of life and lived in the moment. His big heart and compassion were extraordinary. MCGINTY--Captain James D. Age 94. Jim sailed with US Lines for 45 years. He served with USN-FAW1 from 1943-1946. A 1941 graduate of the NYMMA, he loved the sea and a good yarn. His daughter, Kathie and granddaughter, Gaia wish him fair skies. Memorial in May, Old Lyme, CT. 1/3

ROCKEFELLER--Mary Molly" Gillett, 93, passed away peacefully with family by her side on Monday, March 30, 2015 at her home in Paul Smith's, NY. She was born on September 26, 1921 in Pelham Manor, NY, the younger of two daughters of Harriet (Duncan) and William Van Kirk Gillett. She was presented at the Westchester and Baltimore Cotillions in 1938. She was a member of the Junior League of Pelham Manor, volunteered with the American Red Cross during the Second World War and became an active member of many organizations including the New York Botanical Garden and the National Trust for Scotland Foundation USA and served as President of the Board of Lady Managers of the Osborn (formally the Miriam Osborn Home). She married William Rockefeller in 1947 and the couple raised their family in Rye, NY. Mrs. Rockefeller was married twice. William Rockefeller predeceased her in 1990. Her second husband, Jeremiah Milbank, died in 2007. She is survived by her three daughters: Mary Gillett Burchell (Ian) of Leighton Buzzard, UK, Edith Rockefeller Laird of Seattle, WA and Kapalua, HI and Sarah Rockefeller Bogdanovitch (Philip) of Paul Smith's, NY. She is also survived by her six grandchildren, William Gillett Fogarty (Christine Kiriacopoulus) of Beverly, MA, Michael Avery Gillett (Whitney Ilg) of Marblehead, MA, Edith McKee "Tracy" Laird of Seattle, WA and New York, NY, Rebecca Stillman Hession (Matthew) of Andover, MA, Philip Matthew Bogdanovitch (Christine Dupuis) of Kailua-Kona, HI, Sarah Goodsell Bogdanovitch of Jacksonville, FL, and eight great-grandchildren. She was an aunt and dear friend to many. A family memorial celebration will be held later this year. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her name to the New York Botanical Garden at 2900 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458-5126 or the National Trust for Scotland Foundation USA at 45 School Street, Boston, MA 02106. 1/3

PURNELL--Marguerite H. (Maggie) of Locust Valley, Fishers Island and New York, NY passed away peacefully at home on March 26, 2015 after a long illness. She was 94. Maggie was predeceased by her beloved husband of 45 years Richard I. and her adored sisters Constance H. Oliver O'Neil and Audrey H. Hilliard. She is survived by her daughter Marguerite W. Purnell, her son Peter F. Purnell, her four grandchildren James, Theodore, Robert and Henry. She is also survived by her cherished sister Sally H. Childs and numerous nieces and nephews, on whom she doted. Maggie's energy and enthusiasm were boundless, and she put those traits to good use, first as a daughter, sister, aunt, wife, mother, and friend and later as a long serving board member of many charitable organizations. In her 20's she worked under the tutelage of Dr. Howard A. Rusk in the nascent field of physical rehabilitation, an area of interest that would remain near and dear to her throughout her life. She served on many boards and was a tireless champion for each one, from her early years with the Junior League to her involvement with the Rusk Institute (and later the World Rehabilitation Fund), the International Center for the Disabled, FOCUS, the Venture Fund, the Episcopal Mission Society, Classroom, Inc. and in particular her lengthy involvement with the Boys Club of New York and The Central Park Conservancy, where she was one of the four founders of the Women's Committee. Maggie was a quintessential people person, and she demonstrated it every day through her profound love for her family, her friends and those whose causes she championed. She particularly liked to empower young people, whether through education, rehabilitation, job opportunities and/or recreational opportunities. Renowned for her charm and her charisma, she lit up every room she entered. Truly, she was one of a kind. A memorial service to celebrate Maggie's life will be held at a later date. A private interment was held at Fishers Island. Services by Dodge-Thomas. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Maggie's name to the World Rehabilitation Fund (worldrehabfund.org), the Boys Club of New York (bcny.org) or the Central Park Conservancy (centralparknyc.org).

DWORKIN, Sylvia Raab passed away in her home in San Francisco on March 31st, after a courageous two-year battle with pancreatic cancer. She was 63. Born in New York and raised in Englewood, NJ, and Elkins Park, PA, Sylvia knew from her first trip to California as a teenager that the Golden State was where she wanted to live, and in the 1970s not long after graduating from Hunter College she moved to San Francisco. Sylvia pursued pre-med studies at Mills College and began medical school at the University of Alabama before switching to business and obtaining an MBA there. Returning to California, she was the founding marketing director at the College of Professional Studies of the University of San Francisco. After marriage and the birth of her first daughter, she dedicated herself to her family and friends, and to community service, notably as President of the Hamlin School Parent Association and as a founder of the Friends of the Carol Frank Buck Breast Care Center at the University of California at San Francisco. Sylvia's true vocation, however, was practicing kindness; she was an extraordinary listener and friend, and had a rare gift for accepting people on their own terms. She is survived by her husband of 31 years, Peter Dworkin; her daughters, Kate and Meredith Dworkin; her mother Theodora Raab, sisters Jamie and Victoria Raab, and many friends who share in the sorrow of her passing. A celebration of her life is being planned for a future date. For information, write to sylviadworkinmemorial@ yahoo.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network. 1/3

FAHEY--Joseph P.,died March 4, 2015 in the Dominican Republic. He is survived by his wife, Susan, and sons William and John Adam and grandson Jack. Memorial service will be held on April 25th at 11 am at St. Gregory's Church, 144 West 90th Street, NYC. 1/3

LAIBE--John 1928-2015 John William Laibe, of Greenwich, CT and Nantucket, MA, passed away March 29 after a prolonged illness. Born February 4, 1928 to the late Mark William and Lauretta Hayes Laibe and raised in Akron, Ohio, John attended Buchtel High School and Cornell University, where he earned a Bachelor of Mechanical Engineering in 1951. John was a member of Psi Upsilon fraternity and member of the track team. Among his fondest memories of his Cornell days was a trip to England he made with the track team, in which they competed against Oxford and Cambridge and met Roger Banister. After graduation, John went to work for Enjay Chemical company, leaving after two years to serve as an officer in the U.S. Navy, first at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and then in Subic Bay, Philippines. Upon his return to the U.S. he rejoined Enjay (future Exxon), where he spent his entire career, rising to Vice President and President positions in New York, Hong Kong, Miami and Darien, CT, retiring in 1993. These postings gave the entire Laibe family many treasured experiences in faraway lands. In addition to his Exxon tenure, his career included service on various corporate and community boards of directors, including Chairman of Acheson Chemical Company and Cell-O-Core, whose founder introduced John to his adored wife of 57 years, Ann Jesse Davis Laibe, who survives him. As the chairman of Acheson Industries, a manufacturer of specialty chemicals, John led the company to a successful sale to Imperial Chemical Industries (ICI) in 1998. In memory of his classmate Howard A. Acheson Jr. he and Acheson Industries endowed the Laibe/Acheson Professor of Business Management and Leadership Studies at Cornell. His community leadership extended to organizations as diverse as the Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra, St. Mary's School of Greenwich, and Sankaty Head Golf Club. John's optimism in both life and business was unquenchable and infectious, and it combined with a tenacity that would never allow him to give up on any challenge. He would in turn challenge others to share that outlook and to seek out creative ways to surmount their own obstacles. Anyone approaching him could expect a quip, an uplifting comment, insight and an offer of help. John held a lifelong passion for the game of golf, which he pursued as a member of the Stanwich Club, Sankaty Head Golf Club and the Royal Hong Kong Golf Club, along with countless other courses around the world. It was the setting for both business and personal interaction. For over fifty years, he eagerly anticipated their annual visit to Nantucket for its beauty and the prospect of golf at Sankaty. In addition to Ann, he is survived by daughter Anne Laibe Bertolino and her husband Jerome, of Boxborough Mass.; sons Marc and his wife Liza, of Rowayton Conn.; Christopher and his wife Lynne of New Orleans, La.; and Timothy, of Rochester N.Y., along with 16 grandchildren. His daughter Constance Laibe Hays preceded him in death in 2005; her beloved husband John is a close member of the family. A mass of Christian burial will be held April 7 at 11:00am at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made in John's name to the Sankaty Head Foundation, PO Box 875, Siasconset, MA 02564. 1/3

OGDEN--Elizabeth "Biff" Kohnstamm, died peacefully on March 6th at the age of 94. Biff was loved by a great many people of three generations. NEPOMNYASHCHY-- Catharine. Ann Whitney Olin Professor of Russian Literature and Culture and Chair of the Barnard College Slavic Department, died on March 21. A native of New Jersey, Nepomnyashchy earned a B.A. in Russian Literature and French Literature and an M.A. in French Literature at Brown. She then pursued her Ph.D. in the Department of Slavic Languages at Columbia. She joined the faculty at Barnard College in 1987. Nepomnyashchy was the first woman to direct the Harriman Institute (2001-2009). She drew academics, writers, chiefs of state, ambassadors, public intellectuals, conceptual artists, dancers, and others to the Institute, and she broadened the geopolitical range to include Central Asia and Georgia and she made it a center of interdisciplinary inquiry. She was honored as the Institute's Alumna of the Year in 2012. Nepomnyashchy was on the Harriman Institute's Executive Committee and its National Advisory Council, and was affiliated with Barnard's Comparative Literature and Human Rights programs. She served as President of the American Association of Teachers of Slavic and East European Language (AATSEEL), as well as member of the Kennan Institute's Advisory Council and the Board of Directors of the American Association for the Advancement of Slavic Studies. She chaired the Executive Committee of the Slavic Division of the Modern Language Association. In 2011, she received AATSEEL's Award for Outstanding Service to the Profession. Cathy Nepomnyashchy was a masterful teacher and a curricular visionary. Her regular repertory included all periods of Russian literature and all forms of Russian culture, including popular culture. She collaborated in the classroom with colleagues in history, political science, and human rights. Her intellectual energy was a force of nature. She was an agent of change in the institutions and programs she served, the scholarly fields she pursued, and no less in the hearts and minds of the many people she knew. As a scholar, Cathy Nepomnyashchy's range was broad. She published on Pushkin, on great writers of the Soviet period, on emigre Russian writers, on women writers, on Jane Austen in Russia, on ballet, on popular culture and new media. She is known especially for her work on Abram Tertz (Andrei Sinyavsky): "Abram Tertz and the Poetics of Crime" (1995), and a translation with Slava Yastremski of Tertz's "Strolls with Pushkin." She coedited" Under the Skies of My Africa: Alexander Pushkin and Blackness," a volume that inspired an editorial by Henry Louis Gates, Jr. "Mapping the Feminine: Russian Women and Cultural Difference," another coedited volume, was a landmark in the study of writings by and about women. At the time of her death, Cathy was working on a book entitled? "Nabokov and His Enemies: Terms of Engagement." In each of her books she put a feature of Russian literary life into play in a way that expanded the horizons of her field. She is survived by her daughter Olga Nepomnyashchy, her mother Jo-Anne Theimer, and her brother and sister-in-law James Theimer and Sunnie Noellert. Cathy Nepomnyashchy was a brilliant scholar, thinker, teacher, mentor, and administrator. A memorial service will be held at Columbia University in the fall. 1/3

PAHK--Christina Berlin. Born in 1947 to Hearst Corporation President and CEO, Richard E. Berlin and his socialite wife, Honey, Christina grew up in New York City. Schooled at Sacred Heart and Chapin, she attended the Neighborhood Playhouse and fell in love with the local theatre. A true Broadway baby, Christina went on to work for Hearst, ending her career as the New York editor of Harpers & Queen. Along the way, and as a dedicated ballet aficionado, she was thrilled to work as assistant to both Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, providing her the chance to meet Mikhail Baryshnikov, with whom she had a brief romance. Christina was instrumental in helping Baryshnikov defect to Toronto, Canada in 1974. Christina was self-declared homebody with a rich life beyond her famous friends and family. A voracious reader and news junkie, Christina was also a gourmet cook, happily creating memorable feasts, always without a recipe. A serious fashionista, Christina's trademark bob was captured in two Andy Warhal portraits. Upon retirement, Christina moved to Pinehurst, NC with her beloved husband, Michael Pahk. The life of the party, story teller, embellisher, beach bum, music lover and sharp wit, she will be dearly missed by her many friends and family. Christina is survived by her husband, Michael Pahk, and her three siblings, Brigid Berlin, Richie Berlin and Richard Berlin, Jr. 1/3

KANE-- Christopher J. A resident of Pompano Beach, Florida, New York, New York and Toronto, Canada, passed away on April 1, 2015 at home surrounded by his family after a valiant four year battle with pancreatic cancer. Born April 30, 1953 in the Bronx, New York, he is survived by his loving wife, Jan Sternin, his parents, James G and Carol J Kane, and his mother in law, Julia Sternin. He is also survived by Paul and Diane Kane, Teresa and Keith Catucci, James Kane and Jeannine Lane, Jeffrey and Katherine Kane, Shannon Pena, and Jamie Wilcox, and their families. A graduate of Pace University, he was a lifelong banking and investment professional. Chris commenced his career with the County Trust Company as a teller. His career culminated as Managing Director, Chief Operating Officer and Principal of Institutional Mortgage Capital based in Toronto, Canada. He was active in many civic organizations and was a founding member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in Putnam County, New York. An avid cruiser, either by ship or motorcycle, Chris's passions included entertaining family and friends, the view of the ocean from his rooftop, fine scotch and cigars, and the love of his family. The family will receive friends on Wednesday April 8th, from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9 pm at THE HERITAGE FUNERAL HOME, Morrissey Drive, Putnam Valley, N.Y. A mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Thursday, April 9th at 11am at the Church of the North American Martyrs, Putnam Valley, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to a cancer related charity of your choice. 1/3

TANNENBAUM--Bernice Salpeter. Born on November 6, 1913 in New York City and passed away April 6, 2015 at 101 years of age. Predeceased by two beloved husbands, Hyman Salpeter and Nathan Tannenbaum as well as her only cherished son Richard Salpeter, she is survived by her daughter-in-law Deanna Salpeter Warshauer and Marshall Warshauer, her grandchildren Ellen Salpeter, Scott and Jenette Salpeter, Jennifer Salpeter and Herbert Williams and great grandchildren Joshua, Laura, Kara, Lewis, Elliot, Obediah, Elizabeth and Hikma. Born Bernice Franklin in Brooklyn, NY, she spent her life as an unstoppable force for positive change for Israel, for peace, for medicine and particularly for women and girls. Her list of accomplishments is long: past National President of Hadassah, founder of Hadassah International, past chair of the American Section of the World Zionist Organization, a delegate to every World Zionist Congress from 1956 to 2010, an officer of the JTA, vice president of United Israel Appeal and National Vice President of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee and so much more. Despite her myriad roles, the one she cared about most was that of family matriarch. Always an inspiration, Bernice taught us to respect the past, embrace the present and dream into the future. Services on Thursday, April 9 11:45am at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam and 76th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah. 1/3

Tannenbaum--Bernice S. Bernice S. Tannenbaum, who served as national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, from 1976 to 1980, and who later founded Hadassah International, passed away on April 6. She was 101. We mourn the loss of a great leader not only of Hadassah but of the Jewish people, said Marcie Natan, Hadassah's current national president. Bernice was one of the most beloved and productive Hadassah figures of the past half century. She was a tower of strength and a fount of wisdom. The legacy of accomplishment and inspiration that she leaves is immeasurable. During her presidency, Mrs. Tannenbaum initiated the practice of Hadassah periodically holding its annual convention in Israel, convening the first such Jerusalem gathering in 1978. From 1980 to 1984, Mrs. Tannenbaum served as chair of the Hadassah Medical Organization. In 1983, she founded Hadassah International, transforming Hadassah from a U.S.-based Zionist movement into a global network that is currently represented in 21 countries. After the United Nations General Assembly approved Resolution 3379, equating Zionism with racism, in 1975, pro-Israel groups around the world, supported by the American government and many others, mobilized to have the resolution overturned. Mrs. Tannenbaum spearheaded the U.S. campaign for repudiation, which came to a successful conclusion in 1991 when the UN repealed the resolution. In 2000, Mrs. Tannenbaum played a central role as spokesperson for Hadassah's successful campaign to achieve NGO consultative status in the United Nations Economic and Social Council. Mrs. Tannenbaum co-chaired the Strategic Study Research Committee on Hadassah's Israel projects, which led to the creation of the Hadassah Foundation in 1998. The purpose of the Foundation is to provide funding to initiatives that share Hadassah's mission but are beyond the scope of its projects. Mrs. Tannenbaum served for many years as the Foundation's liaison to the Hadassah National Board. In 2003, Mrs. Tannenbaum received Hadassah's highest honor, the Henrietta Szold Award for Distinguished Humanitarian Service. Other recipients of the award, established in 1949, have included Eleanor Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Golda Meir, Yithzak Rabin, Shimon Peres and Elie Wiesel. In recognition of Mrs. Tannenbaum's lifetime of service to Hadassah, Israel and the Jewish people, in 2009 the Hadassah Foundation established the Bernice S. Tannenbaum Prize, which recognizes innovative contributions to advance the lives of women and girls in Israel and the United States. Mrs. Tannenbaum was born Bernice Franklin and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She studied at Brooklyn College, earning a bachelor's degree in English literature and art. She joined Hadassah in 1944 and was a founder of the Kew Gardens Chapter in Queens, NY, eventually becoming the chapters president. She later became president of the Long Island Region. Mrs. Tannenbaum's first husband, Hyman Salpeter, died in 1969. They had one son, Richard, who died in 2003. In 1975, she married Nathan Tannenbaum. He died in 1991. Mrs. Tannenbaum is survived by her daughter-in-law Deanna Salpeter Warshauer, three grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Hadassah, The Women's Zionist Organization of America

HANSMANN--Ralph Emil. Born on May 25, 1918, Ralph Hansmann led a long, compassionate, abundant life distinguished by his disarming twinkle. He was, first and foremost, a gentleman. Ralph was raised in Utica, New York, the only child of Emil C. and Friedericka (Fuchs) Hansmann. In 1940, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Hamilton College in nearby Clinton, NY and went on to Harvard Business School. Upon completing his MBA, Ralph enlisted in the Navy and worked in the Bureau of Ordinance in Washington, D.C. While serving in the Navy, he established a friendship with William T. Golden that developed into a lifelong working relationship. Together with Harold F. Linder, they worked as partners in a private investment firm in New York City for sixty years. In his capacity as an investment analyst and portfolio manager, he served as trustee and treasurer for such institutions as The New York Public Library, The Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ, and Hamilton College. In recognition of his stewardship of its endowment, Hamilton awarded him an honorary degree in 1992. Ralph Hansmann leaves a legacy of wise counsel and goodwill. He died in his sleep at his home in Ridgewood, New Jersey in the early morning of April 2, 2015, leaving his wife of seventy-one years, Doris Macdonald, a son, Robert, a daughter, Jane, her husband, John McKean, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, April 14th at 11am at the Community Church of Ho-Ho-Kus, 400 Warren Avenue, Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ with a reception to follow at the Ridgewood Country Club, 96 West Midland Avenue, Paramus, NJ. A donation in his name can be made to the Doris and Ralph Hansmann Scholarship at Hamilton College, 138 College Hill Road, Clinton, NY 13323. He will be missed beyond measure. 1/3

SEAMAN-- William C. Of Waccabuc NY and Skidaway Island GA, died April 1 at 89. Beloved husband of Joan; and father of Leslie Gauff, Ann Rogerson, Bleecker Seaman; grandfather of 5. 1/3

HANSMANN-- Ralph E. The Board of Trustees and the staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the most beloved and devoted members of the Library family, Ralph E. Hansmann. Mr. Hansmann served tirelessly and with great distinction and enthusiasm as a member of the Library's Board of Trustees for more than three decades. With great wisdom, warmth, and selfless dedication, he was deeply involved in guiding the Library's financial well-being, serving as the Library's Treasurer for more than a quarter century in addition to serving on several key Board committees. He was closely involved in the inner-workings of the Library and showed great love for the Library and all of our staff. At this time, we are particularly honored that the Library's executive conference room is named The Doris and Ralph E. Hansmann Room. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Doris and all of his family and friends. Evan R. Chesler, Chairman Neil L. Rudenstine, Catherine Marron, Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Anthony W. Marx, President 1/3

HANSMANN--Ralph Emil. Born on May 25, 1918, Ralph Hansmann led a long, compassionate, abundant life distinguished by his disarming twinkle. He was, first and foremost, a gentleman. Ralph was raised in Utica, New York, the only child of Emil C. and Friedericka (Fuchs) Hansmann. In 1940, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Hamilton College in nearby Clinton, NY and went on to Harvard Business School. Upon completing his MBA, Ralph enlisted in the Navy and worked in the Bureau of Ordinance in Washington, D.C. While serving in the Navy, he established a friendship with William T. Golden that developed into a lifelong working relationship. Together with Harold F. Linder, they worked as partners in a private investment firm in New York City for sixty years. In his capacity as an investment analyst and portfolio manager, he served as trustee and treasurer for such institutions as The New York Public Library, The Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ, and Hamilton College. In recognition of his stewardship of its endowment, Hamilton awarded him an honorary degree in 1992. Ralph Hansmann leaves a legacy of wise counsel and goodwill. He died in his sleep at his home in Ridgewood, New Jersey in the early morning of April 2, 2015, leaving his wife of seventy-one years, Doris Macdonald, a son, Robert, a daughter, Jane, her husband, John McKean, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, April 14th at 11am at the Community Church of Ho-Ho-Kus, 400 Warren Avenue, Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ with a reception to follow at the Ridgewood Country Club, 96 West Midland Avenue, Paramus, NJ. A donation in his name can be made to the Doris and Ralph Hansmann Scholarship at Hamilton College, 138 College Hill Road, Clinton, NY 13323. He will be missed beyond measure. 1/3

Beloved husband of almost 70 years to Phyllis, adored father of Cheri Targoff, loving grandfather of Ramie Targoff (Stephen Greenblatt), Josh Targoff (Kim), Jason Targoff, (Marcella Anderson), Hannah Saujet (Thomas). Doting great-grandfather to Zachary, Vera, Harry, Zoe, Lou, Theo, Felix, Stella, Raphael and Eleanor. Loving uncle to Eileen Wick and Ilyse Kreiger. "I had a great time...Nothing but happiness". JORDAN--Cecilia, 96, died peacefully on April 3, 2015, Good Friday, at Andrus Nursing Home in Hastings -on-Hudson, NY. Cecilia was born in the Bronx on September 10, 1918 to Peter and Delia McGovern (nee McNamara). After marrying Michael P. Jordan in 1947, Cecilia resided with her husband in Parkchester for the next 60 years. In addition to her life as a loving wife and mother, Cecilia was a devoted and esteemed elementary school teacher in the New York City Public School System. Cecilia also cherished her Catholic faith every day of her life. Cecilia was known for her friendliness, beauty, gentleness, sense of humor and winsome smile. She now enjoying her new life with parents, her loving husband, Michael, son, Christopher, and older sister, Sister Catherine McGovern, a Maryknoll nun, all of whom predeceased her. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Cecilia's beloved alma mater, Academy of Mount St. Ursula, 330 Bedford Park Blvd., Bronx, NY 10458, attn: Office of Development. Mass of the Resurrection, 10am, Thursday at Church of St. Matthew, R.C., Hastings -on-Hudson, NY. 1/3

He was a partner of the firm Fulton, Rowe & Hart LLP and was also a director of the van Ameringen Foundation and the Lily Auchincloss Foundation. Mr. Westergaard graduated from the College of Charleston in 1978 and subsequently attended Columbia University earning an M.A. in 1980 and a J.D. in 1983. Mr. Westergaard practiced in several firms prior to joining Fulton, Rowe & Hart LLP in 1996. Mr. Westergaard is survived by his partner of 30 years, Michael Young, and by a brother, Andreas Westergaard, III. A brief memorial service will be held at the Columbarium of the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine on April 15, 2015 at 1:15pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a contribution to the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine. 1/3

ANGLIM--Paule. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague, Paule Anglim. She was a leading dealer of contemporary art in San Francisco where she had a gallery for 33 years. Her exhibitions encompassed the work of defining figures of the Bay Area such as David Ireland, Paul Kos, Tom Marioni and Jim Melchert. Our sympathy and condolences go to her son Philip Anglim and to her longtime gallery director and friend, Edward Gilbert. Dorsey Waxter, President Linda Blumberg, Executive Director 1/3

LAMATTINA--Larry, 69, passed away peacefully on April 5, 2015, at his home on St. Simons Island, GA. Larry, who was born on September 5, 1945 in Front Royal, VA and grew up on Staten Island, retired to St. Simons Island with his wife, Janice, in 2000. Larry's early career began in his teens as a bass player with The Demotrons, who recorded on Scepter Records and played backup for many famous artists of the 1960s at venues throughout New York City, Long Island, and New Jersey, including the Apollo Theater. After beginning his career at Benton & Bowles and then Scali McCabe Sloves, Larry spent 10 years at Grey Advertising where he rose to Executive Vice President, Director of Media and TV Programming, serving on the agency's policy committee. He later joined The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc. as Executive Vice President of Media and TV Programming where his responsibilities grew to include research, direct marketing, sales promotion, and all other marketing services. Larry was appointed Chief Operating Officer of Lintas New York and elected to the Board of Directors of Lintas Worldwide with global responsibility for media and TV programming and diversified marketing services. In 1989, Larry left Lintas to create E.C. Television, specializing in television production and distribution for the international marketplace. As Chairman and CEO, he pioneered advertiser supported TV programming in Europe through the production and distribution of local versions of "Wheel of Fortune" and "Jeopardy." ECTV acquired and merged with Fremantle International to become the leading producer and distributor of locally produced TV programs outside the United States. In 1994, when All American Communications, Inc. purchased Fremantle, he joined as President and CEO with responsibility for all domestic and international television activities. He was immensely proud of his two daughters and the fine young women and mothers they had become and was quick to brag to friends about their latest accomplishments in acting or TV production. "Poppy" adored his six grandchildren, eagerly awaiting the next Skype opportunity. Every photo, video or text was cherished as he marveled at each accomplishment, be it student council, swimming, soccer, ballet, or dressing up as a fairy princess. Larry was predeceased by his father, Rosario Lamattina; his mother, Rosa Lee Lamattina; and his sisters, Maryann and Kathy Lamattina. He is survived by his wife of 22 years, Janice; his daughters and sons-in-law, Lisa Lamattina and Blake Henry of Princeton Junction, NJ and Laura Lamattina and Sam Vollen of Woodland Hills, CA; his six grandchildren, Dillon Henry, Lily Henry, Spencer Henry, Reed Henry, Ava Lamattina, and Annabelle Lamattina; and his sister and brother-in-law, Audrey and Al Bilotti of Avon, CT. Memorial donations may be sent to Hospice of the Golden Isles, 1692 Glynco Pkwy, Brunswick, GA 31525 or the St. Simons Land Trust, 1624 Frederica Rd. #

NIE--Norman H. Passed away peacefully surrounded by family and friends at his home in Sun Valley, Idaho on April 2, 2015. He was 72 years old. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Carol P. Nie, daughters Anne Nie, Lara Slotwiner-Nie, son-in-law Peter Slotwiner-Nie, and granddaughters Sophia Slotwiner-Nie and Helena Slotwiner-Nie. In addition to his beloved family, Nie leaves a legacy of pioneering innovation as an academic social scientist and technology entrepreneur. He was a Professor of Political Science and chair of his department at the University of Chicago until his retirement in 1998, and then subsequently at Stanford University, his alma matter. Nie met his wife Carol during their college years at Washington University in St. Louis. While completing his Ph.D. at Stanford, he collaborated to invent a computer software package to automate the analysis of quantitative data, SPSS. He was the CEO of SPSS between 1975 and 1992 and continued as Chairman of the Board. Nie was honored as the KPMG Technology Entrepreneur in 1986. Throughout his tenure at SPSS, he simultaneously produced academic research in U.S. political behavior and public opinion. Nie authored many articles and award-winning books and was a nationally recognized expert on voting behavior. In 2006, he was awarded a lifetime achievement award from the American Association of Public Opinion Researchers, and three years later he was elected as a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. His scholarly books were honored with the Woodrow Wilson Award (two times) and the Gladys M. Kammerer Award from the American Political Science Association. While at Stanford, Nie co-founded the Internet survey research firm Knowledge Networks where he was the Chairman of the Board. He was also the CEO of Revolution Analytics, a commercial software company, and served on the boards of numerous high technology firms. Nie mentored hundreds of students throughout his career and was often described by colleagues as a force of nature; a man of vast energy and ambition, omnivorous curiosity, deep intellect, immense creativity, and everyday humanity. After work, he could usually be found on the tennis court. A private burial will be held in St. Louis, and a public memorial is planned for the coming months. In lieu of flowers, his family requests contributions be made to: Hospice and Palliative Care of the Wood River Valley in Ketchum, Idaho. Services are under the care of Wood River Chapel of Hailey, Idaho. Friends may visit www.woodriverchapel.com to share a message, photo or story and to light a candle. 1/3

GOTBAUM--Victor. An indomitable spirit who made a difference in this world, left his mark on our city, with a heart as big as his smile. Victor was a passionate advocate, a champion of justice and righteousness and a fighter to the end. We all cared for him, none as much as Betsy who he never failed to remind us how "crazy" he was for her. He will be missed. Suri and Bruce 1/3

MERCK--Elizabeth Mead. Died peacefully at home with her loving family, hospice nurses by her side, and her two beloved Jack Russell Terriers on her bed Friday, April 3. She lived at her farm, The Fields, Bedminster, NJ with her family since the early 1950s. Her husband George Wall Merck died in 1984. She recently celebrated her 95th birthday and was delighted by the surprise entertainment: a belly dancer. Elizabeth Amy Mead, or "Betty" as she was known, was born in Guelph, Ontario in 1920 to British parents, Olive Mary Holden and William Arthur Mead. Her mother remarried Edward H. Bennett, the architect and city planner, known for his collaboration with Daniel Burnham on the 1909 "Plan of Chicago." She grew up in Chicago and Lake Forest, Il. She attended the Chicago Latin School for Girls, Miss Porter's School, and for a short stint, the Brillantmont School in Lausanne, Switzerland, where she said she learned to speak French, iron a man's shirt in 5 minutes and make perfect hollandaise sauce. She continued as an excellent and adventurous cook for the rest of her life. Mrs. Merck said she grew up on a horse, starting at the age of five. Betty continued to be connected to horses for her entire life - with the Pony Club, winning point-to-points, fox hunting, on a riding safari in Botswana, and running steeplechase horses. She served for several years as Joint Master of the Essex Foxhounds in her mid 80s, and rode her beloved steed Smokey until she was 94. Betty served her community in elected office on the Bedminster Township Council from 1975-1989. She served on local township commissions including the Open Space Farmland Advisory Committee, the Lamington Conservancy, and on the boards of the New Jersey Nature Conservancy, Raritan Headwaters Association, the Lamington Conservancy and Miss Porter's School. A lifelong conservationist, Mrs. Merck was recently celebrated by the Garden Club of America Regional Chapter with an award for conservation. Bedminster recently dedicated a special park bench to her with words she liked, "It is nice to be important but more important to be nice." In 1995, she and her son George "Laddy" Merck began a partnership, The Fields Stable, starting with the first of their winning jumpers, Brigade of Guards. Tom Voss was the trainer of their many winners including Your Sum Man, Approaching Squall, and Guelph. Guelph became three-time champion filly. Betty loved to grow her own flowers and vegetables started from seed and loved to tend to her fields, trees and all her animals. She will be remembered for her loyal service in her community, her gracious style, and her energetic enjoyment of a robust social and sporting life. In addition to her husband, she was predeceased by her brother, Joseph Mead, and her stepbrother Edward H. Bennett, Jr. She was the mother of Antony M. Merck (Ann Wimberley), Josephine A. Merck (James Stevenson), George F. Merck (Adele Shook), six grandchildren, Oona Coy and Morgan Coy, Elizabeth Merck Lake and Elliot Merck, George Merck and Grace Merck, and six great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St Luke's Church Gladstone, NJ on May 30 at 11am. Donations may be made to the Raritan Headwaters Association (raritanheadwaters.org) or Atlantic Home Care Hospice, 465 South St., Morristown, NJ 07960. 1/3

TANNENBAUM--Bernice Salpeter. Born on November 6, 1913 in New York City and passed away April 6, 2015 at 101 years of age. Predeceased by two beloved husbands, Hyman Salpeter and Nathan Tannenbaum as well as her only cherished son Richard Salpeter, she is survived by her daughter-in-law Deanna Salpeter Warshauer and Marshall Warshauer, her grandchildren Ellen Salpeter, Scott and Jenette Salpeter, Jennifer Salpeter and Herbert Williams and great grandchildren Joshua, Laura, Kara, Lewis, Elliot, Obediah, Elizabeth and Hikma. Born Bernice Franklin in Brooklyn, NY, she spent her life as an unstoppable force for positive change for Israel, for peace, for medicine and particularly for women and girls. Her list of accomplishments is long: past National President of Hadassah, founder of Hadassah International, past chair of the American Section of the World Zionist Organization, a delegate to every World Zionist Congress from 1956 to 2010, an officer of the JTA, vice president of United Israel Appeal and National Vice President of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee and so much more. Despite her myriad roles, the one she cared about most was that of family matriarch. Always an inspiration, Bernice taught us to respect the past, embrace the present and dream into the future. Services on Thursday, April 9 11:45am at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam and 76th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah. 1/3

DUBIN--Pauline, age 102, passed away at home on April 5, 2015. Born in New York City to Morris and Bertha Nicenholtz, Mrs. Dubin lived in the Bronx for 28 years before moving to New Milford, NJ 46 years ago. She worked as a nurse having trained at the Sydenham Hospital in New York and continued working there for five years. Then after a 19 year break to raise her family, she worked at Beth David and Medical Arts in New York before working for a private physician for 14 years, retiring in 1974. She was an excellent and accomplished painter, shell craft designer and artist, and had a deep love of gardening. Mrs. Dubin was pre-deceased in 1956 by her husband of 20 years David J., and her brother Sam M. Nicenholtz in 1979. She is survived by her loving son Reese Dubin of New Milford, NJ. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday, April 8, 2015 at 2:45pm in the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. 1/3

SERENBETZ--Warren. Warren Lewis Serenbetz, of Harrison, New York, a pioneer of the container leasing industry, passed away peacefully early on the morning of April 4 at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut, surrounded by his loving family. In his business life, he was a man of great vision and acumen; in his home life, he was a man of great warmth and generosity. Mr. Serenbetz was born in Brooklyn, New York on March 27, 1924. He graduated from Jamaica High School in Queens. In 1944, he graduated from the Navy Officers Training Program at Columbia University with a B.S. in engineering and the rank of ensign. Mr. Serenbetz served as a gunnery and recognition officer aboard the USS Weiss in the north and south Atlantic during World War II. In 1948, Mr. Serenbetz married Thelma Randby, whose love, friendship, and support sustained him over the next seven decades of his life. Mr. Serenbetz received his M.S. in engineering from Columbia in 1949. Shortly thereafter, he began work for the Railway Express Agency as an assistant chief engineer, rising to senior vice president in charge of technical services. During his tenure at Railway Express, he became involved with the American Management Association and the Containerization and Intermodal Institute. He joined the American National Standards Institute where he helped to develop the standards for the international intermodal cargo container. In 1960, Mr. Serenbetz established the REA Leasing Corporation, eventually forming the cargo container leasing division known as Interpool. The division was acquired by Steadman Industries in 1968, with Mr. Serenbetz as president and chief executive officer. Interpool separated from Steadman Industries and registered as a public company in 1969. Two years later the company was listed on the American Stock Exchange. Prior to the companies sale to Thyssen Bornemiza in 1978, Mr. Serenbetz was instrumental in fostering many innovations in the intermodal container business, including chassis leasing in the United States, and the formation of Con-Trailer and Railpool. In 1986, he was part of a small group that formed Trac Lease, a chassis leasing company. In 1988, a group of investors including Mr. Serenbetz bought Interpool from TBG. Interpool grew into the largest marine leasing company in the world, leasing over one million containers. It was sold to the Fortress Group of Funds for $2.4 billion in 2007. Mr. Serenbetz, as a representative of Radcliff Group Inc., oversaw operations and then served as a consultant at the company until his retirement in 2004. During his long career, Mr. Serenbetz served as president and chairman of the Containerization and Intermodal Institute, receiving the organization's Connie award. He served on the board of the American Management Association and as chairman of the compensation committee. He was the co-founder of the Institute of International Container Lessors and was named CEO of the Year by Financial World magazine. Over his four decades in the industry he mentored many executives who were able to witness his tenaciousness and admirable leadership skills. Mr. Serenbetz was a member of the Union League Club in Manhattan, The Apawamis Club in Rye, New York, and the Larchmont Yacht Club. He served as a member of the board of sessions at the Larchmont Avenue Church and ushered regularly up until his death. In December of 1997, Mr. Serenbetz and his wife Thelma established the Serenbetz Family Foundation, a charitable organization whose core mission is to provide educational opportunities for deserving children and young adults. The stewardship of this foundation became one of the passions of their lives. Mr. Serenbetz loved the sea. From boyhood summers at his family's summer home in Cutchogue, to his last vacation in the Caribbean, the sea was for him a source of pleasure and renewal, whether in the water or on it. He was an avid yachtsman and spent many happy hours captaining his sloop and his trawler. Swimming, snorkeling, and walks on the beach with Thelma were among his favorite pastimes. Above all, Mr. Serenbetz was the patriarch, and along with Thelma, the heart and soul of their large and growing extended family. Despite his many remarkable achievements, it was their achievements - professional, educational, athletic, and artistic - of which he was most proud and that brought him the most joy. Mr. Serenbetz is survived by his cherished wife Thelma; his four sons -Warren and his wife Cindi of Wilton, CT; Paul of New Haven, CT; Stuart and his wife Jean of Stamford, CT; and Clay of Friday Harbor, WA; his six grandchildren - Christin (Weberman) and her husband Adam; Warren III and his wife Jenni; Tucker; Hunter; Skyler; and Robert; and by two great-grandchildren; along with many loving nieces and nephews and their spouses and children. A memorial service will be held on Friday, April 10 at 4pm at the Larchmont Avenue Church, 60 Forest Park Avenue, Larchmont, New York, after a private internment ceremony. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Warren's memory to the Centennial Fund at the Larchmont Avenue Church. 1/3

GREIF--Dr. Roger L. A beloved professor of physiology and researcher at Cornell University Medical College, died April 6, 2015 at the age of 98. He was born in Baltimore on August 23, 1916 to Leonard and Amy Greif. He graduated from Haverford College in 1937 and from Johns Hopkins Medical School in 1941. During World War II, he served as a United States Navy doctor in China. Dr. Greif considered himself fortunate to have married well - twice, first to Carol Prince with whom he had three sons - Peter, Nicholas, and Matthew. Dr. Greif remarried in 1973 to Alice Falvey, of Boston. He has two granddaughters, Catherine and Laura Greif. Plans are being made for a celebration of his life at a later date. 1/3
KELLNER--Zoe. April 9th marks 8 years since you lost your life. We think of you and miss you every day. You are in our hearts forever. Love, Mom and John

GALPIN--Stephen Kellogg, 93, of Southport, Conn., died April 3, 2015 of cancer at home with family at his side. Father of four, grandfather of 10 and great-grandfather of six, he was a sailor, paratrooper, newspaper reporter, OSS intelligence agent, humorist, local politico, business executive and renowned dog lover. Born February 2, 1922 in New York City, he was the son of Perrin C. and Stephanie E. Galpin, and grew up in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He graduated from The Harvey School, The Hotchkiss School and Yale University, Class of 1943. In World War II, he served in the Galapagos Islands in an anti-aircraft battery and in Southeast Asia as an intelligence agent with the U.S. Office of Strategic Services. He was honorably discharged from the Army as a first lieutenant. He joined the Hartford Courant as a reporter and later The Wall Street Journal, first in NYC and then in Washington, D.C., covering labor, Congress and the White House. In 1950, he married Ruth Bliss Schwab. She was his beloved wife for 58 years, predeceasing him in 2008. They moved to Rye, NY, in 1955 when he joined General Electric at its NYC headquarters, first as a speechwriter then manager of public affairs. He retired after 26 years with GE. In Rye, he indulged his long interest in sailing and local government, serving as City Councilman, deputy mayor and on various commissions. He was chairman of the Rye United Fund and a trustee of the American Yacht Club. When GE headquarters moved to Fairfield, Conn., Galpin and family moved to nearby Southport. He served as Fairfield Town treasurer and on several town commissions. He was commodore of Pequot Yacht Club and a regular contributor to the Pequot Pilot newsletter. Galpin led creation of Southport Harbor's annual Blessing of the Fleet, a multidenominational event that caps a parade through the village. As a tribute to him, the State of Connecticut declared June 16, 2007, as Southport Blessing of the Fleet Day. He was Grand Marshal of the 2012 Southport Annual Street Parade. Galpin is survived by his four children: Stephen K. Galpin, Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J.; Mary G. Barnes of Guilford, Conn., Priscilla G. Twombly of Easton, Conn., and Susan G. Knowlton of Old Tappan, N.J., as well as grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He is also survived by a sister, Lucy G. Moorhead of Westwood, Mass. His other sister, Anne Perrin Judson, died in 1990. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, at 11 a.m. on April 27. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, Conn., or to Mystic Seaport, Mystic, Conn. 1/3

CONSTANTINE--Spiro. With gratitude for his extraordinary life, the family of Spiro Constantine is saddened to announce his sudden passing on April 5, 2015. Beloved husband of 43 years, brother, uncle and devoted friend. We deeply mourn his loss. 1/3

NATHAN--Vivian, gifted actor, mentor and teacher, died in her sleep Friday night, April 3, 2015 at The Actors Home in Englewood, NJ. She was 98 years old and an original member of The Actors Studio, founded in 1947 by Lee Strasberg, Elia Kazan, Robert Lewis and Cheryl Crawford among others. Vivian made her Broadway debut after winning the John Golden Auditions and appeared in such Broadway productions as "Sundown Beach", directed by Elia Kazan, as well as the first plays by Tennessee Williams, including "The Rose Tattoo" with Maureen Stapleton and "Camino Real" with Eli Wallach, David J. Stewart and Joseph Anthony. For her portrayal of the Charwoman in "Anastasia" directed by Alan Schneider, she won the 1955 Clarence Derwent award. In "The Investigation" by Peter Weiss, a docudrama about Auschwitz, her performance was so riveting audiences believed she had been a holocaust survivor. Her last Broadway performance was in "Golda" with Anne Bancroft directed by Arthur Penn. In addition to her Broadway work that spanned from 1948 to 1977 she participated, at the Actors Studio and theaters across the country, in numerous productions by Ibsen, Chekhov and O'Neill whose plays she profoundly loved. Her 19 film appearances include "Teacher's Pet" with Clark Gable, "The Young Savages" with Burt Lancaster, and "The Outsider" with Tony Curtis. In "Klute" with Jane Fonda and Donald Sutherland, she played Jane's psychiatrist, infusing those scenes with a powerful emotional reality. She featured in over 50 television productions. Her favorite experiences were doing live television in "Playhouse 90" and "Studio One". She appeared regularly in "Alfred Hitchcock Presents" from 1958 through 1961 and worked in television until 1989. Until 1999, Vivian served on the Board of Directors for The Actors Studio with Ellen Burstyn, Estelle Parsons, Paul Newman, Lee Grant and Al Pacino. As a session moderator and teacher, Vivian's acute understanding and passion of the actor's craft brought an internal clarity to all those who worked with her. She was held in high regard by her peers. The actress, Kim Stanley, never prepared a part without working with her friend and mentor, Vivian Nathan. Born Vivian Firko in 1916 in New York City, Vivian was the daughter of Hipolit and Anna Firko. Her husband of over 50 years, Nathan Schwalb, died in 2000. She is survived by her three nieces, Diane Everline, Vivian Mullett and Elizabeth Lebens, as well as her god-daughter Elissa Myers and Ms. Myers' children, Nina and Sasha Friedman, as well as her oldest friend, Nohmie Myers. She will be greatly missed. She was greatly loved. The memorial service will be at "The Riverside," 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY on Sunday April 13 at 5:00pm. 1/3

SMITH--Alan Garrigues, MD. Dr. Smith was born in Minneapolis, MN on July 14, 1927 and died on April 5, 2015 in Brooklyn, NY at the age of 87. In 1945 he joined the Navy right before his High School graduation from Blake School. After the end of WWII, Alan attended Dartmouth College and graduated in 1949. He took pre-med courses at the University of Minnesota where he met his future wife, Joyce Elaine Schlemmer in chemistry class. They were married in 1953 and he graduated from the U of MN Medical School in 1955. He found his vocation when he became the Chief of Orthopaedic Surgery at the Brooklyn Veterans Admin. Hospital in New York in 1964, specializing in the rehabilitation of amputees and training residents. He enjoyed taking his wheelchair bound patients to the New York Giants games. Alan rode his bicycle to work almost every day until his retirement in 1987. He spent much time at his cabin in the Adirondacks near Owl Pond, camping with his family, hiking, chopping wood, fishing, skiing, boating and picking berries. At home in Bay Ridge he tended his garden with Joyce and his cat. He was a fan of the Yankees and came out to support the runners at the NYC Marathon. He is predeceased by his eldest son, David and leaves his devoted wife of 61 years, Joyce and two children: Margaret "Peggy" G. Smith of Manhattan and Peter A. Smith, MD, of Chicago, Il (Mary K. Morrell, MD); four wonderful grandchildren: Andrew G. Greissman, Katherine E. Greissman, Benjamin M. Smith, and Audrey R. Smith. He will be remembered as a man of moral character and determination. Services by McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, Brooklyn, NY www. McLaughlinandSons.com. Funeral at Union Church of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Sunday, April 12, 2pm. Burial at Green-Wood Cemetery. Donations can be made to: Parkinson's Disease Foundation, www.pdf.org Union Church of Bay Ridge, www.ucbr.org The Nature Conservancy www.nature.org 1/3

SIEGEL--Susan Kargman. In Gibran's words, "And what is it to cease breathing, but to free the breath from its restless tides, that it may rise and expand and seek God unencumbered?" Dearest Susan we will hold you in our hearts forever. Our love to Bob, Charley, Callie, Nate & Lola. Dan, Brooke, Jon and Alessandra, Stephen and Aliza & Mallory. 1/3
CHARLES--Ray. We loved the middle aged movie fan! Always will. Skippy and Manny

ANGLIM--Paule. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague, Paule Anglim. She was a leading dealer of contemporary art in San Francisco where she had a gallery for 33 years. Her exhibitions encompassed the work of defining figures of the Bay Area such as David Ireland, Paul Kos, Tom Marioni and Jim Melchert. Our sympathy and condolences go to her son Philip Anglim and to her longtime gallery director and friend, Edward Gilbert. Dorsey Waxter, President Linda Blumberg, Executive Director 1/3

WANTMAN--Carol Chrein, 62, passed away on April 7, 2015. Carol was a devoted and passionate Spanish Teacher at the New Fairfield (Connecticut) Schools for over 16 years. She will be forever remembered by her husband; Walter, her three children; Matthew, Elissa and Benjamin; her sister and sister's husband; Susan and Robert Yules; her niece; Rachel Yules; her Brothers in Law, Samuel Wantman and David Hermeyer; her Aunt Toba; and cousins, Molly, Lily and Nathaniel. Graveside funeral services will take place on Sunday, April 12, 2015 at 11am at New Montefiore Cemetery; West Babylon, NY. Friends will be received on Sunday April 12, 2015 from 2:30 to 5pm at Jowdy Kane Funeral Home; 9 Granville Avenue, Danbury, CT. Memorial contributions can be made to the Ovarian Cancer National Alliance at 901 E Street NW, Suite 405; Washington, DC 20004; and/or the Danbury Ambulance Service at 14 Walnut St; Danbury, CT 06811. 1/3

GOTBAUM--Victor. Victor was a force of nature who shared so much of his life with the City he loved. A man who never backed down from a fight as long as it was a fight for what was right. Victor will be missed by many but most of all by his beloved wife, Betsy. Together they lived with great purpose and passion among so many devoted friends and family. Our hearts go out to you Betsy for this great civic loss. Bruce Ratner MaryAnne Gilmartin Forest City Ratner Companies 1/3

WILZIG--Naomi The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Naomi Sisselman Wilzig of Miami Beach, Florida, and Cliftonassaic, New Jersey, who with her late husband, Siggi B. Wilzig, was a Yeshiva University Guardian. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her children: Alan (and Karin) Wilzig, Ivan Wilzig and Sheri Wilzig; her grandchildren; and her sister, Rachel Araten. May the entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

WILZIG--Naomi, 80, of Miami Beach, FL passed away April 7, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Siggi B. Wilzig, cherished mother of Ivan Wilzig of Miami Beach, Sherry Wilzig-Izak of Livingston, NJ and Alan (Karin) Wilzig of New York City, adored grandmother of Jesse and Jonathan Izak, Siggi and Winni Wilzig. A fitting tribute to her many awards and accomplishments will be published at a later date. Service Thursday, April 9th at 1pm, Bernheim Apter/Dignity Memorial, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ 07309 (973)442-0600. Burial immediately following memorial service at King Solomon Memorial Park, 550 Dwasline Road, Clifton, NJ. Her legacy and the sweetness of her memory will continue to enhance the lives and futures of her family, friends and the myriads of individuals and charitable organizations which she supported and helped. 1/3

NATHAN--Vivian, gifted actor, mentor and teacher, died in her sleep Friday night, April 3, 2015 at The Actors Home in Englewood, NJ. She was 98 years old and an original member of The Actors Studio, founded in 1947 by Lee Strasberg, Elia Kazan, Robert Lewis and Cheryl Crawford among others. Vivian made her Broadway debut after winning the John Golden Auditions and appeared in such Broadway productions as "Sundown Beach", directed by Elia Kazan, as well as the first plays by Tennessee Williams, including "The Rose Tattoo" with Maureen Stapleton and "Camino Real" with Eli Wallach, David J. Stewart and Joseph Anthony. For her portrayal of the Charwoman in "Anastasia" directed by Alan Schneider, she won the 1955 Clarence Derwent award. In "The Investigation" by Peter Weiss, a docudrama about Auschwitz, her performance was so riveting audiences believed she had been a holocaust survivor. Her last Broadway performance was in "Golda" with Anne Bancroft directed by Arthur Penn. In addition to her Broadway work that spanned from 1948 to 1977 she participated, at the Actors Studio and theaters across the country, in numerous productions by Ibsen, Chekhov and O'Neill whose plays she profoundly loved. Her 19 film appearances include "Teacher's Pet" with Clark Gable, "The Young Savages" with Burt Lancaster, and "The Outsider" with Tony Curtis. In "Klute" with Jane Fonda and Donald Sutherland, she played Jane's psychiatrist, infusing those scenes with a powerful emotional reality. She featured in over 50 television productions. Her favorite experiences were doing live television in "Playhouse 90" and "Studio One". She appeared regularly in "Alfred Hitchcock Presents" from 1958 through 1961 and worked in television until 1989. Until 1999, Vivian served on the Board of Directors for The Actors Studio with Ellen Burstyn, Estelle Parsons, Paul Newman, Lee Grant and Al Pacino. As a session moderator and teacher, Vivian's acute understanding and passion of the actor's craft brought an internal clarity to all those who worked with her. She was held in high regard by her peers. The actress, Kim Stanley, never prepared a part without working with her friend and mentor, Vivian Nathan. Born Vivian Firko in 1916 in New York City, Vivian was the daughter of Hipolit and Anna Firko. Her husband of over 50 years, Nathan Schwalb, died in 2000. She is survived by her three nieces, Diane Everline, Vivian Mullett and Elizabeth Lebens, as well as her god-daughter Elissa Myers and Ms. Myers' children, Nina and Sasha Friedman, as well as her oldest friend, Nohmie Myers. She will be greatly missed. She was greatly loved. The memorial service will be at "The Riverside," 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY on Sunday April 12 at 5:00pm. 1/3

SELIGMAN--Donald David, passed away on April 6, 2015. Loving husband of 74 years to his dear wife Dorothy, who survives him, dear father to John and wife Susan, and Nancy and husband Harry Goldmark, adoring and adored grandfather and "Pop" to Ken (Lisa), James (Julia), Brian (Autumn) and Dori (Eric), great-grandchildren Charlotte, Lola, Nina and Alexander, and sister to Diane Tuska, who survives him. He was born July 21, 1921, and was raised by his parents in the Five Towns on Nassau County's South Shore. He was a three sports star at Lawrence High School. Don then went on to Columbia University, where he again played and lettered in three sports. Upon graduation, he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps, commissioned as Second Lieutenant, and served in the Pacific theater, including Peleliu, attaining the rank of Major before being discharged after World War II ended. He embarked upon a career in the ladies' shoe business, first at several department stores, including Lord & Taylor, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman-Delman, before opening and operating his own chain, the totally unique Shop for Pappagallo-NYC, and four other Northeast locations, for over 10 years. Don then repped for several lines of designer accessories, before retiring and moving to Rhinebeck NY, where he and Dorothy lived for almost 20 years; in a home which was a very special "go to" home base for his children and grandchildren. This was followed up by another almost two decades in Heritage Hills, Somers, NY, and the final few years in Ossining, NY at the Atria. He was a fine athlete, playing tennis well into his 80s, and a lifelong New York Rangers fan. Never has a husband, father, and grandfather given more love, guidance, and happiness to his family, extended family, friends, colleagues, and anyone else with whom he came in contact. His modesty, warmth, wit, and charm, will be missed. There will be a private funeral for immediate family on Sunday. Shiva at John and Susan Seligman's home, 45 Main Street, Hastings on Hudson, NY on Sunday from 3 to 9pm and Monday from 2pm to 4pm and 6:30pm to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to your favorite charity, in Don's memory. 1/3

SZOR--Leopold (94) Born April 4, 1921 in Lwow (Poland), died April 8, 2015 in New York, NY. A survivor of the Holocaust, he managed to escape the notorious Janowska concentration camp and traveled to Russia where he fought with the Polish brigade of the Red Army in the liberation of Warsaw. He later emigrated to New York where he lived for over 60 years. He was successful businessman who created an international media advertising firm based in Monaco. An avid amateur playwright, he wrote a number of short pieces set in the time of the Holocaust. A collection of his plays, entitled The True Messiah, was published in 2010 and is available online. He is survived by his long-time partner Tove-Lin Dalmau and by his son Daniel, daughter-in-law Katia, grandsons Henry and Alex and granddaughter Emily. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, April 12th, for immediate family at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, followed by a reception at home. 1/3

PEYSER--Herbert. The Mount Sinai Health System is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Herbert S. Peyser, MD, a former Assistant Clinical Professor of Psychiatry and Associate Attending Psychiatrist. Over his long and distinguished career, Dr. Peyser also served as a psychiatric consultant to the Smithers Alcoholism Treatment and Training Center at Mount Sinai St. Luke's. He was a Distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association (APA), and a New York Academy of Medicine Fellow. In 2004, Dr. Peyser received a Special Presidential Commendation from the APA for his legislative advocacy on behalf of mental illness. The Mount Sinai community extends heartfelt condolences to his family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Ruth, celebrated the arts every day sharing her passion with friends, family, and professional colleagues. Despite being diagnosed with progressive supranuclear palsy, she never lost her passion and continued sharing her amazing energy and panache. As Program Coordinator of the Contemporary Collectors Circle at Stanford University's Cantor Arts Center, Ruth spent nearly 20 years educating collectors by leading art tours of private and public collections worldwide. She passed away Tuesday at the age of 76. Ruth is predeceased by her loving husband of 46 years, Jerome. She is survived by her brother Irwin Weiss of Las Vegas; two sons Adam Gottlieb of Davis, CA and Geoffrey Gottlieb of Los Angeles; daughters-in-law Elizabeth Nelson and Rebecca Plack; and twin grandchildren, Jonah and Margo. A graveside service will take place Sunday, April 12 at 10:30am at Cemetery Beth David in Elmont, New York. 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Magda. 92, of Yonkers, NY, passed away peacefully on Sunday, April 5, 2015. She is predeceased by her husband, Dr. Bernard Schneider, of 52 years, her first daughter, Dr. Susan Spencer, and her brother, Tarjan Gyorgy. She is survived by her daughters, Beth Weingarth of Wallingford, CT and Karen Kimball of North Haven, CT, her grandchildren, Andrea Spencer-Kimchi (Eyal), Joanna Spencer-Segal (Yaniv), Michael Weingarth (Ellen Devine) and Caroline Kimball, and two great- grandchildren. She was born in Kisvarda, Hungary in 1922, came to this country when she was 24 years old, and built a wonderful life. She was loved and adored by her family, friends, and by the patients of her husband with whom she worked for many years supporting his medical practice. She was a devoted and loving wife, mother, grandmother and recently a great-grandmother. She was fearless, strong, and determined, and extraordinarily gracious and generous to family and friends alike. The essence of class, beauty and elegance, with a keen sense of wit, she was a source of strength to everyone around her. She always did the right thing and inspired others to do the same. A remarkable woman, a remarkable life. Her shining light and enduring love will continue to burn in everyone who knew her. She will be greatly missed, and shall remain forever with much love and admiration in our hearts and minds. Funeral services will take place Sunday, April 12th at 10am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Donations in her memory and the spirit of caring can be made to Habitat for Humanity International: A Gift From the Heart, 322 West Lamar Street, Americus, Georgia 31709, or www.habitat.org, or 1-800-422-4828. 1/3

FOLEY--Joseph Lindberg, died at home April 9 of pulmonary complications. Mr. Foley was a gregarious and adventurous man who had many interests. He had been a Merchant Marine Officer; an Arthur Murray dance instructor; a model; an artist; owner of a construction company; and later a partner in his wife Joan Coleman Foley's The Foley Literary Agency. He was a good Irishman, but he was also proud of his Swedish heritage. In addition to his wife Joan, he is survived by a brother Charles Foley, and several nieces and nephews. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated in St. Patrick's Lady Cathedral, Saturday, April 11, 2015 at 9:30am where he had been an altar boy. Burial will be in St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx, NY. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. 1/3

CONNOR--Dr. Frances Partridge, Professor Emeritus of Education at Teacher's College, Columbia University, died on March 28, 2015 at her home in Boca Raton, FL. She was 95. Dr. Connor was the head of the Department of Special Education at Teacher's College (TC) for 23 years, from 1966-1989. She was also Director of the Special Education Research and Demonstration Center, and responsible for a multi-million dollar grant which allowed Teacher's College to construct the four story campus building, Thorndike Hall. Under her leadership, TC's Department of Special Education enrolled the largest number of graduate students in the nation in the 1980s. Dr. Connor's association with TC began in 1949 with the award of her Master's degree and subsequently with her Doctorate in 1953. She taught children with Cerebral Palsy in Suffern, NY and children with physical disabilities at the New York Rehabilitation Hospital in West Haverstraw, New York. After serving as a Research Associate for the Department of Education in Washington DC and as a Research Associate for the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene, she joined the TC Faculty and rose through the ranks quickly. She also taught at Hunter College's graduate program for several years. Dr. Connor was a sought after special education speaker and consultant, giving hundreds of speeches on educational issues, and consulting on educational programs throughout the nation and in over 60 countries around the world. Her sabbatical years were spent teaching as part of intensive graduate teaching programs in foreign countries. During the memorable year of 1962 she consulted in over 18 countries around the world and even one weekend left after classes on Friday, spoke at Oxford University and was back in time to teach Monday classes at TC. Dr. Connor was politically active in both Albany and Washington D.C. working to create positive change for disabled children. She served as Chairperson of Governor Hugh Carey's Committee on the Handicapped and was a member of the five person committee which helped close the infamous Willowbrook State School. Her efforts over many years in the 60's and 70's were crucial in the passage of the national law to make mandatory the education of all handicapped children. She served for many years on the National Advisory Committee to the United States Office of Education (now the Department of Education) and was a member of the Steering Committee of the White House Conference on the Education of the Handicapped from 1975-1978. She was a member of the Board of Trustees of Mt. St. Mary College, Newberry, NY from 1970 until her death. She was awarded an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from New Rochelle College. Her work for the Counsel for Exceptional Children (the largest professional organization on behalf of children with special needs) led to her presiding over the group in 1963 and 1964, to her being awarded The Best Contribution Award, and the J.E. Wallace Wallin Lifetime Achievement Award. She was also an officer and member of numerous other educational societies. Her extensive and notable research publications and writings are too numerous to name. Her contributions in education and advocacy have changed the world, and she will be remembered fondly by many. Frances Connor was predeceased by her loving husband of over 50 years, Dr. Leo Connor and two of her three sisters, Anne and Sybil. She is survived by her sister Katherine McIntyre of New York and many nieces and nephews. A Mass of the Christian Burial will be celebrated at 9:30 A.M. on Friday, April 24, 2015 at St. Joan of Arc Catholic Church, 501 SW 3rd Ave, Boca Raton, FL 33432. Interment to follow at Boca Raton Mausoleum. 1/3

She was preceded in death by her adoring husband Arthur (Rick) E. Seales. Survived by extended family and close friends, who love Dottye and will always remember her warmth, generosity, sharp wit, boundless energy and sense of style. 1/3
