SZOR--Leopold (94) Born April 4, 1921 in Lwow (Poland), died April 8, 2015 in New York, NY. A survivor of the Holocaust, he managed to escape the notorious Janowska concentration camp and traveled to Russia where he fought with the Polish brigade of the Red Army in the liberation of Warsaw. He later emigrated to New York where he lived for over 60 years. He was successful businessman who created an international media advertising firm based in Monaco. An avid amateur playwright, he wrote a number of short pieces set in the time of the Holocaust. A collection of his plays, entitled The True Messiah, was published in 2010 and is available online. He is survived by his long-time partner Tove-Lin Dalmau and by his son Daniel, daughter-in-law Katia, grandsons Henry and Alex and granddaughter Emily. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, April 12th, for immediate family at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, followed by a reception at home. 1/3

CRYSTAL--Allan. Allan A. Crystal, 85, of Southbury CT, died April 7, 2015, after a long decline. Mr. Crystal was born on August 11, 1929 in Brooklyn, New York, the youngest of six children born to Hirsch and Fanny Crystal. Mr. Crystal obtained a degree in accounting from New York University and completed Brooklyn Law School at night while working full-time. He then worked his way up the corporate ladder from an accountant at Railway Express to Vice-President and Treasurer for Pitney-Bowes, where he retired in 1993. He was then recruited by Governor Lowell Weicker to serve as Connecticut Commissioner of Revenue Services, where he successfully implemented the State's first income tax. For many years he also served in leadership roles in United Way of Connecticut. Allan and his wife of 60 years, Eleanor, raised three children in Westport, Connecticut, Francine (now of Boston, MA), Jeffrey (previously of Naugatuck, CT) and Howard (of Washington, DC). They reveled in the growth of their grandchildren Josh and Adam Krigman, Jesse and Jake Crystal, and Sheina and Nate Crystal, along with numerous nieces and nephews. Allan and Ellie retired to Heritage Village in Southbury, where he served as Vice-President and Treasurer, and where they lived for 10 years. They loved sailing and later in retirement in Bluffton, South Carolina, he enjoyed playing tennis and pickle ball. They more recently returned to Southbury to live at The Watermark. His funeral will be held Sunday, April 12 at 1pm at Temple B'nai Israel on Main Street N., Southbury, CT followed by internment at Melchizedek Cemetery, Waterbury, CT. In lieu of flowers, his family requests donations be made to Memory Matters (www.memory-matters.org), the Alzheimer's Association (www.alz.org), or the Tuberous Sclerosis Alliance (www.tsalliance.org). The Southbury Funeral Home of Munson-Lovetere, 235 Main St. North is in charge of services. For online condolences visit: www.munsonloveterefuneralhome.com. 1/3

FACCUITO--Eugene Louis. Luigi, innovator of his world famous jazz dance technique, died in his home in New York City on April 7th. He was 90. Born Eugene Louis Faccuito, the stage name, "Luigi," was given to him by Gene Kelly. Luigi performed in film, TV, Broadway and other venues. He became an internationally lauded teacher who influenced many, from a "Who's Who" in show business to people in every walk of life. A wake will be held at Vanella's Chapel, New York City, Saturday, April 11, 2-5pm. He will be buried in Steubenville, Ohio. FORBES--Patricia (nee Walsh) 83, of Brooklyn, NY passed away peacefully at home on Friday, April 10th, 2015. She is predeceased by her husband Raymond C. Forbes. Sarn (Larry) and her eleven grandchildren. Devoted sister to Irene Whiting, Marie Walsh and Marguerite Walsh. She is now reunited in heaven with her loving parents Patrick J. and Mary Walsh. DEVINE--W. John Jr.,W. John Devine Jr, went to his heavenly home on February 17, 2014 following a year long battle with leukemia that he came close to beating after extensive chemo treatments. John's Celebration of Life will be held in the San Diego, CA area on Saturday April 25th, prior to what would be his 75th birthday. Anyone who knew John well and is interested in attending, please contact wjohndevinecol@gmail.com for more details. John was preceded in death by his father William John (Jack) Devine Sr., mother Rita Marie Kiernan Devine and former wife Sara (Tabby) Tyler (Devine). John was the firstborn son, born in Brooklyn, NY on April 27th, 1940. He attended St. Anselm's Priory (now Abbey) High School in D.C. and Catholic University and the University of Maryland. In 1958, John joined his parents in the Chevy Chase Capers Show in Chevy Chase, MD where he did an amazing unforgettable performance gyrating and back bending with a guitar in his hands during an Elvis impersonation! John had a sense of humor like none other. His stories were spun so that they were different every time and they were funny! Johnny had a warm heart, genius mind and genuine generous giving personality. All in all, John will be remembered for his unique qualities that made life worth living! John could sit at a piano and play Exodus, without ever having a lesson in his life. John served in the US Army from 1963 to 1965. His gift of encouraging and entrusting those he worked with while delegating in a fun-loving way, gave John friends through work as well as casual and formal events, especially bridge and golf tournaments. John was a genius with numbers, math of any kind and used his knowledge in a multitude of areas throughout his education, army service, opening Toys R Us stores as Executive Vice President and COO, hiring and with wisdom, found funny experiences that he related along his life's way! John joined Toys R Us in 1966 and helped grow the company from four stores to over 200 and from $10 million to over $1 billion in sales. He opened their second market in Los Angeles in 1968. In 1972 he was promoted to Executive V.P. and COO and started their international division in 1982. He retired in 1983 to the Dominican Republic. In 1991, John became Chairman of Child World. He moved to San Diego in 1996, when he bought Auto Parts Club, and served as Chairman and CEO. John was a world class bridge player including being three-time National Bridge Champion. He began playing bridge with his brother Brian as teenagers by playing "honeymoon bridge." They later ventured out to tournaments and were known as "The Smith Bros.", because of their heavy beards - Jade Barrett recalls playing against them. John owned a bridge club in Tenafly, NJ in the 1980s. John won the Jacoby Open Swiss in 1985 playing with Roger Bates, John Mohan, and Alan Sontag. The same team placed second in the Mitchell BAM in 1985. They also won the Jacoby Open Swiss again in 1987 with the addition of Eddie Kantar. John was also an outstanding golfer including being a three-time Club Champion at the Knickerbocker Country Club in New Jersey and Sr. Club Champion and two-time winner of the Lomas Cup at Lomas Santa Fe Country Club in Solana Beach, CA. John is survived by his beloved fiance, Jan Gallagher, his two sons, Jack and Liam, and his two daughters, Tyler and Juliana. He is also survived by his two brothers, Brian and Terry and two sisters Rita Marie Grace and Ann Burns, and his three grandsons, Walker, Miles, and Dominic. He also is survived by his ex-wife Karin Stella Devine. John's Celebration of Life will be held in San Diego, CA on Saturday April 25th, 2015. For all who knew John, please send photos and stories to: wjohndevinecol@gmail.com 1/3

WELP--Theodore M. (Ted). June 13, 1934 - March 8, 2015. The Board of Directors, leadership and staff of Research Corporation Technologies remember our longtime director and friend, Ted Welp, who died tragically in Boise, Idaho, along with his wife, Elaine, and adult son, Tom. A founding director of the company, Mr. Welp provided unwavering vision and guidance to RCT for nearly 30 years. We grieve this senseless loss but celebrate his life and good works. Optimism - Love - Family 1/3

VAN HOUTEN--Erskine Blauvelt Jr.,90, of Richmond, VA, died on April 9, 2015 after experiencing declining health. He was born to Erskine Blauvelt and Sarah Margaret MacLeod van Houten on November 25, 1924 in Nyack, NY. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Harriet Zahner van Houten; and his second wife, Harriet Craigie Hotchkiss van Houten. He is survived by his daughter, Dr. Margaret V. Blanchard; his grandchildren, Anne Lawton Blanchard and Thomas MacLeod Blanchard; and his sister, Elizabeth Sprague and her husband, David. Also surviving are his stepchildren, Charles A. Hotchkiss, Carter W. Hotchkiss and Nelle P. Hotchkiss. Erskine was very fond of his niece and nephews, Susan MacGregor, Lawrence and Gordon Sprague. A memorial service will be held 2:30pm, Tuesday, April 14, at Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church, Richmond, Va. Burial in Hollywood Cemetery will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Deerfield Academy, the Richmond Council of the Navy League of the United States or Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church. 1/3

SEALES--Dorothy J. Dr. Dottye Seales passed away on March 23, 2015. An educator, psychologist, activist and world traveler, she was raised in Orlando FL and moved to New York City as a young lady. Dr. Seales was an Adjunct Professor at the College of New Rochelle/School of New Resources, and formerly an Associate Professor and Lecturer at CCNY. She earned her Doctorate in Counseling and Psychology from Fairleigh Dickerson University and several Master of Science degrees from CCNY. She was preceded in death by her adoring husband Arthur (Rick) E. Seales. Survived by extended family and close friends, who love Dottye and will always remember her warmth, generosity, sharp wit, boundless energy and sense of style. 1/3
LANGFORD--Therese Kernanec, born February 17, 1927 in New York City, died April 3rd, 2015 in Houston, TX. 1/3

FACCUITO--Eugene Louis. Luigi, innovator of his world famous jazz dance technique, died in his home in New York City on April 7th. He was 90. Born Eugene Louis Faccuito, the stage name, "Luigi," was given to him by Gene Kelly. Luigi performed in film, TV, Broadway and other venues. He became an internationally lauded teacher who influenced many, from a "Who's Who" in show business to people in every walk of life. A wake will be held at Vanella's Chapel, New York City, Saturday, April 11, 2-5pm. He will be buried in Steubenville, Ohio. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to Luigi's Jazz Centre Scholarship Fund c/o his school. 1/3

FORBES--Patricia (nee Walsh) 83, of Brooklyn, NY passed away peacefully at home on Friday, April 10th, 2015. She is predeceased by her husband Raymond C. Forbes. She is survived by her five loving children Christopher J. Forbes (Kim), Raymond J. Forbes (Cynthia), Patrick J. Forbes (Bettina), Marie-Regina Sotos (Peter) and Patricia M. Sarn (Larry) and her eleven grandchildren. Devoted sister to Irene Whiting, Marie Walsh and Marguerite Walsh. She is now reunited in heaven with her loving parents Patrick J. and Mary Walsh. She was born on March 15th, 1932 in Newfoundland, Canada and came to this country, which she very greatly loved, at age five. She built a beautiful life, centered on family and traveled the world which she thoroughly enjoyed. A mass will be held in her honor at St. Patrick's Church in Brooklyn at 10:00am on Monday, April 13th.

BERWITZ--Mildred. Remembering our Mom on the first anniversary of her passing at the age of 94. A music major at Northwestern University, Mom was a brilliant musician for her entire life. She played piano, violin, viola, cello and bass with the Queens College Orchestral Society for a remarkable 58 years, as well as other ensembles, countless chamber music groups and her amazing solo performances for family and friends. She was survived by Abner Berwitz, her husband of 72 years (who joined her four months later), her children Barbara Berwitz Miller, Ken Berwitz and Larry Berwitz, seven grandchildren, five greatgrandchildren and her sisters Esther Heller and Gloria Gimbel. Mom was as sweet and gentle a soul as God ever put on this earth. We miss her beautiful face, her magnificent singing voice and, most of all, the unconditional love she gave to us all. 1/3

HARRIS--Renee, (nee Levine), 85, of East Brunswick, NJ passed away peacefully on April 10, 2015. Predeceased on February 14, 2015 by husband Herman, she is survived by her sons Larry (Constance Schwartz) and Bill (Lori Nanton), and grandson Cole. She was proud to be a President of the Middlesex County Ostomy Association and a Life Member of Hadassah. 1/3
HARMAN--Sidney. August 5, 1918 - April 12, 2011 My beloved father, Not a day goes by. Love, Lynn 1/3

SCHEINMAN--Robert L.,Jr., 55. Preceded in death by his father and grandparents, survived by his mother Annette Bodzin and his sisters Wendy Kadens and Kate Scheinman. May his memory be for a blessing. 1/3

NILES--Alex, 32. Son of Susan and Stephen Niles, brother of Jonathan, grandson of Lola Zuckerman and John Niles. Loved life, friends, and family with passion. His SMILE will never be forgotten.

SIMON--Lisa. The staff of Sesame Workshop, and cast and crew of Sesame Street mourn the loss of our colleague Lisa Simon. BLAU--Lawrence Martin, PhD, 77, April 2, 2015. Son of the late Frances Suchman Blau and Joseph Blau. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Survived by wife, Judith H. Blau; daughter and family, Laura, Jonathan, Ethan and Cassandra Paul; son and family, Richard, Arleen and Joseph Blau. Born in New York City, resident of New Rochelle and Eastchester, NY. Graduate of Princeton '59, University of Rochester, Physics PhD '65. Research Physicist '65-'69 at Columbia University. Attending Physicist for Nuclear Medicine and Director of Computer Services at Hospital for Special Surgery '69-'87. Vice President of Database Administration at Instinet Corp., Reuters '88-'02. Independent consultant after retirement. A loving man of strength, courage and intellect, he will be missed. 1/3

DEVINE--W. John Jr.,W. John Devine Jr, went to his heavenly home on February 17, 2014 following a year long battle with leukemia that he came close to beating after extensive chemo treatments. John's Celebration of Life will be held in the San Diego, CA area on Saturday April 25th, prior to what would be his 75th birthday. Anyone who knew John well and is interested in attending, please contact wjohndevinecol@gmail.com for more details. John was preceded in death by his father William John (Jack) Devine Sr., mother Rita Marie Kiernan Devine and former wife Sara (Tabby) Tyler (Devine). John was the firstborn son, born in Brooklyn, NY on April 27th, 1940. He attended St. Anselm's Priory (now Abbey) High School in D.C. and Catholic University and the University of Maryland. In 1958, John joined his parents in the Chevy Chase Capers Show in Chevy Chase, MD where he did an amazing unforgettable performance gyrating and back bending with a guitar in his hands during an Elvis impersonation! John had a sense of humor like none other. His stories were spun so that they were different every time and they were funny! Johnny had a warm heart, genius mind and genuine generous giving personality. All in all, John will be remembered for his unique qualities that made life worth living! John could sit at a piano and play Exodus, without ever having a lesson in his life. John served in the US Army from 1963 to 1965. His gift of encouraging and entrusting those he worked with while delegating in a fun-loving way, gave John friends through work as well as casual and formal events, especially bridge and golf tournaments. John was a genius with numbers, math of any kind and used his knowledge in a multitude of areas throughout his education, army service, opening Toys R Us stores as Executive Vice President and COO, hiring and with wisdom, found funny experiences that he related along his life's way! John joined Toys R Us in 1966 and helped grow the company from four stores to over 200 and from $10 million to over $1 billion in sales. He opened their second market in Los Angeles in 1968. In 1972 he was promoted to Executive V.P. and COO and started their international division in 1982. He retired in 1983 to the Dominican Republic. In 1991, John became Chairman of Child World. He moved to San Diego in 1996, when he bought Auto Parts Club, and served as Chairman and CEO. John was a world class bridge player including being three-time National Bridge Champion. He began playing bridge with his brother Brian as teenagers by playing "honeymoon bridge." They later ventured out to tournaments and were known as "The Smith Bros.", because of their heavy beards - Jade Barrett recalls playing against them. John owned a bridge club in Tenafly, NJ in the 1980s. John won the Jacoby Open Swiss in 1985 playing with Roger Bates, John Mohan, and Alan Sontag. The same team placed second in the Mitchell BAM in 1985. They also won the Jacoby Open Swiss again in 1987 with the addition of Eddie Kantar. John was also an outstanding golfer including being a three-time Club Champion at the Knickerbocker Country Club in New Jersey and Sr. Club Champion and two-time winner of the Lomas Cup at Lomas Santa Fe Country Club in Solana Beach, CA. John is survived by his beloved fiance, Jan Gallagher, his two sons, Jack and Liam, and his two daughters, Tyler and Juliana. He is also survived by his two brothers, Brian and Terry and two sisters Rita Marie Grace and Ann Burns, and his three grandsons, Walker, Miles, and Dominic. He also is survived by his ex-wife Karin Stella Devine. John's Celebration of Life will be held in San Diego, CA on Saturday April 25th, 2015. For all who knew John, please send photos and stories to: wjohndevinecol@gmail.com 1/3

LEE--King H.,died on April 7, 2015 in New York, NY, in the presence of his wife Shui Ying Chang and sons Tsee Yuan Lee and Tsee Yung Lee, after a valiant battle against colon cancer. GRUSS--Emanuel, 93, died April 10, 2015, at his home in New York, NY. Mike was born in Lwow, Poland, to Oscar and Regina Gruss. He obtained a bachelor's degree from the University of Manchester, England, and fought with the U.S. Army in the Battle of the Bulge. After World War II, he became a partner at Oscar Gruss & Son Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Ria, daughter Brenda and son-in-law Daniel Hirsch, daughter Leslie and Michael Kramer, grandchildren Oren Hirsch, Ripton Rosen, Jonathan Hirsch, Morgan Rosen, and Leni Hirsch, and sister Elizabeth Goldberg. Carlos Suarez, Kindu Jones, and Phil Medina considered Mike their grandfather also. The funeral will be held at noon on Sunday, April 12, at the Abraham Joshua Heschel School, 30 West End Avenue (at 61st Street), New York, NY, followed by interment at Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. HALSBAND--Jerome. Passed away on April 8th, 2015 he was surrounded by family and friends. A graduate of Cornell University '54, he went on to serve in the USAF for three years as the Assistant Director of Special Services for the United Kingdom, Ireland, and Norway. Following his time in the military, he became the Director of Camp Lenni Lenape in 1958. Known as a giant in the camping industry, Jerry served as a Board member for: the Association of Private Camps, the American Camping Association New York Section, the New York State Camp Directors Association, and was President of the National Camping Association. In 1973, he became the first owner of both Raquette Lake Girls Camp and Raquette Lake Boys Camp. He retired in 2000 and continued to work as a staff recruiter for over 100 camps around the country. He also served as a Director of the Smalley Foundation for many years. Jerry is survived by his loving wife Rennie Halsband, son Kenneth Halsband wife Brooke and Grandson Jacob, son Michael Halsband, and longtime friend Steve Norman. In lieu of flowers, a donation in his memory can be made to the Wounded Warrior Project. Jerry touched many lives through his years of directing summer camps, all who knew and loved him will miss him dearly. 1/3

HENNESSY--Rubye. Rubye Graham Hennessy, died peacefully at Cornell Presbyterian Hospital, New York City as a result of a stroke on April 6, 2015. She was 85 years old. She was born in Kentucky August 31.1929 and graduated with honors in journalism from the University of Kentucky in 1949. Rubye was fashion editor for the Philadelphia Inquirer from 1959 to 1973 during the height of the era of fashion celebrities and designers. She was one of the earliest American fashion writers to regularly attend the European Couture shows in Paris, Rome, Milan and London in the early 60's. She went on to become the executive editor of Seventeen Magazine from 1973 to 1975 and was known for her innovative writing and the introduction of fashion to the teenage generation of the 70's. Her most famous publication was Seventeen's cover story featuring Caroline of Monaco when she turned seventeen. She married G. Michael Hennessy in 1977 and partnered with him in 1982 in G. Michael Hennessy Furs of New York. Predeceased by her husband and is survived by her sister Dr. Nettie King, niece Karen King, grandniece Taylor Jordan Brantly and G. Michael Hennessy's children. The special people in her life were her "adopted" daughters Odile de Candia and Susan Ciccone. Her interment is being handled by Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home in New York City. No service is currently planned. Contributions to the Metropolitan Opera in her memory will be appreciated. 1/3

SMITH--Alan Garrigues, MD. Dr. Smith was born in Minneapolis, MN on July 14, 1927 and died on April 5, 2015 in Brooklyn, NY at the age of 87. In 1945 he joined the Navy right before his High School graduation from Blake School. After the end of WWII, Alan attended Dartmouth College and graduated in 1949. He took pre-med courses at the University of Minnesota where he met his future wife, Joyce Elaine Schlemmer in chemistry class. They were married in 1953 and he graduated from the U of MN Medical School in 1955. He found his vocation when he became the Chief of Orthopaedic Surgery at the Brooklyn Veterans Admin. Hospital in New York in 1964, specializing in the rehabilitation of amputees and training residents. He enjoyed taking his wheelchair bound patients to the New York Giants games. Alan rode his bicycle to work almost every day until his retirement in 1987. He spent much time at his cabin in the Adirondacks near Owl Pond, camping with his family, hiking, chopping wood, fishing, skiing, boating and picking berries. At home in Bay Ridge he tended his garden with Joyce and his cat. He was a fan of the Yankees and came out to support the runners at the NYC Marathon. He is predeceased by his eldest son, David and leaves his devoted wife of 61 years, Joyce and two children: Margaret "Peggy" G. Smith of Manhattan and Peter A. Smith, MD, of Chicago, Il (Mary K. Morrell, MD); four wonderful grandchildren: Andrew G. Greissman, Katherine E. Greissman, Benjamin M. Smith, and Audrey R. Smith. He will be remembered as a man of moral character and determination. Services by McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, Brooklyn, NY www. McLaughlinandSons.com. Funeral at Union Church of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Sunday, April 12, 2pm. Burial at Green-Wood Cemetery. Donations can be made to: Parkinson's Disease Foundation, www.pdf.org Union Church of Bay Ridge, www.ucbr.org The Nature Conservancy www.nature.org 1/3

GOODMAN--Brunhilde Metlay. Died on March 31, 2015 at age 90. Beloved mother of Ann Goodman, Naomi Press (Steve) and David Goodman (Wendy Felson). THOM--Anne-Marie. November 13, 1921-April 1, 2015, 93, of Sun City and formerly of New York City died April 1st at home. She is survived by her two long time friends, Janet Van Name and Barbara M. Hinck of Sun City, a sister, three nieces and two nephews all living outside the area. Ms. Thom was born in Wilhelmshaven, Germany and came to Canada in 1926 with her parents and then to New York a few years later. A graduate of Bellevue Hospital School of Nursing in New York City, she earned a Bachelor's degree in Public Health Nursing and a Masters in Supervision and Administration from New York University. After graduation, she joined the Army Air Corps nursing division with the rank of Lieutenant and rose to the rank of Captain spending three years caring for wounded P38 pilots at an Army hospital in Oklahoma. In 1947, Ms. Thom joined the Visiting Nurse Service of New York (VNSNY) as a staff nurse and spent the next 13 years moving from staff to Supervisory positions. From 1960-1962, while on loan from VNSNY, she served as Project Director of Columbia University's Long Stay Hospital Study on patients in voluntary and municipal hospitals. She coauthored a report of this study which was recognized as a precursor to the many hospital utilization studies that followed. In 1962, she joined the Associated Hospital Service of New York, which later became Blue Cross/Blue Shield of Greater New York, to head its Home Care Department. For eleven years there she helped many metropolitan hospitals to establish Blue Cross participating home care departments and discharge planning units also working with many Visiting Nurse Associations and Health Departments in Greater New York and surrounding counties in these efforts. Appointed as Director of Utilization Review at BlueCross/Blue Shield in 1973, she helped develop a system of retrospective review of Medicare and Blue Cross patient records from hospitals, nursing homes and home health agencies. During these times, she held faculty appointments at Columbia University, NY Medical College and Cornell University-New York Hospital. In 1976, Ms. Thom became the Executive Director of the VNSNY and was responsible for many innovations there in the delivery of home health care services, retiring from that position in 1982. During all of these years she was an influential Board member on multiple health organizations and a frequent and popular speaker at local, state and national meetings on the emerging field of home health services and its significant value in providing an alternative to prolonged hospitalization. Services handled by Sauls Funeral Home. Anyone wishing to, may send donations to the Friends of the Performing Arts of the Lowcountry for the Sun City Chorus or to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY, 107 East 70th Street, NY, NY 10021. 1/3

SHIELDS--Margaret McNeely died on April 5th 2015 on her way to church for Easter Sunday. She is survived by her beloved husband of 38 years, Robert McCormick Shields, Jr., her two loving children, Jennifer Shields Christopher and Virginia (Ginger) McCormick Shields, and her new granddaughter, Sadie Elizabeth Christopher. She is also survived by her brother, John Walker McNeely, and her sister, Joy McNeely Engel. Margaret was the most loving mother, wife and friend anyone could ever hope for. She was a life long New Yorker who graduated from The Nightingale-Bamford School in 1964 and a very active member of the community, supporting and volunteering at many different organizations and charities including The New York Junior League, The Colonial Dames of America, The City Gardens Club of New York and The Bridge Fund of New York. She was so artistic and creative, with a passion for flowers and making jewelry. She exuded warmth, kindness and generosity to all who knew her. With her beautiful smile and positive attitude she would bring strength and happiness to any situation. She touched the lives of so many. Margaret will be deeply missed by all. A memorial Service will be held at 3pm on Monday, April 13 at The Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Ave (Corner of 74th St), New York. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Margaret's name to The Bridge Fund of New York (www.thebridgefund.org) 1

SONNENBLICK--Jack Earl. Was born October l, 1923 in Washington Heights, NY. He was the eldest son of Nathan and Lillian Sonnenblick and grew up in Mt. Vernon. He graduated from Horace Mann School. After studying building construction at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he served in World War II as First Lieutenant in the Combat Engineers under General George Patton in Europe, and was in the Battle of The Bulge. He married his wife Dani (Augusta Dann) in 1946, and they raised their family in Harrison, NY. He started his real estate career in 1946, eventually becoming the Chairman of the Board of Sonnenblick Goldman Company, a National Mortgage Banking and Real Estate firm specializing in he placement of large commercial mortgages. Jack was former trustee of the New York Bank for Savings, and was the original Managing Trustee and Founder of the North American Mortgage Investors, the first publicly held R.E.I.T. He was also the Founder of Mortgage Growth Investors, another publicly held R.E.I.T. Jack was chairman of the Mortgage Committee of the New York Real Estate Board in 1967-68. In 1971-72 he was President of the National Assoc. Of Real Estate Investments Trust and a former Director of the Brokerage Division of the New York Real Estate Board. He was also a Board Member of the American Technian Society, and a former member of the Board of Trustees of the Horace Mann School. After retiring to Florida he and his wife Dani became legacy members of the Boca Raton Museum of Art, to whom they have left a substantial part of their art collection. Mr. Sonnenblick was member and former President of Boca Rio Golf Club, and was member of the Old Oaks Country Club, in Purchase, NY. Jack loved golf, and was always know as the best bunker player at Boca Rio. He was a very well respected bridge player in New York and Florida, and his reputation as an ethical person was well deserved. He leaves behind his beloved wife Dani, after 68 years of marriage. May was to be their 69th anniversary. He leaves his cherished children, Jon Sonnenblick, Micki Sonnenblick Hirsch (Steven Hirsch), and Robert Sonnenblick (Pam Sonnenblick). He was adored by his eight grandchildren, Karen, Lisa, Jesse, Adam, Leah, Alexandra, Cary, Savannah, and six great-grandchildren, Daniel, Jonah, Nicholas, Julie, Henry and Jack. He also leaves behind his sisters, Jean Saklad, and Muriel Perry, and brother Arthur Sonnenblick and (Sybil), his brother-in-law and sister-in-law, Richard and Rosemary Dann, and his devoted dog Poochon. The family would like to give thanks to his devoted aides and to Hospice for their exception care. Donations in his memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., W. Palm Beach, FL 33407. Boca Regional Hospital, Art: Marcus Neuroscience Institute, 745 Meadows Rd. Boca Raton, FL 33486. 1/3

MERCK--Elizabeth Mead. Died peacefully at home with her loving family, hospice nurses by her side, and her two beloved Jack Russell Terriers on her bed Friday, April 3. She lived at her farm, The Fields, Bedminster, NJ with her family since the early 1950s. Her husband George Wall Merck died in 1984. She recently celebrated her 95th birthday and was delighted by the surprise entertainment: a belly dancer. Elizabeth Amy Mead, or "Betty" as she was known, was born in Guelph, Ontario in 1920 to British parents, Olive Mary Holden and William Arthur Mead. Her mother remarried Edward H. Bennett, the architect and city planner, known for his collaboration with Daniel Burnham on the 1909 "Plan of Chicago." She grew up in Chicago and Lake Forest, Il. She attended the Chicago Latin School for Girls, Miss Porter's School, and for a short stint, the Brillantmont School in Lausanne, Switzerland, where she said she learned to speak French, iron a man's shirt in 5 minutes and make perfect hollandaise sauce. She continued as an excellent and adventurous cook for the rest of her life. Mrs. Merck said she grew up on a horse, starting at the age of five. Betty continued to be connected to horses for her entire life - with the Pony Club, winning point-to-points, fox hunting, on a riding safari in Botswana, and running steeplechase horses. She served for several years as Joint Master of the Essex Foxhounds in her mid 80s, and rode her beloved steed Smokey until she was 94. Betty served her community in elected office on the Bedminster Township Council from 1975-1989. She served on local township commissions including the Open Space Farmland Advisory Committee, the Lamington Conservancy, and on the boards of the New Jersey Nature Conservancy, Raritan Headwaters Association, the Lamington Conservancy and Miss Porter's School. A lifelong conservationist, Mrs. Merck was recently celebrated by the Garden Club of America Regional Chapter with an award for conservation. Bedminster recently dedicated a special park bench to her with words she liked, "It is nice to be important but more important to be nice." In 1995, she and her son George "Laddy" Merck began a partnership, The Fields Stable, starting with the first of their winning jumpers, Brigade of Guards. Tom Voss was the trainer of their many winners including Your Sum Man, Approaching Squall, and Guelph. Guelph became three-time champion filly. Betty loved to grow her own flowers and vegetables started from seed and loved to tend to her fields, trees and all her animals. She will be remembered for her loyal service in her community, her gracious style, and her energetic enjoyment of a robust social and sporting life. In addition to her husband, she was predeceased by her brother, Joseph Mead, and her stepbrother Edward H. Bennett, Jr. She was the mother of Antony M. Merck (Ann Wimberley), Josephine A. Merck (James Stevenson), George F. Merck (Adele Shook), six grandchildren, Oona Coy and Morgan Coy, Elizabeth Merck Lake and Elliot Merck, George Merck and Grace Merck, and six great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St Luke's Church Gladstone, NJ on May 30 at 11am. Donations may be made to the Raritan Headwaters Association (raritanheadwaters.org) or Atlantic Home Care Hospice, 465 South St., Morristown, NJ 07960. 1/3

WILHOFT--Dr. Daniel C. Born November 16, 1930, passed away peacefully on April 5, 2015. He was predeceased by wife Dorothy Duxbury Wilhoft. He is survived by his current wife Elizabeth C. Hotaling; sister, Jean Wilhoft; son, Daniel C Wilhoft, Jr and wife, Amelia; daughter Linda Wilhoft Rhodes and husband, Jeffrey, and three grandchildren, TJ, Alex and Mike Forlenza. Dr. Wilhoft spent four years in the United States Navy Submarine Service. He then pursued his education, completing undergraduate studies at Rutgers, Newark. His graduate studies were conducted at the University of California, Berkeley, where he attained a PhD in Zoology. Dr. Wilhoft contributed greatly to the advancement of herpetology, focusing his research on reptilian endocrinology. He was awarded a Fullbright Scholarship to conduct research in Australia before returning to Rutgers where he gained tenure. He retired as Professor Emeritus from his alma mater after 40 years of dedicated service in the field and lecture hall. The Biology Department honored him by launching an annual seminar series in his name. Dr. Wilhoft volunteered for 10 years with the South Orange Rescue Squad and later in life, served as president of the New Jeresey Naval Museum. He was a man who worked hard in pursuit of his goals; traveling extensively through six continents to see the world and experience other cultures. He was kind to everyone he met and was an inspiration to his family, friends, students and colleagues. He will be missed by all that knew him. A celebration of Daniel's life and interment at Arlington National Cemetery will be held at a later date. 1/3

RIEBER--Dr. Robert. Dr. Robert W. Rieber, professor emeritus, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, of New York City and Prospect Point, Maine, passed peacefully on April 9 at age 83. Dr. Rieber gained recognition asserting that "Sybil," whose tale brought multiple-personality disorder to public attention, actually had a single troubled personality. Dr. Rieber authored "Manufacturing Social Distress: Psychopathy in Everyday Life" and "The Psychopathology of Language and Cognition." He edited the Encyclopedia of the History of Psychological Theories, and The Collected Works of L.S. Vygotsky. A film noir connoisseur, he co-wrote "Film, Television, and the Psychology of the Social Dream." A Penn State grad, with doctorate from University of London, he was on faculty of Columbia, and fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Psychological Association, and New York Academy of Sciences. He was editor of the Journal of Social Distress and the Journal of Psycholinguistics. Lover of rare literary treasures, his distinguished collection is now catalogued. Survived by wife, Louise, children Dan (Dee) Rieber, Andi (Steven) Irwin, and Sara Rieber, and granddaughters, Kathryn Rose Rieber and Rose Irwin. 1/3

MUELLER--Henry, of Summit passed away peacefully on April 9, 2015. Henry was born in Brooklyn, NY, on June 24, 1917. When he graduated from high school in 1934, he aspired to become a journalist, but no post was available. He took a "temporary" job at Citibank as a page and studied economics nights at New York University. When a New York Times offer came, he couldn't accept it because of conflicting hours. The bank then paid his way through Princeton. When he graduated in 1941, he was recruited for the diplomatic service and posted to Panama, then Cairo. His first assignment, developing courier networks, was shadowy and took him over much of the world. In 1944, he was present at the Breton Woods monetary and financial conference. He then volunteered for the Marines, becoming adjutant of a Corsair fighter squadron and attaining the rank of captain. In 1946, he returned to the State Department and was appointed secretary of the Second West Indian Conference, convened to improve economic and social conditions throughout the islands. Following this, he rejoined Citibank, rising through the ranks to become chairman of its credit policy committee, overseeing a $77 billion loan portfolio. He was a visiting lecturer at the University of Virginia for twenty-one years and founding chairman of the Darden School's Center for International Banking Studies. Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh awarded him a doctorate in 1981, honoring him as "a leading innovator and thinker in the field of banking and education". He was a fruitful author and teacher, inspiring generations of bankers to develop professionally. When he retired from banking in June 1982, Mueller became chairman of SAAB Cars in this country and served on the boards of Skandinaviska Enskilida Banen (New York), Atlas Copco, and other companies in the Wallenberg group. He was chairman of the Swedish-American Chamber of Commerce-USA and a director of the Marcus Wallenberg Foundation in the U.S. The King of Sweden decorated him with the Order of the Polar Star in 1986. A private memorial service will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Henry's name to the Trustees of Princeton University. For more information, please visit www.bradleyfuneralhomes. com. 1/3

WHITAKER--Francis C.,84 died on Friday the 20th of February, 2015 at his home in Aiken, South Carolina. Born 1930 in Camden, South Carolina, he was the youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Clarke Whitaker, brother of Caleb Clarke Whitaker III of Cincinnati and Palm Beach and sister Mary Whitaker Mithoefer of Charleston. His family arrived in Jamestown, Virginia in 1619 and by the mid-1700s had settled in South Carolina. He is a descendent of signer of the Declaration of Independence, Edward Rutledge. He attended Woodbury Forest in Virginia and the University of South Carolina. In 1956 he married the former Elizabeth Low, daughter of E.H. Low and Mary Holland of New York City. He worked in investment banking at Fahnestock and Lazard. He then moved his family to England, where in addition to restoring an 18th century manor house, Wyberton Park, he established an antiques business specializing in English and French 18th century furniture. Mr. Whitaker was a member of Piping Rock, Locust Valley, NY and the Racquet & Tennis Club, NY, as well as Boodle's and the Hurlingham Club, London and the Huguenot Society of South Carolina. He is survived by three children, Susan Clarke Capparelle of Cos Cob, CT, Andrew Burnet Rhett Whitaker of Darien, CT. and Edward Rutledge Burnet Whitaker of New York City, and as well as three granddaughters. 1/3

ARONSON--Stanley Maynard, M.D.,1922-2015. Emeritus Professor, Brown University, Founding Dean Brown University School of Medicine, Professor and Dean of SUNY, Downstate, 1954-1970. CCNY, 1942, NYU College of Medicine, 1947, Harvard School of Public Health, 1981. Numerous honors, awards, professorships, NIH Commissions, author of 15 textbooks and 400+ published scientific papers. Nationally known weekly columnist. U.S. Army 1942-1947, 1951-1952. Beloved husband of Gale Matheson Aronson, and the late Betty Aronson, M.D. Cherished father of Sarah Aronson, M.D., Susan Symons, and the late Lisa Aronson; adored grandfather and great-grandfather. Memorial in Providence, RI, May 1. Details Brown University Alpert School of Medicine. 1/3

GIBSON--William S. January 2, 1933 - March 24, 2015. Survived by wife Charmaine and children Bill, Tracy, Susan, Josh, six grandchildren Bill was one of the finest intellectuals in the Insurance Business. His sense of humor as well as his kindness will be missed by all.
SONNENBLICK--Jack E. He was the older brother everyone should have. I loved him and will miss him. Arthur 1/3

OLER--Rev. Clarke, died April 6, 2015 at age 89. Beloved father to Ellen, Kim and John, this generous, compassionate, revered Episcopal priest at Holy Trinity Church in Manhattan and All Saints Pasadena taught us always to believe in our God-given goodness. He is survived by his three grateful children and four grandchildren, and will be deeply missed by everyone who knew him. 1/3
BERNSTEIN--Steven Jay. Always loved. Always missed. 1/3
PESKA--Paul. (1943-2015). A long-time Yonkers resident, Paul left a legacy of varied interest and memories with his daughter, Caroline, sister, Blanka (Alex), nieces, and friends. He will be missed.

BENNET--Carrie L. Carrie L. Bennet (nee Moyses), Age 89. Beloved wife of the late John Bennet; dear mother of Dr. John (Beth) of Lakewood, OH and Andrew (Rocio) of Barcelona, Spain; grandmother of Julia and Laura Bennet and Carolina and Richard Bennet; sister of Harvey Moyses (Marian) of Upland, CA; daughter of the late Harry and Johannah Moyses. Passed away Wednesday, April 8, 2015. Friends may call in The McGorray-Hanna Funeral Home of Lakewood, 14133 Detroit Avenue, Sunday 1-4pm. Interment Private. Family suggests memorial contributions to ASPCA (American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals) P.O. Box 96929, Washington, DC 20090-6929. Services handled by McGorray-Hanna Funeral Home 14133 Detroit Ave. Lakewood, OH 44107. www.mcgorray-hanna.com 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Magda. 92, of Yonkers, NY, passed away peacefully on Sunday, April 5, 2015. She is predeceased by her husband, Dr. Bernard Schneider, of 52 years, her first daughter, Dr. Susan Spencer, and her brother, Tarjan Gyorgy. She is survived by her daughters, Beth Weingarth of Wallingford, CT and Karen Kimball of North Haven, CT, her grandchildren, Andrea Spencer-Kimchi (Eyal), Joanna Spencer-Segal (Yaniv), Michael Weingarth (Ellen Devine) and Caroline Kimball, and two great- grandchildren. She was born in Kisvarda, Hungary in 1922, came to this country when she was 24 years old, and built a wonderful life. She was loved and adored by her family, friends, and by the patients of her husband with whom she worked for many years supporting his medical practice. She was a devoted and loving wife, mother, grandmother and recently a great-grandmother. She was fearless, strong, and determined, and extraordinarily gracious and generous to family and friends alike. The essence of class, beauty and elegance, with a keen sense of wit, she was a source of strength to everyone around her. She always did the right thing and inspired others to do the same. A remarkable woman, a remarkable life. Her shining light and enduring love will continue to burn in everyone who knew her. She will be greatly missed, and shall remain forever with much love and admiration in our hearts and minds. Funeral services will take place Sunday, April 12th at 10am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Donations in her memory and the spirit of caring can be made to Habitat for Humanity International: A Gift From the Heart, 322 West Lamar Street, Americus, Georgia 31709, or www.habitat.org, or 1-800-422-4828. 1/3
KROLL--Douglas. July 7, 1967 - April 8, 2002 Your spirit, your love, your humor, your generosity, and your passion for life live on in all who love you. 1/3

SUSSMAN--Leonard, 94, died peacefully at his home in Craftsbury, Vermont with his sons Mark and David and his caregiver, Tina Maynard, at his side. Born and raised in Manhattan, he attended DeWitt Clinton High School, NYU, and Columbia's School of Journalism. Stationed in Puerto Rico during World War II, he served in the US Army and was awarded the Legion of Merit. After the War he became the press secretary to the Governor of Puerto Rico. He returned to New York and after working for daily newspapers, joined and eventually ran, the American Council for Judaism. In 1967, Leonard became the Executive Director of Freedom House, an institution devoted to promoting democracy and freedom. During his 21 years running that organization, he became an internationally known champion of press freedom and advocate for human rights. He participated in election monitoring in new democracies, launched Freedom House's annual survey "Freedom in the World,", and served as US representative to UNESCO. After leaving Freedom House, he taught press ethics at NYU and Columbia and focused on his writing, producing 18 books on international affairs and personal subjects. A passionate New Yorker, Leonard loved to walk the city. When he wasn't exploring New York, his wanderlust carried him to more than 75 countries. Leonard's marriage to Frances Rukeyser ended in divorce and he married Marianne Gutmann in 1958, who died in 2009. In addition to his sons, Leonard had a daughter, Lynne, who predeceased him in 1999. He is survived by his grandchildren, Jane, Rebecca, Benjamin, Sam and Finn, by Mark's wife, MJ Thompson, and by Lynne's husband, Philip Hyde. Memorial services will be held in Craftsbury, VT and New York. Those wishing to make a gift in Leonard's memory can donate to The Sussman Freedom Fund at Freedom House or The Sussman Family Fund at Memorial Sloan Kettering. 1/3

DELUGG--Milton. December 2, 1918 - April 6, 2015. In 1950, after years of working in radio, Milton Delugg became music director on television's "Broadway Open House," often considered the forerunner of "The Tonight Show." He worked with many other fine composers, including Frank Loesser. One of his best known compositions is "Orange Colored Sky," remembered as a hit for Nat King Cole. His "Hoop-Dee-Doo" polka was a smash hit for Perry Como. In 1958 he produced the Buddy Holly hit "Rave On!" He was music director of Johnny Carson's Tonight Show in 1965-66. Delugg also enjoyed a long association with Chuck Barris, producer of many popular game shows. Milton Delugg remained active as the Music Director of the annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade through 2013. He passed away at home April 6, 2015 at the age of 96. No services at this time. Donations to St., Jude's Hospital. He is survived by two loving sons Michael (Vivien) and Stephen. 1/3

FRANKFORT--Miriam "Mimi" Isaacson, born December 2nd, 1931, peacefully passed away April 2nd, 2015 at home in Boca Raton, Florida at the age of 83. Born in New York to Fred and Clair Isaacson, she is survived by her siblings Nathan and Linda, four sons, Jonathan, James, Peter and Adam, and eight grandchildren. There will be a private memorial service to celebrate the richness of her life. Having moved on to a better place, she will be deeply missed and warmly remembered. 1/3

SELIGMAN--Donald David, passed away on April 6, 2015. Loving husband of 74 years to his dear wife Dorothy, who survives him, dear father to John and wife Susan, and Nancy and husband Harry Goldmark, adoring and adored grandfather and "Pop" to Ken (Lisa), James (Julia), Brian (Autumn) and Dori (Eric), great-grandchildren Charlotte, Lola, Nina and Alexander, and brother to Diane Tuska, who survives him. He was born July 21, 1921, and was raised by his parents in the Five Towns on Nassau County's South Shore. He was a three sports star at Lawrence High School. Don then went on to Columbia University, where he again played and lettered in three sports. Upon graduation, he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps, commissioned as Second Lieutenant, and served in the Pacific theater, including Peleliu, attaining the rank of Major before being discharged after World War II ended. He embarked upon a career in the ladies' shoe business, first at several department stores, including Lord & Taylor, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman-Delman, before opening and operating his own chain, the totally unique Shop for Pappagallo-NYC, and four other Northeast locations, for over 10 years. Don then repped for several lines of designer accessories, before retiring and moving to Rhinebeck NY, where he and Dorothy lived for almost 20 years; in a home which was a very special "go to" home base for his children and grandchildren. This was followed up by another almost two decades in Heritage Hills, Somers, NY, and the final few years in Ossining, NY at the Atria. He was a fine athlete, playing tennis well into his 80s, and a lifelong New York Rangers fan. Never has a husband, father, and grandfather given more love, guidance, and happiness to his family, extended family, friends, colleagues, and anyone else with whom he came in contact. His modesty, warmth, wit, and charm, will be missed. There will be a private funeral for immediate family on Sunday. Shiva at John and Susan Seligman's home, 45 Main Street, Hastings on Hudson, NY on Sunday from 3 to 9pm and Monday from 2pm to 4pm and 6:30pm to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to your favorite charity, in Don's memory. 1/3
BRYAN--John Frederick. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, April 14, 2015 at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021 at 1:00 p.m. EDT. Please note the time change. 1/3

FORBES--Patricia (nee Walsh) 83, of Brooklyn, NY passed away peacefully at home on Friday, April 10th, 2015. She is predeceased by her husband Raymond C. Forbes. She is survived by her five loving children Christopher J. Forbes (Kim), Raymond J. Forbes (Cynthia), Patrick J. Forbes (Bettina), Marie-Regina Sotos (Peter) and Patricia M. Sarn (Larry) and her eleven grandchildren. Devoted sister to Irene Whiting, Marie Walsh and Marguerite Walsh. She is now reunited in heaven with her loving parents Patrick J. and Mary Walsh. She was born on March 15th, 1932 in Newfoundland, Canada and came to this country, which she very greatly loved, at age five. She built a beautiful life, centered on family and traveled the world which she thoroughly enjoyed. A mass will be held in her honor at St. Patrick's Church in Brooklyn at 10:00am on Monday, April 13th.

PERRY--Walter B.,born December 9, 1929, Died March 19, 2015. Long term employee of GHI, Samaritans volunteer, Reverend and Chaplin at Monmouth County Correctional facility, and past Clerk of the Shrewsbury Friends Meeting. Loving husband of Marlyn, father of Walter and Daniel, grandfather of Justin, James, Juliana, Claire and Carolyn. Memorial Service: April 19th at 1:00pm, at the Shrewsbury Friends Meeting, Shrewsbury, NJ. 1/3

MALINA--Judith. The Castillo Theatre is deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and longtime creative companion, the cofounder of the Living Theatre, Judith Malina. Malina was a groundbreaking pioneer of political and experimental theatre; a lifelong anarchist, pacifist and anti-fascist; and a fervent and passionate theatrical force and talent. When they were without a theatrical home, Judith and the Living rehearsed in our theatre. In the award-winning independent film Nothing Really Happens, she played the Holocaust survivor Tillie Hirsch, a role written for her by Castillo's late artistic director, Fred Newman. Judith's characters were unforgettable and so was she! La Lutta Continua! 1/3

CURLEY--M. Louise, passed away at her home on April 8th. After earning her PhD in Economics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1946, she had a long and distinguished career at Scudder, Stevens and Clark and at Haver Analytics. She is survived by her son Mark, daughter-in-law Mary Ellen, and granddaughters Anastatia and Oona. 1

JAFFE--Elaine, born February, 24, 1928, died on April 9th, 2015. Most beloved mother of Ronnie and Amy. She was preceded in death by her loving husband, Wallace. She will be most remembered for her indomitable spirit, and dearly missed by all who knew her. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, April 14th at 12:30pm at: IJ Morris Funeral Home, 21 E. Deer Park Rd., Dix Hills, NY. 1/3

GRUSS--Emanuel. We mourn the passing of Emanuel Gruss, founder and Chairman Emeritus of Oscar Gruss and Son Incorporated. We will miss his presence and advice which guided us through so many cycles. His vision in creating the Tel Aviv office of our firm in 1968 stands out as an act of courage and imagination, but he will be remembered for countless other acts. His demeanor and decency were a guidepost to us all. To his wife, Riane, his daughters, Leslie and Brenda (Daniel), and his grandchildren, we extend our deepest condolences and sympathy. 1/3

KRAMER--Alvera P. April 11, at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Kramer, sister of Peter Paull, mother/ mother-in-law of Ken and DeeDee Kramer, and Josh Kramer and Kathie Weaver, and Grandma to Michael and Amy, Jonathan and Drew, Lauren and Jack. An adventurous world traveler, swimming teacher, tennis player and bargain hunter, and alumna of Brooklyn College and Columbia University. Services at Mt. Moriah cemetery, Fairview, NJ on Monday April 13 at 1pm. Memorial contributions may be made to the New York Botanical Garden or Alzheimer's Foundation of America. 1/3

SHECHTER--Johanna Cohen Siegel, 92, passed April 11th. Survived by beloved daughter Benita and son-in-law Albert Marks. Dear friend of Sidney Rosenheim. Services will be today, 10am, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY. 1/3

GRUSS--Emanuel. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community deeply mourns the death of Mike Gruss beloved husband of Ria, adored father of Brenda and Leslie and revered grandfather. Mike was the original donor to the Heschel School when it was just an idea over thirty years ago. He cared deeply about our community, but most of all, he cared about the well being of our faculty and future contributions of our students. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ria, Brenda, Daniel, Leslie, Michael and grandchildren Oren, Ripton, Jonathan, Morgan and Leni. Mike also considered Carlos, Kindu and Phil his grandchildren. May the entire family find comfort among each other, their friends and in the knowledge that Mike's memory will be for a blessing among all people forever. Joel Citron, President, Board of Trustees Ariela Dubler, Head of School 1/3

WELP--Theodore M. (Ted). June 13, 1934 - March 8, 2015. The Board of Directors, leadership and staff of Research Corporation Technologies remember our longtime director and friend, Ted Welp, who died tragically in Boise, Idaho, along with his wife, Elaine, and adult son, Tom. A founding director of the company, Mr. Welp provided unwavering vision and guidance to RCT for nearly 30 years. We grieve this senseless loss but celebrate his life and good works. Optimism - Love - Family 1/3

KAHAN--Evelyn, on April 11, 2015 at age 98. Beloved wife of the late Bertram. Devoted mother of Marvin, Gerald and Edward. Mother-in-law of Lynn and Nancy. Cherished grandmother of Robin, Adam, Jodi and Jill. Loving great-grandmother of Alex, Remi, Libby, Hannah, Jack, Max, Brooke and Matthew. Loved by all, rest in peace. 1/3

KAVANAGH--Mary Galvin, died on April 11th. She was 91 years old. Formerly of the Bronx and Pelham Manor, New York. Devoted Wife to the late Thomas A. Kavanagh. Loving Mother of Deborah Gentile, Brian, Delia Neitzel, Liam, Maura DeNigris, Thomas, Anthony, Daniel, Malachy and Paul. Dedicated Nana to 16 grandchildren and "Ol" Nana to seven great-grandchildren. A Celebration of Mary's life will be held at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue from 2:00pm to 4:00pm and again from 7:00pm to 9:00pm on Monday, April 13th. A Mass of Christian burial will be at 10:00am on Tuesday, April 14th at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, 559 Pelham Manor Road, Pelham Manor, NY. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Calvary Hospital; 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461 would be appreciated. 1/3
JAMISON--John, of Lubbock, Texas, died March 31, 2015, age 83. He is survived by four children and siblings Aileen Jamison of New York and Richard Jamison of North Carolina.

WALDBAUM--Bernice, The Malinsky Family mourns the loss of Bernice Waldbaum. We will cherish the times spent around the holiday table and in the winner's circle with her horses. She was the strong and loving matriarch of the Waldbaum Family, a mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and friend to us all. She will be missed and was one of a kind. With love and sympathy, Fran, Harold, Aaron, Carolyn, Benjamin, David, Rebecca, Liam and Molly Malinsky. 1/3

Lamley--Richard Doan. April 2nd, 1939 died April 9, 2015. Beloved brother to Michael and Janet and uncle to two nieces and four nephews. Services 5pm Monday, April 13th, 2015 at John Krtil Funeral Home, NYC, 70th St. Make donations to Wounded Warriors Project. Michael Lamley and Janet Crick

GRUSS--Emanuel, 93, died April 10, 2015, at his home in New York, NY. Mike was born in Lwow, Poland, to Oscar and Regina Gruss. He obtained a bachelor's degree from the University of Manchester, England, and fought with the U.S. Army in the Battle of the Bulge. After World War II, he became a partner at Oscar Gruss & Son Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Ria, daughter Brenda and son-in-law Daniel Hirsch, daughter Leslie and Michael Kramer, grandchildren Oren Hirsch, Ripton Rosen, Jonathan Hirsch, Morgan Rosen, and Leni Hirsch, and sister Elizabeth Goldberg. Carlos Suarez, Kindu Jones, and Phil Medina considered Mike their grandfather also. The funeral will be held at noon on Sunday, April 12, at the Abraham Joshua Heschel School, 30 West End Avenue (at 61st Street), New York, NY, followed by interment at Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Heschel School or to Kivunim.
SONNENBLICK--Jack. Remembering my dear brother with great love and admiration. He was always kind and caring. We shared many happy times together, and I shall miss him. Jean Saklad 1/3

OLER--Rev. Clarke, died April 6, 2015 at age 89. Beloved father to Ellen, Kim and John, this generous, compassionate, revered Episcopal priest at Holy Trinity Church in Manhattan and All Saints Pasadena taught us always to believe in our God-given goodness. He is survived by his three grateful children and four grandchildren, and will be deeply missed by everyone who knew him. 1/3

After World War II, he became a partner at Oscar Gruss & Son Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. Carlos Suarez, Kindu Jones, and Phil Medina considered Mike their grandfather also. PEYSER--Herbert S.,MD. Herbert S. Peyser MD, died in his home on April 6 at the age of 90. A lifelong New Yorker, he was admired for his vast intellect and erudition, unflinching directness, dedication to his patients, and his way with a joke. After attending Columbia University for undergraduate and medical school, he had a private practice in psychiatry with a subspecialty in addiction and actively participated in Mt. Sinai Medical Center's Department of Psychiatry from 1965 into his final days. Dr. Peyser was a respected educator and mentor who served on the faculty of Mt. Sinai Medical Center and School of Medicine as well as St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital. A forceful advocate for mental health, he served on and led multiple committees for the American Psychiatric Association, New York State Psychiatric Association, and Medical Society of the State of New York, for which he was a founding member of the Committee for Physician Health. His expertise, achievements, and insights were recognized by his peers and he received many honors, most recently the prestigious Ronald A. Shellow Award to be presented at the APA Assembly meeting in May. He authored many scholarly and position papers and co-edited "Alcoholism: A Practical Treatment Guide." Herb read widely and traveled extensively. He was passionate about music and the classics, and loved to quote from great literature. He is survived by his daughter Kami Seligman and her husband, Mark; son Tony Peyser and his wife, Suzanne Horn; daughter Monica Parks; five grandchildren; and his dear friend Patricia Weiss. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York, NY on April 26 at 2:15pm. Donations can be made in his honor to the Committee for Physician Health (mssny.org/cph) or Doctors Without Borders. 1/3

DALGARNO--Alexander, passed away peacefully on April 9. Born in 1928 and raised in London, he studied mathematics and theoretical atomic physics at University College London. A talented soccer (football) player, he played tennis and squash into his ninth decade. He became a professor at the Queen's University of Belfast and later joined Harvard University's Astronomy Department in 1967, served as its chairman, and became the Phillips Professor of Astronomy. His contributions led to the recognition that none have been greater "in the history of atomic physics and its applications" and he has been called the "father of molecular astrophysics." He established the influential Institute for Theoretical Atomic and Molecular Physics at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. He was a recipient of many awards, including the Benjamin Franklin Medal in Physics, the Royal Society's Hughes Medal, the Royal Astronomical Society's Gold Medal, the American Geophysical Society's Fleming Medal, and the Royal Society of Chemistry's Spiers Medal. He even had an asteroid named after him. He was a gifted mentor to generations of students, a generous and inspiring colleague, and a humanist in every respect. He is survived by his four children, Fergus, Penelope, Piers, and Rebecca, seven grandchildren, and by his partner Fern Creelan. Memorial service details will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in his honor to the Equal Justice Initiative, at www.donatenow.networkforgood.org/eji.

BORDAN--Erika Aleese (nee Pack) of West Caldwell passed away on Saturday, April 11, 2015. Relatives and friends may visit with the family at Paul Ippolito-Dancy Memorial, 9 Smull Ave., Caldwell, NJ on Wednesday, April 15, 2015 from 4 to 8pm and on Thursday, April 16 at 10:30 a.m., followed by a funeral service at 11am at the funeral home. The interment will be at Prospect Hill Cemetery, Caldwell. For directions or to send the family condolences please visit: www.ippolitofuneralhomes. com. Born in Pittsburg, PA, Mrs. Bordan lived in Jersey City before moving to West Caldwell. An attorney and registered nurse, Mrs. Bordan earned her degree in nursing from St. Margaret Memorial Hospital School of Nursing in Pittsburg, PA, and Bachelor of Science degree in nursing from C.W. Postong Island University, where she graduated Summa Cum Laude in 1980. In 1988, she earned her Juris Degree from the University Of Bridgeport School Of Law. As an attorney, Mrs. Bordan specialized in medical malpractice defense litigation and was employed as an associate attorney by Lewis Johs, Aviles & Kaufmann, LLP in Melville, NY from 2001 to 2013. Prior to that, she worked in the same capacity for Bartlett, McDonough, Bastone & Monaghan, LLP in Mineola, NY. During her nursing career, Mrs. Bordan worked at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, NY as an operating room nurse, where she served in many capacities including Clinical Instructor, assistant head nurse and assistant head nurse of orthopedics. She served in the US Army Nurse Corp as a First Lieutenant during the Vietnam War, having served in active duty from 1969 until 1971. She was stationed at U.S. Army Hospital in Fort Polk, LA., and Martin Army Hospital in Fort Benning, GA. During her tenure as a nurse and attorney, Mrs. Bordan gave lectures and presentations and was the recipient of several awards and distinctions. She was a member of the Association of Operating Room Nurses, the American Association of Nurse Attorneys and the American Health Lawyers Association. She was a Board member of the Hudson County Boys & Girls Club of America and a loyal supporter of the Vietnam Veterans of America. She was the beloved wife of 34 years to Dr. Dennis L. Bordan; loving step-mother to Douglas Bordan; dear sister to Karen Bursick and her husband, Tom, Mary Beth Depuydt and her husband, Dan, and the late John Pack; dear sister-in-law of Phyllis Bufferd and Laurie Whitleigh. She is also survived by many loving nieces, nephews and friends, and will be missed by her canine companion "Penny". If so desired donations to the Vietnam Veterans of America, Attn: Janice Stewart, 8719 Colesville Rd., Suite 100, Silver Spring, MD, 20910, or The Humane Society, Dept: Gift Donations, 2100 L Street, NW, Washington, DC, 20037, would be appreciated. 1/3

LEVENTHAL--Sharon Tanzer, age 74, passed away April 12, 2015. Sharon was a graduate of P.S. duPont High School class of 1958. She received her Bachelor's Degree from Barnard College class of 1962, a Master's Degree from Stanford University and she was a Fulbright Scholar. A longtime resident of Washington, DC, she worked with her husband, Paul Leventhal as the Vice President of the Nuclear Control Institute. Sharon was a passionate advocate for nuclear nonproliferation and a healthy environment. Preceded in death by her husband, Paul; she is survived by sons, Ted and Josh and their spouses; three grandchildren; three siblings and many nieces and nephews. A graveside service will be 11am, Wednesday, April 15, 2015 at the Jewish Community Cemetery, 401 Foulk Road, Wilmington, DE 19803. Shiva will be observed 7pm, Wednesday and Thursday at the home of Dan and Hinda Tanzer. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Lewy Body Dementia Association (www.lbda.org) Services by Schoenberg Memorial Chapel. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Seymour. 83, passed away peacefully April 13th after a courageous battle against lymphoma. Born in Brooklyn on June 18, 1931. He served in the Korean War. Seymour married, his loving wife of 40 years, Laura Retzky, who passed away in 1997. Starting out as a factory worker he became part owner of Monarch Luggage. He helped build that company into one of the largest luggage manufacturers in the country. He retired in 2001. He lived with his companion, Irene Glover, who passed in 2014. Seymour took pride in caring for all family members. He had a joy for life and a zest for living. He always tried to do the right thing. Seymour was a real role model. He is survived by his beloved children Lynne Koufakis and husband, Michael, Helene DeCillis and husband, Paul, and Richard Schwartz and wife, Greta. He was deeply loved by his seven grandchildren, Jeremy, Jared, Jake, Jenna, Alexander, Ava and Natalie. He will be sorely missed. Funeral services on Wednesday, April 15th, 11am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY. 1/3

EPSTEIN--Danal Paul, 91, died peacefully on April 12 in York, ME. Danal lived for many years in Scarsdale, NY. He served in the Navy during World War II, achieving the rank of lieutenant. After the war he started as a salesman in the family business, eventually becoming president of CF Hathaway Co. and president of Warnaco International Licensing. Danal was active in many charities and was deeply involved with York Hospital in Maine, having served as Chairman, and his alma mater, Lehigh University in Bethlehem, PA, where he established the Epstein Scholarship Fund. He was a past president of the National Democratic Club in New York. He was predeceased by his wife Jane Epstein (Bleyer), his parents Louis and Tiela, and his brother Jon. He is survived by his loving son Michael (spouse Scott) and loving daughter Amy and four grandchildren. He was admired and respected by all and will be sorely missed. Above all, Danal loved family and friends. Donations may be made to York Hospital or Lehigh University. Services entrusted to Lucas & Eaton Funeral Home, York, Maine. 1/3

LUK--Patricia. Patricia Luk, 83, died peacefully on April 11, 2015 in Manhattan. In 1971, Patricia and Francis, her husband of 51 years co-founded Pacific Delight Tours and worked side by side for 37 years. Their mutual love of ballroom dance earned a silver medal. All those close to Patricia benefitted from her love of life, infectious smile and her flair for fashion, entertaining and floral arranging. She's remembered fondly for bringing people together with a home-cooked meal. Patricia's understated elegance, quiet demeanor and wise and practical advice was her hallmark. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Francis. She received the love, honor and respect, as matriarch and loving mother of Mimi and Eddie Soo, Sophia and Michael Brenner and Theresa Luk. Cherished grandmother of Angela and Dr. Robert Chang, Jacqueline and Joshua Endler, Stephanie Oprea, Elizabeth Miller and Olivia Miller. Adored great-grandmother of Ella Endler, Everett Chang and Vivienne Endler. Much loved sister of Jenny and Lt. Col. (Ret) Kenneth Wu, Eddie Wong, and Harry Wang and Lily Mui. Loved by nephews Arthur and Carmen Wu, and Raymond Wong, nieces Jade Wu and Christine Wong, grand nieces Kisch and Michael Konold, and Stephanie and TR Alviani and respective children Nora, Jack and Max. She will be missed by her dear friends and employees whom she considered her extended family. Her spirit is carried on by her three daughters, five granddaughters, two great-granddaughters and great-grandson. Patricia lives on in those who love her. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel located on 1076 Madison Avenue on Wednesday, April 15th from 6pm-8pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue and 84th Street, New York at 10am, Thursday April 16th. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Mount Sinai National Jewish Health Respiratory Institute, 10 East 102nd St., Fifth Floor, New York, NY 10029. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Seymour. 83, passed away peacefully April 13th after a courageous battle against lymphoma. Born in Brooklyn on June 18, 1931. He served in the Korean War. Seymour married, his loving wife of 40 years, Laura Retzky, who passed away in 1997. Starting out as a factory worker he became part owner of Monarch Luggage. He helped build that company into one of the largest luggage manufacturers in the country. He retired in 2001. He lived with his companion, Irene Glover, who passed in 2014. Seymour took pride in caring for all family members. He had a joy for life and a zest for living. He always tried to do the right thing. Seymour was a real role model. He is survived by his beloved children Lynne Koufakis and husband, Michael, Helene DeCillis and husband, Paul, and Richard Schwartz and wife, Greta. He was deeply loved by his seven grandchildren, Jeremy, Jared, Jake, Jenna, Alexander, Ava and Natalie. He will be sorely missed. Funeral services on Wednesday, April 15th, 11am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY. 1/3

SCHREIBER--Melvin. More than a man, more than a partner, more than a friend. You will always be remembered. Our condolences to Lynn, Jeff, Jill, Gary and the entire family that meant so much to him. Love, Phyllis & Alan Wolpert 1/3

WALDBAUM--Bernice Cohen, passed away Sunday, April 12, 2015. She was born in Brooklyn in 1927. She attended Midwood High School. She married her elementary school sweetheart, Ira Waldbaum. Together they shared 54 beautiful years together, true partners in every way. Together they raised four children had ten grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. They travelled the world, and actively supported numerous charities both here and abroad. Bernice filled her life with friends and family. The Waldbaum's, Malinsky's, Nimkoff's and Raphael's will keep her memory in our hearts. 1/3

WALDBAUM--Bernice, of Long Island and Del Ray Beach passed away Sunday, April 12, 2015. Bernice was a strong and courageous lady of valor. She and her husband, Ira Waldbaum, were partners for 54 years. Together they shared an extraordinary journey filled with adventure and fun. They had four children, ten grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. We have missed Dad for 13 years and know that he is reunited with his life partner. Bernice found great comfort in her family. She expected the best from them and wanted the best for them. Mom, Grandma we love and miss you. Always remember that you live eternally in our hearts. Martin, Nancy, Adam, Ilana, Olivia and Cooper 1/3

LUK--Patricia. Patricia Luk, 83, died peacefully on April 11, 2015 in Manhattan. In 1971, Patricia and Francis, her husband of 51 years co-founded Pacific Delight Tours and worked side by side for 37 years. Their mutual love of ballroom dance earned a silver medal. All those close to Patricia benefitted from her love of life, infectious smile and her flair for fashion, entertaining and floral arranging. She's remembered fondly for bringing people together with a home-cooked meal. Patricia's understated elegance, quiet demeanor and wise and practical advice was her hallmark. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Francis. She received the love, honor and respect, as matriarch and loving mother of Mimi and Eddie Soo, Sophia and Michael Brenner and Theresa Luk. Cherished grandmother of Angela and Dr. Robert Chang, Jacqueline and Joshua Endler, Stephanie Oprea, Elizabeth Miller and Olivia Miller. Adored great-grandmother of Ella Endler, Everett Chang and Vivienne Endler. Much loved sister of Jenny and Lt. Col. (Ret) Kenneth Wu, Eddie Wong, and Harry Wang and Lily Mui. Loved by nephews Arthur and Carmen Wu, and Raymond Wong, nieces Jade Wu and Christine Wong, grand nieces Kisch and Michael Konold, and Stephanie and TR Alviani and respective children Nora, Jack and Max. She will be missed by her dear friends and employees whom she considered her extended family. Her spirit is carried on by her three daughters, five granddaughters, two great-granddaughters and great-grandson. Patricia lives on in those who love her. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel located on 1076 Madison Avenue on Wednesday, April 15th from 6pm-8pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue and 84th Street, New York at 10am, Thursday April 16th. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Mount Sinai National Jewish Health Respiratory Institute, 10 East 102nd St., Fifth Floor, New York, NY 10029. 1/3
