LEWIS--Ira (Metsky), 82, a resident of Greenwich Village for most of his life, died on April 4, 2015. He was an actor and playwright whose work has been presented around the world. He wrote several full length plays including "The Sponsor" and "Chinese Coffee". "Chinese Coffee" was produced on Broadway and starred Al Pacino before being made into a film. Ira loved New York and cared deeply about the New York theatre community. He is survived by his brothers Marvin and Seymour Metsky and lifelong friends Cheryl Hartley and Walter Furer. A service will take place on Thursday, April 16, 2015 at 1:30pm at Doyle Memorial Cemetery, 350 Provinceline Rd., Wrightstown, NJ. 1/3

WALDBAUM--Bernice. All of us at Perelson Weiner extend our thoughts, prayers and deepest sympathies to the family of Bernice Waldbaum as we mourn the loss of our long-time friend and client. She will be missed by all those whose lives she touched. She will be remembered as a loving wife, mother, grandmother and great- grandmother. We will dearly miss Bernice, and sincerely hope that her family will be greatly comforted by their memories of her. Bernice was a kind, generous and highly principled woman who treasured her family and their combined charitable giving through the l Waldbaum Family Foundation which will be carried on by her descendants. Please accept our respects. 1/3

KAPLAN--Leonard Jerome. Leonard Jerome Kaplan, age 86, of Greensboro, NC, died peacefully on April 12, 2015. He is lovingly survived by his wife of 50 years, Tobee Kaplan, his children Lyn Chasen and husband Barry Chasen, Randall Kaplan and wife Kathy Manning, Scott Kaplan and wife Maeve Kaplan, grandchildren Brandon Chasen and wife Catherine, Blake and Ben Chasen, Elizabeth, Robert and Jennifer Kaplan, Sara Kaplan Stricker and husband Elon Stricker, Sophia, Aubrey and Henry Kaplan, and great-grandson Brandon Chasen, Jr. He was predeceased by his beloved daughter Lori Kaplan. Mr. Kaplan grew up in High Point, NC, the son of the late Sara and Harry Kaplan and the brother of the late Dr. Arthur Kaplan. Forced to leave UNC to take over his father's janitorial supply company when his father became ill, he graduated from High Point University while running his family business. He served in the U.S Army during the Korean War, then returned to the business and used his determination, creativity, and hard work to build Kay Chemical Company into a worldwide supplier of cleaning chemicals to the giants of the fast food industry. When Kay merged with Ecolab in 1996, he was proud that Kay maintained its location in Greensboro and continued to thrive. Mr. Kaplan's life was guided by his desire to make the world a better place, and he had a lasting impact through his significant philanthropic efforts. With the creation of the TOLEO Foundation, he and his wife Tobee pursued a deep commitment to philanthropy in education, women and children's issues, homelessness, hunger, healthcare and human services, the arts, civil rights, and quality of life for the greater community in general and the Jewish Community in particular. Mr. Kaplan was a driving force in projects ranging from the creation of the Moses Cone Cardiac Unit, the founding of Camp Ramah Darom, and the School of Public Administration for Leadership at High Point University. He helped found pivotal agencies such as Jewish Family Services and the Jewish Foundation of Greensboro, and helped build new facilities for the Greensboro Jewish Federation, The Women's Resource Center, Habitat for Humanity, B'nai Shalom Day School, Greensboro Day School, Beth David Synagogue, Temple Emanuel, and UNC Hillel. He was a major supporter of United Way and Urban Ministries, and he funded food programs in needy areas in Eastern Europe and Israel. He was a major contributor to the arts in Greensboro, including the Tanger Center for the Performing Arts, Greensboro Symphony, EMF and Triad Stage, whose Pyrle Theater is named for his late mother-in -law Pyrle Gibson. A visionary thinker, Mr. Kaplan created two international organizations to address global needs. Through his Wealth and Giving Forum, he educated and motivated others to use their wealth for charitable purposes. With The Alliance for Global Good, he encouraged innovative solutions to poverty, health and environmental, issues, funding grants worldwide, including the building of a maternal health clinic in Ghana. Among his many awards, Mr. Kaplan received an honorary doctorate from the Jewish Theological Seminary, Greensboro Chamber of Commerce's Thomas Z. Osborne Citizen of the Year Award, Greensboro Jewish Federation's Benjamin Cone, Sr. Leadership Award, and the 2014 NCCJ Citation Award. Mr. Kaplan had deep love for his family, which always came first in his life. He was a kind, caring, deeply ethical, witty man who was fiercely loyal. His charm, intellect, warmth and resolve made the world a better place and will be sorely missed. Mr. Kaplan's funeral will take place at Beth David Synagogue, Wednesday at 11am. 1/3

DUVAL--Linda Mastercola, 67, of Port Douglas, NY, passed away peacefully, Monday, April 13, 2015 at her home following a courageous battle with Parkinson Disease. She was blessed to be surrounded by her loving family and friends. She was born in Norristown, PA, August 9, 1948, the daughter of the late, Michael and Vera (Scandone) Mastercola. Linda graduated from St. Joseph School of Nursing in Reading, PA. She retired after 40 years as a Charge Nurse in the Emergency Department at Roosevelt Hospital in NYC, and was instrumental in establishing the Sexual Assault Forensic Examiner (SAFE) program. Together with her husband, Jean-Audouin "JD", they travelled the world providing Advanced Cardiac Life Support education, touching thousands of lives. Left to cherish her memories are her devoted husband, JD Duval; loving step-daughter, Lisa Hinds and her husband Joe; dedicated sister, Marlene Mastercola and her husband Norman Rubanoff; and caring father-in-law, JeanJacques Duval. Services will be private and at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers, her family requests memorial donations be made to the National Parkinson Foundation or The National Shrine of St. Jude. Services are in the care of the Hamilton Funeral Home, 124 Clinton Street, Keeseville, 834-7667. To light an online candle and offer condolences in the memory of Linda Duval please visit www.hamiltonfuneralhome. com 1/3

SCHREIBER--Melvin. April 13, 2015. Melvin Schreiber of Manhasset, NY, and Delray Beach, FL, passed away peacefully this morning after a long but courageous battle with cancer and heart disease. He was 85. Mel was a retired partner of Moses & Schreiber, LLP, CPA's in Lake Success with which he was affiliated for 53 years. A lifelong New Yorker, he was a graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx and NYU where he received both an undergraduate degree in accounting and a Masters Degree in Taxation. He is survived by his loving widow, Lynn (Rawitz) Schreiber, his children, Jeffrey, Jill (and Loren) Kleinman, and Gary (and Hillary) Schreiber, his grandchildren, Dr. Dawn (and Dr. Dan) Amoruso, Cari (and Jeffrey) Katz, Jason Kleinman, Brooke Schreiber, Matthew Schreiber, his sister Gladys Meyrowitz, nephews, cousins, and friends, clients, and colleagues all over the U.S. Funeral services will be on Wednesday, April 15, beginning at 9:30am at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Burial will follow the funeral at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, New Jersey. Donations should be made to Dr. Offitt's work at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th floor, New York, NY 10017 Attn: Jane Weyl. 1/3

WALDBAUM--Bernice. To our dear friend and partner Bernice. We will miss our Friday afternoon calls, your perspective on life, your quick wit, and our trips to the winner's circle. You will be sorely missed. Rest in peace. Jodi and Robert Rosenthal 1/3

BRADLEY--Right Reverend Monsignor William J.,of Riverdale, NY, aged 83, passed away after a lengthy illness on Monday April 13th. The eldest son of William J Bradley and Mary Kilgallon Bradley he is survived by his sister Margaret M Laux of Norwalk, CT, and brother Thomas A Bradley and his wife Sally of Riverdale, NY. (He was predeceased by his youngest brother, John F Bradley.) He was the proud uncle of seven nieces and nephews - Edward, William(deceased), and Thomas Laux and Mary Terese Campbell, Eileen Kyriacou, William Bradley, and Janine Carlson, plus sixteen grand nieces and nephews. Raised in Washington Heights, and educated at Incarnation school, Cathedral College HS, and St Joseph's Seminary he was ordained a priest by Francis Cardinal Spellman on June 1, 1957. He was part of the first ordination class assigned to Ponce, Puerto Rico to become immersed in the Spanish language and culture of the islands, and upon his return was assigned to Holy Name of Jesus in Manhattan, where he resided for fifteen years. He became pastor of St. Jude in Manhattan in 1972, building their first church during his tenure. He was named pastor of Our Lady of Mercy in Port Chester, NY in 1983, serving there for thirteen years; and while there, he was named a Monsignor by John Cardinal O'Connor in November 1995. He became pastor of Blessed Sacrament in New Rochelle, NY in 1996, where he remained until his retirement in June 2013. He had a life long passion for music, and was considered one of the great Irish tenors in the Archdiocese. More importantly, he imparted his love of music to hundreds of his young parishioners through the establishment of marching bands at Holy Name and St. Jude, where they became yearly fixtures at the St. Patrick's Day Parade. He reveled in his role as part chaperone, part Officer Krupke at the Friday night dances at Holy Name. He was known in the early years of his priesthood as the "priest with the best left hook" in the diocese. He performed over 3200 weddings, the most in the history of the diocese, and, by his own account, in America too! He was passionate about the NY Giants, both football and baseball. He was a member for over 50 years at the Winged Foot Golf Club. But most importantly, he was the epitome of the NYC parish priest, and he loved every minute of it. Viewing hours will be 2-4 and 7-9 on Thursday April 16th at Riverdale on Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. Bronx, NY. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated by Timothy Michael Cardinal Dolan at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, 6000 Riverdale Ave. Friday April 17th at 10:00am. Interment will be at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations made be made in his memory to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave., Hawthorne, NY 10532. 1/3

SPIRA--Joel. As a young man he invented the electrical dimmer, then went on to create "Lutron" the premier lighting company now in more than 100 countries. We have had the honor and good fortune to know Joel for more years that we can remember. He was an astute business man, paternal leader, honorable, ethical, devoted family man, philanthropist, community leader and most important a gentlemen. Our hearts go out to Ruth and his family. Jacques M. Levy & Co., LLP 1/3

WALDBAUM--Bernice, of Long Island and Del Ray Beach passed away Sunday, April 12, 2015. Bernice was a strong and courageous lady of valor. She and her husband, Ira Waldbaum, were partners for 54 years. Together they shared an extraordinary journey filled with adventure and fun. They had four children, ten grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. We have missed Dad for 13 years and know that he is reunited with his life partner. Bernice found great comfort in her family. She expected the best from them and wanted the best for them. Mom, Grandma we love and miss you. Always remember that you live eternally in our hearts. ANELLI--Elda, on April 8, 2015. Mass of Christian burial 9:45am, April 18, 2015, Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Church, 34-24 203rd St., Bayside, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery. 1/3

STARK--Morgan Babcock Philanthropist and financier, Morgan Babcock Stark, died at his home in Manhattan on Monday, April 13th, after a battle with cancer. He was born in New York and remained a lifelong resident, although he also maintained homes in Sag Harbor, New York, and Stowe, Vermont. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York, The Maidstone Club of Easthampton, The Devon Yacht Club of Amagansett, and the Sag Harbor Yacht Club. In 1979, Mr. Stark joined the Chemical Bank as Senior Vice President and Treasury Department Deputy Head. and became President and CEO of Chemical Securities, Inc.; in July of 1995, he and Thomas W. Strauss joined Ramius as partners with Peter A. Cohen in the development of Ramius' investment management business. Mr. Stark was a Founder, Managing Member, and member of the Executive Committee of Ramius LLC. Mr. Stark's industry and philanthropic activities included his position as member of the Investment Committee for the American Heart Association - Heritage Affiliate. He joined the Board of Directors of the New York Heart Association in 1985 and became Chairman of the Board of the New York City Affiliate. He gave over 35 years of his life to saving and improving the lives of people with cardiovascular disease, and was an avid supporter of the AHA's Basic and Clinical Research program. Morgan Stark previously served as President, Vice President, and member of the Board of Directors of the Dealer Bank Association advising the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and also served on the Treasury Borrowing Committee serving three Secretaries of the US Treasury. At his death, he was President of the Board of Directors of the Perlman Music Program, centered around a camp for young virtuosi string instrument players with a campus on Shelter Island, NY. He claimed his work with the Perlmans and their students to have been the most fulfilling of his life. Mr. Stark is survived by his wife of nearly 50 years, Sidney Stires Stark, his two sons Nicholas and Mason, and two grandchildren, Dante and Nicolette Stark. 1

HURWITZ--Rafi. Hashomer Hatzair mourns the loss of our devoted friend Rafi, who passed away April 14, 2015. Rafi was beloved by the many generations of the Shomer community. The funeral takes place on April 17 at 11:00 am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

WALDBAUM--Bernice Cohen, passed away Sunday, April 12, 2015. She was born in Brooklyn in 1927. She attended Midwood High School. She married her elementary school sweetheart, Ira Waldbaum. Together they shared 54 beautiful years together, true partners in every way. Together they raised four children had ten grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. They travelled the world, and actively supported numerous charities both here and abroad. Bernice filled her life with friends and family. The Waldbaum's, Malinsky's, Nimkoff's and Raphael's will keep her memory in our hearts. 1/3
BEALL--Harry. We worked together for 30 years; we were loving friends for life. Rest in peace, dearest Harry. Gary and Naomi 1/3

MENGER--Adella Simone, passed peacefully on April 10, 2015 at Morristown Memorial Hospital. During her last days, she was in the comfort of friends and her daughter Simone. Adella loved animals and music. She is survived by her daughter Simone Menger Lopez of Somerville, NJ and brothers Eugene Charles Menger of Star Ranch, WY and John McAuliffe Menger of New Vernon, NJ. Services will be held the week of April 20, 2015. For further information or to send a condolence, please go to www.bradley funeralhomes.com or contact Wm. A. Bradley & Son FH (973) 635-2428. MALLOY--Susan Rabinowitz, on April 14, 2015 in her 92nd year. Beloved wife of the late Edwin A., devoted mother of Jennifer Malloy Combs and Timon. Loving grandmother of Meredith and Titania Lily Combs, Jacob Arthur Malloy and Tess Adina Malloy. Dear aunt to many nieces and nephews. Sister of Alan Rabinowitz and the late Betty R. Sheffer. HOCHBERG--Joseph A.,93, of New Rochelle, NY. He was born and lived most of his life in Mount Vernon, NY. He graduated from University of Louisville Dental School, and served as a dental officer in the Navy. Together, with his wife, Glenna, they raised a family while he practiced dentistry in Mount Vernon. Well-read on a variety of topics, he had a life-long interest in the field of psychology. Joseph loved classical music, was an engaging conversationalist, and an avid walker into his later years. He is survived by his sons, Bruce, Paul, and Ronald; daughter-in-law Arlene; granddaughter Shelby, and several nephews. Devoted to his family and friends, he will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, April 17 at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY. 1/3

DISTENFELD--Ariel, born in Israel, served and injured in its war of independence. Graduated from NYU School of Medicine in 1957. A Hematologist and clinical professor of medicine at NYU. Many years in private practice; published several peer review articles. Former medical director of Cabrini Hospice. Predeceased by first wife Joy. Survived by loving wife Harriet Friedes; children Rona Distenfeld, Suzy Crabb (Ian) and Elana Gitter (Henry) and grandchildren Michael, Rebecca, Joy and Shayna. Funeral services will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Thursday at 11:15am. Contributions can be made to the VNSNY Hospice. 1/3

MEZZACAPPA--Damon. Died peacefully April 14th, at home in Palm Beach Florida, after a valiant struggle with lung cancer. He was 79 year old. He is survived by his wife, Katherine Bryan, her children George Gurley, Austin and Jack Bryan, his son Jonathan Mezzacappa, daughter Jessica Mezzacappa and her husband John Zieman, and son Benjamin Mezzacappa and his wife Pia Mezzacappa, four grandchildren, Lily Elizabeth Friedberg, Damon Christopher Friedberg, Alessia Sophia Mezzacappa and Caroline Helena Mezzacappa. He was pre-deceased by his daughter Jennifer Anne and his second wife, Elizabeth. After graduating from Harvard College in 1958, Damon served his country in the US Army. He then began his brilliant career on Wall Street at FS Smithers in Boston, and then held senior positions at Morgan Stanley and Lazard Freres in New York, where he ran Capital Markets and was Vice-chair. After retiring from Lazard, Damon founded Mezzacappa Management, an investment firm specializing in the Hedge Fund space. Damon also was a lead investor in the real estate company developing Wynwood, Miami's new art district. He was an avid golfer and art collector, a loyal friend, dog lover, and generous donor to the many causes that captured his heart. In lieu of flowers please consider making a donation to the Peconic Land Trust.

COOPER--Joel J.,56, beloved President of List Strategies, Inc. and philanthropist, passed away unexpectedly at his Southampton home on Monday, April 13, 2015. RICHARDS--David Kimball, age 75 died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) at home in Santa Monica, California, with his family Carol, Adam, and Peter at his side. He was an investment manager with a global and historical perspective, ethical in business and in the conduct of his life. As an investor, his special gift was drawing connections between seemingly disparate events and displaying a brave and contrarian bent, setting him apart and keeping him a step ahead of others. He devoted much of his life to making sense of the most complex of matters as a way to make the world a better place. He possessed great intellectual curiosity and pragmatic wisdom which informed all his pursuits. He was a wonderful observer of economic history and a generous supporter of the work of the Joint Centers for History and Economics at Harvard and Cambridge Universities. He supported pioneering research at the RAND Corporation to articulate a vision for a successful Palestinian State, once peace is achieved. He supported a second ambitious RAND study on the costs to Israel and Palestine of continued conflict, to be released this spring. He was a member of the RAND Board of Trustees, and served on the Board of Advisors of RAND Health and RAND Center for Middle East Public Policy. He was born in Portland, Maine, the son of Robert Ladd Richards M.D. and Janice Kimball Richards and grew up in Vermont. He received a Bachelor's degree in English literature from Harvard College in 1961, a Master's in Philosophy, Politics and Economics from Wadham College, Oxford in 1963, and a Master's in Business Administration from the Harvard Business School in 1965. He kept strong ties to Harvard and Wadham, as a valuable advisor and supporter, serving on the Chancellor's Court of Benefactors at Oxford and as a Foundation Fellow at Wadham, and at Harvard on Dean's Councils and the Committee on University Resources. David won three varsity letters rowing for the lightweight varsity crew at Harvard for three undefeated years in 1959, 1960 and 1961, and was elected captain in his senior year. His boat dominated its American competitors and won the E.A.R.C. Championships three years in a row. Internationally, in 1959 and 1960, the lightweights won the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta, the premier rowing event in the world, setting three course records in 1960. He went on to row for the Oxford University Crew and Isis Boat Club, then coached the Harvard Lightweight Crews for two years while attending Harvard Business School. His passion for rowing continued throughout his life. David had a deep respect for the people and communities of the Maine Coast. As a citizen of the world, he enjoyed global travel. However, he nourished his spirit in Maine, walking, hiking and lobster-roll lunching with friends. For 35 years, fishermen, seals and others witnessed David on the ocean in the calm early morning hours, joyfully rowing his single shell among the islands off Stonington. He is survived by his wife, Carol, his two sons Adam and Peter, two grandchildren Theo and Ian, their mother Jane, and his brother, Robert. 1/3

GREEN--Freeda, 102, died peacefully on April 13 at her home overlooking the Guggenheim Museum. She was the loving wife for 68 years of Bernard Green, who died in 2003. MEZZACAPPA--Damon. Died peacefully April 14th, at home in Palm Beach Florida, after a valiant struggle with lung cancer. He was 79 year old. He is survived by his wife, Katherine Bryan, her children George Gurley, Austin and Jack Bryan, his son Jonathan Mezzacappa, daughter Jessica Mezzacappa and her husband John Zieman, and son Benjamin Mezzacappa and his wife Pia Mezzacappa, four grandchildren, Lily Elizabeth Friedberg, Damon Christopher Friedberg, Alessia Sophia Mezzacappa and Caroline Helena Mezzacappa. He was pre-deceased by his daughter Jennifer Anne and his second wife, Elizabeth. After graduating from Harvard College in 1958, Damon served his country in the US Army. He then began his brilliant career on Wall Street at FS Smithers in Boston, and then held senior positions at Morgan Stanley and Lazard Freres in New York, where he ran Capital Markets and was Vice-chair. After retiring from Lazard, Damon founded Mezzacappa Management, an investment firm specializing in the Hedge Fund space. Damon also was a lead investor in the real estate company developing Wynwood, Miami's new art district. He was an avid golfer and art collector, a loyal friend, dog lover, and generous donor to the many causes that captured his heart. In lieu of flowers please consider making a donation to the Peconic Land Trust.

SPANIER--Maury. Passed away peacefully Wednesday evening, April 8th in hospice care at the Osborn Retirement Home in Rye, NY at the age of 98. Born and raised in New York City, he had a substantial career as an attorney, business leader and philanthropist. He graduated from City College in 1936, Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa. He received his LLB from Columbia University, class of 1939, where he was Editor of the Law Review and a Kent Scholar. After being admitted to the New York State Bar in 1939, he joined the law firm of Hays, Podell & Shulman (later Hays, Porter, Spanier & Curtis), engaging primarily in corporate litigation, taxation and trusts and estates becoming a Partner in 1946. Except for Army service from 1942-1946 in the Judge Advocate Generals' Department, he remained with that firm until 1982. Mr. Spanier became legal counsel of United Aircraft Products (UAP), an Ohio defense contractor, in 1946, joined the Board in 1962 and became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer in 1971 - taking over a company that had been losing business and operating at a loss. As Chairman, he was instrumental in leading UAP to a successful turnaround and eventual purchase by Parker Hannifin in 1986. During this time, he also served as a Governor of the American Stock Exchange from 1980 to 1986. Beginning almost 50 years ago and continuing into 2015, Mr. Spanier became increasing involved in philanthropic activities. He established the Dextra Baldwin McGonagle Foundation in 1967, where he served as Chairman from its inception until his death. He also was a Trustee and Member of the Executive Committee of Beth Israel Medical Center; Trustee, St. Luke's-Roosevelt; Member of the President's Council of Columbia University; and Director, American Committee for Weizmann Institute. He will be remembered as a loving husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He and Helen Green Spanier, who passed away in 2010, were married for 69 years. He is survived by two sons, David and Jon, four grandchildren, Eli, Ian, Ben, and Abby, and four great grandchildren. 1/3

KIMBALL--Richard A. Richard A. Kimball Jr.,of Lincoln, Massachusetts and Leadbetter Island, Maine, formerly of New York, died on April 15 in Massachusetts. He was 85. The cause was Parkinson's disease, his family said. Mr. Kimball was born in New York City in 1930, and grew up in Manhasset, Long Island. He was the son of Richard A. Kimball, an architect, and Josephine Dodge Kimball. After graduating from Brooks School and Yale University, he served in the U.S. Army for the 82nd Airborne before attending Yale Law School. He practiced law in New York as a partner of Hughes, Hubbard and Reed. An ardent Whiffenpoof, an a capella group at Yale, he was also passionate about Land Conservation, serving for years on the Board of the Dutchess Land Conservancy in Millbrook, NY, where he retired. He is survived by his wife, Hopeton, three children, George Kimball, Sam Kimball and Sylvia Kimball Perry, and eight grand children. Burial will be private. Memorial donations may be made to the Dutchess Land Conservancy, P.O. Box 138, Millbrook, NY 12545. 1/3

STARK--Morgan B. It is with profound sadness that we announce the passing of our dear friend and colleague Morgan B. Stark, 75, on April 13, 2015. Born in 1939 in New York, New York, Mr. Stark was a legendary investor, dedicated philanthropist and iconic teacher. He is survived by his wife of nearly half a century, Sidney, sons Nick and Mason, daughter-inlaw Jacqueline, and grandchildren Dante and Nicolette. Mr. Stark was a Managing Member of Ramius, LLC where he served most recently as the Chairman of Ramius Alternative Investments and Head of Macro Trading Strategy. Widely regarded as one of the most respected and knowledgeable investors in the industry, Mr. Stark began his career in the 1960s at Chase Manhattan Bank where he received a comprehensive grounding in syndicate management, municipal bonds, bond trading and sales management. He remained with the company in various roles until he joined Chemical Bank as Senior Vice President and Treasury Department Deputy Head in 1979. Mr. Stark's unwavering dedication to his clients and extraordinary knowledge of the financial markets propelled him into roles of increasing importance within the bank, resulting in his appointment to the role of President and CEO of Chemical Securities, Inc., in 1989. After serving in this role for four years, he joined Granite Capital International Group as a Portfolio Manager and Managing Director to develop a non-correlating investment management business. In 1995, he and Thomas W. Strauss joined Ramius as partners with Peter A. Cohen in the development of Ramius' investment management business. Mr. Stark was widely credited for working with his peers to develop Ramius into a successful alternative investment management business with his unwavering commitment to employees and clients. Mr. Stark served as a member of the Investor Advisory Committee on Financial Markets for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. He also once chaired the Treasury Borrowing Advisory Committee of the Bond Market Association, where he was a long time member. Mr. Stark attended the Cornell University Industrial Labor Relations School and held a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration from New York University. He served for three and a half years in the U.S. Marine Corps. In addition to his professional accomplishments, employees recognized Mr. Stark for his generosity and commitment to the long-term welfare of his employees. As Managing Member of Ramius he advocated for employees to have access to a wide range of estate, retirement planning and health care programs and personally advised many colleagues on their use. Known as a skilled raconteur and bon vivant, Mr. Stark had no shortage of hobbies, including music, skiing and golfing. A dedicated gardener, Mr. Stark took up bee keeping in his effort to enhance his floral garden in North Haven, New York. In 2005, Mr. and Mrs. Stark were invited to dinner by legendary violinist and oenophile Itzhak Perlman. Mr. Stark, eager to share his love of fine wines, brought a 1982 Chateau Lynch-Bages. Perlman, it turns out, had planned to serve the very same Bordeaux. A quick friendship developed and Mr. Stark soon after became President of the Board of Directors of the Perlman Music Program where he committed himself to helping the Program renovate its campus to meet the future needs of young musicians. In 2011, Mr. Stark told The Wall Street Journal that his work with the Program, "Fills my soul," and that the young musicians he had met, "are people that if they don't become the next best and the greatest cello or violin player, they are likely to be doctors or lawyers. But they will be wonderful people." Mr. Stark was active in a number of industry and philanthropic activities including his position as a member of the Investment Committee for the American Heart Association--Heritage Affiliate. He also previously served as President, Vice President, and member of the Board of Directors of the Dealer Bank Association and as a trustee to various charitable organizations including the Stires-Stark Foundation. Donations may be made in Mr. Stark's memory to The Perlman Music Program, 19 West 69th Street, Suite 304, New York, NY 10023. You will be missed. Peter Cohen, Tom Strauss, Jeff Solomon and your friends at Cowen and Ramius 1/3
MENDOLA--Joseph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Mendola, associated with The New York Times from October 15, 1977 until retiring on January 6, 1997. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Joel. You were the wind beneath the wings of so many people. We all love and miss you. Bruce, Iris, Peter and Naama Klatsky 1/3

STARK--Morgan B. It is with deep sadness that Bonnie and I acknowledge the passing of Morgan and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Sidney, his sons Nick and Mason, his daughter-in-law, Jackie and his grandchildren Dante and Nicolette. He carried the extraordinary distinction of being a Grand Slam colleague for 47 years. We were competitors, he was a client, we were partners, and best of all, we were friends. Over the years we were partners in establishing the Wall Street Run for the Heart Association, we were partners at Granite Capital and finally at Ramius. That says it all about the character of this man. He was generous in so many ways and was a mentor to so many throughout his life. One could always count on Morgan for advice and counsel no matter who you were or whatever the subject, and so many at Ramius did. His passion and his presence will leave a big void and I will personally miss him. Tom Strauss 1/3

WOLF--Rosel, died peacefully on April 17, 2015, at her long-time home in Mamaroneck, NY. Born June 14, 1921 in Bochum, Germany, she was the daughter of Joseph and Fanny Fruchter. She immigrated to the United States in 1937, marrying in 1942. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Arthur, and survived by her daughters Sandy Wolf Soule and her husband Steve Soule of Riverside, CT; Diane Wolf and her husband Lewis Bennett of Wilmington, DE; grandchildren Hilary Soule Shea and her husband David; Jeff Soule and his wife Rebecca; Lisa Bennett and her husband David Almog; Joshua Wolf Bennett and his wife, Katie, and great-grandchildren Zachary, Arianna, Ellie, Jacob, and Max. Rosel was a talented teacher, mentor, and a partner in Arthur's businesses. She was an active member of Larchmont Temple for over 60 years, and a strong supporter of Israel. As a refugee from the Holocaust, Rosel valued every family member, and made family of friends, students and employees. Her loving spirit will be a blessed memory forever. The funeral will take place at Larchmont Temple on Sunday, April 19 at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the Arthur & Rose Wolf Israel Fund, Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY 10538. Contributions may also be made on the Internet at https://securec29.ezhosting server.com/larchmont temple-org/About/Contribute Services are being handled by the John J. Fox Funeral Home. www.jjffh.com 1/3

STRAUSS--Ruth Ehrenkranz, 67, died on April 17, 2015. Ruth was a very special person who spent much of her life as a psychotherapist in the service of others. A beloved woman, she leaves behind a family in deep mourning, husband Robert Strauss, daughters Leah and Jenny Strauss, sister Elaine Ehrenkranz Kaplan (Jerome), brother Dr. Howard Ehrenkranz (Jane), nephews, niece, cousins, aunt and legions of friends, colleagues and patients. She was above all a lover of people devoted to inspiring and improving lives. In every role in life she embraced, Ruth was brilliantly successful. A peerless wife, mother, sister, friend, colleague and therapist, her deep generosity of spirit, wit, intelligence and wisdom dazzled all who had the great luck of entering her life. The world is a far better place for her having walked through it, and a sadder, colder one for her having departed. Service Sunday, April 19, 2015, 12:45 pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Ruth's name may be made to the Association For Fronto-Temporal Degeneration, www.theaftd.org. 1/3

SCHRANZ--Rabbi Allan. The entire congregation of Sutton Place Synagogue mourns the loss of Rabbi Allan Schranz, who led the synagogue from 1999-2012. He captivated and provoked us with his brilliant sermons; he was there for any congregant in need. Under his leadership, the Sachs Educational Center was built to house the Stanley Kaplan Nursery School and Jackson Religious School, fulfilling his vision that Jewish learning must be accessible to all. Our condolences go out to his beloved Ellen, his children, Asher (Haley) and Molly. May his memory be a blessing. Rick Kaminer, President Rachel Ain, Rabbi 1/3

FEIGENBAUM--Lawrence H. 96 of Melville, NY passed away on April 17. He is survived by two sons, Harold and Arthur, as well as three grandchildren. He is mourned by his loving companion Rosemarie. CORMAN--Betsy (Rubin) 68, a resident of Stamford, CT and formerly of Derwood, MD and Wellesley, MA passed away on April 17, 2015 after a valiant 18 month battle with pancreatic cancer. She was born June 24, 1946 in Brockton, MA to Sylvia Rubin and the late Charles V. Rubin. She was raised and educated in Brockton, MA graduating from Thayer Academy in 1964 and Cornell University in 1968. Betsy worked for IBM Corporation in various locations for 32 years, retiring in 2000. Upon her retirement she started her second career as a volunteer with Greenwich Hospital. Gradually increasing her participation, Betsy was the coordinator for the oncology volunteers at the hospital, including training of new oncology and hospice volunteers, and scheduling monthly educational sessions for the volunteers and she also served as Vice President of the Greenwich Hospital Auxiliary for one term. She was one of the founding members who brought the Schwartz Center (for Compassionate Care) Rounds to Greenwich Hospital and remained as the coordinator for this program until her death. She started the Healing Shawls program, which has provided over 2,300 shawls to oncology patients who have been treated at the hospital on both inpatient and outpatient bases. She was also a member of the hospital's Cancer and Palliative Care Committees. She was nominated three times for the hospital's Quality Award and received several Certificates of Appreciation. Involvement with palliative and compassionate care led to Betsy and her husband becoming the founding donors of the hospital's Palliative Care Department. Further philanthropic ventures included major grants to Boston Latin School, The Schwartz Center for Compassionate HealthCare, Appalachian Mountain Club, and WSHU radio. Significant donations were also made to Stamford Hospital, Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Massachusetts General Hospital, Cancer Care, Doctors Without Borders, Kids in Crisis, Westport Country Playhouse, Stamford Museum and Nature Center, Connecticut Public Broadcasting, Habitat for Humanity, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, Puppies Behind Bars, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Sloan School of Management and Koch Center for Integrative Cancer Research), Cornell University, and numerous other charitable organizations. Mrs. Corman is survived by her devoted husband Stephen Corman, her sister Deborah Rubin Cooper of Schuylkill Haven, PA, and her mother Sylvia Rubin of Stamford, CT. She was predeceased by her brother Donald Rubin of Vancouver, BC, Canada, and her father Charles V. Rubin of Chestnut Hill and Brockton, MA. She also leaves behind eight loving nieces and nephews and 12 grand nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held privately with a memorial Celebration of Life service to be held in her honor at a later date. Visitation (Shiva) will be held at her residence at 65 Apple Valley Rd, Stamford, CT 06903 on Sunday April 19, 2015 from 7pm to 9pm and Monday April 20, 2015 and Tuesday April 21, 2015 both from 3pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Memorial donations in memory of Betsy Corman may be made to Greenwich Hospital Palliative Care Department, c/o Greenwich Hospital Foundation, 35 River Road Cos Cob, CT 06807. 1/3

SARASOHN GOLD--January, of Manhattan and Southold, died suddenly after a brain aneurysm on her birthday. Fabulous daughter and best friend of Helen Sarasohn, loving wife of the late Jack Gold and dear sister of Lane Sarasohn. She'll be missed by her many cherished family and friends. VARGISH--Dr. Jacob J. died April 13, 2015 at home in Tequesta, Florida. He was 98 years old. From 1946 until 1986, Dr. Vargish practiced Family Medicine in River Edge, N.J. with his spouse, the late Dr. Hildegard S Vargish. He was a graduate of the University of Michigan and received his Medical Degree from Long Island College of Medicine (SUNY Downstate) in Brooklyn, N.Y. He did his Internship at Kings County Hospital and then served in the US Navy during WWII and again during the Korean War. He was an active member of the Staff at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. until his retirement. He is survived by his companion, Mrs. Esther Votos, his son, Dr. Thomas Vargish, two grandchildren and five great grandchildren. He is predeceased by his daughter, Jolyn Vargish Rosenthal. No memorial service is planned. 1/3

GOLTRA--Gail Wright, passed away peacefully on April 17th ending a 22-year battle with cancer. She was 73. She was actively interested in the work of the Venerable Order of St. John of Jerusalem at its eye hospital in East Jerusalem making over ten trips there and two to the Order's ophthalmic clinic in Gaza. She was made a Dame of the Order by Queen Elizabeth, II in 1994 to recognize her support and commitment. Gail is survived by her husband, Peter, her two stepsons Tad and Alexis, their children Phoebe, Wells, Charlotte and Josie and her sister Gill Bentley. In lieu of a funeral at this time there will be a memorial service on Martha's Vineyard this summer. 1/3

CALICCHIO--Steven C. April 18, 1961 - June 21, 2008 To our beloved son, brother and father, There was no one like you; free spirited, kind, generous and talented. You are missed & loved everyday. Forever in our hearts. Your Loving Family 1/3

DOUGHERTY--Michael. Michael "Gregg" Dougherty of Rumson, NJ passed away at the age of 48 on April 12, 2015 after a 6 1/2 year battle with a neurological brain disease. Gregg is survived by his wife Becky, son Jack, parents Frank and Pat, brother Scott, sister Lynn. Rest peacefully our beautiful angel. 1/3

HOLMBERG--Theodore, "Ted" lived a vibrant life full of stories. His friends remember him as being charming, generous and a witty conversationalist who loved verbal sparring. An award-winning newspaper columnist as well as a reporter, editor, and publisher, he was also a serious and thoughtful person who cared about people and events. Born on July 16, 1931, on Staten Island, NY, to Teodor Linus Holmberg (from Sweden) and Elizabeth "Lil" (Codd) Holmberg (from England/Ireland), his parents instilled in him a deep respect for learning and achieving. His father served as a Merchant Marine officer in World War II, then worked at The New York Daily News. Ted graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School and Brooklyn College, playing basketball for both. He received athletic and academic scholarships and was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society. His childhood in Brooklyn provided him with many of the defining elements of his life: his love for beaches; his life-long interest in athletics; his love of reading and writing and his love for newspapers. His romance with newspapers began when he wrote a sports column for the Sheepshead Bay News; he later graduated from the Columbia School of Journalism with honors. Ted's career included two years in the Army, 20 years as a reporter, editor and Assistant Vice-President of the Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin, culminating in his dream of owning newspapers for 25 years. In 1975, he purchased the Pawtuxet Valley Daily Times, (later the Kent County Daily Times) in West Warwick, R.I. Ted sold the paper to Independent News Corp., based in New Zealand to become President of the U.S. division and bought community newspapers in Houston and California. As President of the New England Society of Newspaper Editors in the 1980s, Ted led the first delegation of journalists to the Soviet Union. He taught journalism at Providence College. After retirement in 2000, Ted split his time between Bethesda, MD and Rhode Island. Ted pursued his love of writing, publishing three murder mysteries: "Murder Between the Sheets; The Art of Murder"; and "Murder Moons the Beach." Ted and his wife Susan shared their love of global travel, movies, the opera and ballet, dancing and walking on beaches. He had a genuine love for his wife, his children and grandchildren. Ted passed away at home in Bethesda, MD, on April 12, 2015, after a valiant struggle with cancer and its effects. He is survived by his wife, Susan Bokern; his children Ingrid Holmberg (Sean Cheesman), Erik Holmberg (Ronna Kress), Teodor James Holmberg; his sister Lillian Holmberg; a grandson, Samuel Holmberg; and his first cousin Norman Enger (Marianne). He was predeceased by his grandson Harry Holmberg. 1/3

O'DONNELL--Nancy Lindsay (Pullen). Nancy was born March 23, 1958 in Richmond, VA. Nancy did undergrad at William & Mary, North Carolina, and Golden Gate University. She earned her law degree at the University of California at Boalt Hall. Nancy also received a Masters Degree from the Harvard School of Public Health. She earned her nursing credentials from Winchester Hospital. Nancy, also known as Shushu, had a strong thirst for knowledge that formal education could not quench. Nancy loved music and was an award winning pianist in high school. Her musical palette ran the gamut from Boz Scaggs, Puccini, Marina and the Diamonds. Nancy was a loyal friend to both humans and felines. A better person did not exist. She loved reading, and had a warm, engaging singing voice. Nancy was married two decades to Brian M. O'Donnell of Boston, MA. He is devastated. She was predeceased by her father, John; mother, Lois (Morrison), and her beloved brother William. Services will be private and very sad. Sic Gorgians allos subjectatos nunc. "We gladly feast on those who would subdue us." 1/3

ZANGER-- Norman W.,M.D., April 18, 1937 - April 14, 2015. Dr. Norman Zanger of Seven Lakes, Ft. Myers, FL, formerly of Madison, NJ died peacefully on April 14, 2015. Dr. Zanger was born April 18, 1937 in Brooklyn, NY. He was a graduate of Temple University and University of Brussels in Belgium where he received his M.D.. He served in the US Army from 1967 to 1970 and was stationed at the 67th Evacuation Hospital in Vietnam Dr. Zanger practiced general pediatrics in Union, NJ for over 35 years. He was the founder and director of The Childhood Lead Clinic at Newark Beth Israel Medical Center and at Elizabeth General Medical Center. Survivors include his beloved wife Jill of Fort Myers, FL; his son, Lee (Jane) Zanger of Annapolis, MD; daughter, Jennifer (Alejandro) Blanco of Brooklyn, NY; his son Dr. Matthew (Janet) Zanger of Swampscott, MA; stepchildren, Kendra (Jocelyn) Hebert of Loudon, NH; David (Kristie) Farrington of Murfreesboro, TN; 11 grandchildren and many dearly loved nieces, nephews, and friends. A service will be held in Ft. Myers, FL on April 24, 2015. 1/3

JACOBSON--Sara. Born on December 13, 1931 to parents Esther and Eliezer Pogostky of Haifa, Israel; died Friday April 10, 2015 at her residence in Tucson, Arizona. Sara will be remembered as a beautiful, spirited and spiritual woman, devoted mother, grandmother and wife to her late husband, Edwin Jacobson, with whom she resided for many years in New York City, Southampton and later Chicago. Ed passed away in 2007. She leaves three daughters; Anita, Gela and Carol as well as five grandchildren and a great grandson. Sara had a passion for life and lived it with abundance. She was an adventurer who trekked the Himalayas, and as a photographer she had exhibits at the New York Explorers Club among other venues. Later in her life she became a rancher that bred prize-winning cattle. Sara J will be remembered by all who knew her as a super-nova, a shining star who brought a brightness and beauty to the lives of all who came to know her. 1/3

KAPLAN--Dorothy, died on April 13, 2015 at the age of 92. She was a loving wife, mother, grandmother, great -grandmother and friend. She was very accomplished and took pride in her ability to complete the New York Times crossword puzzle every Sunday into her 90's. She will be missed by the many people who have been touched by her kindness and love. 1/3

LEFKORT--Rita, died on April 13th at age 90 after a lingering illness. She was the beloved wife of Leonard for over 50 years; the loving mother of Maurice (Faith) and loving grandmother of Jared and Jason. She is also survived by her sister Naomi Abramowitz, and nephews, grand-nephews and grandnieces all of whom live in Israel. Rita was born in New Jersey and grew up in Miami, FL. She was a graduate of the University of Miami (FL) and earned a masters degree from the Medill School of Journalism of Northwestern University. As Rita Grossman, she came to New York in 1947 and joined the press department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine where she worked tirelessly with I.L. (Si) Kenen to support the partitioning of Palestine and the creation of a Jewish State. She was present at the UN when the vote was taken to partition Palestine, and in her memoir describes the Havdala service which took place that evening. After the State was declared, her department became part of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Rita arranged for the Israel flag to be raised over the Agency building in New York on May 14, 1948 when the State of Israel was proclaimed. She represented the Israel Consulate in the services for the funeral of Col. Mickey Marcus. She left her work with the Israel government and worked with Kenen in creating and developing AIPAC. She resigned in 1965 to raise her son. Rita remained active in Jewish organizations and became President of the Sharon Group of Hadassah in New York. When she returned to work she was affiliated with American Professors for Peace in the Middle East and American Friends of the Open University of Israel until she retired in 1989. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Sharon Hadassah, c/o Sherry Cohen, 174 East 74th Street, New York, NY 10021. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Joel H.,passed away on April 16, 2015. Beloved husband of Robbie. Loving and devoted father of Emily and Jason. Adoring grandfather of Joseph, Ben and Jack. Founder and president of Career Consultants, a company with a national reputation for excellence in assisting corporations to improve their human resources. As a consultant for more than 20 years to sports teams including the New York Giants and New Jersey Nets, he was an innovator in the field of sports psychology. SAFFIR--Leonard, devoted husband, father and friend passed away in Lake Worth, FL in January. He is survived by his wife Eleanor, children Andrew, Michelle, Samantha, grandchildren Cecily, Beckett. He served in the Marines, was a foreign correspondent, founded four newspapers (two award winning), authored three books on public relations, was chief of staff and press secretary to former U.S. Senator James L. Buckley, and executive vice president of Porter Novelli. Among many awards, he won the Silver Anvil Award by the Public Relations Society, and was president of the Overseas Press Club of America. Love and peace on this day - his birthday, and forever. 1/3

STEINBRUNER--John. Carnegie Corporation of New York mourns the passing of John Steinbruner, Professor of Public Policy at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and Director of the Center for International and Security Studies at Maryland. A true Renaissance man, Dr. Steinbruner was for decades a valuable and trusted advisor on all the Corporation's work in peace and security, sharing his deep knowledge of a wide range of subjects, including arms control and nuclear nonproliferation, international policy, biosecurity, relations with Russia and China, and civil conflict. He was the architect of the post -Cold War concept of cooperative security, who, primarily through his roles in the think tank and academic worlds, provided groundbreaking ideas that shaped policy in substantive ways. His colleagues at the Corporation remember him fondly as a kind, thoughtful, unpretentious, phenomenally knowledgeable individual, who was often the smartest person in the room. As an educator at the University of Maryland he mentored a generation of young international policy experts for the twenty-first century and forged educational linkages between upcoming American and Russian international relations specialists. He will be missed by his many devoted students, friends, and colleagues the world over. 1/3

STRAUSS--Ruth Ehrenkranz, 67, died on April 17, 2015. Ruth was a very special person who spent much of her life as a psychotherapist in the service of others. A beloved woman, she leaves behind a family in deep mourning, husband Robert Strauss, daughters Leah and Jenny Strauss, sister Elaine Ehrenkranz Kaplan (Jerome), brother Dr. Howard Ehrenkranz (Jane), nephews, niece, cousins, aunt and legions of friends, colleagues and patients. She was above all a lover of people devoted to inspiring and improving lives. In every role in life she embraced, Ruth was brilliantly successful. A peerless wife, mother, sister, friend, colleague and therapist, her deep generosity of spirit, wit, intelligence and wisdom dazzled all who had the great luck of entering her life. The world is a far better place for her having walked through it, and a sadder, colder one for her having departed. Service Sunday, April 19, 2015, 12:45 pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Ruth's name may be made to the Association For Fronto-Temporal Degeneration, www.theaftd.org. 1/3

STUART--Ronald L.,CPA. This could never be a goodbye forever, its only an expression of the things you have been to me. BEEBE--David C. PhD the Janet and Bernard Becker Professor of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences died at his home in St. Louis on Friday, March 27, 2015, from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). He was 70. A world renowned expert on the development of the eye, Dr. Beebe was a long-time leader in the Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences at Washington University Medical School in St. Louis. His research focused on early eye development and the causes and potential prevention of nuclear cataracts and glaucoma. Also a professor of cell biology and physiology, he was recently honored with the creation of an endowed lectureship in his name. In 2014, he was the recipient of a Distinguished Educator Award for Postdoctoral Research Mentoring. Dr. Beebe served in various leadership roles in the Association for Research in Vision and Ophthalmology (ARVO) over the past 20 years. He served on the ARVO board of trustees from 1996-2002, and was elected ARVO President in 2000. Most recently, he was elected to a five year term as Editor-In-Chief of the ARVO journal, Investigative Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences. Dr. Beebe had been chosen to receive ARVO's highest service award, the 2015 Joanne G. Angle Award, which his wife will accept on his behalf at the annual meeting in May. He earned a bachelor's degree in zoology from the University of Rhode Island in 1966, a master's degree in biomedical sciences at Brown University in 1969, and completed a doctorate in biology at the University of Virginia in 1974, where he received the Andrew Fleming Award as the outstanding graduate student in Biology. He grew up on the south shore of Long Island, NY, in intimate contact with the water. His natural curiosity and close contact with frogs and fish and many hours staring at creatures buzzing beneath the surface of the stream in his backyard awakened his interest in biology, his lifelong passion. His proximity to Great South Bay and competitive spirit resulted in his becoming an outstanding competitive sailor, receiving many trophies and filling display cases at the Sayville Yacht Club. He was on the sailing team at URI the year they captured the North American Inter-Collegiate Sailing Championship. After a postdoctoral fellowship at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), Dr. Beebe took a faculty position in the Department of Anatomy at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences in Bethesda, Maryland. During his first year at USUHS, he met and married his wife, "the love of his life." He eventually became Chairman of the Department of Anatomy and Cell Biology and received two Golden Apple (teaching) awards from the medical students during his tenure there. Dr. Beebe is survived by Anne-Elizabeth B. Beebe, PA-C, his wife of 37 years; three children, Peter (Fay Bouman), Colin (Jennifer Sullivan) and Jessica (Philip Quitslund), four grandchildren; and a younger brother, Don, also a sailor, who still lives near Great South Bay on Long Island, NY. Services: There will be no funeral, but a memorial service is planned for May 16th at Washington University Medical School in St Louis, MO. Memorial contributions may be made to the Dr. David C. Beebe Lectureship Endowment Fund in the Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences at Washington University School of Medicine. Attn: Kevin Largent 7425 Forsyth Blvd., Campus Box 1247, St. Louis, MO 63105. Online condolences at ambrusterchapel.com 1/3

SWANBERG--Edmund R. 93, died peacefully on April 12, 2015. Born in Newton, MA on October 18, 1921, "Ned" graduated from Rye, NY High School and M.I.T., class of 1943, where he was a member of Sigma Nu fraternity. Upon graduation, Ned entered Officers Candidate School, married his sweetheart Ruth and was commissioned a 2nd Lieutenant in the United States Army. His service to his country was Planning and Control Officer of the Red River Ordnance Depot in Texarkana, TX after which he was commissioned Captain. Entering civilian life in 1946, Ned joined the Investment Counsel firm Scudder, Stevens & Clark of Boston and New York, where he established his career of 52 years. Initially a young Research Analyst, he later became co-Director of Research and was elected Partner in 1961. Subsequently, he became Director, President and Portfolio Manager of the the company's Development, Special Mutual and International Funds. He retired in 1998 when Scudder was sold to Zurich Insurance. A resident of New Canaan, CT for 60 years, Ned was a pillar of his community. He was active as Treasurer of the United Fund, served on the Republican Town Committee for 12 years, and District Leader and Delegate to the State Republican Convention for many years. Additionally, Ned served on the Board of Governors of The Country Club of New Canaan and as President in 1970-72. He was a Trustee of St. Luke's School and a Board member of the Waveny Care Center. Perhaps Ned's greatest civic contribution was as one of the five founders of the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan in 1955. He served on the Search Committee which chose the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers, Jr. as its first Pastor. Ned served as Treasurer, Elder and Third Clerk of Session of the Church. Ned was a gifted sportsman well into his advanced years, golfing into his nineties as a member of the U.S. Seniors' Golf Association and both downhill skiing and playing platform (paddle) tennis well into his eighties. A gifted paddle tennis player, Ned was instrumental in traveling the country to promote the nascent sport. He was a three -time winner of the National Men's Doubles Seniors Championship. Ned served as a Treasurer and a President of the American Platform Tennis Association. Ned belonged to the Union and Racquet and Tennis Clubs of New York, the Blind Brook Club, Country Club of New Canaan and the Wharf Rat Club in Nantucket MA. ENGLISH--Mary C.,(born January 15, 1914) passed away peacefully at her home on April 15, 2015. Daughter of Michael Joseph and Mary Elizabeth English. Sister of Catherine A (English) Kerry, John P, Matthew P, Joseph A English and Genevieve T (English) Fitzsimons, all of whom predeceased Mary. Beloved Aunt to John and Robert English, Lynne Marie (English) O'Connor, and Richard, Bernard, Michael and Dennis FitzSimons. Mary had a life of service that spanned over 101 years. From the death of her own father in 1931, she became a significant support of her family. She had a successful business career and retired after 25 years as an Executive Administrative Assistant at Time Incorporated. The more important aspect of her life was the support and care that she provided to her immediate family in sickness and in health. From 1985 on, Mary shared life in her apartment with her sister, Genevieve, as the last members of their generation of the English family. Mary was small in stature, but an absolute tower of strength and self-discipline. She is loved and will be missed. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church, Jackson Heights, NY at 10:30am, Monday, April 20. The family asks for your prayers in Memory of this wonderful person who was a constant source of love and support to her family. 1/3

DESVARIEUX--Jessie. Jessie Villard Desvarieux, 61, transitioned to be with the Divine on Wednesday, April 8, 2015 in Brooklyn, NY after a valiant fight. Jessie was born on January 5, 1954 in Plaisance, Haiti and she emigrated to Brooklyn with her family at the age of seven. Throughout her life, Jessie served numerous NYC communities as a Registered Nurse. Jessie was a devoted, beloved, selfless and extraordinary mother, daughter, sister, nurse and friend. She showered all whom she encountered with love, respect, kindness and words of wisdom. She is survived by her three daughters, Farah, Jessica and Stephanie, her mother, sisters and numerous members of her extended family. Jessie was passionate about empowering the people of Haiti, her motherland. Thus, contributions in memory of Jessie may be made to an organization devoted to development without dependency, Roots of Development. See more at rootsofdevelopment.org 1/3

RICHARDS--David Kimball, age 75 died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) at home in Santa Monica, California, with his family Carol, Adam, and Peter at his side. He was an investment manager with a global and historical perspective, ethical in business and in the conduct of his life. As an investor, his special gift was drawing connections between seemingly disparate events and displaying a brave and contrarian bent, setting him apart and keeping him a step ahead of others. He devoted much of his life to making sense of the most complex of matters as a way to make the world a better place. He possessed great intellectual curiosity and pragmatic wisdom which informed all his pursuits. He was a wonderful observer of economic history and a generous supporter of the work of the Joint Centers for History and Economics at Harvard and Cambridge Universities. He supported pioneering research at the RAND Corporation to articulate a vision for a successful Palestinian State, once peace is achieved. He supported a second ambitious RAND study on the costs to Israel and Palestine of continued conflict, to be released this spring. He was a member of the RAND Board of Trustees, and served on the Board of Advisors of RAND Health and RAND Center for Middle East Public Policy. He was born in Portland, Maine, the son of Robert Ladd Richards M.D. and Janice Kimball Richards and grew up in Vermont. He received a Bachelor's degree in English literature from Harvard College in 1961, a Master's in Philosophy, Politics and Economics from Wadham College, Oxford in 1963, and a Master's in Business Administration from the Harvard Business School in 1965. He kept strong ties to Harvard and Wadham, as a valuable advisor and supporter, serving on the Chancellor's Court of Benefactors at Oxford and as a Foundation Fellow at Wadham, and at Harvard on Dean's Councils and the Committee on University Resources. David won three varsity letters rowing for the lightweight varsity crew at Harvard for three undefeated years in 1959, 1960 and 1961, and was elected captain in his senior year. His boat dominated its American competitors and won the E.A.R.C. Championships three years in a row. Internationally, in 1959 and 1960, the lightweights won the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta, the premier rowing event in the world, setting three course records in 1960. He went on to row for the Oxford University Crew and Isis Boat Club, then coached the Harvard Lightweight Crews for two years while attending Harvard Business School. His passion for rowing continued throughout his life. David had a deep respect for the people and communities of the Maine Coast. As a citizen of the world, he enjoyed global travel. However, he nourished his spirit in Maine, walking, hiking and lobster-roll lunching with friends. For 35 years, fishermen, seals and others witnessed David on the ocean in the calm early morning hours, joyfully rowing his single shell among the islands off Stonington. He is survived by his wife, Carol, his two sons Adam and Peter, two grandchildren Theo and Ian, their mother Jane, and his brother, Robert. 1/3

PRATT--James C.,born March 28, 1935 in Richland, New York, the son of Wayne and Elizabeth Pratt, died suddenly on April 13, 2015. Survived by wife Mary Beth Pratt and loving family: Sons and daughters-in-law Mike and Sherri Pratt, St. Charles, MO; Rob and Kristina Dunne, Northville, MI; Josh and Sarah Pratt, Tupper Lake, NY; and dear family friends Debra Sutton and Butch Beals, Malvern, PA. Ten grandchildren Kristy, Daniel and Megan Pratt; Erin, Robert, Jeremiah and Agnes Dunne; Lowden and Amelia Pratt; Erin Sutton-Beals. Siblings Betty Gerdon, Hemet, CA; Gloria and Dick Young, Fountain Hills, AZ; Doug and Barbara Pratt, Sandy Creek, NY; and his wife's brother's family Rick and Jodi Tully, Columbus, OH. Many nieces, nephews and other family friends. An Eagle Scout, Jim received his B.S. from SUNY Cortland and an M.S. from SUNY Brockport. He served in the army after college, from 1957 to 1959. Jim's career was spent in the service of youth, starting in Rochester, NY, as a street gang worker for the YMCA. He became the executive director of Threshold, Center for Alternative Youth Services, in 1975, and in 1988 the executive director of the New York State 4-H Foundation, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY. Jim retired in 2000 and became an active volunteer with Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, Bryn Mawr, PA. A memorial service will be held at Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, 625 Montgomery Ave, Bryn Mawr, PA, at 3:00 p.m. on Saturday, May 9, 2015. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, gifts in Jim's name be made to one of the following: Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church Foundation, 625 Montgomery Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA, 19010; New York State 4-H Foundation, 248 Grant Ave., Suite II-A, Auburn, NY, 13021; "Habitat for Humanity Philadelphia, West Philadelphia Repair Initiative," 4157 W. Girard Ave., Philadelphia, PA, 19104; or The Wild Center, 45 Museum Drive, Tupper Lake, NY, 12986. 1/3

CORMAN--Betsy (Rubin) 68, a resident of Stamford, CT and formerly of Derwood, MD and Wellesley, MA passed away on April 17, 2015 after a valiant 18 month battle with pancreatic cancer. She was born June 24, 1946 in Brockton, MA to Sylvia Rubin and the late Charles V. Rubin. She was raised and educated in Brockton, MA graduating from Thayer Academy in 1964 and Cornell University in 1968. Betsy worked for IBM Corporation in various locations for 32 years, retiring in 2000. Upon her retirement she started her second career as a volunteer with Greenwich Hospital. Gradually increasing her participation, Betsy was the coordinator for the oncology volunteers at the hospital, including training of new oncology and hospice volunteers, and scheduling monthly educational sessions for the volunteers and she also served as Vice President of the Greenwich Hospital Auxiliary for one term. She was one of the founding members who brought the Schwartz Center (for Compassionate Care) Rounds to Greenwich Hospital and remained as the coordinator for this program until her death. She started the Healing Shawls program, which has provided over 2,300 shawls to oncology patients who have been treated at the hospital on both inpatient and outpatient bases. She was also a member of the hospital's Cancer and Palliative Care Committees. She was nominated three times for the hospital's Quality Award and received several Certificates of Appreciation. Involvement with palliative and compassionate care led to Betsy and her husband becoming the founding donors of the hospital's Palliative Care Department. Further philanthropic ventures included major grants to Boston Latin School, The Schwartz Center for Compassionate HealthCare, Appalachian Mountain Club, and WSHU radio. Significant donations were also made to Stamford Hospital, Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Massachusetts General Hospital, Cancer Care, Doctors Without Borders, Kids in Crisis, Westport Country Playhouse, Stamford Museum and Nature Center, Connecticut Public Broadcasting, Habitat for Humanity, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, Puppies Behind Bars, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Sloan School of Management and Koch Center for Integrative Cancer Research), Cornell University, and numerous other charitable organizations. Mrs. Corman is survived by her devoted husband Stephen Corman, her sister Deborah Rubin Cooper of Schuylkill Haven, PA, and her mother Sylvia Rubin of Stamford, CT. She was predeceased by her brother Donald Rubin of Vancouver, BC, Canada, and her father Charles V. Rubin of Chestnut Hill and Brockton, MA. She also leaves behind eight loving nieces and nephews and 12 grand nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held privately with a memorial Celebration of Life service to be held in her honor at a later date. Visitation (Shiva) will be held at her residence at 65 Apple Valley Rd, Stamford, CT 06903 on Sunday April 19, 2015 from 7pm to 9pm and Monday April 20, 2015 and Tuesday April 21, 2015 both from 3pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Memorial donations in memory of Betsy Corman may be made to Greenwich Hospital Palliative Care Department, c/o Greenwich Hospital Foundation, 35 River Road Cos Cob, CT 06807. 1/3

Her beloved brother, professor of management Chenglie Pan, died three days after Ms. Pan in China. TEMOYAN--Edward D. of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, died April 12, 2015. Proud UPenn graduate, beloved cousin, wonderful friend, the life of the party. You will be missed. 1/3

MATTHEWS--George J. Born 9/6/23 in Queens, NY passed away peacefully on 4/16/15 in Manhasset, NY. He was 91 years old. He is survived by his adoring wife Mary of 66 years, children Russell, Lynn, Brian (Rachel), George & Greg and grandchildren Matthew, Kelly, Ryan, Emily, Owen, Jeffrey and Kate. He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII, after which he worked at Webster Tobacco in NYC while pursuing a degree in Accounting at Pace University. Thereafter, he enjoyed a career as a Sales Executive at John Hancock Insurance Company. His most cherished moments were spent with his wife, children, grandchildren and large extended family at the Matthew's summer home on Asharoken Beach in Northport, LI. He was loved by all. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Make-A-Wish Foundation, 1111 Marcus Avenue, North New Hyde Park, NY 11042. 1/3

TAUBMAN--A. Alfred. The Board of Directors and staff of Sotheby's mourn the loss and celebrate the life of our pioneering former owner, Alfred Taubman, who passed away on Friday. Alfred's achievements in business were matched only by his unwavering philanthropy. He translated his own personal success into support for countless civic, medical and arts institutions. Alfred acquired Sotheby's in 1983 and used his innovative retail experience to transform the auction market during his tenure. Once the province of dealers, Alfred opened the auction process to private collectors in a way that had never been done before and he played a critical role in shaping a modern vision for the art market. Passionate about art, he amassed an enviable collection and was a tireless supporter of museums, including the Detroit Institute of Arts. Alfred remained devoted to Sotheby's throughout his lifetime and we will always remember him as a loyal friend, gifted visionary and great humanitarian. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. 1

WHYMAN--Frank S. The Board of Trustees and families of Ocean Beach Club mourn the passing of Frank S. Whyman. Frank was a member of Ocean Beach Club for over 50 years, and he deeply cherished his ocean swims. Our thoughts are with his wife Susie, and all the members of the Whyman family. William Herrman II, President Shawn Wallach, Secretary 1/3

LEWIS--Phoebe. You were family as well as a dear friend. We will miss you terribly. Our heartfelt sympathy and love go out Bob, Michelle and our very special Deborah. All our love Madeleine and Jack 1/3

GARFINKEL--David. Glen Head, New York. August 11, 1923 to April 15, 2015. He is survived by his loving wife Gina, his daughter Eva Drabkin and husband Jess Drabkin, and grandchildren Michael, Hilary and Brooke, and by son James Garfinkel and wife Naomi Garfinkel and granddaughter Maya. David and Gina had a 60-year marriage and a 61-year love affair. David was from Sosnowitz, Poland, the son of Yakov and Chava Garfinkel. They were devout Radomsky Chassidim. David was the youngest and the last surviving child of nine brothers and sisters, six of whom perished in the Nazi death camps. He spent World War II in Nazi slave labor camps and death camps, including Markstadt, Auschwitz, Buna, Dora and Bergen Belsen. To us, David was a superhero, an indomitable spirit and a fighter who survived not only the camps, but four different types of cancer, and for the last five years a heart valve that barely functioned. Had you met him, you never would have known he had a bad day in his life. Everything was always "perfect." He loved life. He was a generous and selfless man who was devoted to his family, and who loved being surrounded by his friends. David was a rock on which you could always depend. He knew his values and he knew himself, and he never wavered from what he believed. Our hearts are broken. A great light has gone out of this world. 1/3
SCHWARTZ--David. April 20, 1913 Dear Daddy/ Grandpa Davey, OUR HERO. We love and miss you. Your Family 1/3

LEWIS--Phoebe (Boxer), March 22, 1945 - April 18, 2015. Phoebe was a compassionate and caring friend, whose love of golf, gardening, skiing and bridge was exceeded only by her devotion to her family. She was the beloved daughter of Rosalie and Stanley Boxer (deceased), devoted and adored wife of Robert for 49 wonderful years, loving mother of Michelle and Eric Salzman and Deborah and Russell Kern, incredible grandmother to Spencer and Andrew Kern and Adam and Alexandra Salzman, devoted sister to Bonnie and Victor Metsch and sister-in-law to Margie and Stuart Frost and Judith and Stanley (deceased) Lewis. We will miss her wit, intellect, inner and outer beauty and artwork. She was a great listener who will always be loved and remembered by her family and friends. In the last several months, she bravely faced her most challenging battle with dignity and valor. Donations in her memory to the Israel Defense Forces, Winthrop University Hospital Oncology and Homecare would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

TAUBMAN--Alfred A. The Board of Governors, Membership and Staff of Deepdale Golf Club, note with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Alfred A. Taubman. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman President 1/3
LEWIS--Phoebe. To my favorite golfing partner and wonderful friend. May you find fairways and greens always. We will miss you. With Love, Janie and Barry Salzberg 1/3

MALLOY--Susan Rabinowitz. The Skidmore College community deeply mourns the death of Susan Rabinowitz Malloy, Class of 1945, a talented artist, generous benefactor, and patron of the arts. In 1995 she endowed the Malloy Visiting Artist Lecture series at Skidmore, a program that brings to campus leading artists of our time both for public lectures and for close interaction with our students. She was a major donor to the Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore, with one of her gifts endowing the curator's position there, and she was a founding member of the Tang Museum's National Advisory Council. An art major at Skidmore who received further training at the Art Students League in New York City and in Europe, Susan was a talented painter who steadily earned acclaim for her work. Among the exhibitions that featured her paintings were many shows at Skidmore, including the Alumni Invitational Exhibition at the Tang. Skidmore acknowledged Susan's leadership in supporting the arts with an Outstanding Service Award in 2000 at her 55th reunion. All of us in the Skidmore community offer our deepest condolences to Susan's family and friends. Linda G. Toohey Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach President 1/3

WHYMAN--Frank S.,of Fair Haven, NJ passed away on Sunday, April 19th, 2015 after a valiant three-year battle with leukemia. Loving husband of Susie for 56 years, father of Jennifer and Bill, grandfather of Benjamin, Evan, David and Eric, brother of Betty, Madeline and Winnie, brother-in-law of Ellen, and father in-law to David and Paula. He was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 40 years and Senior Partner of Einhorn & Company. A man of courage, sweetness and unwavering optimism, our loving southern gentleman will be sorely missed. Frank was born in Burlington, North Carolina on August 10, 1927 and raised in South Boston, Virginia. He graduated from Virginia Tech and was a member of its military corps. He served in the Navy in the 2nd World War and was recalled to the Army in the Korean War, where he performed with distinction in the US 9th Corps with Princess Pat's Canadian Light Infantry. He attended the Amos Tuck School at Dartmouth. On the floor of the NYSE, he guided Einhorn and Company through volatile markets with grace, candor, and steadiness. Traders loved his unique accent, his colored shirts and his jovial manner. After 40 years, he rang the closing bell to the cheers of his colleagues. Like his father, Frank was active in Jewish charities and led the UJA of Monmouth County for any years. He had a lifelong interest in women's education and served on the Board of Trustees of Mount Holyoke College. He enjoyed Ocean Beach Club, his flat in Oxford UK, and his horse brass and tobacco jar collection, which reflected his southern heritage. A man of quiet wisdom and confidence who grasped the important things in life, he cared deeply about other people. Funeral Services will be held at 11am on Tuesday, April 21 at Monmouth Reform Temple, 332 Hance Avenue, Tinton Falls, NJ, 07724. After interment at Temple Beth Miriam Memorial Park, Neptune, 07753, the family will receive visitors on Tuesday from 4-7pm and on Wednesday, April 22 from 1-3pm and 6-8pm at 153 Buttonwood Drive, Fair Haven 1/3

KAHN--Irving. The family of Irving Kahn will hold a memorial celebration of his 109 years of life on Sunday, May 17, 2015 at the Harmonie Club, 5 East 60th Street, from 12:30pm to 4:00pm. Please RSVP to 212-980-5050 or rsvp@kahn brothers.com. The family has also established the Irving Kahn Fund at the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR) through Kahn Brothers Advisors LLC. This fund will serve as a perpetual endowment in Irving's name to fund annual research grants exploring the biology of aging. 1/3
KLEIN--David B. 4/20/1925 - 8/ 18/2013. Remembering you today and everyday. Lorinda, Warren and Mary Lou 1/3
