YELEN--Helen, whose abundance of love, caring and devotion affected her family and friends so thoroughly that her presence will be felt long after she is gone, died Sunday morning, April 19, 2015. She was 97. The love she gave was universally returned, and it is easy to understand why: Helen offered the world a broad, beautiful smile and infectious laugh; she slathered sweetness on us, each person made to feel almost like one of her sublime, signature cookies or delightfully tailored birthday poems. Perhaps this was particularly so with children -- hers and others. These were some of the beacons from Helen's soul that could part the darkness. Her voice is stilled now, a voice that brought to life, with brilliant color, a time when she grew up, a time that is long gone. But the stories live on in all who survive her and help keep her spirit alive. Helen's darling husband George, who predeceased her, was surely the center of her life for 69 years. With him she rose from humble beginnings; with him she made her beautiful homes; with him she enjoyed many magnificent trips, among them were visits to European cities and art museums she dreamed of going as a child; with him she had a family. Her children, Stephen Yelen (and wife Rosalie,) William Yelen, and Charles Yelen (and wife Barbara) survive Helen, were blessed by her motherhood, and mourn her deeply. Helen's daily care and concern for her children was unmatched. One thing for sure: they never went unnourished - she thought through every meal, every snack, every forkful; she cared about what they ate, that they ate, and how they ate. Oh, and she did her share of eating as well. There was always gastronomic bounty in that home. Her grandchildren, Jennifer, Elizabeth Weiss (and husband Daniel,) Ariel, and Joanna; and great-grandchildren, Elijah and Caleb are eternally grateful to have had Grandma Helen in their lives. You could not conjure up a better, more perfect Grandma - to listen to Helen, eureka, none of her grandchildren have any faults! She is also survived by loving nieces, nephews, and cousins. Many who have departed were essential to Helen, these include her beloved younger sister and brother, Blanche Lederer and Joe Zwillenberg (and surviving wife, Alice a vast array of cousins, aunts and uncles; and her close-knit group of friends -- especially Millie, but also Florence, Sarah, Rose, and Blanche. (Helen claimed to have done better in her classes than all her friends at Tilden High in Brooklyn, Class of 1935; most assuredly in French, but not in Geometry. No one is around to dispute the claim.) May she be reunited with all of them, and with her father, Morris, and with her mother Sarah whose illness and death when Helen was young seared her. While her childhood was tainted by great pain, it was also leavened by the unstinting loyalty and affection she received from loved ones. What joy they gave her! A joy Helen clung to and savored her whole life. And so she managed, with an inner strength, and with the outward support of many, to rise far above and beyond those painful beginnings and to give so much light to her world. We were all touched by and cherish the grace she showered on us; we were all made to feel special. So long, doll. In lieu of flowers or food, the family requests contributions be made to the UJA or any other charity of your choice. Services: Star of David Memorial Chapel, 1236 Wellwood Avenue. W Babylon, NY, 11704, Tuesday, April 21, 2015, 12:00 noon. For more information visit: jewish-funeral-home.com 1/3

FALK--Charlotte. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Charlotte Falk, a cherished, longtime friend of JTS. Charlotte established the Falk Rabbinical School Scholarship Fund at JTS where her beloved daughter, Judith Stern Peck, served as the inaugural chair of The Rabbinical School Advisory Board, and her son-in-law, Stephen M. Peck (z"l), was the chair of the Board of Trustees from 1984-1991. We offer our condolences to her legacy: her children, her grandchildren, step-grandchildren, and 22 great-grandchildren. May her memory be a blessing to all who knew her. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair 1/3

KOMISAR--Dr. Arnold, passed away on April 20th, 2015 after an extended battle with cancer. Dr. Komisar leaves behind his wife Marcella, his brother Sydney, and his children Lexie and Johnny. Dr. Komisar was born on November 27, 1947 in Brooklyn. He received his undergraduate degree from Bradley University and later attended NYU, from which he received a DDS, and Hahnemann Medical College, from which he received an MD. A leader in thyroid and parathyroid surgery, Dr. Komisar pioneered a ground-breaking and minimally invasive salivary gland operative surgery procedure in the United States. Dr. Komisar was also an active research physician, serving as Clinical Professor of Otolaryngology at the NYU School of Medicine and Professor at Hofstra North Shore-LIJ School of Medicine. Arnie, as he was known to those closest to him, was a devoted husband, father, and friend. He will be greatly missed. Services will be held on Wednesday, April 22nd 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

GRAHAM--Frederick Frederick Lorimer Graham. Died peacefully at the home of his son in Santa Barbara on the morning of April 12th, 2015 at the age of 99. He was born to Lynda and Arthur Butler Graham on July 20th, 1915 in Bayshore, Long island. He attended the Buckley School in New York, the Loomis Institute (now the Loomis Chaffee School) in Connecticut, Princeton University (class of 1937), and the Sorbonne in Paris. As a reserve lieutenant, he called into the Army of the United States in 1941 and assigned to Fort Hancock, New York, as a regular Army artillery officer charged with mining New York Harbor. He was then sent to Morocco. Alegeria and Tunisia. He was assigned successively to Allied Forces Headquarters (AFHQ), to Fifteenth Army Group. to Liaison at Seventh Army with Gebreal Patton, and to Fifth Army with General Clark. He was recalled to AFHQ liaison officer for political affairs. In this capacity he played a major role in the Allies' decision not to impose a military government in France. Major Graham was then transferred to the First French Army as liaison officer for political affairs. In the above assignments, Major Graham took part in the landings of Gela, Salerno, Anzio and Normandy, France, Germany and Austria. After the Armistice, he became Chief of Mission to the French Zone if Occupation in Austria. He was a lieutenant colonel when he returned to the U.S. and was demobilized in 1974. Fred Graham married Colette Perrier in 1945. They had three children, Sylvia, Isabelle and Frederick. Sylvia died in June 2005. Isabelle and her husband Patrick Hennessy reside in Palm Springs, California, and Frederick lives in Santa Barbara. In 1947, Fred returned to France and became European Manager of Cabot Corporation and later of Witco Chemical Company. He then established a business which eventually had 1,000 employees in eight countries and which he sold in 1992 to an American corporation. In 1978, Fred Graham married Anita Jaatinen of the Finnish diplomatic service. She died in 2009. Fred Graham developed a passion for horseback riding in his forties and continued riding and breeding horses well past his retirement. One of his horses, Caucalis, was selected by the French Olympic team for the 2000 Olympics in Sydney, Australia. Another Aime, was recognized as one of the top breeders of French saddle horses. He was an active member of the Society of the Cincinnati, America's first patriotic association of which George Washington was the forst President General. The Society is noted for its library, museum and educational programs focused on the Revolution and the founding era. It has a French branch orginnaly organized with the approval of Louis XIV, and works on supporting strong French-American relations. Mr. Graham was elected president general of the society in 1992 and served to 1995. Fred received many decorations including nine campaign medals, and the French Croix de Guerre with Palm. He is an Officer of the French Legion Honor. In addition to his daughter Isabelle, his son Frederick, and his son-in-law Patrick Hennessy, Fred Graham is survived by his grandchildren Domitille, Ludivine and Jean-Bertil Camus, his niece Karen Graham Hoaas and his step-daughter Patsy Newhouse Gerachis. His funeral will be held at two o'clock in the afternoon of April 25th, 2015 at Woodlawn Cemetery, The Bronx, New York. 1/3

GALLAGHER--John S.T. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of John "Jack" S.T. Gallagher, the health system's founding president and chief executive officer. Jack died suddenly Saturday night, April 18, of a heart attack at his home in Palm Beach, FL. He was 83. Jack was a legendary leader whose foresight and vision as president and CEO of North Shore University Hospital (NSUH) in Manhasset laid the groundwork in the early 1990s for hospital mergers on Long Island and Queens, creating a model for the integrated health systems that are so prevalent in today's healthcare market. During an era when managed care was first taking hold and hospitals were struggling financially, Jack sought to level the playing field for healthcare providers. He negotiated a merger with what was then known as Community Hospital at Glen Cove in 1990, before formally establishing the North Shore Health System in 1992. Over the next four years, he would develop relationships with Huntington, Plainview, Franklin, Forest Hills, Syosset, Staten Island University and Southside hospitals, before the network expanded further with the 1997 merger with Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Medical Center. The historic merger created the North Shore-LIJ Health System that stands today as the largest in New York State and the nation's 11th largest non-profit health system. A Queens native who obtained a business degree from Holy Cross College, Jack left the family tire business in his early 30s to begin pursuing a career in healthcare administration, earning a master of science degree from Yale University in epidemiology and public health. He joined the administrative staff at what was then called North Shore Hospital as an intern in 1963, working for then-Executive Vice President and CEO Dennis Buckley. The two would work closely together over the next two decades before Jack became president and CEO in the 1980s - a job he would hold until his retirement at the end of 2000. He had continued to serve as a life trustee of the health system. In addition to his unparalleled dedication and commitment to his work, Jack was extremely affable and approachable, enjoying coffee and breakfast with front-line staff and playing the piano at hospital holiday parties and other gatherings. On behalf of the staff and trustees of the entire North Shore-LIJ Health System, we extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Aileen O'Halloran Gallagher; sons John, Robert, Thomas and Paul; daughters Grace Haggerty and Louise Grecco; seven step-children; 27 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. In honor of Jack, flags at all North Shore-LIJ facilities will be flown at half-staff. Calling hours will be held this Thursday, April 23, from 3pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm at the Oyster Bay Funeral Home. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, April 24, at 10am at St. Gertrude's Catholic Church in Bayville. Please join us in remembering Jack and his family in your thoughts and prayers. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System 1/3

SUTTON--Ann G. Ann G. Sutton, "Boo", age 84, of Delray Beach, Florida, passed away peacefully in the arms of her children and caregiver, on Tuesday morning April 14th at 6:25am at Harbour's Edge in Delray Beach. She was born in Providence, Rhode Island on January 29, 1931 to G. Mason and Anna D. Gross. Boo graduated from Finch College. She was married to Timothy W. Knipe, father of her three children, on March 12, 1951. This marriage was followed by her marriages to Allen H. Salvesen and then to John ("Jack") B. Sutton. Boo was the definition of a "free spirit" and today her spirit is truly free. She changed the lives of everyone she touched in many ways. Boo had a gift for enabling others to see the sunny side of the street in their own lives. From dancing on tables in Coconut Grove in the 60's with Vivian Vance or strolling down the top of an antique dining table old soccer shoes at her rehearsal dinner for her wedding to Jack Sutton, Boo lived life without boundaries and brought everyone with her. In short, it was impossible to be afraid when you were with Boo. There was simply no room for it. There was only light and warmth and laughter. She is survived by her sister, Cherry Krech; her children, Timothy W. Knipe, George S. (Steve) Knipe, and Anna K. Donahue, and their respective spouses, Nancy R. Knipe, Mary Donna Knipe, and Michael Donahue; her grandchildren Nicholas A. Donahue, Natalie R. Knipe, Alden P. Knipe and Lily D. Donahue. She is predeceased by her brothers, Fred and George Gross. There will be a memorial service at sea on the morning of May 2. For more information, contact the family at: annsuttonmemorial@gmail.com. Donations to Achievement Centers for Children & Families in Delray Beach would be appreciated in place of flowers. achievementcentersfl.org/ 1/3

GALLAGHER--John Silas T. December 9, 1931 - April 18, 2015. We are deeply saddened to announce that John S.T. Gallagher passed away peacefully at his home in Palm Beach on Saturday, April 18. He was born on December 9, 1931, in Jackson Heights, New York of Mercedes Wright Gallagher and Thomas Gallagher, Sr. He attended Xavier High School and graduated with a BS in Business Administration from Holy Cross College and a Masters of Science, Epidemiology and Public Health from Yale University. As a great visionary with a caring heart, he embarked on his career in the health care industry and, as he would say, "gave birth" to the North Shore Health System. Ultimately, as Chief Executive of the North Shore-LIJ Health System, John Gallagher did more than any single individual to mold the Long Island hospital market, as referenced in the Newsday article "100 Who Shaped a Century". After changing careers in his 30s, leaving the family tire business to study public health at Yale University, the Queens native had been driven by a vision of a superior health care system that would not only survive the assault of profit-driven managed care companies but thrive and deliver charity care to the poor as well. Gallagher, a workaholic with an affable nature, joined the administrative staff at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset in 1963 as an intern. He was appointed Executive Vice President in 1982. In the 1990s, when managed care started making inroads into New York, Gallagher began hatching a plan to develop an integrated health care system, joining multiple hospitals and care facilities that could span a broad geographic area, achieve economies of scale and, most important, be able to exercise muscle in rate negotiations with insurance companies and HMOs. More recently, he merged the North Shore Health System with the Long Island Jewish Medical Center to create the North Shore-LIJ Health System, a powerhouse of 18 hospitals and numerous outpatient centers that stretches from Suffolk to Staten Island. It is no exaggeration to say that Jack Gallagher's vision is one of the reasons that the North Shore-LIJ Health System exists today. After his retirement, he remained active, serving on many boards. When Jack was not playing the piano or painting, he would be on the water enjoying his boat. He is survived by his wife, Aileen O'Halloran Gallagher, six children: John, Grace, Robert, Louise, Thomas and Paul, seven stepchildren, 27 grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. For his friendship, for his wisdom, for his deep sense of caring, he will be missed. Visitation will be at Oyster Bay Funeral Home on Thursday, April 23 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Gertrude RC Church in Bayville, NY on Friday, April 24 at 10am. Interment is private. oysterbayfuneralhome.com 1/3

KAPEL--Saul "Bud", MD, passed away on April 19, 2015. He was 86 years old and is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Harriet Chaprack Kapel. Devoted father of Sherri Kapel Kaplan MD (Marc Kaplan MD) of Scarsdale, NY; Karen Kapel Astrachan (David Astrachan MD) of Orange, CT; and Robert Chaprack Kapel MD (Jamie Klein) of Weston, CT. Proud grandfather of Alexandra (David) Corwin and Jeffrey Kaplan, Ariel (Isaiah) Toback, Daniel and Brian Astrachan, and Brandon, Jared and Lindsey Kapel. He was born in Atlantic City, NJ, son of Betty and Emanuel Kapel. After graduating NYU, he received his MD from the University of Bologna, Italy. He completed his residency in psychiatry at New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center, and a child fellowship at Albert Einstein. In addition to his private practice, he was Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College. From 1972-1982, he authored a biweekly column "Parents and Children," which appeared in The New York Daily News and was nationally syndicated by the Chicago Tribune. He was a Distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association. He loved working with his patients and teaching residents. He treasured his family and adoring wife. Services will be held Tuesday April 21, 1:30pm, Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

TAUBMAN--A. Alfred. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn the passing of Alfred Taubman former Board member. A founding member of the Whitney Museum National Committee and a patron of the Painting and Sculpture Committee, Alfred was a great supporter of the Museum's collection and its programs, and we will always be incredibly grateful for his generosity and kindness. Our most heartfelt condolences go out to his beloved wife Judy; his sons Bob and Bill; his daughter, Gayle Kalisman; two stepchildren, Christopher Rounick and Tiffany Dubin; and his entire family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chair Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chair Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director 1

KAHN--Irving. The family of Irving Kahn will hold a memorial celebration of his 109 years of life on Sunday, May 17, 2015 at the Harmonie Club, 5 East 60th Street, from 12:30pm to 4:00pm. Please RSVP to 212-980-5050 or rsvp@kahn brothers.com. The family has also established the Irving Kahn Fund at the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR) through Kahn Brothers Advisors LLC. This fund will serve as a perpetual endowment in Irving's name to fund annual research grants exploring the biology of aging. 1/3
LEWIS--Phoebe. To my favorite golfing partner and wonderful friend. May you find fairways and greens always. We will miss you. With Love, Janie and Barry Salzberg 1/3

MALLOY--Susan Rabinowitz. The Skidmore College community deeply mourns the death of Susan Rabinowitz Malloy, Class of 1945, a talented artist, generous benefactor, and patron of the arts. In 1995 she endowed the Malloy Visiting Artist Lecture series at Skidmore, a program that brings to campus leading artists of our time both for public lectures and for close interaction with our students. She was a major donor to the Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore, with one of her gifts endowing the curator's position there, and she was a founding member of the Tang Museum's National Advisory Council. An art major at Skidmore who received further training at the Art Students League in New York City and in Europe, Susan was a talented painter who steadily earned acclaim for her work. Among the exhibitions that featured her paintings were many shows at Skidmore, including the Alumni Invitational Exhibition at the Tang. Skidmore acknowledged Susan's leadership in supporting the arts with an Outstanding Service Award in 2000 at her 55th reunion. All of us in the Skidmore community offer our deepest condolences to Susan's family and friends. Linda G. Toohey Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach President 1/3

WHYMAN--Frank S.,of Fair Haven, NJ passed away on Sunday, April 19th, 2015 after a valiant three-year battle with leukemia. Loving husband of Susie for 56 years, father of Jennifer and Bill, grandfather of Benjamin, Evan, David and Eric, brother of Betty, Madeline and Winnie, brother-in-law of Ellen, and father in-law to David and Paula. He was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 40 years and Senior Partner of Einhorn & Company. A man of courage, sweetness and unwavering optimism, our loving southern gentleman will be sorely missed. Frank was born in Burlington, North Carolina on August 10, 1927 and raised in South Boston, Virginia. He graduated from Virginia Tech and was a member of its military corps. He served in the Navy in the 2nd World War and was recalled to the Army in the Korean War, where he performed with distinction in the US 9th Corps with Princess Pat's Canadian Light Infantry. He attended the Amos Tuck School at Dartmouth. On the floor of the NYSE, he guided Einhorn and Company through volatile markets with grace, candor, and steadiness. Traders loved his unique accent, his colored shirts and his jovial manner. After 40 years, he rang the closing bell to the cheers of his colleagues. Like his father, Frank was active in Jewish charities and led the UJA of Monmouth County for any years. He had a lifelong interest in women's education and served on the Board of Trustees of Mount Holyoke College. He enjoyed Ocean Beach Club, his flat in Oxford UK, and his horse brass and tobacco jar collection, which reflected his southern heritage. A man of quiet wisdom and confidence who grasped the important things in life, he cared deeply about other people. Funeral Services will be held at 11am on Tuesday, April 21 at Monmouth Reform Temple, 332 Hance Avenue, Tinton Falls, NJ, 07724. After interment at Temple Beth Miriam Memorial Park, Neptune, 07753, the family will receive visitors on Tuesday from 4-7pm and on Wednesday, April 22 from 1-3pm and 6-8pm at 153 Buttonwood Drive, Fair Haven. Donations may be sent to Monmouth Reform Temple and the Benjamin Einhorn Discretionary Fund, Mount Holyoke College, 50 College Street, South Hadley, MA 01075. 1/3

SHALITA--Eileen, passed away on April 20, 2015 at age 90 at peace in the home she lived in for 63 years and never wanted to leave. Loving and much beloved wife (of Paul Shalita) and mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend to so many. She loved and cherished all her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and the feelings were returned. She never saw a glass as half empty because she would fill it with her warmth, charm, elegance, humor, grace and enthusiasm. She lived a long happy life because she saw the best in every person she met and the bright side of every situation. Funeral at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, NY on Wednesday, April 22, 2015 at 10am. Donations may be made to Hospice Care Network. 1/3

TAUBMAN--A. Alfred. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Alfred Taubman. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. 1

STEINBRUNER--John D. The Board and staff of the Financial Services Volunteer Corps (FSVC) are profoundly saddened by the death of John D. Steinbruner. John served as a member of FSVC's Board of Directors for ten years. We have lost a dear friend and valued colleague. John understood the strategic importance of FSVC's mission to strengthen financial sectors in the emerging markets, and through his brilliant insights he helped all of us understand more clearly the bigger picture and context of that work. He was instrumental in conceiving, designing and implementing a multi-year series of symposia, administered by FSVC and supported by Carnegie Corporation of New York, that brings together experts from the United States, Russia, China and India to seek solutions to complex problems involving the international financial system, energy security and climate change. This pathbreaking work has resulted in a unique quadrilateral dialogue that has reflected John's personal qualities of openness and honesty. His rare combination of intellectual brilliance, humility and humanity will be missed greatly. His commitment to help make the world a better place will live on in FSVC's work. On behalf of the FSVC Board and staff, William H. Donaldson, Chairman J. Andrew Spindler, President & CEO 1/3

RUBIN--Jacquelyn (Audi), nee Ragona, 88, of New York City, died on Saturday, April 18th, 2015. She was predeceased by her loving husband Ed and survived by son Joshua and daughter-in-law Gina. Gravesite service: Tuesday, April 21, 1pm at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. For information call 201-944-0100. 1/3

CUDAHY--Michael, Jr.,76, died Friday, April 17, 2015 at home with his family in Carmel, CA. He was born in Chicago, Illinois, and grew up in Lake Forest. He went to Deerfield Academy and graduated from Colorado College where he was member of the Kappa Sigma fraternity. Michael's business career began in sales at Marshall Field's and then at Callaghan Publishing Company. In 1970 he moved to the San Francisco Bay Area and went into the natural foods business. Michael sold the business, Rock Island Foods, in 2001 to Nestle International. Michael was an avid golfer and a member of the Cypress Point Club in Pebble Beach, California, and the King Kamehameha Golf Club in Maui, Hawaii. Michael is survived by his wife of 41 years, Mary Cudahy; three stepchildren: Henry Combs, Elizabeth Somerby, and Mastin Combs; his mother, Annie May McLucas; his sister, Shaun Cudahy Block. He was the son of the late Michael Cudahy. 1/3

TAUBMAN--A. Alfred. The Board and staff of American Friends of the Israel Museum mourn the death of our National Committee member and friend, A. Alfred Taubman. Al was a staunch supporter for decades, member of our Director Circle, and lifelong friend of the Israel Museum. We offer heartfelt condolences to Judy and the family. Stacey Bronfman President, AFIM; Judy Steinhardt AFIM Board Co-Chair; James S. Snyder Anne & Jerome Fisher, Dir., IM; Leah Siegel Executive Director, AFIM 1

ASCH--Kathryn Ottilie, born October 30, 1958 in New York City, died too soon on April 16, 2015. Katie graduated from St. Ignatius Loyola School in Manhattan. She spent her first years of college at Duke University before graduating from New York University Film School. She later moved to Southern California. She is survived by her husband Robert Guralnick, her son Leland Guralnick, her parents Ann and Gerard Asch, her sister Ann Margaret Asch, her brother William Asch, her many nieces and nephews and countless dear friends. Katie loved animals and had dogs, cats, chickens and numerous kittens she fostered in her home and beautiful gardens in Fryman Canyon. Leland Bond Guralnick will dedicate his graduation, in May, from Southern Methodist University to his mother and best friend. A memorial celebration will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena, CA on April 25th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a contribution to the David Sheldrick Wildlife trust, at sheldrickwildlifetrust.org. 1/3

COLELLA--Cathleen B.,of Locust Valley, NY, formerly of Yarmouth, MA on April 21, 2015 at the age of 76. Beloved wife of Dr. Henry V. Loving mother of Cathleen Graham (Gordon, Jr.). Cherished grandmother of Harrison and Olivia Graham. Dear sister of William, Daniel, Dennis, Anne and Rita Battles and Marilyn Gregory and Joanne Burke, she also survived by many beloved cousins, nieces and nephews. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Whitting Funeral Home 300 Glen Cove Ave., Glen Head, NY 11545 www.whitting.com. Funeral Service 11am Friday at St. John's Episcopal Church of Lattingtown, NY. RACHELLS--Florence. The members and staff of Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC note with profound sadness the passing of Florence Rachells at the age of 102. She served as our Comptroller for over 40 years and as recently as one month ago was still coming to the office on a regular basis. We will miss her remarkable skills, but above all, we will miss her warmth and guidance. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC Eugene M. Grant, President 1/3

SHALITA--Eileen, passed away on April 20, 2015 at age 90 at peace in the home she lived in for 63 years and never wanted to leave. Loving and much beloved wife (of Paul Shalita) and mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend to so many. She loved and cherished all her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and the feelings were returned. She never saw a glass as half empty because she would fill it with her warmth, charm, elegance, humor, grace and enthusiasm. She lived a long happy life because she saw the best in every person she met and the bright side of every situation. Funeral at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, NY on Wednesday, April 22, 2015 at 10am. Donations may be made to Hospice Care Network. 1/3

KAHN--Irving. The family of Irving Kahn will hold a memorial celebration of his 109 years of life on Sunday, May 17, 2015 at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, from 12:30pm to 4:00pm. Please RSVP to 212-980-5050 or rsvp@kahn brothers.com. The family has also established the Irving Kahn Fund at the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR) through Kahn Brothers Advisors LLC. This fund will serve as a perpetual endowment in Irving's name to fund annual research grants exploring the biology of aging. 1/3

TAUBMAN-- A. Alfred. The Museum of Arts and Design (MAD) mourns the passing of A. Alfred Taubman. A leading supporter of cultural and civic institutions, Mr. Taubman enriched the lives of millions of children, students, artists, and families through his philanthropy. He was an important benefactor of our institution, generously supporting the capital campaign for our Jerome and Simona Chazen Building at 2 Columbus Circle. In 2006, the Museum honored Mr. Taubman with a Visionaries! Award, which celebrates leaders in the fields of art, craft and design, in recognition of his philanthropic activities and his many innovations in the retail and auction sectors. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family, including Museum Trustees William and Ellen Taubman. Lewis Kruger, Chairman, Glenn Adamson, Nanette L Laitman Director, Board of Trustees and staff of the Museum of Arts and Design 1

GEFFEN--Abraham on April 20. Born September 22, 1916. Funeral Wednesday 2:00 pm at Beth El Cedar Park. Dr. Geffen was a radiologist for 44 years at Beth Israel Medical Center. Survived by children David and Mitzi, Robert and Yaffa, Sara and Leon, seven grandchildren, eight great grandchildren.

McCARTHY--Martin N. The West Side Federation for Senior and Supportive Housing deeply mourns the passing of our extraordinary Founder and General Counsel, Martin N. McCarthy. From the organization's inception, Martin was instrumental in our housing development, from the initial concepts through the financing, construction, and management. For decades, he devoted his legal expertise, keen intellect and caring heart to the development of safe and affordable permanent housing for people of low income and special needs. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Laura R. Jervis (our esteemed Executive Director and Founder), to Brigid, Christopher, and DeYan, and to all the members of their great extended family. 1/3

KOMISAR--Dr. Arnold, passed away on April 20th, 2015 after an extended battle with cancer. Dr. Komisar leaves behind his wife Marcella, his brother Sydney, and his children Lexie and Johnny. Dr. Komisar was born on November 27, 1947 in Brooklyn. He received his undergraduate degree from Bradley University and later attended NYU, from which he received a DDS, and Hahnemann Medical College, from which he received an MD. A leader in thyroid and parathyroid surgery, Dr. Komisar pioneered a ground-breaking and minimally invasive salivary gland operative surgery procedure in the United States. Dr. Komisar was also an active research physician, serving as Clinical Professor of Otolaryngology at the NYU School of Medicine and Professor at Hofstra North Shore-LIJ School of Medicine. Arnie, as he was known to those closest to him, was a devoted husband, father, and friend. He will be greatly missed. Services will be held on Wednesday, April 22nd 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

McGAHREN--Richard G. (1928 - 2015) "And he said to him, 'Truly, I say to you, today you will be with me in Paradise." Luke: 23:43. Richard G. McGahren of Naples, FL, and Katonah, NY passed away peacefully on Wednesday, April 15, 2015, surrounded by loved ones. Richard was born on June 18, 1928, the second son of Eugene and Cecelia McGahren. Richard grew up in Yonkers, NY and graduated from Roosevelt High School. After high school Richard enlisted in the United States Army and served two years in Japan. Richard was honorably discharged and left the Army with the rank of Sergeant. Richard went on to receive degrees from Columbia College and Columbia School of Law. Richard enjoyed a long and fulfilling career as an attorney and partner with D'Amato & Lynch, LLP in Manhattan, NY. Richard was a successful and respected litigator spending much of his career representing fortune 500 companies. Richard retired in 1994 from law and married for the first time. He enjoyed a wonderful marriage to his wife Marjorie. Richard had many hobbies but his favorite pastimes were painting and sailing. He was self-taught in both. He became a proficient sailor and sailed out of marinas in Bridgeport, CT. and Naples, FL. Richard painted many scenes from the places he and Marjorie loved to travel to, especially their favorite countries, France and Germany. Richard enjoyed many things including writing, skiing, and biking and could always be found rooting for his New York Giants and Yankees. Richard is survived by his wife Marjorie and five children and their spouses; Christine and Kyle Groff, Jennifer and Perry Cooper, Lawrence and Jennifer Waterhouse, Kevin and Angela Waterhouse and Patrick and Lindsay Waterhouse. In addition, Richard is survived by two brothers and three sister-in-laws, George and Elizabeth, Kenneth and Jean and Elizabeth, his older brother Eugene's wife. Eugene predeceased Richard earlier this year. He is also survived by 19 loving grandchildren and 12 nieces and nephews and their families. A private visitation, for family and close friends of Richard and Marjorie McGahren, will be held on Thursday, April 23rd at Clark Associates Funeral Home in Katonah, NY. A Mass to celebrate Richard's life will be held on Friday, April 24th at 10:00am at St. Mary's Church in Katonah, NY with interment to follow at the Gates of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made to the Thomas Hartmann Center for Parkinson's Research, checks can be made payable to the Stony Brook Foundation - Fund#

GREALISH--Thomas. June 22nd, 1949, passed away Monday, April 13th, 2015. Thom received a B.S. in Business Administration from SUNY Albany in 1971 and an M.B.A. in Marketing from Hofstra University in 1981. He founded Integra Consulting in 1994. Thom was a dedicated and loving father to Adam and PJ. His impact was felt by many as a coach, mentor, and friend. Thom is survived by his partner Katja Huismans; sons Adam and PJ; brother Peter Grealish; and four sisters, Judith Thomas, Dale Grealish, Marian Grealish-Forino, and Rita Segura.

NOTARIS--Antonio Frank, 81, died Sunday, April 19, 2015 at home with his children in Brooklyn, NY. He was born and raised in New York City. He served in the US Army and served in the Korean War. He earned his Certified Public Accountant designation and worked at large, national firms until he began his own practice in NYC where he practiced for over 30 years. In addition to being a hard worker, he was an avid family man who treasured time with his family and friends. He believed in philanthropy and was extremely generous during his lifetime. Frank was predeceased by his wife of 59 years, Marie, who died in May of 2014 and his sister, Pauline. He is survived by his children, Mary Notaris and her spouse, Deborah DeFelice, Annemarie Girgenti and her husband Vincent, and James Notaris, CPA, Esq., and his wife Amanda. He is also survived by eight grandchildren: Vincent, Nicholas, Jaime, Jason, Douglas, Austin, Russell, and Benjamin. 1/3

Brier, President & CEO Maimonides Medical Center 1/3

LICHTENSTEIN--Dr. Aharon Yeshiva University mourns the passing of HaRav Dr. Aharon Lichtenstein '53YC, '59R. An unparalleled Torah giant, Rabbi Lichtenstein, Rosh Yeshiva of Yeshivat Har Etzion, was a devoted student of Rav Joseph Soloveitchik, his father-in-law, and expanded Brisker scholarship on a wide range of topics, leaving an extensive legacy of Torah erudition. He provided a powerful model of integrity, able to synthesize the arena of Torah and academic knowledge, and took positions to ensure the moral conscience and compass of our people. At YU, he served as the Rabbi Henoch and Sarah D. Berman Professor of Talmud and was the inaugural Rosh Kollel of the Caroline and Joseph S. Gruss Institute of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Tovah, his children Yitzchak, Moshe, Meir, Shai, Esti and Tonya, and by two sisters Hadassah Kleiman and Shoshana Lichtenstein, as well as many grandchildren and thousands of students across the Jewish world. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

O'NEILL--Nicholas P.,of Rockville Centre and Shelter Island, NY. December 24, 1933 to April 19, 2015. Beloved husband for 56 years of Patricia (McKaigney) O'Neill; role-model father to James M. O'Neill and daughter-in-law Ellen Prescott O'Neill of South Orange, NJ; proud grandfather of Seamus and Liam O'Neill; devoted brother to Michael O'Neill of Westwood, NJ and his wife Una, Kevin O'Neill of Eaton's Neck, NY and Patrick O'Neill of Houston, TX and his wife Virginia. ERVIN--Judith, (nee Tingerthal) died April 19, at age 70, from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Born in St. Paul, MN, she graduated from the College of St. Catherine and earned an MBA from New York University. She spent her career in New York City, primarily working for Citicorp, where she retired as a vice-president in 2007. She traveled widely, enjoyed the cultural life of New York, and skied in Europe, at Killington and at Taos. After retiring, Judy became an enthusiastic volunteer for the Central Park Conservancy, an activity she continued well after her health started to decline. Her failing health caused her to leave her Central Park West condo and move closer to her family in Minnesota, where she passed away. She leaves behind her sisters and brothers, their spouses, her nieces and nephews and grand nieces and nephews. She also leaves her many friends, work colleagues and her neighbors at 392 CPW. Judy's family especially remembers the devotion of her friend and neighbor, Janet Smith, and her care-giver, Mary Folan. A funeral service will be held April 24 In Minneapolis, MN and burial will be at St. John's Cemetery in Collegeville, MN on May 2. A gathering to remember Judy's life is being planned for mid-June in New York City. Memorials are suggested to the Alzheimer's Association, the NC Little Hospice or the Central Park Conservancy.

RACHELLS--Florence. The members and staff of Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC note with profound sadness the passing of Florence Rachells at the age of 102. She served as our Comptroller for over 40 years and as recently as one month ago was still coming to the office on a regular basis. We will miss her remarkable skills, but above all, we will miss her warmth and guidance. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC Eugene M. Grant, President 1/3

ESCH--Robert Ernst. Born 1932 in Detroit, died April 19 in Ottsville, Pa. Predeceased by Ann, wife of 51 years. Survived by wife Judy, five children and six grandchildren. Memorial 5 to 8pm, May 8, Holcombe-Fisher Funeral Home, Flemington, N.J.

Funeral services were privately held. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461. 1/3
VAN BUREN--Robert. April 23, 1925. Happy Birthday, Dad. You're in my heart every minute of every day. Love, "Bronc" 1/3

MALM--Eric Sigfrid. January 5, 1927 - April 15 2015. Beloved husband of Nancy and father of Scott and Karen. Formerly of Morristown, NJ. Retired Attorney Davidson, Dawson & Clark. Service: April 25, 2015 at 1pm; St. Andrew's Church, New London, NH. View Obituary: chadwickfuneralservice.com

O'NEILL--Nicholas P.,of Rockville Centre and Shelter Island, NY. December 24, 1933 to April 19, 2015. Beloved husband for 56 years of Patricia (McKaigney) O'Neill; role-model father to James M. O'Neill and daughter-in-law Ellen Prescott O'Neill of South Orange, NJ; proud grandfather of Seamus and Liam O'Neill; devoted brother to Michael O'Neill of Westwood, NJ and his wife Una, Kevin O'Neill of Eaton's Neck, NY and Patrick O'Neill of Houston, TX and his wife Virginia. Nick worked for decades selling ad time at WPAT, WNEW and WINS radio stations, and was a dedicated volunteer, coaching youth basketball and baseball, helping spearhead fundraising drives, reunions, retreats and employment support groups at Fordham University, his alma mater, and tutoring students at De La Salle School in Freeport, NY. Visitation Wednesday 7-9pm, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm, Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 11am, St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. www.mackenmortuary.com 1/3

DAHAN--Bonnie Babbitt. The law firm of Dahan & Nowick LLP mourn the passing of Bonnie Babbitt Dahan, the beloved wife of our senior partner M. Marc Dahan. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Marc and the entire Dahan and Babbitt families. 1/3

SORACI--Doreen. Beautiful and beloved mother of Sasha Tulchin, treasured sister to Karen Grande and Jod Soraci, and favorite aunt of Victor, Todd and the late Charles Grande, Doreen Soraci died on Sunday April 19th, 2015 after a long battle with Lewy Body Dementia. SCHWARTZ--Judith G.,98.5. A pioneer of creative movement for children and longtime champion of social justice died April 22nd. Judy taught dance at the University of Illinois and at Washington University in St Louis. She then spent 30 years as a professor in the Dance in Education Department at NYU. While at NYU, she founded Kaleidoscope Dancers, a company that performed for children in NYC schools. Judy was among the first members of Women Strike for Peace. Happily married to the late Robert N. Schwartz for 70 years, she was a loving mother to Fran (Michael Weinstein) and Jim (Wendy Selene), an adoring grandmother to Zach, Lev and Nelly and a devoted aunt, sister-in-law, mentor and friend to many. 1/3

BONDY--Joan M. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Joan M. Bondy, and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

PREWITT--Ken, 68, the consummate gentleman and authoritative voice of Bloomberg Radio, passed away at home in Manhattan on April 11, 2015. He embraced life. His greatest loves were his home in the Berkshires where he spent so many of his happiest days. He loved the solitude of fly fishing and the speed of Formula One. He loved Bella, his beloved Brittany, and Faye, his adoring, devoted and lucky wife of 34 years. Ken was a treasure who will be missed every day and remembered forever. A memorial service will be held in New York on Thursday, April 30th, 2015 at 10:30am at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue, corner of West 53rd Street. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Ken's name to The Neuro- Oncology Research Fund, Memorial Sloan Kettering, 633 Third Avenue, 28th floor, New York, NY 10017. 1/3

AGUS--Saul. The Board of Directors of Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design Jerusalem extends its heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Vice President, Raanan Agus, on the loss of his father, Saul. Our condolences also go to his mother, Marcelle, and his siblings, Yosef, Elizur and Michal Fox. 1/3

PATTERSON--Robert P. Judge Robert P. Patterson jr., patriotic citizen, committed public servant, and beloved father, uncle, brother and grandfather passed away on April 21, 2015, at the age of 91, after a heroic battle with multiple myeloma cancer. He is survived by his sisters, Susan Patterson and Ginger Montgomery, his children Anne, Margaret, Paul and Katherine, and several grandchildren. His wife, Bevin Daly Patterson, predeceased him, as did two children, Robert and Bevin, and his sister Lee Seldes. A wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC 10028 on Friday April 24 from 4 to 7pm. On Saturday April 25 at 11:00am funeral services will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street and Fifth Avenue, with reception to follow. Burial will be at 4:30pm on Monday, April 27 at Cold Spring Cemetery, Peekskill Road, Cold Spring, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Focus Forward (www.thefocusforward project.org/), and Legal Aid Society(www.legal-aid.org). 1/3

BRAUN--Ruth F. 1918 - 2015. Talented pianist and organist; passed away on April 15th. Graduate of Evander Childs High School, Hunter College and Columbia University (M.A., Music). Husband, Arthur (L.Cdr., U.S.N.R.) died 1999. Leaves sons Geoffrey and Donald of Santa Clara County, CA., three granddaughters; a brother (Solomon Fisher), and 13 nephews and nieces. Ruth spent her life making and writing music and as an educator in the Glen Cove Public School system. Performed piano recitals at the 92d St. "Y" up to age 91. A private memorial service will be held at Ruth's home. 1/3
BRADSHAW--Patricia Salter, of Palm Beach and New York passed away peacefully at Good Samaritan Medical Center on April 20, 2015 in West Palm Beach, FL. 1/3

AISENBERG--Michele Kaiden, of New York City, formerly of New Rochelle, NY, peacefully in her home on April 22, 2015. Mickey was a lifelong supporter and advocate for women's rights and liberal causes. A founding member of the Independent Democrats of New Rochelle, candidate for New York State Assembly and Chair of the Women's Caucus of the Democratic National Committee. Supporter of the arts, accomplished and prolific painter. Long-time member of Bonnie Briar Country Club. Remembered for her impeccable style and grace. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, devoted mother of Elizabeth "Betty" and Robert "Bob" and daughter-in-law Kathy. Adored grandmother of Alison, Danny, James, Jonathan, and his wife Katie. Great grandmother of Lucia. Service Sunday, April 26th, 2015, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Service Fund of NOW NYC, 150 West 28th St., Suite 304, New York, NY 10001 attn: Deborah Dewees. 1/3

AGUS--Dr. Saul. The Board of Directors of American Friends of Shalva mourn the passing of Saul Agus, beloved father of Shalva Board member Raanan Agus. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Marcelle and to Raanan, Nicole and the entire Agus family. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Norm Alpert and Carol Levin, Co-Presidents, Kalman Samuels, Shalva Founder and Director, Leo Klein, Executive Director 1/3

ERVIN--Judith, (nee Tingerthal) died April 19, at age 70, from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Born in St. Paul, MN, she graduated from the College of St. Catherine and earned an MBA from New York University. She spent her career in New York City, primarily working for Citicorp, where she retired as a vice-president in 2007. She traveled widely, enjoyed the cultural life of New York, and skied in Europe, at Killington and at Taos. After retiring, Judy became an enthusiastic volunteer for the Central Park Conservancy, an activity she continued well after her health started to decline. Her failing health caused her to leave her Central Park West condo and move closer to her family in Minnesota, where she passed away. She leaves behind her sisters and brothers, their spouses, her nieces and nephews and grand nieces and nephews. She also leaves her many friends, work colleagues and her neighbors at 392 CPW. Judy's family especially remembers the devotion of her friend and neighbor, Janet Smith, and her care-giver, Mary Folan. A funeral service will be held April 24 In Minneapolis, MN and burial will be at St. John's Cemetery in Collegeville, MN on May 2. A gathering to remember Judy's life is being planned for mid-June in New York City. Memorials are suggested to the Alzheimer's Association, the NC Little Hospice or the Central Park Conservancy.

AGUS--Dr. Saul G. I am profoundly saddened by the loss of a beloved family friend, Dr. Saul G. Agus. His good deeds, his acumen, his good words, his dedicated devotion to his patients, his endless capacity for giving, and his love of life uplifted us all. He taught by example as he kindly devoted himself on the behalf of others, the patients he cherished, the family so beloved, his friends, his community. Indeed, it has been a great privilege and honor to have known him His beautiful soul will always be bound in the center of our lives. Susan Wexner 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Sybil (Friedman), loving mother of Diane, Judith and Andrew; grandmother of Joanna, Stewart, Miles, Harry and Leah. Sister of Charlotte Zavon, beloved aunt, cousin and friend. Services at Riverside Chapels, 21 Broad St., Mt. Vernon, 12 noon, Friday. 1/3

MURPHY--James F.,III, 85 of Garden City, LI passed away on April 22, 2015. Born in Brooklyn on August 10, 1929 and raised in Rockville Centre, LI, Jim graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1955. After three years in the Army, he joined the business co-founded by his father, and had an over-50 year career in the dredging, ship repair, real estate industries, serving as President and Chairman of the Board of several companies, including New York Shipyard Corp. in Red Hook, Brooklyn. In 1962, Jim married Helen Marie Fagan and together they raised their five children in Rockville Centre and then Garden City, LI. Jim was predeceased by his wife, and his son, James F. Murphy IV, and is survived by his four daughters, Kathleen Murphy Alcock (Mark) of New York City, Elizabeth Cooke (Dan) of Glen Head, NY, Helen M. Sweeney of Sea Cliff, NY, and Kristin Hubschman (Jon) of Rockville Centre, NY, his daughter-in-law, Jeanine Kelly Murphy, and nine grandchildren. A man of deep integrity, understated wit, and a deep sense of family and tradition, Jim will be sorely missed by all who knew him. A wake will be held at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City on Saturday, April 25th, 7-9pm, Sunday, April 26th, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, April 27th at 10am at St. Joseph's RC Church at 450 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, followed by interment at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury. 1/3
AGUS--Saul, M.D. In loving memory of our beloved physician and friend. He cared for us and he cared about us. We shall never forget him. Lenore & Ernest Braverman 1/3

WALDMAN--Fay. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Jewish Foundation for the Righteous mourn the passing of Fay Waldman, a survivor of Auschwitz, beloved mother of JFR Trustee, Hannah Waldman. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Hannah and her family. May her memory be a blessing. Harvey Schulweis, Chairman Roman Kent, President Stanlee Stahl, Executive Vice President

SCHWARTZ--Judith G.,98.5. A pioneer of creative movement for children and longtime champion of social justice died April 22nd. Judy taught dance at the University of Illinois and at Washington University in St Louis. She then spent 30 years as a professor in the Dance in Education Department at NYU. While at NYU, she founded Kaleidoscope Dancers, a company that performed for children in NYC schools. Judy was among the first members of Women Strike for Peace. Happily married to the late Robert N. Schwartz for 70 years, she was a loving mother to Fran (Michael Weinstein) and Jim (Wendy Selene), an adoring grandmother to Zach, Lev and Nelly and a devoted aunt, sister-in-law, mentor and friend to many. 1/3

HAROCHE--Gilbert, in New York City on April 23, 2015. Co-Founder and President of Liberty Travel. He pioneered the vacation package and Liberty Travel was the largest privately held leisure travel company in the United States for over 25 years. He was philanthropically active and involved with numerous charities. Survived by his beloved wife Charlene; his devoted children, Marcella, Maurice and Andre; son and daughters-in-law, Peter Leone, Janna and Hilary Haroche; grandchildren, Callie, Peter, Juliette, Jack, Annabelle, Sage, Gavin and Kira. Also, survived by children Bob and Kim and grandchildren Liev and Skyler. Service: Sunday, April 26, 2015, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to: LEO Zoological Conservation Center, www.LeoZoo.org or to the American Cancer Society, www.cancer.org 1/3

ABRAMS--M.H. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, the distinguished teacher, critic, and theorist who changed how we look at English poetry. 1

KIMBALL--Richard "Dick" Hughes Hubbard & Reed mourns the loss of retired partner, colleague and friend Richard "Dick" Kimball, who passed away on April 15 at the age of 85 from Parkinson's disease. For more than 30 years, Dick was a significant contributor to the development of the firm's trusts and estates practice. He will be remembered for his integrity, his love of the firm and his relentless good cheer. We are grateful for the time we had with him and send our deepest condolences to his family. He will be greatly missed. 1

PISELLI--Louis Carmine, died peacefully on April 14, 2015. He was born in Manhattan in 1932. He served in the 82nd Airborne Division of the Untied States Army. He lived a full and happy life. He is survived by his daughter Francine Suarez and her husband Javier, his grandchildren Amanda, Andrea and Alexander and great-grandchildren Ethan, Phoenix, Dashel and Julian. His big heart, sense of humor and loving soul will be sorely missed. A Memorial Mass will be held on April 27th, 11am at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71 St., New York, NY. If desired, donations in his memory may be made to the Humane Society of New York or to: www. gifts4thegoodguys.org 1/3

O'BRIEN--Thomas H.,90, Veteran, Financier, Friend to All. Thomas H. O'Brien, of Chatham, New Jersey, died at the age of 90 on April 22, 2015 surrounded by family. Beloved son, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend to all, he was born in Hamden, CT, son of the late Thomas C. and Edna O'Brien. His wife, Mary Ann Kachinski O'Brien, his youngest daughter, Marianne O'Brien Stiansen (Stephen), his brother, Jack O'Brien, and his sister, Doris preceded him in death. He is survived by his three remaining children Thomas H. O'Brien, Jr. and wife Sally, Diane O'Brien Vaglio and husband Nicholas, Michael P. O'Brien and wife Mariel. Also survived by his by 10 grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren, two step grandchildren, six step great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Tom served his country during World War II as a member of the United States Air Force. He graduated with a B.A. degree in Economics from Wesleyan University in Middletown, CT, and did post-graduate studies at New York University's Stern School of Business and Columbia University. He was also a faculty member at the American Institute of Banking and Hofstra University, where he was also a trustee. During his six decades in the financial services industry, with a particular expertise in public utility finance, he was associated with Chase Manhattan Bank, Lehman Brothers, Citibank, Long Island Lighting Company, Jamaica Water Supply Company and his own consulting company, O'Brien Associates. During that time he also served as a director and trustee for numerous companies and organizations. The O'Brien family wishes to extend our sincere thanks to the special caregivers of Visiting Angels of Suburban Essex and our friends at Juniper Village in Chatham. Visitation will be held on Sunday, April 26, 2015 from 1:00pm to 4:00pm at Gallaway & Crane, 101 S. Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge, NJ. Mass of the Christian Burial will be held on Monday, April 27 at 11:00am at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, 111 Claremont Road, Bernardsville, New Jersey. Burial will follow at the Holy Cross Cemetery in Basking Ridge. To light an online condolence candle for the family please visit the funeral home's website at gcfuneralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Marianne O'Brien Stiansen Scholarship Fund, c/o Linda Ceci, 759 Walnut Street, Cranford, New Jersey, 07016. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Sylvia. August 6, 1919 - April 25, 2014 In commemoration of the first Yahrzeit of our beloved mother, grandmother, aunt and friend. May your memory be for a blessing. We miss you and love you. 1/3

PERUTZ--Gerald, E.A, age 85, died peacefully in London on April 20th 2015. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Dinah Fyffe Perutz. He is survived by their children; Sandie MacClancy, Simon and his wife Kim, Tim and his wife Susanna, and grandchildren Kate, Tessa, Sophie, Lucy, Andrew, Matthew, Alex, Hugo and Anna; his second wife, Cornelia Brewster Opdycke Perutz, his step daughter Abigail Walsh and husband Patrick, stepdaughter Anna Payne and husband Will, step grandchildren Stella, Eliza, Declan, and Jack. Born in Vienna, Austria. Emigrated to England in 1938. Spent the first half of his career as an Executive with the Bell and Howell Company before helping start Nimlok Ltd with his friend, Neil Nimmo. Over the past 45 years the company has grown to be a leading global supplier of products for displays and exhibitions. Funeral service will be held at 11:00am on Thursday, April 30th at St. Laurence Church, Lurgashall, West Sussex, England. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Andrew Grene Foundation, 9033 Murphy Road, Woodridge, IL 60517. www.andrewgrene.org 1/3
BRADSHAW--Patricia Salter, of Palm Beach and New York passed away peacefully at Good Samaritan Medical Center on April 20, 2015 in West Palm Beach, FL. 1/3

AISENBERG--Michele Kaiden, of New York City, formerly of New Rochelle, NY, peacefully in her home on April 22, 2015. Mickey was a lifelong supporter and advocate for women's rights and liberal causes. A founding member of the Independent Democrats of New Rochelle, candidate for New York State Assembly and Chair of the Women's Caucus of the Democratic National Committee. Supporter of the arts, accomplished and prolific painter. Long-time member of Bonnie Briar Country Club. Remembered for her impeccable style and grace. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, devoted mother of Elizabeth "Betty" and Robert "Bob" and daughter-in-law Kathy. Adored grandmother of Alison, Danny, James, Jonathan, and his wife Katie. Great grandmother of Lucia. Service Sunday, April 26th, 2015, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Service Fund of NOW NYC, 150 West 28th St., Suite 304, New York, NY 10001 attn: Deborah Dewees. 1/3

KAPEL--Saul "Bud", MD, passed away on April 19, 2015. He was 86 years old and is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Harriet Chaprack Kapel. Devoted father of Sherri Kapel Kaplan MD (Marc Kaplan MD) of Scarsdale, NY; Karen Kapel Astrachan (David Astrachan MD) of Orange, CT; and Robert Chaprack Kapel MD (Jamie Klein) of Weston, CT. He was born in Atlantic City, NJ, son of Betty and Emanuel Kapel. After graduating NYU, he received his MD from the University of Bologna, Italy. He completed his residency in psychiatry at New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center, and a child fellowship at Albert Einstein. In addition to his private practice, he was Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College. From 1972-1982, he authored a biweekly column "Parents and Children," which appeared in The New York Daily News and was nationally syndicated by the Chicago Tribune. He was a Distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association. He loved working with his patients and teaching residents. He treasured his family and adoring wife. VEHSLAGE--Ramsay Watson, 77, of Skillman, NJ, died peacefully and suddenly on Friday, April 17, at the University Medical Center of Princeton at Plainsboro. He is survived by his beloved and loving wife, Ann; his much- loved children, Ramsay Watson Vehslage, Jr., of Madison, NJ; his daughter Murray Vehslage Isgrig of Denver, CO, her husband, Trent and their three children, Wyatt, Milly, and Hazel. He was predeceased by his brother, Stephen, in 2002. He was born in New York City on November 4, 1937, and moved at age 10 with his family to Haverford, PA. He graduated from The Haverford School and with the class of 1959 from Princeton University. Prior to his retirement in 2010, Ramsay was president of the Bonney-Vehslage Tool Company of Newark, NJ, a manufacturing business founded by his grandfather in 1906. The company is now located in Springfield, NJ. Ramsay was a nationally-ranked squash player in his teens and 20's, an avid fly-fisherman, talented photographer, determined golfer, enthusiastic gardener, and a man deeply and quietly devoted to his family. His signature style was one of affection, humor, and integrity. Ramsay will be forever missed. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, June 12, at the Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, NJ. In honor of his lifelong interest in squash, donations may be made to The Pingry School for the Pingry Squash Courts, and sent to The Pingry School, Office of Institutional Advancement, 131 Martinsville Road, Basking Ridge, NJ 07920, or made via their website at www.blueprint.pingry.org. 1/3

HAVEN--Ellen, 65, of Garrison, New York, died peacefully on April 1, 2015 after a long illness. To the end of her days, almost incomprehensibly, she never allowed the maladies inflicted upon her to interfere with her cheery disposition, and she remained fun to be with, and possessed of great generosity of spirit throughout. Ellen was born in Peekskill on July 24, 1949 and grew up in the Hudson Valley, ultimately settling there with husband John, son Darius, and a virtual menagerie of pets after spending many wonderful years in New York City. Ellen loved the environment, whether it be wild, cultivated, or urban and had an affinity for both the land and the water, whether river or sea. She was an ardent gardener, naturalist, and lover of all creatures great and small, especially her dogs. She had a lifelong passion for the arts, specifically visual art, and spent most of her professional life working in the arts community in Westchester and Putnam counties, both as administrator and artist, in her very last position serving as the Chair of the Board of the Garrison Arts Center. In both her work and her personal relationships, Ellen shall be remembered for her unpretentious wisdom and quick wit, unflagging kindness, and invariable good humor. She had an ability to find common ground in people - in their thinking, in the work toward which they could contribute their different talents, and in the shared interests to which each could add a perspective. Ellen was a person whose visit always left others feeling just a little bit better than before. Needless to say, Ellen's constituency in the not-for-profit community was extremely well served by these attributes. The great joy Ellen experienced in her art became striking in her last few years, when, while undergoing the most intense medical treatments, she became the most prolific in her abstract creations, so much so that others around her were often drawn into her enthusiasm in the context of their own creative efforts. She leaves behind great memories and smiles with all that she knew. She was predeceased by her parents, Elliott W. Schryver and Alice Stinnett Schryver. She is survived by her husband of many years, John Grimmer, their son Darius Hartwell, and two grandchildren, Isaiah and Delilah Hartwell, all of Portland, Oregon, and her sister, Ann Temple, and nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews, all from the San Francisco Bay Area. Ellen was buried in the Cold Spring Cemetery in a private ceremony. A larger celebration of her life will follow in mid-June and will occur on the banks of the Hudson River at Garrison Landing in the shadow of the Garrison Arts Center and Bear Mountain. In recognition of Ellen's belief that the act of charity should be a very personal choice, anyone wishing to remember Ellen is requested to make a donation in her name to their own favorite charity. We, Ellen's family, greatly mourn her loss. We know that that sentiment is shared by friends near and far. 1/3

McGINTY--Park. On Friday, April 10, 2015, liberated himself from the final stages of a battle with cancer that he endured with courage and grace, and without bitterness. He was a man of many high-level accomplishments in a wide and varied field of endeavors, and was one of the most self-transformative of men. After studying Comparative Religion at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, he earned a doctorate in Comparative Religion at the University of Chicago. He subsequently served on the faculty of Moravian College and of Lehigh University, where he resigned from a tenured position in order to attend Yale Law School. After earning a J.D. from Yale in 1983, he practiced law in New York City as an Associate at Richards & O'Neil and subsequently at Davis Polk & Wardwell. He left the practice of law in order to teach law at New York Law School. The author of several books and scholarly articles, he retired from academia and law to write fiction and to pursue a deep study of science and the natural world; these intensive studies eventually culminated in and influenced his full-time creation of art and the development of his signature style. His sculptures and paintings, often involving the intricate placement of hundreds of pieces of glass, beads and jewels, related to his sensualist nature and his vision of ecstasy in color, form and light. These intricate works were accomplished despite his having been born with only one hand. His will provides for a Foundation to preserve and promote his art. Of his many achievements, Park took significant pride in his overcoming a decades-long depression, which he triumphed over with therapy and anti-depressants, in his cultivating deep friendships, and in creating art. His abundant capacity for love and his generous spirit in his appreciation of others will be missed by those lucky enough to have known him. Park McGinty was born in Atlanta, GA, in 1943, to Dr. A. Park McGinty and Murray Smith. His passions included many profound loves and two marriages which ended in amicable divorces. He is survived by his many first cousins and friends. 1/3

COHEN--Dr. Theodore B.,M.D., psychoanalyst and specialist in children and adolescents, died peacefully on April 22 at his home in Narberth, Pennsylvania. He was 92 years old. Dr. Cohen was well known for his active work and practice on "the vulnerable child", a subject he had worked on for over 60 years. Dr. Cohen was born in Brooklyn, New York on February 4, 1923, and had attended Brooklyn College, majoring in psychology. He was drafted into the US Army in 1942 and served in the US Army of General George Patton when it conquered Germany in 1945. His college training in psychology led to the assignment to lead surviving children from the Dachau concentration camp to be cared for by the Red Cross. He later enrolled in medical school at the University of Pennsylvania, graduated in 1951, and completed residencies at the major hospitals in the Philadelphia area in 1956. He began his practice in Philadelphia, associated with the Psychoanalytic Center of Philadelphia, with which he was associated for more than 60 years. He was deeply committed to understanding children, how they learned, and how disabilities could be overcome. In 1976 he organized the first international meeting on children and adolescents in Philadelphia. He led the Discussion Group on Vulnerable Children of the American Psychoanalytic Society for many years, holding annual meetings in New York, as well as sessions at the Association for Child Psychoanalysis. He edited three volumes on this subject with his colleagues Dr. Hossein Etezady and Dr. Bernard Pacella. In addition to his professional practice, Dr. Cohen was an avid sportsman, playing tennis and also table tennis. He advised the US Olympic Table Tennis team at the Seoul Olympics in 1988. He attended all of the summer Olympic Games from 1960 to 2008. He also was deeply engaged with the natural environment, supporting many environmental organizations. Dr. Cohen is survived by his son, Charles Cohen, Charles's wife, Bridget Cohen, and two grandchildren, Scott and Leigh-Anna, all of Daytona Beach, Florida, as well as by his brother, Dr. Seymour S. Cohen of Woods Hole, Massachusetts, and his family. Dr. Cohen's wife of 39 years, Barbara Cohen, died in 1988. His previous marriage to Sylvia Cohen ended in divorce. Funeral services Monday 9:30am Goldsteins Rosenberg's Raphael-Sacks, 6410 N. Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA. Burial will follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY at approximately 1pm. 1/3

NOTARIS--Antonio Frank, 81, died Sunday, April 19, 2015 at home with his children in Brooklyn, NY. He was born and raised in New York City. He served in the US Army and served in the Korean War. He earned his Certified Public Accountant designation and worked at large, national firms until he began his own practice in NYC where he practiced for over 30 years. In addition to being a hard worker, he was an avid family man who treasured time with his family and friends. He believed in philanthropy and was extremely generous during his lifetime. Frank was predeceased by his wife of 59 years, Marie, who died in May of 2014 and his sister, Pauline. He is survived by his children, Mary Notaris and her spouse, Deborah DeFelice, Annemarie Girgenti and her husband Vincent, and James Notaris, CPA, Esq., and his wife Amanda. He is also survived by eight grandchildren: Vincent, Nicholas, Jaime, Jason, Douglas, Austin, Russell, and Benjamin. 1/3

RUSH--Michael. The founding director of the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University and award-winning curator, author and critic, died at 65 on March 27, 2015 after a courageous two-year battle with pancreatic cancer. Rush began his tenure at the Broad MSU in 2010 and was instrumental in opening the museum and in establishing its vision of exploring global contemporary culture and ideas through art. He was a prodigious essayist and art critic, a sought-after public speaker, and author of pioneering surveys, most notably "New Media in Late 20th Century Art" (1999), "Video Art" (2003, 2007) and "New Media in Art" (2005), all published by Thames and Hudson. From 2005-2009, Rush served as the director of the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis University, where he was widely recognized for his leadership during a controversial and successful effort to legally prevent the university from selling its collection and closing the museum. He had received several awards for his curatorial work and in 2015 was awarded The Charles A. Gliozzo International Award for Public Diplomacy from the MSU Office of International Studies and Programs. Prior to his work in the art museum field, Rush was an experimental theater artist and early in his career was a Jesuit priest and psychologist. Rush will be missed dearly by all those who knew him and our condolences go out to his closest friends and family. A public memorial service will be held on June 14 at the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum in East Lansing, MI. Donations may be sent to the Broad MSU for the Michael Rush Prize for Creative Exploration. http://broadmuseum. msu.edu/michael-rush 1/3

APPENZELLER--Stanley, passed away on April 18, 2015 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old. Stanley is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Lenore, and was the cherished father of Allise and William. He was the adored grandfather of Matthew, Kate, Kelly, and Emily and father-in-law to Jack Vicens and Donna Appenzeller. Stanley began his career as a publicist with NBC working on the Today show and NBC News. His fondest memories were of the times he spent at his home in Ghent, NY. He continued to work part-time as a publicist for the Chatham Synagogue and served on their Board of Directors. He will be remembered as the finest and kindest person by all those who knew him. 1/3

ESCH--Robert Ernst. Born 1932 in Detroit, died April 19 in Ottsville, Pa. Predeceased by Ann, wife of 51 years. Survived by wife Judy, five children and six grandchildren. Memorial 5 to 8pm, May 8, Holcombe-Fisher Funeral Home, Flemington, N.J.

DYE--Marjorie Post, died April 14, 2015 surrounded by family and friends at her home in Santa Monica. She was 86. She was born April 20, 1928 to Thomas Wells Durant and Adelaide Brevoort Close in New York. As a teenager she moved to California. In 1956 she graduated from the University of Southern California, where she was an All American swimmer. Her swimming career continued at the Santa Monica Athletic Club and the Los Angeles Athletic Club. She became known as one of the greatest open water swimmers of her time. It was at the Los Angeles Athletic Club that she met her life partner of 43 years, Charles Fautz. Marjorie lived her life abundantly and was very well known for her independent spirit and outspoken nature. Her passion was thoroughbred horse breeding and racing. She was married twice, first to Ron Waller, running back for the Los Angeles Rams and second to Peter Dye (deceased 2013). She is survived by sisters Ellen Charles and Melissa Cantacuzene. Marjorie had five children, Wende, Steven, Timmy, John Phillip Patrick and Nedenia (deceased 2013). Grandchildren, Amanda, Thommy and Christopher, life partner Charles Fautz, cat Simon, dogs Dolly and Posty and her special pet Millie. Gates, Kingsley & Gates Moeller Murphy Mortuary Funeral Directors (310)395-9988 www.gkgmm.com 1/3

KIMBALL--Richard "Dick" Hughes Hubbard & Reed mourns the loss of retired partner, colleague and friend Richard "Dick" Kimball, who passed away on April 15 at the age of 85 from Parkinson's disease. For more than 30 years, Dick was a significant contributor to the development of the firm's trusts and estates practice. He will be remembered for his integrity, his love of the firm and his relentless good cheer. We are grateful for the time we had with him and send our deepest condolences to his family. He will be greatly missed. 1

KASNER--Dr. Victor H.,83, of Wellington FL and Livingston, NJ passed away on Friday, March 13, 2015. Dr. Kasner was a Capt in the Air Force at Langley Air Force Base, Hampton, VA. He practiced Periodontics and Implantology in West Orange, NJ. He was a Clinical Professor at NYU Dental School for 25 years. Surviving Dr. Kasner is his loving wife Martha (Goobich), son David (Renee), twin daughters Robin Muhlstein (Philip), Lisa Friedman (Steven), grandchildren Adam, Danielle, Larry, Scott, Rachel, Benji, Aaron, and Jordan. Graveside services were held on March 15, 2015 with Military Honors. 1/3

Born in New York City to Marco and Flora Behar, Gloria is survived by her loving partner of 12 years, Barnett Singer (daughters, Alexa, Laura and Mindy), her adoring children Abby (Len) and Paul (Jane), grandchildren Margot and Andrew Haas, William and Holly Gottsegen, and nephew Brett Behar (Teri). KUFLIK--Frieda, born December 11, 1924 in the small Polish town of Szydlowiec, passed away peacefully on April 26, 2015. The oldest child of Herschel and Shaindel Kurlender, her parents and two younger brothers, David and Avraham, perished in the Holocaust. She survived a horrific internment at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp from which she was liberated by the English Army on April 15, 1945, a day emblazoned in her memory. In December 1946 she arrived in New York City with her sole surviving brother Yachov (Jack). Penniless, she worked in a garment factory sewing piece goods to earn a living. In 1948, sitting at the "singles table" at a friend's wedding, she met a fellow Holocaust survivor, Seymour Kuflik, from Korczyna, Poland. They married that same year, had two children, Sidney and Sheila, and made a beautiful life together in this new country they both so loved. They raised their family in the Bronx and Queens, NY, with many joyous summers spent at bungalow colonies in the Catskill Mountains. Frieda was a loving and devoted wife to her husband, who predeceased her in 2005, a caring and adoring mother, grandmother and great grandmother, a doting aunt, and a dear friend to many. She was the stereotypical Jewish mother "on steroids" and for that she was treasured by one and all. She is survived by her son Sidney Kuflik and his wife Madeline, her daughter Sheila Ben and her husband Stuart, her grandchildren Chad Ben and his wife Lindsey, Ian Ben, Cara Ruda and her husband David, Joanna Kuflik, Elana Kuflik, and her great-granddaughter Sara Ben. The running gag in our family was that when the topic of conversation turned to the number of children a couple should have, a topic she often raised herself, with certainty and clarity Frieda would proclaim, "Three is nice". Although we would chuckle at this oft repeated phrase, which she freely shared with brides and grooms at weddings, the truth is that her actions and ideas reflected deep seeded wisdom and thoughtfulness. She will be terribly missed by her family, friends and anyone who was fortunate enough to have known her. Donations in her name may be made to the U.S. Holocaust Museum in Washington DC, or any charitable organization where the memory of those lost during the Holocaust are remembered and sanctified. 1/3
